prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.A.S. program; fourth-year standing in Sociology; fourth-year standing in the B.A. Honours Architecture/Art History program; or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: The Design Professions

desc: Projects to develop skills in the analysis of building performance. Examination of occupancy analysis, safety and risk assessment, post-occupancy evaluation, and social impact assessment. (Workshop).
name: ARCH 4205
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: User-Building Synopsis

desc: Concepts of mediating old and new architecture at the scale of the city through to the detail of the construction joint. Issues in sustainability and cultural identity illuminated by recycled architecture and adaptive reuse are explored through readings, drawings and case studies. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4206
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.A.S. program or by permission of the instructor or fourth-year standing in the B.Eng. Architectural Conservation and Sustainability program.
subject: ARCH
title: Recycling Architecture in Canada and Abroad

desc: 18 th - and 19 th- century architecture and urban form in Western Europe. Emphasis on the cultural and philosophical framework of rising modernity to illuminate architectural production and theory as well as the development of urban form. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4300
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Neo-Classical Architecture

desc: Theoretical, ideological and artistic debates that have influenced the development of world architecture since 1950. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4301
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or ARTH 3609 or permission of the instructor.
subject: ARCH
title: Post-War Architecture

desc: Monumental temples of the ancient Mesoamericans are compared with other world traditions at similar levels of cultural development. Selected examples considered in terms of morphology, technology, iconography, social/political context, world view and general architectural theory. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4302
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Pre-Columbian Architecture

desc: Architecture of Greek antiquity and its relationship to its philosophical, artistic, and mythical contexts. The development of the idea of the city; the presence of architecture within its symbolic landscape. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4303
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Greek Architecture

desc: Rome in its classical to late-antique periods. Its founding mythologies and landscape. In-depth analysis of Rome, with special attention to its public buildings. Early Christian architecture within the Roman context. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4304
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: The Architecture of Rome

desc: Gothic architecture and its relation to its philosophic and artistic predecessors. Special attention to the coexistence of the monastic tradition, late Romanesque building, and new experiments in gothic during this period, marked by intellectual and political ferment. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4305
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Medieval Architecture

desc: The rise of architectural theory within the context of the Italian Renaissance. Canonic texts explored and compared in the context of the architectural developments of the period. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4306
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Renaissance Theory

desc: Historical and theoretical discussions about the architecture of Muslim cultures. Selected sites and monuments from eighth to eighteenth century, covering the vast geography from North Africa to Southeast Asia. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4307
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Muslim Architecture

desc: Anthropological history of the architecture of the Near and Far East. The architecture and urban form of Ancient Egypt, Anatolia, Sumer and Persia; ancient China and India. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4308
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Asian Architecture

desc: Selected works of Mesoamerican architecture in terms of iconography, morphology, technology, function, historical development, and concept. Mesoamerican architectural features compared with other world traditions. Emphasis on design. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4309
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Mesoamerican Architecture

desc: A survey of the architectural and urban history of a specific culture. These discussions address the present reality of a country, region or city being visited by the fourth year of the program. (Elective Course).
name: ARCH 4400
prereq_text: clear standing to fourth year and permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Theory

desc: Preparation for the independent research and design work. Work related to the nature of research and criticism in architecture, with emphasis on current issues. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4502
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCH
title: Research and Criticism

desc: History and theory of architecture. Topics will vary from year to year. Limited enrolment. (Elective Course).
name: ARCH 4505
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.A.S. or B.A. (Honours) Architecture/Art History programs, or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Seminar in Theory and History

desc: An aspect of architecture in the area of theory and history. Topics vary from year to year. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCH 4801
prereq_text: ARCH 2300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCH
title: Special Topics

desc: (Elective Course).
name: ARCH 4808
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCH
title: Independent Study

desc: Supervised readings and research projects. Guidelines must be obtained from BAS Academic Advisors prior to registration. (Core course).
name: ARCH 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.A.S (Philosophy and Criticism).
subject: ARCH
title: Directed Reading

desc: Students propose a topic of study in Philosophy and Criticism for approval and produce a substantial research project, supervised by BAS faculty. (Core course).
name: ARCH 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.A.S (Philosophy and Criticism).
subject: ARCH
title: Honours Project

desc: A survey of the history, theory, and science of structures pertaining to buildings and civic works. Structural systems, construction techniques, materials and details, and the cultural factors involved in the synthesis of traditional structural design.
name: ARCC 1202
prereq_text: registration in B.A.S.
subject: ARCC
title: History of Structures

desc: Survey of structural planning, including a historical survey of structural systems, details and the study of the factors involved in the synthesis of a suitable structural scheme. The course is intended as a survey of the science and the structural properties of materials. (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 2001
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Structures in Architecture

desc: General introduction to materials and methods of construction with focus on wood and timber frame construction. Site conditions, foundations, structure and envelope design in terms of their response to local climate: sun (light and heat) wind, moisture. (Core course).
name: ARCC 2202
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Architectural Technology 1

desc: Wood frame, post and beam, steel and concrete systems and construction techniques. Structural systems and building envelope principles and practise are explored in conjunction with mechanical and electrical systems in smaller buildings. Emphasis on precedent, tradition and methodology of architectural detailing for construction.
name: ARCC 2203
prereq_text: ARCC 2202 and third-year standing for B.A.S. students and third-year standing for students in B.Eng. Architectural Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: ARCC
title: Architectural Technology 3

desc: Relationship between environmental factors, energy and architectural form. Ways in which buildings and building elements can be planned and designed to take advantage of natural cycles in order to minimize the need for supportive energy inputs. (Workshop).
name: ARCC 3004
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Workshop: Energy and Form

desc: Medium scale steel, concrete, and wood frame buildings as case studies to explore approaches to building science principles, building envelope design, advanced construction methods and materials, acoustics and sound control, and fire protection. Focus on sustainable design strategies and environment impact. (Core course).
name: ARCC 3202
prereq_text: ARCC 2203 and third-year standing for B.A.S. students or ARCC 2203 and third-year standing for students in B.Eng. Architectural Conservation.
subject: ARCC
title: Architectural Technology 4

desc: Application of building materials, including the forming of building parts and the design of joints for performance and assembly. Practical constructions using new technology are emphasized. (Workshop).
name: ARCC 3305
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Materials Application

desc: Introduces conservation concepts to understand the values associated with existing buildings and landscapes. Through the analysis of sites and case studies, students will discuss the potentials and limitations of architectural conservation, as well as, testing its possibilities for sustainable retrofitting practices.
name: ARCC 3502
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Introduction to Architectural Conservation

desc: A specific aspect of architecture in the area of architectural technology. Offerings vary from year to year. (Workshop).
name: ARCC 3902
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Architectural Technology

desc: A study of daylighting and/or lighting design techniques, with a focus on project-based learning. (Workshop).
name: ARCC 4100
prereq_text: ARCC 2203 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Lighting for Architecture

desc: Sound in enclosures, including interior design of auditoria and special applications. Sound reproduction and reinforcement systems. Acoustic privacy and protection, sound control in buildings, materials for noise control, community noise, industrial noise. Acoustic measurements and instrumentation. (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 4102
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Acoustics in Architecture

desc: Energy as a criterion in decision-making for architectural design. Conventional energy resources and state-of-the-art alternative energy resource systems with respect to building shape, size, materials, openings, orientation, siting, and use. (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 4103
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Energy and Form

desc: Interdisciplinary study of structural and developmental morphology focusing on dynamic generative design processes, integrative systems, spatial modulations and fundamental generative principles of spatial form and structure as it relates to architecture. (Workshop).
name: ARCC 4200
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Structural Morphology

desc: Introduction to structural design in timber. Properties, anatomy of wood, wood products, factors affecting strength and behaviour, strength evaluation and testing. Design of columns, beams and beam-columns. Design of trusses, frames, glulam structures, plywood components, formwork, foundations, connections, connectors. Inspection, maintenance and repair. (Elective course).
name: ARCC 4202
prereq_text: CIVE 2200, CIVE 2700.
subject: ARCC
title: Wood Engineering

desc: In-depth study of the conventions, methods, and tools used in the assessment of buildings and their sties including traditional field survey, photogrammetry, laser scanning technologies, and hybrid representations.
name: ARCC 4207
prereq_text: enrolment in the BAS Conservation and Sustainability program and fourth-year standing.
subject: ARCC
title: Advanced Building Assessment

desc: Contemporary and traditional construction techniques and materiality are discussed within the framework of current practices, with emphasis on the analysis of material properties, structure and sustained performance, as well as their contribution to the adaptive reuse of existing and/or historical building. (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 4300
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Building Materials

desc: Design in relation to materials and building construction including the effects of building codes, zoning bylaws, approvals, processes and legislation, the organization of the building industry, and cost estimating control. (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 4400
prereq_text: ARCC 3300 or permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Design for Construction

desc: Principles of building economics. Determinants and prediction of building costs. Uncertainty and investment economics. Creative cost control for buildings during schematic design, design development, construction document preparation and construction. Economic evaluation during all phases of design process; emphasis on sustainable strategies.
name: ARCC 4500
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.A.S. program or permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Design Economics

desc: A specific aspect of architecture in the area of architectural technology. Topics vary from year to year. (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 4801
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCC
title: Architectural Technology

desc: (Elective Course).
name: ARCC 4808
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCC
title: Independent Study

desc: Students propose a topic of study in Conservation & Sustainability for approval and produce a substantial research project, supervised by BAS faculty. (Core Course).
name: ARCC 4909
prereq_text: fourth- year standing in BAS (Conservation and Sustainability).
subject: ARCC
title: Honours Project

desc: Seminar in selected topics related to Urbanism at an introductory level.
name: ARCU 2100
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCU
title: Special Topics in Urbanism

desc: Primary structural, spatial and formal organization and elements that characterize the morphology of cities; historical and contemporary significance for architecture and urban design. (Core).
name: ARCU 3100
prereq_text: First-year standing in the B.A.S. Urbanism major, second or third-year standing in other B.A.S. majors, or permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: The Morphology of the City

desc: Practical significance of landscape elements as they relate to built-form by integrating structure and site. (Workshop).
name: ARCU 3203
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: Landscape Architecture

desc: Project-based workshop investigating current design attitudes and solutions affecting the physical morphology of cities. Formally sophisticated urban design projects. Various procedures and basic urban design ideas. (Workshop).
name: ARCU 3405
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: Urban Design

desc: Interdisciplinary investigation, analysis and synthesis of the institutions, processes, environments and demography of Canadian cities. Guest lecturers. (Workshop).
name: ARCU 3409
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: City Organization and Planning Processes

desc: A specific aspect of architecture in the area of urban studies. Topics vary from year to year. (Workshop).
name: ARCU 3902
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: Urban Studies

desc: Course addresses cities such as Istanbul, Mexico City, Venice, Paris, Ottawa, Mumbai, and New Orleans. Topics presented by the instructor and guests include environmental resilience and climate change; social justice and informal settlement; smart cities and data privacy; and urban design, memory, and imagination.
name: ARCU 4103
prereq_text: Second-year standing or permission of the Instructor.
subject: ARCU
title: Cities

desc: Theories of urbanism throughout history; emphasis on schools of post-WWII academic thought. The impact of Marxist theory, location and systems theory; the expanding array of models, tools and techniques that have contributed to various theorizations of urbanism.
name: ARCU 4300
prereq_text: ARCU 3100.
subject: ARCU
title: History of Theories of Urbanism

desc: Structure, form and functioning of cities. Infra-structure, facilities and networks, ecosystems, demographic and social organization, government, quality of life, goals and perceptions, urban management, development, regulation and codes, design, planning and policy-making. (Elective Course).
name: ARCU 4400
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCU
title: City Organization and Planning

desc: Background factors pertaining to housing in both industrial and developing countries; traditional and contemporary housing approaches; social housing; and people's right to adequate housing. Guest lecturers. (Elective Course).
name: ARCU 4500
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCU
title: Human Shelter

desc: Urban renewal in the post-war period in response to housing shortages, suburbanization, transportation infrastructure and other factors. Gentrification and the emerging form of the post-industrial city, including new urbanism and sustainable communities. Case studies from Canada, Europe and the U.S. (Theory/History Elective).
name: ARCU 4600
prereq_text: ARCU 3100 and third or fourth-year standing in the B.A.S. Urbanism program or permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: Post-WWII Urbanism

desc: Urban utopias throughout history, with emphasis on the 20th century. Garden Cities, anti-urbanism and radical decentralization, the city in the region, Italian Rationalist cities, Le Corbusier and CIAM, post-WWII New Towns (England, Scandinavia and the US), Sustainable Urbanism.
name: ARCU 4700
prereq_text: third or fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism program or permission of the School.
subject: ARCU
title: Urban Utopias

desc: Advanced seminar in selected topics related to urbanism. Topics may include histories and theories related to urban systems, design, and planning. (Core course).
name: ARCU 4801
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism) or permission of the Instructor.
subject: ARCU
title: Topics in Urbanism

desc: (Elective Course).
name: ARCU 4808
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCU
title: Independent Study

desc: Advanced investigation into issues related to urbanism and urban form. Topics will vary from year to year.
name: ARCU 4901
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism) or permission of Instructor.
subject: ARCU
title: Topics in Applied Urbanism

desc: Fundamental concepts of line and line weight, light and shadow, perspective, contrast and composition. Exercises will include some mixed media and will introduce students to drawing as a way of translating ideas into images.
name: ARCN 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCN
title: Introduction to Drawing: Seeing Through the Hand

desc: Computer modeling as a medium of architectural analysis, documentation, and presentation. Principles and techniques of 2D drawing and 3D modeling. Extensive practical work using appropriate applications. (Core Course).
name: ARCN 2105
prereq_text: second-year B.A.S. standing or permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Digital Practice and Theory

desc: Analogue and digital systems and graphic processes used in the making of images. Fundamentals of still photography and videography combined with current computer technologies in the application of visual communication techniques.
name: ARCN 2106
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCN
title: Introduction to Multimedia

desc: Design and fabrication of theatre productions, one of which is staged on campus. Visiting directors, designers, technical consultants and others. Visits to theatres and production facilities. (Workshop).
name: ARCN 3003
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Theatre Production

desc: Application of existing software and programming techniques to various architectural problems. (Workshop).
name: ARCN 3206
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Computer Applications

desc: The architectural anatomy of selected contemporary buildings. Use of graphic techniques of analysis to develop an understanding of their basic compositional principles and language. (Workshop).
name: ARCN 3302
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: The Anatomy of Architecture

desc: Analysis of architecture for its elemental, formal and narrative properties. These relationships through the medium of painting. Architecture as analogy to painting. (Workshop).
name: ARCN 3303
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Architecture as Painting

desc: Development of the capacity to visualize and communicate in several graphic media. Development of sensitivity to form, structure, space, texture and colour. May involve historical investigation. (Workshop).
name: ARCN 3400
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Visual Design

desc: Traditional and alternative techniques for image making and manipulation. Basic image formation techniques, advanced darkroom manipulations, past-darkroom imaging, and digital imaging within a theoretical overview of current photographic processes and techniques. (Workshop).
name: ARCN 3401
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Photography

name: ARCN 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCN
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Methods of heritage building documentation including hand recording, photography, rectified photography, total station, gps, photogrammetry, and laser scanning. Non-destructive testing techniques; environmental assessment tools for determining air quality and energy efficiency. Multidisciplinary teams for all project work.
name: ARCN 4100
prereq_text: second-year standing in B.A.S. Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: ARCN
title: Historic Site Recording and Assessment

desc: Various types of non-numeric data, their representation within primary and secondary storage, and the manipulation of various representations. Comparative evaluation of languages for non-numeric problems. (Elective Course).
name: ARCN 4102
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Problems in Computing

desc: The changing relationship of architectural design and digital technology with a focus on 1:1 constructions using emerging computational software and fabrication techniques. (Workshop/Elective Course).
name: ARCN 4103
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ARCN
title: Digital Fabrication and Theory

desc: Deterioration mechanisms for concrete, timber, steel and masonry structures. Identification of design deficiencies; criteria for selection and design of rehabilitation systems. Design techniques to reduce deterioration in new construction and historical structures.
name: ARCN 4200
prereq_text: ARCN 4100 and third-year standing in B.A.S. Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: ARCN
title: Building Pathology and Rehabilitation

desc: (Elective Course).
name: ARCN 4808
prereq_text: None
subject: ARCN
title: Independent Study

desc: Free-hand drawing as a way of observing and understanding the world. Various media and techniques introduced through a wide range of studio and outdoor exercises. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 1005
prereq_text: registration in the B.A.S. program.
subject: ARCS
title: Drawing

desc: Students from all BAS majors are introduced to the fundamentals of designing for the built environment using the conventions of varied modes of analog representation and physical making.(Core Course).
name: ARCS 1105
prereq_text: registration in the B.A.S. program.
subject: ARCS
title: Studio 1

desc: Supported by the core curriculum, focuses on small-scale building in a local context. Using analog methods, projects introduce the integration of basic structure and building systems while furthering fundamental concepts such as space, inhabitation, and materiality.(Core Course).
name: ARCS 2105
prereq_text: ARCS 1005 and ARCS 1105.
subject: ARCS
title: Studio 2

desc: With a focus on small to medium scale building projects, projects consider analog and digital methods to advance consideration of site, program, and the materials as the means for shaping the built environment. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 2106
prereq_text: ARCS 1005 and ARCS 1105.
subject: ARCS
title: Studio 3

desc: Conservation methodologies will be tested and studied through design exercises and historical research on existing architectures, cities and landscapes. The emphasis on the understanding and the relation with the setting will be essential.
name: ARCS 2302
prereq_text: ARCC 3502, ARCS 1005, ARCS 1105 and second-year standing in B.A.S. major Conservation and Sustainability or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Conservation Studio 1

desc: Through readings, discussions and projects, students will examine a number of the forces that produce the built environment and explore a variety of approaches to documenting, representing, analyzing, organizing and controlling the growth, shape, density, and mix of uses associated with cities.
name: ARCS 2303
prereq_text: ARCS 1005 and ARCS 1105, or permission of instructor.
subject: ARCS
title: Urbanism Studio 1: Fundamentals of Urbanism

desc: Supported by the core curriculum, focuses on a medium-scale building within a regional context. May include a small design-build. Projects further analog and digital methods. May introduce concepts like adaptive re-use while furthering the understanding of structure and building systems in a complex building.(Core Course).
name: ARCS 3105
prereq_text: ARCS 2105 and ARCS 2106.
subject: ARCS
title: Studio 4

desc: The Directed Studies Abroad (DSA) studio considers large-scale, mixed-use buildings in an international context. Design projects advance analog and digital methods to explore broader cultural and social conditions within a complex site often in conjunction with a site visit abroad. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 3107
prereq_text: ARCS 2105 and ARCS 2106.
subject: ARCS
title: Studio 5

desc: Historical building projects exploring architecture as a form of cultural expression. Consideration of site, program and materials. Introduction of conservation, sustainability and adaptive re-use principles, development standards, architectural codes, using case studies in Ottawa and elsewhere. Physical, digital drawings and models to explore designs. (Core).
name: ARCS 3301
prereq_text: ARCC 3502, ARCS 2302 and third-year standing in B.A.S. Conservation and Sustainability major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Conservation Studio 2

desc: The role of architecture in culture, stressing site and program with respect to their historic, social and ecological implications. Synthesis of issues, methods and techniques of the conservation and sustainability curriculum. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 3302
prereq_text: ARCS 3301 and third-year standing in B.A.S. Conservation and Sustainability major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Conservation Studio 3

desc: Intensification, revitalization, gentrification, brownfield redevelopment, sustainability, development standards, form-based codes, and the larger impact of migration on urban density. Through design, students explore the ramifications of practices, policies, pressures, processes and cultural preferences on the evolving form and function of the urban core.
name: ARCS 3303
prereq_text: ARCN 2105 and ARCS 2303, and third-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Urbanism Studio 2: Urbanism in the Core

desc: Urbanization, sprawl, growth models, land consumption, containment strategies (smart growth, greenbelts, growth boundaries), edge cities, the Just City, Ecological Urbanism, and informal suburbanization in developed and developing countries. Through design, students explore the impact of practices, pressures, processes and cultural preferences on the expanding city.
name: ARCS 3304
prereq_text: ARCN 2105, ARCS 2303 and third-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Urbanism Studio 3: Urbanism on the Periphery

desc: Focussing on multi-unit housing, students from BAS majors collaborate to develop strategies for redevelopment of large urban sites. Engages urban design, site planning, programming, adaptive reuse, and community consultation. Students produce detailed designs for buildings, emphasizing building systems and envelope design. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 4105
prereq_text: ARCS 3105 and ARCS 3107, or ARCS 3303 and ARCS 3304.
subject: ARCS
title: Comprehensive Studio

desc: Offers a range of topics for exploration. Students use analog and digital methods and techniques to culminate the undergraduate studio sequence while offering focused research-led investigation into key social, political, spatial issues. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 4107
prereq_text: ARCS 3105 and ARCS 3107.
subject: ARCS
title: Option Studio

desc: Issues of program and site as the culturally defining aspects of sustainable architectural practice within complex urban and social situations, using difficult sites, historically significant buildings and/or locations and hybrid programs. projects brought to a high degree of formal and graphic resolution. (Core Course).
name: ARCS 4301
prereq_text: ARCS 3302 and fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Conservation and Sustainability major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Conservation Studio 4

desc: Conservation decision-making process and contemporary conservation concepts in the development of a design for the adaptive reuse, in Ottawa and elsewhere. Consideration of sustainability aspects, site, program, and materials.
name: ARCS 4302
prereq_text: ARCS 4301 and fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Conservation and Sustainability major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Conservation Studio 5

desc: Housing as it affects urban form. The design of multi-unit housing in a variety of forms and for a range of demographic groups. After thorough research of applicable codes and bylaws, students engage the design of housing at the site, building and detail level.
name: ARCS 4303
prereq_text: ARCS 3303 and ARCS 3304 and fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Urbanism Studio 4: Housing

desc: Urbanization as a global phenomenom. Study of various forms of urbanization and de-urbanization in relation to economic, political and cultural forces. Through design, students explore the (trans)formation of settlements and communities outside of the North American context.
name: ARCS 4304
prereq_text: ARCS 3303 and ARCS 3304 and fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism major or permission of the School.
subject: ARCS
title: Urbanism Studio 5: Global Perspectives

desc: A survey of art, architecture and artifacts from prehistory to the Renaissance. Ways of understanding visual culture through this span of history.
name: ARTH 1100
prereq_text: None
subject: ARTH
title: Art and Society: Prehistory to the Renaissance

desc: A survey of art, architecture and related visual forms in their expanding contexts from the Renaissance to the present. Ways of understanding visual culture through this span of history.
name: ARTH 1101
prereq_text: None
subject: ARTH
title: Art and Society: Renaissance to the Present

desc: A variety of visual material is organized topically to examine the elements of art (line, shape, value, colour, texture, space), the principles of pictorial organization, the materials and techniques of art, and recurrent tendencies in artistic styles and outlooks.
name: ARTH 1105
prereq_text: None
subject: ARTH
title: Art as Visual Communication

desc: An introduction to the history of architecture from prehistory to ca. 1500, considering technological, formal, intellectual and social developments that informed the built environment through a range of building types.
name: ARTH 1200
prereq_text: None
subject: ARTH
title: History and Theory of Architecture: Prehistory to 1500

desc: An introduction to the history of architecture from ca. 1500 to the present, considering technological, formal, intellectual, and social developments that informed the built environment through a range of building types.
name: ARTH 1201
prereq_text: None
subject: ARTH
title: History and Theory of Architecture: 1500 to Present

desc: A survey of historical Canadian art, from the period of European settlement to the early twentieth century, examining craft and fine art, amateur and professional artists, art institutions, gender, nationalism, regionalism and ethnicity. Students will be exposed to works in the National Capital region.
name: ARTH 2002
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Canadian Historical Art

desc: A survey of twentieth-century and contemporary Canadian art in a variety of media within social, political and cultural contexts. Regionalism, multiculturalism, nationalism, gender, race and identity will be considered in relation to local and national collections in Ottawa.
name: ARTH 2003
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Canadian Twentieth-Century and Contemporary Art

desc: Introduction to the visual arts of Indigenous peoples of the eastern and central regions of North America. A post-colonial perspective will be used to consider selected examples of creative production from time immemorial to the present.
name: ARTH 2005
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Arts of the First Peoples: The Woodlands, the Plains and the Subarctic

desc: Introduction to the visual arts of Indigenous peoples of the western and northern regions of North America. A post-colonial perspective will be used to consider selected examples of visual materials from time immemorial to the present.
name: ARTH 2006
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Arts of the First Peoples: The Southwest, the West Coast and the Arctic

desc: Surveys Asian art from second-century China to post-war Japan. Representational strategies of court artists and artists from the capital are compared with artists on the periphery. Articulation of power in tombs, palaces and war propaganda is examined, as is the individual and the eccentric.
name: ARTH 2007
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Asian Art

desc: Survey of visual art produced by Canadian Inuit from the circumpolar area.
name: ARTH 2008
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Inuit Art

desc: Examination of techniques, materials and institutions of art history; lectures and workshops on art historical research and writing, the materials of art, professional skills; site visits to art institutions.
name: ARTH 2009
prereq_text: ARTH 1100 and ARTH 1101, or permission of the discipline. Restricted to students enrolled in the Art History B.A. or B.A. Honours.
subject: ARTH
title: Art Live: Art History Workshop

desc: The art, architecture and archaeology of ancient Greece. Vase painting, sculpture, architecture, town planning and analogous arts are studied.
name: ARTH 2102
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: ARTH
title: Greek Art and Archaeology

desc: The art, architecture and archaeology of the ancient Romans. Vase painting, sculpture, architecture, town planning and analogous arts are studied.
name: ARTH 2105
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: ARTH
title: Roman Art and Archaeology

desc: A survey of Chinese art from the pre-modern era to re-inventions of traditions in modern and contemporary art. Artworks in various media (ink painting, calligraphy, Buddhist sculpture, ceramics, lacquer and garden architecture) will be studied in their historical, cultural and socio-political contexts.
name: ARTH 2106
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: ARTH
title: Chinese Art and Visual Culture

desc: Survey of artistic movements in Islamic art and architecture in the Mediterranean, the Near East, and Central and South Asia, from the seventh century to ca. 1450. Commonalities and differences between major dynastic visual cultures will be explored.
name: ARTH 2107
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Islamic Architecture and Art

desc: Survey of an area of global art history. Topics may vary from year to year, and will be posted on the School for Studies in Art and Culture website.
name: ARTH 2108
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: ARTH
title: Art Worlds

desc: A survey of architecture and art in Europe from ca. 313-1500 C.E. Sacred, secular, and domestic works will be discussed with reference to cultural meaning, social function, structure, and form.
name: ARTH 2202
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Medieval Architecture and Art

desc: An examination of major works of art and architecture, issues and themes in the Italian Renaissance; emphasis on the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, with a look at roots in the fourteenth.
name: ARTH 2300
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Italian Renaissance Art

desc: An examination of architecture from the late medieval period to the 18th century with particular attention paid to architecture and design cultures within the European and Islamic worlds and their cross-cultural interactions.
name: ARTH 2310
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Architecture of the Early Modern World [1400-1750]

desc: Tracing developments in 17th- and 18th-century painting, graphic art, sculpture, and architecture. Introduction to artists, art works, and issues central to the relationship between art and society.
name: ARTH 2404
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Art of the 17th and 18th Centuries

desc: Tracing developments in 19th-century painting, graphic art, sculpture, and architecture. Introduction to artists, art works, and issues central to the relationship between art and modernity.
name: ARTH 2502
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Art of the 19th Century

desc: A survey of key monuments, theories, forms and technological developments of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century architecture.
name: ARTH 2510
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Architecture of the 18th and 19th Centuries

desc: Major artistic movements in Europe from about 1900 to 1945.
name: ARTH 2600
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Modern European Art 1900-1945

desc: Issues, themes, movements in photography and individual photographers from the origins of the medium to the present.
name: ARTH 2601
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: History and Theory of Photography

desc: Developments in architectural form and culture through the course of the twentieth century, with emphasis on the formation and subsequent critique of the Modern Movement.
name: ARTH 2610
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Twentieth-Century Architecture

desc: Development of critical thinking, writing, and looking skills in connection to architecture, through a combination of site visits, workshops and classroom exercises.
name: ARTH 2710
prereq_text: ARTH 1200 and ARTH 1201 or permission of the discipline. Restricted to students in the History and Theory of Architecture B.A. or B.A. Honours program.
subject: ARTH
title: Experiencing Architecture

desc: Philosophical approaches to the study of art. Topics such as: the nature of art and artistic value; representation and symbolism in art; art and artifice; art and the emotions; art, culture and ideology; post-structuralism and art; theories of creativity; relationship between artworks and audiences.
name: ARTH 2807
prereq_text: None
subject: ARTH
title: Philosophy of Art

desc: Selected aspects of Canadian art in a variety of media. Students will be exposed to works in the National Capital region.
name: ARTH 3000
prereq_text: ARTH 2002 or ARTH 2003 or (for a photography topic) ARTH 2601 and second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Themes in Canadian Art

desc: Canadian architecture from the seventeenth century to the present day, covering both stylistic and technological developments. Building styles, methods, and materials in the context of social and economic conditions and construction techniques.
name: ARTH 3002
prereq_text: ARTH 1100 and ARTH 1101, or ARTH 1200 and ARTH 1201, or ARCH 1002 and ARCH 1201, and second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Canadian Architecture

desc: Examination of the intersections between architecture, representations, and cultures.
name: ARTH 3003
prereq_text: ARTH 1100 or ARTH 1101 or ARTH 1200 or ARTH 1201 and second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Architecture and Representation

desc: The cultural history of the United States as expressed through its architectural heritage. Selected buildings and complexes from the earliest settlements through the early twentieth century are examined.
name: ARTH 3005
prereq_text: ARTH 1201 and second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: American Architecture

desc: Modern and contemporary art in East Asia, beginning in Japan with the 1868 Meiji revolution and the 1911 revolution in China.
name: ARTH 3007
prereq_text: second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Modern Asian Art

desc: Modern and contemporary art in China and beyond from the reform period in 1979 until today. Artworks will be examined in terms of their (art-)historical, discursive, socio-political, infrastructural and transcultural conditions of production and reception.
name: ARTH 3008
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Contemporary Chinese Art and Art History

desc: The study of the history of art and architectural history and the methodologies and research tools employed.
name: ARTH 3100
prereq_text: third-year or higher standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: History and Methods of Art and Architectural History

desc: A study of period or theme in the art and archaeology of Ancient Greece. Topics may vary from year to year. This course is repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: ARTH 3102
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.
subject: ARTH
title: Studies in Greek Art

desc: A study of a period or theme in the art and archaeology of the ancient Romans. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: ARTH 3105
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.
subject: ARTH
title: Studies in Roman Art

desc: The study of the methodologies and research approaches employed by architectural historians.
name: ARTH 3107
prereq_text: ARTH 3100 and third-year standing or higher in History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: History and Methods of Architectural History

desc: The study of current methodologies and research tools employed by art historians.
name: ARTH 3108
prereq_text: ARTH 3100 and third-year standing or higher in Art History, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: History and Methods of Art History

desc: Exploration of printmaking techniques from the 16th century to the present focusing on the work of famous and lesser-known printmakers. Topics may include: printmaking genres (from fine art prints to caricature), originality versus reproduction, book illustration, the art market, posters and propaganda.
name: ARTH 3400
prereq_text: second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: History of Printmaking

desc: An examination of one artist's or group of artists' life and work. Relevant artistic, intellectual, social, political and theoretical contexts are considered.
name: ARTH 3507
prereq_text: ARTH 1101 or ARTH 2502 and second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: The Artist in Context

desc: Contemporary art in the global context from 1945 to the present, including Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Postmodernism, object art, performance art and installations.
name: ARTH 3600
prereq_text: second-year standing or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Art Since 1945

desc: The study of art and/or architecture on site outside the National Capital Region, in Canada or internationally. May include a combination of study in Ottawa and on site. Locations vary. Students are expected to bear all travel and other costs arising from site visits.
name: ARTH 3701
prereq_text: permission of the Discipline. Applicants will normally have third-year standing with a minimum of 1.0 credit in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture and a GPA of 8.0 or above.
subject: ARTH
title: Art and Architecture on Site

desc: This seminar complements a major exhibition held at a specific museum. Students enrolled in this course are expected to bear all travel and other costs arising from required visits to the museum.
name: ARTH 3705
prereq_text: second-year standing or higher or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Selected Museum Exhibition

desc: The impact of imperial power and aspiration on the built environment, from the Ancient world to the present day, taking ‘empire’ in its broadest political, social and economic sense.
name: ARTH 3710
prereq_text: ARTH 1100 or ARTH 1101 or ARTH 1200 or ARTH 1201 and second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Architecture and Empire

desc: Selected aspects of art history and visual culture from ancient times to the present.
name: ARTH 3809
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: A Closer Look at Art and Visual Culture

desc: Selected aspects of the history of the designed environment, from ancient times to the present.
name: ARTH 3810
prereq_text: ARTH 1100 or ARTH 1101 or ARTH 1200 or ARTH 1201 and second-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: A Closer Look at the Designed Environment

desc: Practical experience gained by working on specific projects under the supervision of the staff of a museum, cultural institution, public- or private-sector organization associated with art, architecture, design, or heritage. A maximum of 1.0 credit in practicum courses may be used to fulfill program requirements.
name: ARTH 3900
prereq_text: B.A. or B.A. (Honours) in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture with third-year standing or higher and a CGPA of 9.00 or better in ARTH courses, and permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Practicum in Art and Architectural History

desc: Selected topics in Canadian art. Students will be exposed to works in the collections of the National Capital region.
name: ARTH 4000
prereq_text: one of ARTH 2002, ARTH 2003, ARTH 3000 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Canadian Art

desc: Critical examination of contemporary Chinese art. Topics include socially engaged art, historiographies of Chinese contemporary art, re-inventions of traditions, gender and politics of the body, exhibition histories and infrastructures of contemporary art in China.
name: ARTH 4003
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Contemporary Chinese Art

desc: This course will use critical theory to examine aspects of contemporary visual art created by the Inuit and First Peoples in North America.
name: ARTH 4005
prereq_text: ARTH 2005 or ARTH 2006 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Contemporary Indigenous Art

desc: A selected topic in East Asian Art, which may include 19th century Ukiyo-e woodblock prints, The Gutai Group, performance art in China and Japan, and contemporary Chinese art.
name: ARTH 4007
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Asian Art

desc: Critical examination of transnational theories of cultural analysis, including Orientalism, Post-Colonial theory, translation theory and theories of cultural hybridity.
name: ARTH 4008
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Transnational Theory

desc: Selected aspects of Islamic Architecture and Art.
name: ARTH 4107
prereq_text: ARTH 2107 or ARTH 2310 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Islamic Architecture and Art

desc: Selected aspects of Medieval or Medievalist Architecture and Art.
name: ARTH 4202
prereq_text: ARTH 2202 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Medieval Architecture and Art

desc: Selected aspects of Renaissance art and society.
name: ARTH 4305
prereq_text: ARTH 2300 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Renaissance Art

desc: Selected aspects of 18th-century and/or 19th-century art.
name: ARTH 4402
prereq_text: ARTH 2404 or ARTH 2405 or ARTH 2406 or ARTH 2502 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Art of the 18th and 19th Centuries

desc: Art and/or architectural creation, reception and/or historiography through the lens of gender identities.
name: ARTH 4600
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Art, Architecture, and Gender

desc: Relates the themes of selected theoretical texts on photography to specific examples of photographic practice.
name: ARTH 4602
prereq_text: ARTH 2601 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Issues in the Theory and History of Photography

desc: Selected topics in architecture and design of the Modern era.
name: ARTH 4610
prereq_text: ARTH 2610 and fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Modern Architecture or Design

desc: Intensive study of art and/or architecture on site outside the National Capital region, in Canada or internationally. May include a combination of study in Ottawa and on site. Students are expected to bear all travel and other costs arising from site visits.
name: ARTH 4701
prereq_text: Permission of the Discipline. Applicants will normally have fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture and a CGPA of 8.0 or above.
subject: ARTH
title: Art and Architecture on Site

desc: Studies a major exhibition held at a specific museum. Students enrolled in this course are expected to bear all travel and other costs arising from required visits to the museum.
name: ARTH 4705
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture and permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Seminar: Selected Museum Exhibition

desc: Selected aspects of architectural history from ancient times to the present.
name: ARTH 4800
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Architectural History

desc: Selected aspects of art history and/or criticism from ancient times to the present.
name: ARTH 4809
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Topics in Art History and Criticism

desc: Supervised readings and research projects. Guidelines must be obtained from the Undergraduate Supervisor prior to registration. A written project outline, approved by the supervising Art History or History and Theory of Architecture faculty member, must be submitted by the last day for course changes.
name: ARTH 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture and permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Directed Readings and Research

desc: An essay of approximately 10,000 words, resulting from independent research, supervised by Art History or History and Theory of Architecture faculty.
name: ARTH 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Art History or History and Theory of Architecture with a minimum CGPA of 9.00 and permission of the Discipline.
subject: ARTH
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: Cellular functions and their interrelationships. Introduction to thermodynamics, membrane structure and function, transport mechanisms, basic metabolic pathways, energy production and utilization, communications between cells. It is strongly recommended that Biology Majors and Honours students take this course in their second year of study.
name: BIOC 2200
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104), (CHEM 1006 or CHEM 1002) or permission of the Institute. It is strongly recommended that students in Biochemistry programs take this course in their second year of study.
subject: BIOC
title: Cellular Biochemistry

desc: Energy of biological systems, molecular interactions, diffusion principles, introduction to protein folding, structure and thermodynamics, ligand binding and nucleic acid structures; experimental design and data management.
name: BIOC 2300
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 (can be taken concurrently with BIOC 2300) and MATH 1007 and MATH 1107, and (PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008) or (PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004).
subject: BIOC
title: Physical Biochemistry

desc: Students carry out a laboratory research project under the supervision of a faculty member from the Institute of Biochemistry. A research report must be submitted by the last day of classes for evaluation by the Director and Faculty supervisor.
name: BIOC 2400
prereq_text: restricted to Honours students of second-year standing in a Biochemistry program with a GPA of 10.0 or higher in first year, and approval of the Director and a Faculty supervisor.
subject: BIOC
title: Independent Research I

desc: A practical exploration in the application of information technology to biochemistry and molecular biology. Insight into biological knowledge discovery via molecular structure and function prediction, comparative genomics and biological information management.
name: BIOC 3008
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200; or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Bioinformatics

desc: Chemistry, structure and function of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates and nucleic acids. Monomers, linkages and types of biochemical polymers that are formed. Mechanism of action of enzymes, regulatory control mechanisms of proteins and integration of biochemical pathways.
name: BIOC 3101
prereq_text: (BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200), and (CHEM 2203 and CHEM 2204) or (CHEM 2207 and CHEM 2208) or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: General Biochemistry I

desc: Anabolic and catabolic processes. Regulation of cell compartment (membranes, mitochondria, chloroplast, peroxisome, nuclei) composition. Genetic controls of transcription, translation and post-translational modification of protein structure and function. Biochemical processes of disease, development, and toxicology.
name: BIOC 3102
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and BIOL 2104.
subject: BIOC
title: General Biochemistry II

desc: Introduction to experimental biochemistry and the theory and concepts dealt with in BIOC 3101, and BIOC 3202.
name: BIOC 3103
prereq_text: (BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200) and CHEM 2203 or permission of the Institute. CHEM 2204 and (BIOC 2300 or CHEM 2103) are also recommended. It is highly recommended that BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3202 be taken concurrently.
subject: BIOC
title: Practical Biochemistry I

desc: Introduction to experimental biochemistry and the theory and concepts dealt with in BIOC 3101, BIOC 3102, and BIOC 3202.
name: BIOC 3104
prereq_text: BIOC 3103. It is highly recommended that BIOC 3102 be taken concurrently.
subject: BIOC
title: Practical Biochemistry II

desc: Theory and applications of current biochemical/biophysical instrumentation and techniques including biophysical spectroscopy, molecular structure determination, calorimetry, and mass spectrometry.
name: BIOC 3202
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Biophysical Techniques and Applications

desc: Biochemical principles of pharmacology, including receptor mechanisms, signal transduction, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics. Genome-wide association studies, pharmacogenomics, and personalized medicine will also be included.
name: BIOC 3203
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200, or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Biochemical Pharmacology

desc: Students carry out a laboratory research project under the supervision of faculty member from the Institute of Biochemistry. A research report must be submitted by the last day of classes for evaluation by the Director and Faculty supervisor.
name: BIOC 3400
prereq_text: restricted to Honours students of third-year standing in a Biochemistry program with a GPA of 10.0 or higher in second year, and approval of the Director and Faculty supervisor.
subject: BIOC
title: Independent Research II

desc: Practical experience for students enrolled in the co-operative option. Students must receive a satisfactory evaluation from their work term employer; and present a written report describing their work term project. Graded Sat or Uns.
name: BIOC 3999
prereq_text: registration in the Biochemistry co-operative option and permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Principles and applications of modern biochemical methodology, including ultracentrifugation, electrophoresis, ELISA, EMSA, experimental planning, ligand binding kinetics, fluorescence spectroscopy, affinity purification, and in vitro translation.
name: BIOC 4001
prereq_text: BIOC 3103 and BIOC 3104 or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Methods in Biochemistry

desc: The application of biochemistry to the production of biological compounds useful in nutrition, medicine, and the food and chemical industries. General strategies for efficient production of these compounds by controlling the activities of living cells or enzymes.
name: BIOC 4004
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3102 (BIOC 3102 may be taken concurrently), or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Industrial Biochemistry

desc: Regulation at the transcriptional, translational and metabolic level; regulation of cell and subcellular organelle function and other timely topics may be included.
name: BIOC 4005
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3102.
subject: BIOC
title: Biochemical Regulation

desc: Biochemical and biophysical aspects of biomembrane structure and function. Topics may include: membrane lipids and proteins, lipid polymorphism, model membranes, liposomes, membrane biogenesis, the membrane cytoskeleton, membrane trafficking, membrane fusion, exocytosis and signal transduction across membranes.
name: BIOC 4007
prereq_text: BIOL 2200 or BIOC 2200, or BIOC 3101 (which may be taken concurrently with BIOC 4007), or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Membrane Biochemistry

desc: Modeling and simulation of metabolic and regulatory networks towards understanding complex and highly dynamic cellular systems. Biotechnological applications include metabolic engineering, synthetic biology, and drug discovery.
name: BIOC 4008
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Computational Systems Biology

desc: The biochemical basis of disease including genetic and metabolic disorders such as cancer, neurological degenerative conditions, diabetes, stroke and microbial infections.
name: BIOC 4009
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3102, or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Biochemistry of Disease

desc: The organization and function of the immune system, including the anatomy of the immune system, the properties and behaviour of cells of the immune system, and the molecular and genetic bases of the immune response.
name: BIOC 4200
prereq_text: BIOL 3201 or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Immunology

desc: Theory and application of current techniques and developments in cell culture as applied to research questions in the field of stem cells and tissue engineering.
name: BIOC 4201
prereq_text: BIOL 3201 or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Cell Culture and Tissue Engineering

desc: A mechanistic study of mutagenesis and DNA repair. Topics include DNA structure perturbations, spontaneous and induced mutagenesis, the genetics and biochemistry of DNA repair and recombination, and the role of mutations in the development of genetic disease and cancer.
name: BIOC 4202
prereq_text: BIOL 3104 and BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200, or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Mutagenesis and DNA Repair

desc: Structure, biochemical derivation and function of secondary metabolites such as toxins and antibiotics. Examples from plant, fungal and animal systems.
name: BIOC 4203
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3102, or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Metabolism

desc: An advanced lecture, discussion and seminar course covering the theory, development and current techniques of protein and enzyme engineering. Topics to be discussed may also include applications in biotechnology, nanotechnology and new frontiers in basic and applied research.
name: BIOC 4204
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3202 (may be taken concurrently), or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Protein Biotechnology

desc: Basic theorems of toxicology with examples of current research problems. Toxic risk is defined as the product of intensive hazard and extensive exposure. Each factor is assessed in scientific and social contexts and illustrated with many types of experimental material.
name: BIOC 4708
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 and fourth-year standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Principles of Toxicology

desc: Selected topics of current interest in biochemistry are offered upon approval by the Director in consultation with members of the Institute.
name: BIOC 4901
prereq_text: None
subject: BIOC
title: Selected Topics in Biochemistry

desc: Collaborative, interdisciplinary research project approved by the Director. Requires co-supervision, with at least one faculty member from the Institute of Biochemistry. Evaluation is based on a written thesis and poster presentation.
name: BIOC 4906
prereq_text: (BIOC 3103 and BIOC 3104) and (BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3102) or equivalent, eligibility to continue in Honours Biochemistry or in Biochemistry and Biotechnology, permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Interdisciplinary Research Project

desc: An independent research study using library or computational resources. The candidate will prepare a critical review of a topic approved by a faculty adviser. Evaluation will be based on a written report and a poster presentation of the project.
name: BIOC 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours Biochemistry program and permission of the Institute.
subject: BIOC
title: Honours Essay and Research Proposal

desc: Students carry out a research project approved by the Director, under the supervision of a faculty member of the Institute, in either the Biology or Chemistry departments. Evaluation is based on a written thesis and poster presentation.
name: BIOC 4908
prereq_text: (BIOC 3103 and BIOC 3104) and (BIOC 3101 and BIOC 3102) or equivalent, and eligibility to continue in Honours Biochemistry or in Biochemistry and Biotechnology.
subject: BIOC
title: Research Project

desc: A course for students interested in the science behind recent advances in biotechnology. The different ways in which biotechnology is being applied in agriculture, health care, and the environment will be examined.
name: BIOL 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: BIOL
title: Biotechnology and Society

desc: A research-oriented course focusing on the scientific process of biological exploration at the cellular level. Topics include cell organization, metabolism, genetics, and reproduction.
name: BIOL 1103
prereq_text: Ontario 4U/M in Biology (or equivalent), or Ontario 4U/M in Chemistry (or equivalent).
subject: BIOL
title: Foundations of Biology I

desc: A research-oriented course focusing on the scientific process of biological exploration at the macroscale. Topics include evolution, diversity of life, and ecological relationships.
name: BIOL 1104
prereq_text: Ontario 4U/M in Biology (or equivalent) or BIOL 1103.
subject: BIOL
title: Foundations of Biology II

desc: Formulation of biological research questions, development of hypotheses and predictions, design of experiments, collection and analysis of data, interpretation and presentation of results.
name: BIOL 1105
prereq_text: None
subject: BIOL
title: Biological Methods, Analysis and Interpretation

desc: A course designed primarily for students in non-biology programs to investigate the natural history of plants and animals, and the communities in which they occur. Particular attention is paid to the Ottawa region, but appropriate examples from other locales are also included.
name: BIOL 1902
prereq_text: None
subject: BIOL
title: Natural History

desc: An introduction to the diverse structures of animals (both invertebrates and vertebrates) in relationship to their functions, discussed within an evolutionary framework.
name: BIOL 2001
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Animals: Form and Function

desc: An introduction to the structure and development of higher plants (at cellular, morphological and organism levels) discussed in relation to their function.
name: BIOL 2002
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Plants: Form and Function

desc: A course for non-specialists interested in how the human body works. Topics will include biological molecules, cells, genetics, and various organ systems. Examples will be used to connect concepts taught in the course with general knowledge of human health and disease.
name: BIOL 2005
prereq_text: BIOL 1003 or BIOL 1103 and (CHEM 1001 and CHEM 1002) or (CHEM 1005 and CHEM 1006) or permission of the Department. Students in Biology and Biochemistry programs may only take this course as a free elective.
subject: BIOL
title: Human Biology

desc: Lecture/laboratory course on the mechanisms of inheritance and the nature of gene structure, composition and function, introducing both classical Mendelian genetics and modern molecular genetics. It is strongly recommended that this course be taken by Biology majors in their second year of study.
name: BIOL 2104
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Introductory Genetics

desc: Mechanisms of inheritance and the nature of gene structure, composition and function, introducing both classical Mendelian genetics and modern molecular genetics.
name: BIOL 2107
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Genetics

desc: Cellular functions and their interrelationships. Introduction to thermodynamics, membrane structure and function, transport mechanisms, basic metabolic pathways, energy production and utilization, communications between cells. It is strongly recommended that Biology Majors and Honours students take this course in their second year of study.
name: BIOL 2200
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104), (CHEM 1001 and CHEM 1002) or (CHEM 1005 and CHEM 1006), or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Cellular Biochemistry

desc: A study of the molecular, metabolic and structural organization of cells in relation to function. This course is recommended for students not taking upper year Biology laboratory courses for which BIOL/BIOC laboratories are prerequisites.
name: BIOL 2201
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 or BIOL 1103) and (CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1006), or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Cell Biology and Biochemistry

desc: An introductory course on the science, technology, entrepreneurial skills and business considerations related to biotechnology. The course will survey broadly across the disciplines of Biology, including applications in agriculture, health, environment and industry.
name: BIOL 2301
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104) or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Biotechnology I

desc: The biology of the bacteria, Archaea, Viruses and Protozoans, from the fundamentals of cell chemistry, molecular biology, structure and function, to their involvement in ecological and industrial processes and human disease.
name: BIOL 2303
prereq_text: BIOL 1003 or BIOL 1103.
subject: BIOL
title: Microbiology

desc: The scientific study of interactions of living organisms and their environment, and how these affect the distribution and abundance of life. Topics include energy transformation and flow, nutrient cycling, population and community dynamics, human impacts on ecosystems, conservation issues. Laboratory includes field and computer exercises.
name: BIOL 2600
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104), or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Ecology

desc: Introduction to the remarkable diversity and ecological relationships of Ontario's flora and fauna, which are explored in a habitat context.
name: BIOL 2903
prereq_text: BIOL 1004 or BIOL 1104 or BIOL 1902.
subject: BIOL
title: Natural History and Ecology of Ontario

desc: Introductory course dealing with the taxonomic diversity, anatomy, behavior and physiology of insects, as well as their impacts on ecosystems, agriculture and animal and human health.
name: BIOL 3004
prereq_text: BIOL 2001.
subject: BIOL
title: Insect Diversity

desc: A practical exploration in the application of information technology to biochemistry and molecular biology. Insight into biological knowledge discovery via molecular structure and function prediction, comparative genomics and biological information management.
name: BIOL 3008
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Bioinformatics

desc: This introductory course will cover the morphology, physiology, life cycles, evolution, ecology and biotechnology of the fungi.
name: BIOL 3102
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107.
subject: BIOL
title: Mycology

desc: A lecture course dealing with modern advances in molecular genetics.
name: BIOL 3104
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Genetics

desc: Evolution of mammals, reptiles and birds. Emphasis on surveying amniote diversity, and the origin of key amniote transformations, as evidenced by the fossil record.
name: BIOL 3111
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 or ERTH 1009, or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Vertebrate Evolution: Mammals, Reptiles, and Birds

desc: Evolution of fish and amphibians. Emphasis on surveying fish and amphibian diversity, and the origin of key transformations of these groups, as evidenced by the fossil record.
name: BIOL 3112
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 or ERTH 1009, or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Vertebrate Evolution: Fish and Amphibians

desc: A lecture and laboratory course on the structure, composition, and function of eukaryotic cells.
name: BIOL 3201
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 and BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Cell Biology

desc: Introduction to the underlying principles and mechanisms governing development in multicellular animals and plants. Differentiation, growth, morphogenesis, and patterning will be examined at the organismal, cellular, and molecular levels to provide a balanced view of developmental phenomena in key model organisms.
name: BIOL 3202
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107 and one of BIOL 2001 or BIOL 2002, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Developmental Biology

desc: A lecture and laboratory course consisting of selected topics in metabolism and physiology of plants, including photosynthesis, nutrient uptake and transport, intermediary and secondary metabolism, germination, growth and development.
name: BIOL 3205
prereq_text: BIOL 2002 and BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Plant Biochemistry and Physiology

desc: An interdisciplinary course on interactions between science, invention and innovation in biotechnology. Case studies related to regional biotechnology opportunities; social and ethical issues impacting biotechnology.
name: BIOL 3301
prereq_text: BIOL 2301, BIOL 2104, and BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Biotechnology II

desc: Intensive training in laboratory techniques in microbiology, using bacteria and other microorganisms to demonstrate processes of cell growth, metabolism, gene expression, rapid evolution, gene transfer, microbial community dynamics and interactions with other organisms.
name: BIOL 3303
prereq_text: BIOL 2104, BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 and BIOL 2303, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Experimental Microbiology

desc: The properties of physiological systems and components of humans and other animals with an emphasis on physical and chemical bases.
name: BIOL 3305
prereq_text: BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 and BIOL 2001. A credit in PHYS at the 1000-level is strongly recommended.
subject: BIOL
title: Human and Comparative Physiology

desc: The anatomy and physiology of the neuromuscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and excretory systems of humans with comparison to other animals.
name: BIOL 3306
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104), and (CHEM 1001 and CHEM 1002) or (CHEM 1005 and CHEM 1006), and third year standing.
subject: BIOL
title: Human Anatomy and Physiology

desc: The anatomy and physiology of the endocrine, skeletal, digestive, immunological, and reproductive systems, with additional emphasis on the embryological origins of the major physiological systems.
name: BIOL 3307
prereq_text: BIOL 3305 or BIOL 3306.
subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Human Anatomy and Physiology

desc: Properties of muscles, tendons, bones, joints and the co-ordinated use of these structures. Human and other animal locomotion and fitness, bird flight, especially the soaring of the vulture and the albatross, and animal migration are covered in detail.
name: BIOL 3501
prereq_text: (BIOL 1003 and BIOL 1004) or (BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104).
subject: BIOL
title: Biomechanics

desc: Exploration of the unique contribution of the ecosystem approach to ecology, and of early key literature in ecosystem ecology through to current work on global environmental change.
name: BIOL 3601
prereq_text: BIOL 2600.
subject: BIOL
title: Ecosystems and Environmental Change

desc: The science of biology as applied to the problem of maintaining species diversity. Topics include: history of conservation biology, valuation of species, indices of biodiversity, extinction, conservation genetics, conservation planning in parks and reserves, landscape ecology and case studies of conservation problems.
name: BIOL 3602
prereq_text: BIOL 2600 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Conservation Biology

desc: Introduction to the analysis of biological data. Students analyze real biological data sets in weekly laboratory sessions. Methods introduced include simple linear, polynomial, and multiple regression analysis, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, tests of independence and logistic regression analysis.
name: BIOL 3604
prereq_text: BIOL 1105 or STAT 2507.
subject: BIOL
title: Statistics for Biologists

desc: An intensive study of living organisms under natural conditions. Credit is based on two weeks of full-time fieldwork with attendant assignments. Transportation and room and board costs are borne by the student. Ontario Universities Program in Field Biology; see offered modules for specific prerequisites.
name: BIOL 3605
prereq_text: at least one course in BIOL beyond the 1000-level and written permission of the Department. Students may take both BIOL 3605 and BIOL 3606 for credit, but neither may be used to repeat a particular module.
subject: BIOL
title: Field Course I

desc: An intensive study of living organisms under natural conditions. Credit is based on two weeks of full-time fieldwork with attendant assignments. Transportation and room and board costs are borne by the student. Ontario Universities Program in Field Biology; see offered modules for specific prerequisites.
name: BIOL 3606
prereq_text: at least one course in BIOL beyond the 1000-level and written permission of the Department. Students may take both BIOL 3605 and BIOL 3606 for credit, but neither can be used to repeat a particular module.
subject: BIOL
title: Field Course II

desc: Contemporary and past controls on distribution of plants and animals at global, regional and local scales; significance of these distributions.
name: BIOL 3608
prereq_text: BIOL 2600 or GEOG 1010 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Biogeography

desc: Evolution is the change in population properties across generations. Genetic variation, mutation, selection, drift, gene flow, genome evolution, speciation, development, biodiversity, fossils, and macro-evolution.
name: BIOL 3609
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107 or permission of the instructor.
subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Concepts

desc: The term “adaptation” is meaningful only with respect to an ecological context. Ecological contexts lead to evolutionary outcomes such as diverse mating systems, ageing, sexual reproduction, sexual dimorphism, geographic variation, phenotypic plasticity, and diverse life histories.
name: BIOL 3611
