prereq_text: BIOL 2600.
subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Ecology

desc: Introduction to the development and use of computer programs to address biological problems. Topics include the development of programs to analyse ecological data, models of population dynamics, deterministic chaos, cellular automata, simulations of foraging behaviour and evolutionary computation.
name: BIOL 3612
prereq_text: BIOL 2600 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Computational Methods in Ecology and Evolution

desc: Exploration of the chemical, physiological, ecological and evolutionary interactions that underlie the relationship between plants and their insect herbivores.
name: BIOL 3801
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 and BIOL 2002.
subject: BIOL
title: Plants and Herbivores

desc: Advanced study of animal behaviour including the environmental, genetic, and neural influences on behaviour. Topics such as predator-prey interactions, mating behaviour, migration, parental care and social interactions are interpreted in an evolutionary context.
name: BIOL 3802
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 or BIOL 2600 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Animal Behaviour

desc: Diversity in social behaviour from evolutionary and ecological perspectives. Topics include ecological determinants of social living, social networks, social foraging, inclusive fitness, kin selection, altruism, cooperation, and mating systems and strategies.
name: BIOL 3804
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 and BIOL 2600, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Social Evolution

desc: The development of a competitive research proposal in consultation with an advisor.
name: BIOL 3901
prereq_text: third year standing in an Honours Biology program and permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Research Proposal

desc: Specific topics of current interest. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: BIOL 3902
prereq_text: third-year standing in a Biology program or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Topics in Biology I

desc: Practical experience for students enrolled in the Co-operative Option. Students must receive satisfactory evaluations from their work term employer. Written reports describing the work term project will be required. Graded Sat or Uns.
name: BIOL 3999
prereq_text: registration in the Biology Co-operative Option and permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Co-operative Work Term Report

desc: Recent advances in plant development including molecular, biochemical, genomics, and proteomics studies.
name: BIOL 4008
prereq_text: BIOL 2002 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Plant Development

desc: The interface of molecular biology, ecology and population biology. Topics include experimental design and a survey and critique of molecular genetic methods to study ecology.
name: BIOL 4102
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107 and BIOL 2600; BIOL 3104 or one of BIOL 3601, BIOL 3602 (may be taken concurrently), or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Ecology

desc: Evolution of gene frequencies, including selection, mutation, genetic drift, inbreeding, gene flow, and population structure.
name: BIOL 4103
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107 or permission of the Department. A course in statistics is highly recommended.
subject: BIOL
title: Population Genetics

desc: An overview of the molecular evidence of evolution, speciation as well as the phylogenetic analysis of biological sequence data and biometrical traits.
name: BIOL 4104
prereq_text: (BIOL 2001 or BIOL 2002) and (BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107) or permission of the Department. A course in statistics is recommended.
subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Genetics

desc: Review of the application of high throughput approaches to research in molecular and cellular biology and biochemistry with an emphasis on gene function and human disease progression.
name: BIOL 4106
prereq_text: BIOL 2303 and (BIOL 3104 or BIOL 3201).
subject: BIOL
title: Advances in Molecular Biology

desc: This laboratory course provides practical familiarity with commonly used techniques in molecular genetics. The laboratory is suitable for students with a developing interest in problems of molecular and cellular biology and biochemistry.
name: BIOL 4109
prereq_text: BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 and BIOL 2303 and BIOL 3104 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Laboratory Techniques in Molecular Genetics

desc: The organization and function of the immune system, including the anatomy of the immune system, the properties and behaviour of cells of the immune system, and the molecular and genetic bases of the immune response.
name: BIOL 4200
prereq_text: BIOL 3201 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Immunology

desc: Theory and application of current techniques and developments in cell culture as applied to research questions in the field of stem cells and tissue engineering.
name: BIOL 4201
prereq_text: BIOL 3201 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Cell Culture and Tissue Engineering

desc: A mechanistic study of mutagenesis and DNA repair. Topics include DNA structure perturbations, spontaneous and induced mutagenesis, the genetics and biochemistry of DNA repair and recombination, and the role of mutations in the development of genetic disease and cancer.
name: BIOL 4202
prereq_text: BIOL 3104 and BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Mutagenesis and DNA Repair

desc: The evolution of sex, including meiosis, syngamy, sex determination, sex chromosomes, and gender from organismal, genetic, and developmental perspectives; the origin, maintenance, function, and ubiquity of sex.
name: BIOL 4203
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107.
subject: BIOL
title: Evolution of Sex

desc: A survey of human genetic variation and mutation in a molecular genetics context. Topics may include molecular basis of diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, genomic imprinting, cancer genetics, genomics, gene mapping and gene therapy.
name: BIOL 4206
prereq_text: BIOL 3104 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Human Genetics

desc: A laboratory-based exploration of techniques and recent developments in the use of model embryological systems as applied to questions of development and human health.
name: BIOL 4207
prereq_text: BIOL 3201 or BIOL 3202 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Embryology & Developmental Biology

desc: An advanced course dealing with recent developments in selected topics of plant physiology.
name: BIOL 4209
prereq_text: BIOL 3205 and CHEM 2203, CHEM 2204 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Plant Physiology

desc: Studies of the application of microorganisms. Topics may include: microbial communities, and agricultural, pharmaceutical, industrial and health sciences.
name: BIOL 4300
prereq_text: (BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2201), BIOL 2303 and (BIOL 3104 or BIOL 3303) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Applied Microbiology

desc: Explorations of developing biotechnologies in areas such as microbial products, protein engineering, plant genetic engineering, environmental remediation, pharmaceuticals production and medical diagnostics and therapy.
name: BIOL 4301
prereq_text: BIOL 3301 or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Current Topics in Biotechnology

desc: Exploration of current microbiology including the molecular biology of infectious agents, use of model micro-organisms to study human cells and diseases, and functional genomics and proteomics. Special attention will be paid to the field’s "big questions". Students will critically examine a number of research proposals.
name: BIOL 4303
prereq_text: BIOL 2303 and (BIOL 3104 or BIOL 3303 or BIOC 3102) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Advances in Microbiology

desc: An introduction to forensics that covers topics in molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, population genetics and statistics as they relate to forensic biology. The course will describe the techniques used to identify body fluids and generate DNA profiles as well as the interpretation of forensic results.
name: BIOL 4304
prereq_text: (BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107) and (BIOL 2200/BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2201) or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Forensic Biology

desc: A course dealing with recent advances made in particular areas of animal neurophysiology.
name: BIOL 4306
prereq_text: BIOL 3305 or BIOL 3306, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Animal Neurophysiology

desc: Biomechanical underpinnings of human performance including the quantitative analysis of human motion in normal activities and in athletic performance. Students will learn modern motion capture methods. This course will require students to design and execute an independent project.
name: BIOL 4309
prereq_text: BIOL 3307 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Studies in Human Performance

desc: Proximate mechanisms underlying animal behaviour. Focus on evolution of nervous systems in response to environmental selection pressures. Topics include: genetic and hormonal influences on behaviour (e.g. maternal care); unique sensory worlds (e.g. magnetic); various levels of neural integration, from simple reflexes to complex social behaviour.
name: BIOL 4317
prereq_text: BIOL 3305 or BIOL 3306, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Neuroethology: The Neural Basis of Animal Behaviour

desc: Lectures, discussions and student presentations will be used to examine adaptations of animals to extreme environments (e.g. desert) or lifestyles (e.g. diving), at the physiological, biochemical and molecular levels. Emphasis on becoming familiar with the current primary literature.
name: BIOL 4318
prereq_text: BIOL 3305, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Adaptations to Extreme Environments

desc: Physiological mechanisms underlying human athletic performance. Exercise physiology and cardio-respiratory activity, metabolic regulation and musculoskeletal function. Practical experience will be gained in the workshop/laboratory based experimental sessions.
name: BIOL 4319
prereq_text: BIOL 3307 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: Studies in Exercise Physiology

desc: Introduction to ornithology, the study of birds; the evolution of birds, migration, geographic variation, adaptations for flight, feeding, reproduction; extinction and preservation.
name: BIOL 4500
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: The Biology of Birds

desc: The taxonomy of birds and species identification are learned through the use of study skins in the lab. Field excursions allow first-hand study of various species. Participants must acquire a pair of binoculars and one of the recommended field guides.
name: BIOL 4501
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 or permission of the department.
subject: BIOL
title: The Taxonomy of Birds

desc: Herpetology is the study of amphibians and reptiles. The behaviours, physiological ecology, conservation and identification of amphibians and reptiles will be examined through lectures, seminars and hands-on activities.
name: BIOL 4502
prereq_text: BIOL 2001.
subject: BIOL
title: Herpetology

desc: Introduction to the diversity and environmental biology of the world's fishes. Applied issues in fisheries management, conservation, and aquaculture. Workshops expose students to techniques in fisheries science through hands-on demonstrations and field excursions.
name: BIOL 4503
prereq_text: BIOL 2600 or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Fish Ecology, Conservation and Management

desc: Overview of the diversity and ecology of freshwater invertebrates. Aquatic invertebrates from local bodies of water will be sampled and identified in the lab. Experiments on the ecology and behaviour of model species of freshwater invertebrates will also be conducted in the lab.
name: BIOL 4504
prereq_text: BIOL 2001 and BIOL 2600.
subject: BIOL
title: Ecology of Freshwater Invertebrates

desc: Examining the diversity of life on coral reefs and their interactions across ecological scales, from the biochemistry of zooxanthellae symbiosis to landscape scale trophodynamics, reticulate evolution, and reef fisheries. Emphasis is on synthesis writing drawn from the current primary literature.
name: BIOL 4505
prereq_text: BIOL 2600.
subject: BIOL
title: Coral Reefs

desc: Covers the cactus family over its entire range, including most of the western hemisphere, with discussion on their anatomy, physiology, ecology, evolution, and classification. Topics include how cacti are both typical flowering plants in some regards, and atypical in others.
name: BIOL 4506
prereq_text: BIOL 2002.
subject: BIOL
title: Cactus Biology

desc: Key concepts in the ecological study of parasites and pathogens, underpinned by evolutionary thinking and relevant to fundamental and applied questions of co-evolution, disease ecology, epidemiology, emerging infectious diseases, environmental parasitology, evolutionary transitions, host species range, immunity, resistance, tolerance, transmission mode, and virulence.
name: BIOL 4507
prereq_text: BIOL 2600 and one of the following: BIOL 3601, BIOL 3604, BIOL 3609, BIOL 3611, BIOL 3612, BIOL 3801, BIOL 3802, BIOL 3804.
subject: BIOL
title: Ecological Parasitology

desc: Evolutionary principles contributing to advancements across fields including medicine, agriculture, conservation, climate change, and engineering. Topics include evolution of virulence, causes of variation in human health, evolution of resistance to pesticides, interventions for recovery of species at risk, and biomimetic modeling in engineering and architecture.
name: BIOL 4602
prereq_text: BIOL 1104 and third-year standing.
subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Applications across Disciplines: From Medicine to Conservation

desc: Major questions on the origin, evolution and adaptation of structures and physiology of terrestrial arthropods, especially insects.
name: BIOL 4603
prereq_text: BIOL 3004, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Insect Evolution and Biology

desc: Landscape ecology is the study of how landscape structure affects the abundance and distribution of organisms. The focus of this course is on research methods and results in landscape ecology. Applications in forestry, agriculture, and species conservation.
name: BIOL 4604
prereq_text: BIOL 2600 or equivalent, BIOL 3601 or BIOL 3602 or BIOL 3608 or equivalent, and fourth-year standing in Biology, Geography, or Environmental Sciences.
subject: BIOL
title: Landscape Ecology

desc: Contemporary issues in behavioural ecology. Topics may include the relevance of behavioural ecology to conservation biology, to new insights into human social behaviour, and will be selected through consultation between professor and students.
name: BIOL 4802
prereq_text: BIOL 3802 or BIOL 3804, or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Animal Behaviour

desc: An introduction to the science of teaching and learning in biology. Students will be introduced to the foundational concepts in, and tools of, Discipline-Based Education Research (DBER) and will conduct their own DBER research project.
name: BIOL 4810
prereq_text: 4th year standing, or permission of the department This course can only be used by science students as a free elective.
subject: BIOL
title: Education Research in Biology

desc: Independent or group study, open to third- and fourth-year students to explore a particular topic, in consultation with a Faculty supervisor. May include directed reading, written assignments, tutorials, laboratory or field work.
name: BIOL 4901
prereq_text: permission of the Department. Students normally may not offer more than 1.0 credit of Directed Special Studies in their program.
subject: BIOL
title: Directed Special Studies

desc: Specific topics of current interest. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: BIOL 4902
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in a Biology program or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Topics in Biology II

desc: Within the context of an active learning environment, students participate in a variety of activities which may include literature reviews and critiques, media releases and response papers, oral presentations, and posters. Projects are focused on an area of biological research of interest to the student.
name: BIOL 4905
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours biology program and permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Honours Workshop

desc: An independent critical review and research proposal, using library resources, under the direct supervision of a Faculty advisor. Evaluation is based on a written report and a poster presentation.
name: BIOL 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours Biology program and permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Honours Essay and Research Proposal

desc: An independent research project undertaken in the field and/or the laboratory, under the direct supervision of a faculty adviser. Evaluation is based on a written thesis and a poster presentation.
name: BIOL 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours biology program with a minimum CGPA of 8.0 in the major or permission of the Department.
subject: BIOL
title: Honours Research Thesis

desc: Discussion of the concepts of asset valuation and income measurement underlying the preparations and interpretation of financial statements.
name: BUSI 1001
prereq_text: second-year standing, or permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Principles of Financial Accounting

desc: An introduction to the use of accounting data for the purposes of planning and control of operations.
name: BUSI 1002
prereq_text: second-year standing and BUSI 1001, or permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Management Accounting

desc: Introduction to accounting information, the basic accounting cycle, and consideration of selected financial statement topics. Analysis of cost behavior and the uses and limitations of accounting information in planning, controlling and decision-making processes.
name: BUSI 1003
prereq_text: None
subject: BUSI
title: Survey of Accounting

desc: Introduction to accounting for business organizations. The student will be introduced to the accounting process and the preparation and analysis of the balance sheet, income statement, and cash flow statement.
name: BUSI 1004
prereq_text: BUSI 1701 or BUSI 1800. Restricted to B.Com. and B.I.B. students.
subject: BUSI
title: Financial Accounting for Business Students

desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information within a business organization for effective management including: planning, directing, motivating, and controlling activities and behaviours.
name: BUSI 1005
prereq_text: BUSI 1004. Restricted to B.Com. and B.I.B. students.
subject: BUSI
title: Managerial Accounting for Business Students

desc: Introduction to ICT in organizations. Topics may include spreadsheets, databases, statistical software, website design and implementation, collaboration software including wikis, blogs and social networking, GPS, m-Commerce.
name: BUSI 1402
prereq_text: None
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Business Information and Communication Technologies

desc: Introduction to the principles and practices of international business. Topics include the impact of culture and the political, economic, and legal systems on global strategy, international institutions, theories of cross-border trade, and the characteristics and effects of regional trade blocs.
name: BUSI 1701
prereq_text: restricted to B.I.B. students.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to International Business

desc: Introduction to contemporary businesses in a complex economy, their role in the society, their history. The various functions that come together to define a business will be examined. All forms of business communications emphasized.
name: BUSI 1800
prereq_text: restricted to B.Com. students with first-year or second-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Business

desc: Introduction to contemporary businesses in a complex economy and their role in the society. An overview of the various functions that come together to define a business will be examined.
name: BUSI 1801
prereq_text: None
subject: BUSI
title: Foundations of Business

desc: An introduction to the knowledge and tools required for a career in Business.
name: BUSI 1995
prereq_text: Restricted to students registered in B.Com. or B.I.B.
subject: BUSI
title: Employability Passport I

desc: An examination of accounting and reporting issues related primarily to asset valuation and revenue recognition.
name: BUSI 2001
prereq_text: BUSI 1001 and BUSI 1002, or BUSI 1004 and BUSI 1005 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Intermediate Accounting I

desc: An examination of accounting and reporting issues related primarily to liabilities and equities.
name: BUSI 2002
prereq_text: BUSI 2001, and BUSI 2504 or BUSI 2503 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Intermediate Accounting II

desc: A foundation course that aims to introduce the fundamental concepts of income tax laws and regulations as significant elements in the planning and decision making process of taxpayers and managers. Problems, issues and planning associated with the Income Tax Act are discussed.
name: BUSI 2005
prereq_text: BUSI 1001 or BUSI 1004 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Income Tax Fundamentals

desc: Models of individual and small group behaviour in organizations. Topics include motivation, communication, job design, leadership and group dynamics to provide systematic explanations of employee and managerial behaviour in organizations.
name: BUSI 2101
prereq_text: second-year standing. Restricted to B.Com. students.
subject: BUSI
title: Organizational Behaviour

desc: Individual and small group behaviors in organizations and management of the same.
name: BUSI 2121
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Organizational Behaviour

desc: Basic problems and practices in marketing. Marketing planning tools and strategies of firms.
name: BUSI 2204
prereq_text: None
subject: BUSI
title: Basic Marketing

desc: Overview of the marketing function within the firm. Introduction to key marketing concepts and principles; business environment analysis, strategic decision making (segmentation, targeting, positioning), marketing mix planning (product, price, place promotion). Analysis of marketing problems using cases and major project.
name: BUSI 2208
prereq_text: BUSI 1004, ECON 1001 and ECON 1002 (or ECON 1000) and one of BUSI 1701, PSYC 1002, SOCI 1005. Restricted to B.Com. or B.I.B. students.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Marketing

desc: Concepts, models, and managerial issues in planning, designing, operating and controlling systems across supply chains for the provision of goods and services. Emphasis on basic ideas and tools.
name: BUSI 2301
prereq_text: second-year standing. Restricted to selected Sprott programs.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Supply and Operations Management

desc: This course helps student to understand the critical role of information systems in organizations and their impact on social and ethical issues. Covers fundamental tools and skills for the development and management of information systems and business analytics in organizations.
name: BUSI 2400
prereq_text: None
subject: BUSI
title: Foundations of Information Systems

desc: Introduction to programming. Fundamentals of structured and object-oriented programming using an OO programming language. Treatment of objects, abstraction and inheritance, event-driven programming, iteration, sequence and selection. Consideration of algorithms for searching, sorting, string processing and numerical analysis. Emphasis on the development of business applications.
name: BUSI 2402
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Applications Development

desc: Basic issues and practices in finance. Survey of business firms' financing, investment, and payout decisions. Emphasis on understanding the principals, resources and trade-offs in the financial area of a business.
name: BUSI 2503
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Finance

desc: Business firms' financing, capital investment, and dividend policy decisions, cost of capital and short-term asset management problems.
name: BUSI 2504
prereq_text: BUSI 1005, and ECON 1001 and ECON 1002 (or ECON 1000) or ECOR 3800. Restricted to selected Sprott programs.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Finance I

desc: Capital investment and financing decisions in the context of risk and return tradeoffs. Primary and derivative securities, and their role in risk management. Mergers, corporate restructuring, the theory of principal-agent relationships, and financial planning, forecasting, and control.
name: BUSI 2505
prereq_text: BUSI 1002 or BUSI 1005, BUSI 2504 with a grade of C or higher in each; ECON 1001 and ECON 1002 (or ECON 1000) and MATH 1009 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Finance II

desc: Analysis and interpretation of an entity's financial statements and annual report from a user perspective. Ratio analysis is used to analyze firm performance and make forecasts of future performance.
name: BUSI 2506
prereq_text: BUSI 2504 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Financial Statement Analysis

desc: The legal system and legal ordering as they affect those engaged in business activities. Emphasis on the law of tort, law of contract, agency and bailment, business associations (partnerships/proprietorships/corporations) and real estate.
name: BUSI 2601
prereq_text: None
subject: BUSI
title: Business Law

desc: Introduction to the context and operation of international business. Topics include international trade theory, trade agreements and blocs, international finance, global marketing, international human resource management and global strategy.
name: BUSI 2701
prereq_text: BUSI 1800.
subject: BUSI
title: Fundamentals of International Business

desc: Applies principles of organizational behavior and organizational theory to the operations of international businesses. Includes discussion of appropriate strategies and structures. Introduces concepts of cross-cultural communication.
name: BUSI 2702
prereq_text: second-year standing in B.I.B. and BUSI 1701.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to International Management

desc: Introduction to contemporary businesses in a complex economy, their role in society and their history. Examination of the various functions that come together to define a business with an emphasis on all forms of business communications.
name: BUSI 2703
prereq_text: second-year standing. No credit for students in B.Com. or BIB.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to International Business

desc: Overview of the basics of entrepreneurship, with emphasis on idea generation and identification, team building, business models, initial strategies and feasibility. A number of organization types will be studied.
name: BUSI 2800
prereq_text: BUSI 1800 or BUSI 1801 and second-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Entrepreneurship

desc: An intermediate course in the knowledge and tools required for a career in Business.
name: BUSI 2995
prereq_text: BUSI 1995.
subject: BUSI
title: Employability Passport II

desc: Accounting problems associated with business combinations, with attention to the preparation of consolidated financial statements. Discussion may extend to financial reporting and diversified companies, reorganizations, etc. Selection of topics may vary from year to year.
name: BUSI 3001
prereq_text: BUSI 2002 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Accounting for Business Combinations

desc: Federal income tax laws and regulations and their impact on an individual's financial and business decisions. Problems, issues and planning associated with the Income Tax Act and concerned with the computation of taxable income and taxes payable by an individual are discussed.
name: BUSI 3005
prereq_text: BUSI 2001 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Taxation I

desc: Auditing theory, methodology and application.
name: BUSI 3007
prereq_text: BUSI 2001.
subject: BUSI
title: Auditing I

desc: The use of accounting information for cost control and performance evaluation. Emphasis is on cost accumulation systems, performance evaluation, control models and analytical tools.
name: BUSI 3008
prereq_text: BUSI 1002 or BUSI 1005 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Intermediate Management Accounting and Control

desc: Data analysis in accounting, working with and making sense of big data using various data analysis tools. Specific topics include; data collection, cleaning, analyzing, visualization, and decision making in different areas of accounting.
name: BUSI 3040
prereq_text: BUSI 2400 and BUSI 3007 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Data Analytics and Information Systems for Accounting

desc: Human Resource Management function in large formal organizations. Topics include human resources planning, recruitment, selection, performance evaluation, career development and training, compensation and benefits and the role of the professional personnel manager.
name: BUSI 3102
prereq_text: second-year standing and one of BUSI 2101, BUSI 2121, BUSI 2702, BUSI 3602, or PSYC 2801.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Human Resources Management

desc: Macro-organization theory. Structuring of organizations in a complex global economy. Effects of the external environment, technology, culture and organizational goals on the structure, processes and effectiveness of the organization.
name: BUSI 3103
prereq_text: second-year standing and one of BUSI 2101, BUSI 2121, BUSI 2702, or PSYC 2801.
subject: BUSI
title: Introduction to Organization Theory

desc: Managing the performance of self and others. Topics include self awareness, motivation, leadership, communication, diversity, and creativity. Extensive use is made of self-assessments and experiential learning.
name: BUSI 3104
prereq_text: BUSI 2101, BUSI 2121, BUSI 2702, or PSYC 2801 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Managing Individual Performance

desc: Principles of working in and managing teams. Topics include self-awareness, team formation, team development, team dynamics, team leadership and team motivation.
name: BUSI 3105
prereq_text: BUSI 2101, BUSI 2121, BUSI 2702, or PSYC 2801 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Managing and Motivating Teams

desc: Analysis of the sources and forms of conflict and effective approaches to managing conflict. Exploration of the effectiveness of various strategies of negotiations.
name: BUSI 3106
prereq_text: BUSI 2101, BUSI 2121, BUSI 2702, or PSYC 2801 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Managing Conflict and Negotiation

desc: Increases student skills in areas beyond technical expertise, with a focus on the importance of fluidity, risk taking, and idea generation. Emphasis on creativity as a process, with exposure to various techniques and concepts including Design Thinking at multiple levels (individual, group, organization).
name: BUSI 3117
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2702 with a grade of C- or higher; or permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Developing Creative Thinking

desc: Examining concepts of environmental sustainability within the business context. Exploring the complex interdependency between organizations, society and the natural environment.
name: BUSI 3119
prereq_text: third year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Business and Environmental Sustainability

desc: Introduction and assessment of key new marketing tools and approaches, including internet marketing, relationship marketing, direct marketing; effective adoption and implementation of these tools and approaches across industries and organizations.
name: BUSI 3204
prereq_text: BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Digital Marketing

desc: Promotion as communication process and marketing tool. Integrating advertising, direct/digital marketing, interactive media, sales promotion, public relations, personal selling through strategic planning (research, budgeting, organizing, creative and media strategy), execution, and campaign evaluation. Regulatory, ethical, social issues considerations.
name: BUSI 3205
prereq_text: BUSI 2208 or BUSI 2204 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Marketing Communications

desc: Concepts essential for understanding and conducting applied marketing research. Methods for collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data relevant to marketing decision-making. Experience in research techniques through case studies, exercises and project.
name: BUSI 3207
prereq_text: BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C or higher; STAT 2607 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Marketing Research

desc: Theories and practice of marketing in business-to-business markets with emphasis on high technology businesses, including strategic marketing management, buyer behaviour and competitive analysis, sales management, new product management, and international issues.
name: BUSI 3208
prereq_text: BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Business-to-Business Marketing

desc: Introduction to the application of psychological theories and methodologies to consumer behaviour. How consumer behaviour is shaped by internal influences. Topics include perception, learning,memory, motivation, affect, personality, the self, attitudes and decision-making.
name: BUSI 3209
prereq_text: third-year standing, and BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Consumer Behaviour

desc: Introduction to strategies in managing supply chain. Topics include strategies for planning and coordinating of all activities involved in procurement, conversion, and channel management in the global environment.
name: BUSI 3301
prereq_text: second-year standing; BUSI 2301 with a grade of C or higher and STAT 2606 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Supply Chain Management Strategies

desc: Overview of logistics and transportation concepts, their roles in creating supply chain value; warehousing and facilities management, packaging and material handling, network design, transportation fundamentals, managing logistics internationally, global transportation providers and intermediaries, performance metrics, trends in logistics and transportation.
name: BUSI 3305
prereq_text: third-year standing; BUSI 2301 with a grade of C or higher, and STAT 2606 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Logistics and Transportation

desc: Concepts of computer simulation for predictive and prescriptive analytics through case studies, worked examples and hands-on projects. Emphasizes static simulations with spreadsheets, discrete-event, and agent-based simulations with specialized software. Input modeling, model design, experimental design, analysis of outputs.
name: BUSI 3308
prereq_text: third-year standing; BUSI 2301 with a grade of C or higher and STAT 2606 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Simulation Modeling and Analytics

desc: Identification, selection, initiation, and organization of projects; risk assessment; project scheduling, performance monitoring and control, and termination. Emphases on foundations, principles and supporting techniques.
name: BUSI 3309
prereq_text: third-year standing, BUSI 2301 and STAT 2606.
subject: BUSI
title: Project Management

desc: Information management, database administration, Entity-Relationship Model, database development life cycle: planning, analysis, design, implementation, and maintenance of database management systems. Construction of a database. Introduction to SQL, distributed databases, object-oriented databases, and data warehousing.
name: BUSI 3400
prereq_text: BUSI 2400 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Data and Information Management

desc: Analysis, design and implementation of electronic business systems. Topics include advanced object-oriented programming, advanced SQL programming, XML, using ASP.NET, MTS and SQL Server.
name: BUSI 3401
prereq_text: BUSI 2402 and BUSI 3400, or COMP 3005 (with a grade of C- or higher in each).
subject: BUSI
title: Applications Development for Online Environments

desc: Methods of analysis of computer-based information systems. The systems development life cycle, planning, analysis, design, implementation and maintenance. Structured and object-oriented methods will be used. Use of a CASE tool.
name: BUSI 3402
prereq_text: one of BUSI 2400, or COMP 2404, or SYSC 2004 (with a grade of C or higher).
subject: BUSI
title: Systems Analysis and Design

desc: Exploration of the significance of cross-functional business processes in the context of e-business transformation. Includes process analysis and modeling techniques. Also considers the application of enterprise resource planning systems, workflow technologies, intranets, and extranets to facilitate process flows inside and outside the organization.
name: BUSI 3405
prereq_text: BUSI 2400 and BUSI 3103 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Enterprise Architecture

desc: An examination of the major issues in corporate finance and applied financial management. Topics include: introduction to portfolio theory, the capital asset pricing model, cost of capital, capital structure and dividend policy, lease financing, capital budgeting under uncertainty, mergers and consolidations.
name: BUSI 3500
prereq_text: BUSI 2505 with a grade of C+ or higher, STAT 2606 and ECON 2009 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Applied Corporate Finance

desc: Procedures and methods of investment analysis. Stock and bond markets. Government regulation of securities markets. Valuation of common stocks and fixed income securities. Options, warrants, convertibles and commodities.
name: BUSI 3502
prereq_text: BUSI 2505 with a grade of C+ or higher, STAT 2606 and ECON 2009 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Investments

desc: Derivative instruments and their use for speculation and hedging. Analysis of different markets where instruments trade, and their characteristics. Pricing models highlighted to determine how individuals and corporations can better manage risk; exotics and newer innovations.
name: BUSI 3512
prereq_text: BUSI 2505 with a grade of C+ or higher, STAT 2606 and ECON 2009 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Derivatives

desc: Within the changing environment, an examination of entrepreneurial strategies related to different functional areas for new ventures and small businesses.
name: BUSI 3600
prereq_text: BUSI 2800 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Entrepreneurial Strategies

desc: Key models and theories of organizational strategy, structure, processes, effectiveness, and individual and group behavior in organizations. Organizational structure, goals, and effectiveness; leadership, motivation and job design.
name: BUSI 3602
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: BUSI
title: Designing Organizational Systems: An Overview

desc: How family businesses are different, what makes them different and how to effectively manage these differences. Challenges arising from the tension between family and business pressures from governance, management and succession planning perspectives.
name: BUSI 3611
prereq_text: BUSI 1005 or BUSI 1002, and BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2121 or BUSI 2702, and third year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Managing the Family Enterprise

desc: The role of governance in organizations. Mission and vision statements, values and objectives. Shaping, implementation and evaluation of corporate strategy. Management of risk and environmental analysis.
name: BUSI 3629
prereq_text: Enrolment in the Post-Baccalaureate Diploma in Accounting, or BUSI 1001 and BUSI 1002, or equivalents.
subject: BUSI
title: Corporate Governance and Strategy

desc: Principles of communication across cultural boundaries are applied to both interpersonal and commercial interactions. Critical incidents and commentary are analyzed. Students submit periodic reports, evaluated by the instructor at Carleton.
name: BUSI 3700
prereq_text: restricted to B.I.B. students who are participating in an academic exchange.
subject: BUSI
title: Cross-cultural Communication

desc: Students will engage in an approved international experience, abroad or within Canada, that fosters the development of a global mindset. This experience will allow students to integrate and apply the material learned in previous International Business courses.
name: BUSI 3701
prereq_text: Third-year standing in BIB and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Practicum in International Business I

desc: Students will engage in an approved international experience, abroad or within Canada, that fosters the development of a global mindset. This experience will allow students to integrate and apply the material learned in previous International Business courses.
name: BUSI 3702
prereq_text: third-year standing in BIB and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Practicum in International Business II

desc: The management of large organizations spanning national boundaries, including domestic firms with international markets, and multinational corporations. Difficulties of maintaining communication and control in international operations in disparate cultural settings.
name: BUSI 3703
prereq_text: second-year standing and BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2702 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: International and Comparative Management

desc: Theories linking environmental factors and business strategy as a basis for study of some major factors and institutions shaping international business strategy. International trade patterns, regionalization, shifts in international finance, research and development and transnational data flows.
name: BUSI 3704
prereq_text: third-year standing, and BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2702 with a grade of C or higher; and ECON 1001 and ECON 1002 (or ECON 1000) with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: The Environment of International Business

desc: Behaviour of end-consumers, business and government buyers, and investors in the international context. National, cross-national, and subnational segments and behaviour differences. Adaptation vs. standardisation strategies in the context of socio-psychological, legal, technological, international procurement rules, and other constraints and opportunities.
name: BUSI 3705
prereq_text: third-year standing, BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208, and BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3703.
subject: BUSI
title: International Buyer Behaviour

desc: Introduction to theory and practice of negotiation in the international business context. Analysis of techniques of conflict resolution and improving ways to reach agreements.
name: BUSI 3706
prereq_text: second-year standing and BUSI 2701 or BUSI 2702 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: International Business Negotiations

desc: Analysis, solution and presentation of complex business issues through cases.
name: BUSI 3800
prereq_text: minimum 7.0 Major CGPA in B.Com. or B.I.B. and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Case Analysis

desc: Business development, growth and expansion through financing activities and new customer acquisition.
name: BUSI 3810
prereq_text: BUSI 2800 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Development

desc: Students will apply entrepreneurial concepts and engage in designing an entrepreneurial project. Students will prepare in groups a business plan, including in-depth analysis and recommendations.
name: BUSI 3820
prereq_text: BUSI 2800 with a grade of C- or higher, and third-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Practicum in Business Design

desc: An advanced course in the knowledge and tools required for a career in Business.
name: BUSI 3995
prereq_text: BUSI 2995.
subject: BUSI
title: Employability Passport III

desc: This course covers the deliverables associated with the co-op work term such as the site visit, work term report submission and employer evaluation.
name: BUSI 3999
prereq_text: This course is for students on a university approved co-op work term.
subject: BUSI
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: An intensive review of federal income tax laws and regulations as significant elements in the planning and decision making process of taxable Canadian corporations. Emphasis on the tax planning function of corporate management and the associated accounting and reporting aspects.
name: BUSI 4005
prereq_text: BUSI 3005 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Taxation II

desc: Builds on concepts covered in management and cost accounting courses. Integrates relevant issues from other functional areas: strategic uses of cost management, budgeting, and performance evaluation systems in managerial planning and control.
name: BUSI 4008
prereq_text: BUSI 3008 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Advanced Management Accounting and Control

desc: Systems, strategies and practices used to effectively leverage human capital in organizations. How to think strategically about managing human assets, and what must be done to successfully implement these systems, strategies and practices.
name: BUSI 4104
prereq_text: BUSI 3102 and BUSI 3103 (with a grade of C- or higher in each).
subject: BUSI
title: Strategic Human Resources Management

desc: An overview of current thinking about change management. Topics covered include understanding the forces for and barriers to change, diagnosing the environment around change and implementing change.
name: BUSI 4105
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3602 or PSYC 2801 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Managing Change

desc: Contemporary training and development challenges facing individuals, organizations, and communities and the role of information technology in enhancing individual and collective skills development, capabilities, core competencies, intellectual capital and competitiveness.
name: BUSI 4108
prereq_text: BUSI 3103 or BUSI 3602 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Organizational Learning

desc: Emphasizes contingency approach to training and development; relevant to organizations of all sizes and resource capacities. Effective training and development is conceptualized as a process that integrates extensive front and back-end planning, implementation, and evaluation activities.
name: BUSI 4111
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2101 (or BUSI 2121 or BUSI 2702) with a grade of B- or higher and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Training and Development

desc: Critical examination of theories of leadership and trends in contemporary research; discussion of practical methods for building leadership capacity.
name: BUSI 4112
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3602 or PSYC 2801 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Organizational Leadership

desc: Increases student skills in areas beyond technical expertise, with a focus on the importance of fluidity, risk taking, and idea generation. Emphasis on creativity as a process, with exposure to various techniques and concepts including Design Thinking at multiple levels (individual, group, organization).
name: BUSI 4117
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of BUSI 2101 or BUSI 2702 with a grade of C- or higher and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Creative Thinking

desc: Challenges of managing arts organizations with emphasis on the changing environment of arts consumption and funding. Tensions arising from blending artistic and aesthetic dimensions with functional considerations when judging organizational and personal issues form a continuing theme.
name: BUSI 4129
prereq_text: third year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: Managing the Arts

desc: An overview of essential marketing metrics used for enhancing marketing decisions. The course consists of seven core modules: share metrics, margins and profits, pricing, product and portfolio management, sales force management, promotion profitability, and customer profitability.
name: BUSI 4201
prereq_text: BUSI 1005 and BUSI 2208.
subject: BUSI
title: Marketing Metrics

desc: Theories and practices of marketing in not-for-profit organizations including government. Similarities and differences between marketing in not-for-profit and for-profit organizations, and the key issues faced by marketers in developing marketing strategies in not-for-profit organizations.
name: BUSI 4203
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Marketing In Not-for-Profit Organizations

desc: The marketing function in international markets from a strategic and managerial perspective. Environments of foreign markets in relation to marketing research, international branding and positioning, and product, price, distribution, and communication strategies. International expansion methods and foreign market evaluation and selection.
name: BUSI 4205
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: International Marketing Strategy

desc: In depth analysis and applications of the managerial aspects of marketing. Marketing strategy development and implementation theory and practice.
name: BUSI 4208
prereq_text: third year standing, BUSI 2208 and one of BUSI 3205 or BUSI 3207 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Marketing Management

desc: Consumer behaviour from a macro and interpretive approach, as a social and cultural phenomenon; the relationships between consumers, the marketplace and cultural meaning.
name: BUSI 4209
prereq_text: third year standing and BUSI 3209 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Consumer Culture Theory

desc: Advanced study of marketing within the arts and culture sectors. Facilitates sophisticated understanding of the knowledge and skills required for marketing managers to respond to changing market environments in order to bring arts and culture offerings to their target audiences.
name: BUSI 4229
prereq_text: third year standing and BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Marketing in the Arts and Culture Sectors

desc: Management science models and methods in business analytics for decision-making with less risk and better outcomes. Emphases on practical applications. Data integration; model formulation, implementation, and solutions, and managerial insights. Applications development and deployment.
name: BUSI 4301
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2301 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Decision Models and Analytics

desc: Quality concepts and methods surrounding the definition, mapping, implementation, improvement of business processes in organizations and global supply chains.
name: BUSI 4302
prereq_text: third-year standing, BUSI 2301 with a grade of C or higher and STAT 2606 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Management of Quality

desc: Core supply chain procurement processes in the private and public sectors involved in the acquisition of goods and services, including sourcing, purchasing, contracting, supplier collaboration and relationship development and management. Emphasis on concepts, principles, practices, and techniques.
name: BUSI 4304
prereq_text: third-year standing; BUSI 2301 with a C grade or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Procurement and Contracting

desc: Acquire hands-on skills to design and develop innovative business models and Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems on top of big real-world data aiming to create value and solve problems that would enhance the performance of e-supply chains along its multiple dimensions.
name: BUSI 4331
prereq_text: third year standing and BUSI 2301 and BUSI 2402 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Artificial Intelligence and E-Supply Chain Technologies

desc: Comprehensive treatment of current trends and management issues associated with information systems within organizations of local, national and international scope. Issues and techniques of information systems planning, administration, resource management and new technology adoption. Case studies are used.
name: BUSI 4400
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, BUSI 2400 and BUSI 3103 (or BUSI 3602) with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: IS Strategy, Management and Acquisition

desc: Challenges and issues managers face in assembling the infrastructure for IT service delivery. IT Service levels, data communications, networks (LAN, MAN, WAN, wireless), internetworking, SOA, web services, SaaS, server and storage virtualization, network security, business continuity and disaster recovery.
name: BUSI 4404
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2400 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: IT Infrastructure

desc: Evolution of decision support systems. Business intelligence. Data mining and warehousing. Web analytics. Mobile apps for business analytics. Strategic use of information systems for competitive advantage.
name: BUSI 4406
prereq_text: third-year standing and BUSI 2400 with a grade of C or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Analytics

desc: Covers the process, tool and techniques necessary to acquire, clean and analyze text that has been generated on social platforms. Social network analysis, sentiment analysis, topic extraction, co-occurrence analysis.
name: BUSI 4408
prereq_text: BUSI 2400, BUSI 2208, STAT 2607, 3rd year standing. Restricted to students enrolled in B.Com, BIB, and the B.Econ Economic Data Science Concentration.
subject: BUSI
title: Social Analytics

desc: An in-depth examination of some of the major theoretical issues in corporate finance. This course requires analyses and presentations of both articles from the finance literature and case studies.
name: BUSI 4500
prereq_text: fourth-year standing; and BUSI 3500, BUSI 3502, BUSI 3512 with a grade of C-or higher in each and STAT 2607 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Advanced Corporate Finance

desc: Analysis of investment requirements for individuals and institutional investors: liquidity, risk and return; portfolio design, construction, management and control; performance measurement; capital market theory.
name: BUSI 4502
prereq_text: fourth-year standing; and BUSI 3500, BUSI 3502 and BUSI 3512 with a grade of C- or higher in each and STAT 2607 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Portfolio Management

desc: Participants of the Sprott Student Investment Fund will be exposed to equity research, analysis, valuation, and portfolio composition. The course allows fund members to fully understand stock selection and fund management, and expose them to the methods and techniques used by industry.
name: BUSI 4503
prereq_text: BUSI 3502 and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Applied Portfolio Management

desc: Management of corporate finance as it is affected by the requirements of international business. Issues related to international acquisitions, global investments, volatile exchange rates and hedging techniques. Role of international markets in financing corporate activity.
name: BUSI 4504
prereq_text: BUSI 2505 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: International Finance

desc: Comprehensive view of the world's financial markets and institutions. The primary focus will be on the purpose and practice of financial institutions, and the specifics of the financial instruments available to the firm and investor.
name: BUSI 4505
prereq_text: BUSI 2505 with a grade of C+ or higher, STAT 2606 and ECON 2009 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Global Financial Markets and Institutions

desc: The theory and practice of mergers and acquisitions; the best ways to analyze, design and implement mergers and acquisitions transactions. A highly practical planning-based approach to managing the acquisition process will be employed.
name: BUSI 4510
prereq_text: BUSI 3500 and BUSI 3502 with a grade of C- or higher in each, and STAT 2607 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Mergers and Acquisitions

desc: Valuation of fixed income securities and interest rate derivatives including bonds, mortgage- and asset-based securities. Analytic tools used in bond portfolio and interest rate risk management including yield curve construction, duration and convexity, and term structure models.
name: BUSI 4511
prereq_text: BUSI 3502, BUSI 3512 with a grade of C- or higher in each, and STAT 2607 with a grade of C- or higher.
subject: BUSI
title: Fixed Income Analysis

desc: Theory and practice of microfinance, its achievements and current challenges; basic skills needed to manage microfinance institutions. The future of microfinance and of financing for development in general. A mix of cases and lectures will be used.
name: BUSI 4515
prereq_text: BUSI 2505 with a grade of C+ or higher, STAT 2606 and ECON 2009 with a grade of C- or higher in each, fourth year standing and enrollment in the Global Financial Management and Systems concentration in the BIB.
subject: BUSI
title: Micro Finance

desc: Use of ethical reasoning to analyze business decisions. The ethical content of these decisions. The role of ethics in business situations. Practice in ethical reasoning. Major ethical systems.
name: BUSI 4601
prereq_text: fourth-year standing B.Com. Note that B.Com. concentration in International Business students require BUSI 4705.
subject: BUSI
title: Business Ethics

desc: Integration of technology and strategy; design of technological strategy; development of new business around new technology; and management of corporate research and development, including pre-competitive consortia.
name: BUSI 4607
prereq_text: third-year standing, and BUSI 2204 or BUSI 2208, and BUSI 3103 with a grade of C- or higher in each.
subject: BUSI
title: Management of Technology and Innovation

desc: The place of business in Canadian society, economics and politics. The internal dynamics of Canadian business (organization, strategy, the rise of the manager), and its external implications (competition, foreign investment, business- government relations).
name: BUSI 4608
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Com. or B.I.B.
subject: BUSI
title: Canadian Business History

desc: Analysis and evaluation of the organization's corporate and business strategies; integration and synthesis of knowledge acquired in the program by application of acquired functional skills to strategic decision making.
name: BUSI 4609
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in all B.Com. and successful completion of all 2000- and 3000- level courses in the Major requirement. Note that B.Com. concentration in International Business students require BUSI 4709.
subject: BUSI
title: Strategic Management

desc: The economic, political, legal, and cultural environment for doing business in the European Union and other regions in Europe. Patterns of foreign trade and investment, market characteristics, science and technology, regulation and European integration, and business culture.
name: BUSI 4704
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: The Business Environment in Europe

desc: Perceptions and behaviors that characterize interactions among individuals from various cultural backgrounds, with emphasis on ethical issues that may arise when business crosses cultural boundaries. Various systems, both organizational and individual, for dealing with contrasting expectations are discussed.
name: BUSI 4705
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B. Com. (International Business Concentration) or B.I.B., and BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3703.
subject: BUSI
title: Ethics and Cross-cultural Interaction

desc: Theoretical and process issues in the recruitment, selection, training, evaluation and repatriation of personnel in multi-country organizations. Issues are examined from the perspective of organizations, expatriates and local employees of multinational firms.
name: BUSI 4706
prereq_text: third-year standing, BUSI 3102, and one of BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3703.
subject: BUSI
title: International Human Resource Management

desc: Trends in globalization versus supra- and sub-national regionalism. Role of international institutions (e.g. OECD, WTO). Strategy adaptation and integration within and across trade blocs (e.g. NAFTA, EU, Mercosur, ASEAN). Strategies for sub-national markets with similarities across different countries.
name: BUSI 4707
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.Com., B.I.B., or Minor in Business, and BUSI 2701 or BUSI 2702.
subject: BUSI
title: Regionalism and Globalization

desc: Internationalization process. Methods of international expansion including exporting, greenfield investment, acquisition, joint venture, and licensing. Theories of international market selection, investment location, and market service.
name: BUSI 4708
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, and BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3703.
subject: BUSI
title: International Expansion and Operations

desc: Development and implementation of strategies within and across international markets. Emphasis on developing strategic perspectives that incorporate the environment, the state of the industry,and the capabilities of the firm. Integrates skills, concepts and theories learned in functional areas.
name: BUSI 4709
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Com. (International Business Concentration) or B.I.B., and successful completion of all 2000- and 3000-level courses in the Major requirement.
subject: BUSI
title: Strategic Management for International Business

desc: Challenges facing entrepreneurs in the creation and growth of competitive knowledge-based new international ventures or ‘born globals’. Identification of opportunities abroad, strategies and logistics, sourcing, international deal making and business models.
name: BUSI 4710
prereq_text: BUSI 2702 or BUSI 3703, and third-year standing.
subject: BUSI
title: International New Ventures

desc: Critical examination of the managerial and institutional issues of globalization from the perspectives of emerging economies. Indigenous and international institutions' role in the evolution of a competitive and inclusive global economy and society. Discerning lessons of experience for newly globalizing societies.
name: BUSI 4717
prereq_text: fourth year standing in B.Com, BIB, or Minor in Business, ECON 1001 and ECON 1002 (or ECON 1000).
subject: BUSI
title: Managing Globalization in Emerging Economies

desc: Students will engage in an approved international experience, abroad or within Canada (can include SSCG), that fosters the development of a global mindset. This experience will allow students to integrate and apply the material learned in previous International Business courses.
name: BUSI 4719
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.Com. International Business concentration and permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Practicum in International Business

desc: An experiential work environment in which students interact with real clients as a consultant. Various types of projects are possible depending on the company and their goals/needs. Companies may be internal (i.e. Carleton, Sprott), or external (i.e. not for profit, for profit, start-ups, entrepreneurs).
name: BUSI 4800
prereq_text: Permission of the Sprott School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Sprott Student Consulting II

desc: Students apply concepts and engage in groups to implement the design of an entrepreneurship project per their business plan developed in BUSI 3820. The projects provide opportunities for experiential learning.
name: BUSI 4810
prereq_text: BUSI 3820.
subject: BUSI
title: Practicum in Business Creation

desc: A selected topics course may be offered. Topics may vary. Consult the School’s website for available topics and prerequisite information. Eligibility for this course to serve as an option for specific concentrations is to be established by the School.
name: BUSI 4901
prereq_text: Vary based on section. Please refer to sprott.carleton.ca/registration for section specific prerequisites.
subject: BUSI
title: Topics in Business I

desc: A selected topics course may be offered. Topics may vary. Consult the School’s website for available topics and prerequisite information. Eligibility for this course to serve as an option for specific concentrations is to be established by the School.
name: BUSI 4902
prereq_text: Vary based on section. Please refer to sprott.carleton.ca/registration for section specific prerequisites.
subject: BUSI
title: Topics in Business II

desc: Reading course on select topics. Students interested in pursuing this course need to contact a faculty member to discuss a proposed directed study.
name: BUSI 4904
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Com. or B.I.B. and permission of the School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Directed Studies I

desc: Reading course on select topics. Students interested in pursuing this course need to contact a faculty member to discuss a proposed directed study.
name: BUSI 4905
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Com. or B.I.B. and permission of the School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Directed Studies II

desc: Provides students with opportunity to conduct research in their area of interest and present the research in an undergraduate thesis format. Conducted under the supervision of a faculty advisor from Sprott, with the specific deliverable determined by Supervisor and student, and approved by Sprott School.
name: BUSI 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Com. or B.I.B. and permission of the School of Business.
subject: BUSI
title: Research Project for Business

desc: An advanced course in the knowledge and tools required for a career in Business.
name: BUSI 4995
prereq_text: BUSI 3995.
subject: BUSI
title: Employability Passport IV

desc: Introduction to interdisciplinary Canadian Studies and diversity's role in defining Canada. Examination of the relationship between national identity and values in an evolving Canada. Topics include: Indigenous peoples, language and ethnicity, race, technology, gender, the arts, and international relations.
name: CDNS 1000
prereq_text: None
subject: CDNS
title: Introduction to Canadian Studies

desc: Introduction to interdisciplinary Canadian Studies and approaches to the critical study of Canada.
name: CDNS 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: CDNS
title: Studying Canada

desc: Examination of various themes and issues that affect Canadians and Canadian society. Topics may include Indigenous peoples, literature, language and ethnicity, race, gender, culture and cultural producers, the environment, and international relations.
name: CDNS 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: CDNS
title: Themes in the Study of Canada

desc: An interdisciplinary examination of Ottawa, looking at its history, evolution, and role as Canada's capital. This course investigates various national institutions related to public policy, governance, history, culture and the arts. Field trips and topics vary from year to year.
name: CDNS 1101
prereq_text: None
subject: CDNS
title: Ottawa: Exploring National Institutions

desc: Introductory examination of interdisciplinary themes, ideas, and debates related to Canada and its place in the world. Topics vary from year to year.
name: CDNS 1102
prereq_text: None
subject: CDNS
title: Introduction to Canada and the World

desc: An in-depth examination of key debates that have shaped the nature of Canada, focusing on major thinkers and the debates their ideas produced. Topics vary annually.
name: CDNS 2000
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Debating Canada

desc: The challenges of constructing a national culture in Canada. Topics may include: colonialism and its cultural legacies, cultural nationalism, cultural policies and institutions, popular culture, technology, regionalism, fears of Americanization, gender, multiculturalism, globalization and cultural hybridity.
name: CDNS 2210
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Introduction to the Study of Canadian Culture

desc: This course questions whether a national identity is possible or even desirable within an increasingly diverse and complex Canada. Examination of the construction of Canadian identities, competing nationalisms within Canadian borders and critical evaluation of the role of nationalism.
name: CDNS 2300
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Critical Nationalism

desc: Approaches to heritage conservation. Topics include built heritage, movable heritage, collections and museums, and intangible heritage. Heritage as a source of memory and identity in Canadian and Aboriginal life.
name: CDNS 2400
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Heritage Conservation in Canada

desc: This course surveys geographical, historical, demographic, cultural, political and social developments in Québec, relations with English Canada and debates on identity and nationalism. Also available in French as CDNS 2511/FINS 2511.
name: CDNS 2510
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Introduction to Québec Society (English version)

desc: Ce cours permettra de découvrir et d'analyser des référents dominants de la trame historique du Québec de même que les débats entourant l'identité et le nationalisme et les relations avec le Canada anglais.
name: CDNS 2511
prereq_text: niveau de deuxième année ou permission de L'École d'études canadiennes.
subject: CDNS
title: Introduction à la société et à la culture québécoises (version française)

desc: What does it mean to sell a country the same way one sells coffee? This course examines the rise of nation-branding in Canada. It discusses the ways governments brand Canada internationally and domestically and the ways corporations brand themselves as "Canadian" to customers.
name: CDNS 2600
prereq_text: None
subject: CDNS
title: Branding Canada

desc: Investigates the theory and methods used in qualitative approaches to research, offering hands-on experience and discussion of the underlying beliefs and claims implicit in scholarly work. Examines the ethical and practical dilemmas confronting researchers and develops student skills in gathering, interpreting, and presenting knowledge.
name: CDNS 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing in Canadian Studies or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Producing Knowledge

desc: Interdisciplinary examination of feminism's impact on Canadian history, culture and politics, and Canadian approaches to feminism in a global context. Surveys the role of feminist thinkers, activists and organizations in shaping Canadian society.
name: CDNS 3400
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Feminists and Feminism in Canada

desc: Exploration of intercultural encounters between French and English Canadians in political, popular and “official” cultures, through an examination of media, art, music, literature, cinema and the built environment.
name: CDNS 3550
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Interfaces between English and French Canadian Cultures

desc: Interdisciplinary study of questions related to identity, belonging, and Canadianness. Intersections of individual and group dimensions of "being Canadian" and state efforts to define the Canadian identity. Topics may include: religion, sexuality, immigrant and diasporic relations, race and ethnicity, region, nationalisms, and multiculturalism.
name: CDNS 3600
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Cultural Politics and Identities in Canada

desc: An examination of the political economy tradition in Canada, looking at explanations of Canada's political, economic, social and cultural development, and Canada's evolving position in the global economy.
name: CDNS 3610
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: The Canadian Political Economy Tradition

desc: Comparative, interdisciplinary examination of Canada and the United States, including the evolution of the Canada-US relationship. Historical, sociological, cultural, and political approaches are used. Topics covered may include the economy, defence, foreign policy, diplomacy, borderlands, Indigenous peoples, and culture.
name: CDNS 3620
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Canada-US Relations

desc: Aspects of cultural heritage, folklore and/or cultural traditions in Canadian folk art, music, dance, story-telling and performance. The genesis of these various expressions, and the cultural contexts that have ensured their survival.
name: CDNS 3700
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Cultural Traditions in Canada

desc: Topics vary from year to year.
name: CDNS 3901
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Selected Topics in Canadian Studies

desc: Emphasis on refining analytic and research skills, including teamwork skills and using knowledge to solve problems outside the university. Students will engage in a collective research project in partnership with a local, national or international organization.
name: CDNS 4000
prereq_text: CDNS 3000 and fourth-year standing in Canadian Studies or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Capstone Seminar in Advanced Research in Canadian Studies

desc: The relationship between language use and political, economic, and cultural power in Canada. Topics may include cultural and linguistic pluralism, bilingualism, Aboriginal language revitalization, discourses of endangerment, the role of media and the state and in legitimizing language use.
name: CDNS 4010
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Language, Culture, and Power in Canada

desc: An interdisciplinary seminar using cultural studies methods to explore how popular cultural texts, images, rituals and practices are constructed, disseminated, regulated, consumed and reappropriated by Canadian institutions, corporations, cultural groups and individuals.
name: CDNS 4200
prereq_text: fourth-year honours standing, or permission of the School.
subject: CDNS
title: Canadian Popular Culture

desc: Exploration of the relationship between space, culture, and identities in Canada. Analysis of concepts, practices and conflicts which may include: urban/rural space, the suburbs, regionalism, gender and space, public/private space, national spaces, borderlands, indigenous territories, cultural survival, collective identity, and memory.
name: CDNS 4300
prereq_text: fourth-year honours standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Contested Spaces and Communities

desc: Cultural landscape appreciation and the development of Canadian individual and collective cultural identities, through the lenses of history, geography, planning, and representational/literary sources of expression. Cultural landscapes as a tool for understanding physical and mental landscapes and their shaping of identity.
name: CDNS 4400
prereq_text: fourth-year honours standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Cultural Landscape and Cultural Identity in Canada

desc: Exploration of the recent shift in heritage conservation discourse that embraces objectives of environmental, social, and economic sustainability. Investigation of synergies and gaps between natural and cultural conservation ideas. Introduction to theory, principles and practices through analysis of Canadian and international research, policy and projects.
name: CDNS 4403
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Heritage Conservation and Sustainability

desc: Interdisciplinary examination of Canada's role in the global political economy and its impact on issues such as work, community, public services, and the state.
name: CDNS 4500
prereq_text: fourth-year honours standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Canada and the World

desc: Advanced seminar focusing on selected aspects of Québec history, society, culture and/or politics.
name: CDNS 4510
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Québec Studies

desc: Practicum placements are available in institutional settings, primarily in the Ottawa area. Students must meet regularly with the academic evaluator and submit a final written report. A maximum of 1.0 practicum credits may be taken in fulfillment of Canadian Studies requirements.
name: CDNS 4800
prereq_text: permission of the School and fourth-year Honours standing in a Indigenous and Canadian Studies program.
subject: CDNS
title: Internship Practicum

desc: Practicum placements are available in institutional settings, primarily in the Ottawa area. Students must meet regularly with the academic evaluator and submit a final written report. A maximum of 1.0 practicum credits may be taken in fulfillment of Canadian Studies requirements.
name: CDNS 4801
prereq_text: permission of the School and fourth-year Honours standing in a Indigenous and Canadian Studies program.
subject: CDNS
title: Internship/Practicum

desc: Practicum placements are available in institutional settings, primarily in the Ottawa area. Students must meet regularly with the academic evaluator and submit a final written report. A maximum of 1.0 practicum credits may be taken in fulfillment of Canadian Studies requirements.
name: CDNS 4802
prereq_text: permission of the School and fourth year Honours standing in an Indigenous and Canadian Studies program.
subject: CDNS
title: Internship/Practicum

desc: Topics vary from year to year.
name: CDNS 4901
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Selected Topics in Canadian Studies

desc: Topics vary from year to year.
name: CDNS 4902
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Selected Topics in Canadian Studies
