desc: Cours facultatif offert seulement aux étudiants de quatrième année Honours en Études canadiennes (Mention : Français). Ce cours comprend des lectures dirigées et des travaux écrits dans un domaine relié aux Études canadiennes.
name: CDNS 4903
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Études dirigées I

desc: Cours facultatif offert seulement aux étudiants de quatrième année Honours en Études canadiennes (Mention : Français). Ce cours comprend des lectures dirigées et des travaux écrits dans un domaine relié aux Études canadiennes.
name: CDNS 4904
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: CDNS
title: Études dirigées II

desc: An optional course normally restricted to fourth-year Honours students in Canadian Studies and to Qualifying-year Graduate students. Includes supervised reading and written work in a Canadian Studies area.
name: CDNS 4905
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Directed Studies I

desc: An optional course normally restricted to fourth-year Honours students in Canadian Studies and to Qualifying-year graduate students. Includes supervised reading and written work in a Canadian Studies area.
name: CDNS 4906
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Directed Studies II

desc: An optional course normally restricted to fourth-year Honours students in Canadian Studies and to Qualifying-year graduate students. Includes supervised reading and written work in a Canadian Studies area.
name: CDNS 4907
prereq_text: permission of the School of Indigenous and Canadian Studies.
subject: CDNS
title: Directed Studies III

desc: Selected topics in academic discourse. Topics vary from year to year, and/or section to section, as determined by the Centre for Initiatives in Education.
name: CIED 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: CIED
title: Selected Topics in Academic Discourse

desc: The development of academic writing, reading, research and analytical skills through the examination of selected topics in the instructor’s field of expertise.
name: CIED 1200
prereq_text: restricted to returning students in the Enriched Support Program/Indigenous Enriched Support Program.
subject: CIED
title: Special Topics Seminar

desc: Inquiry into the theoretical nature of academic language, with emphasis on the social nature of academic writing. Incorporates practical strategies for understanding and enhancing growth in writing.
name: CIED 2100
prereq_text: restricted to returning students in the Enriched Support Program.
subject: CIED
title: Academic Discourse: Theory and Practice

desc: This maths-intensive course covers introduction to periodicity, gas laws, equilibrium, bonding, electrochemistry, and organic chemistry. This is a specialist course for students intending to take second year chemistry.
name: CHEM 1001
prereq_text: Ontario 4U/M in Chemistry or equivalent.
subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry I

desc: This maths-intensive course covers an introduction to solution chemistry, acids and bases, thermodynamics, and kinetics. Specialist course for students intending to take second year chemistry.
name: CHEM 1002
prereq_text: CHEM 1005 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1001.
subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry II

desc: Aspects of chemistry relating to food, food additives, drugs (illicit and beneficial) and their relation to metabolism and health. Topics may include: proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, cofactors, enzymes, steroids, electrolyte and pH balance, trace elements. Available only as a free option for Science students.
name: CHEM 1003
prereq_text: a course in Chemistry (e.g. Ontario Grade 11).
subject: CHEM
title: The Chemistry of Food, Health and Drugs

desc: No science background required. Topics include drug origins, laws, metabolism and dependence, pharmaceutical industry, over the counter medications, placebo effect, antibiotics, pain killers, stimulants, alcohol, marijuana, hallucinogens, birth control and steroids. Students in Science programs may use this course only as a free elective.
name: CHEM 1004
prereq_text: None
subject: CHEM
title: Drugs and the Human Body

desc: Introduction to stoichiometry, periodicity, gas laws, equilibrium, bonding, and organic chemistry with emphasis on examples of relevance to the life sciences. For students who lack the prerequisite for CHEM 1001 or who are not intending to take upper year chemistry.
name: CHEM 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: CHEM
title: Elementary Chemistry I

desc: Introduction to solution chemistry, acids and bases, thermodynamics, and kinetics, with emphasis on examples of relevance to the life sciences. For students who lack the prerequisite for CHEM 1002 or who are not intending to take upper year chemistry.
name: CHEM 1006
prereq_text: CHEM 1001 or CHEM 1005.
subject: CHEM
title: Elementary Chemistry II

desc: The chemistry of arts and artifacts created throughout the ages (Paleolithic, Neolithic, Bronze, Iron, Middle and Modern) will be examined. Basic chemical principles will be explored and reviewed when required. Students in Science programs may use this course only as a free elective.
name: CHEM 1007
prereq_text: None
subject: CHEM
title: Chemistry of Art and Artifacts

desc: Topics include stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, thermodynamics and chemical equilibrium, acid-base chemistry, carbon dioxide in water, alkalinity, precipitation, electrochemistry, kinetics and basic organic chemistry. Laboratory component emphasizes techniques and methods of basic experimental chemistry.
name: CHEM 1101
prereq_text: Ontario 4U/M in Chemistry or equivalent.
subject: CHEM
title: Chemistry for Engineering Students

desc: Basic principles of thermodynamics. Development of the laws of thermodynamics, enthalpy, entropy and free energy, and their applications to phase equilibria, electrochemistry, and kinetics. Brief introduction to quantum mechanics.
name: CHEM 2103
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1002, MATH 1004, MATH 1107, PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004.
subject: CHEM
title: Physical Chemistry I

desc: Structure, organization, and scope of organic chemistry including molecular structures of well-known and important organic chemicals, types of chemical reactions, and spectroscopic methods used in identification. Training in the handling and purification of organic compounds, organic chemical reactions, and the use of infrared spectroscopy.
name: CHEM 2203
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1002.
subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry I

desc: Further discussion of chemical bonding in organic compounds, nomenclature, stereochemistry, and a systematic coverage of the chemical reactions of organic functional groups. Laboratory experience in organic chemical reactions, use of infrared spectroscopy and other techniques to determine the structure of unknown organic compounds.
name: CHEM 2204
prereq_text: CHEM 2203.
subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry II

desc: Structure, organization, and scope of organic chemistry, including molecular structures of well-known and important organic chemicals, types of chemical reactions, and spectroscopic methods used in identification.
name: CHEM 2207
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1002.
subject: CHEM
title: Introduction to Organic Chemistry I

desc: Further discussion of the chemical bonding in organic compounds, nomenclature, stereochemistry, and a systematic coverage of chemical reactions of the organic functional groups.
name: CHEM 2208
prereq_text: CHEM 2207 or CHEM 2203.
subject: CHEM
title: Introduction to Organic Chemistry II

desc: Introduction to quality assurance measures, calibration strategies and the fundamentals of solution-based analytical measurement processes. Qualitative and quantitative analysis using potentiometric and electrolysis techniques including ion selective electrodes, coulometry, amperometry and voltammetry. Redox, acid/base and EDTA titrations in the context of various buffer systems.
name: CHEM 2302
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1101 and (MATH 1007 or MATH 1004).
subject: CHEM
title: Analytical Chemistry I

desc: Spectrophotometric analysis using Uv-Vis, fluorescence and FTIR instrumentation. Modern separation methods including CE, GC and LC. Recent techniques and applications using mass spectrometry. Applications of all of the above to real-world analysis including the advancement of environmental, biochemistry and health-related research.
name: CHEM 2303
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1002, or CHEM 1101, and (MATH 1007 or MATH 1004).
subject: CHEM
title: Analytical Chemistry II

desc: Students carry out a laboratory research project under the supervision of a faculty member from the Department of Chemistry. A research report must be submitted by the last day of classes for evaluation by the Chair and Faculty supervisor.
name: CHEM 2400
prereq_text: restricted to Honours students having second-year standing in a Chemistry program with an overall CGPA of 10.0 or higher, and approval of the Chair and a Faculty supervisor.
subject: CHEM
title: Independent Research I

desc: The basic concepts of inorganic chemistry, including the origins of elemental properties, simple theories of bonding, intermolecular forces, main group and transition metal chemistry, coordination chemistry. Inorganic ions in biochemistry, including ion transport and storage, oxygen carriers and hydrolases, redox proteins.
name: CHEM 2501
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B-, or CHEM 1002.
subject: CHEM
title: Introduction to Inorganic and Bioinorganic Chemistry

desc: A basis of chemistry needed to understand the environment: composition of the atmosphere and natural waters; equilibrium; surface properties; kinetics and spectroscopy; physical and chemical properties of chemicals in the environment. Limited enrolment course. Priority is given to students in Environmental Science/Engineering.
name: CHEM 2800
prereq_text: CHEM 1006 with a minimum grade of B- or CHEM 1002, or CHEM 1101, (MATH 1007 or MATH 1004).
subject: CHEM
title: Foundations for Environmental Chemistry

desc: Further development of thermodynamic equations and their applications to mass changes, chemical potential, chemical equilibria, transport properties and advanced phase equilibria. Use of partial differentials and development of Maxwell's relations will also be covered.
name: CHEM 3100
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 or BIOC 2300, and MATH 1005 or MATH 2007.
subject: CHEM
title: Physical Chemistry II

desc: Classical equations of motion, harmonic oscillator, diatomic and polyatomic molecules, molecular mechanics, quantum mechanics, Schrödinger equation and wave functions, vibrational spectra, hydrogen atom, quantum numbers, electronic spectra, bonding in small molecules.
name: CHEM 3101
prereq_text: CHEM 2103, MATH 2007 and MATH 2008.
subject: CHEM
title: Quantum Chemistry

desc: Molecular orbital theory of organic and inorganic chemistry. Applications of computational chemistry to chemical bonding, aromaticity, molecular spectra. Semi-empirical and ab initio electronic structure theory. Comparison of theoretical methods used to obtain molecular properties. Introduction to statistical thermodynamics.
name: CHEM 3102
prereq_text: CHEM 3101 or PHYS 3701.
subject: CHEM
title: Methods of Computational Chemistry

desc: Industry-standard quantum chemistry software is used for Hartree-Fock, density functional, and post Hartree-Fock correlation calculations. Results are applied to problems in molecular structure, thermodynamics, vibrational spectroscopy, and kinetics. The UNIX operating system, Bourne-shell programming, and Python scripting are also introduced.
name: CHEM 3106
prereq_text: CHEM 3102 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: CHEM
title: Computational Chemistry Methods Laboratory

desc: Thin film production and characterization, scanning electron microscopy, synthesis of metal nanoparticles and particle size determination, computational modeling of nanostructures.
name: CHEM 3107
prereq_text: CHEM 3100.
subject: CHEM
title: Experimental Methods in Nanoscience

desc: Instrumental methods for determining organic structures. Selected organic reactions with emphasis on mechanisms and reactive intermediates.
name: CHEM 3201
prereq_text: CHEM 2204 or CHEM 2206 or CHEM 2208.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Organic Chemistry I

desc: Continued mechanistic survey of additional organic reactions with emphasis on synthetic usefulness and stereochemistry. Interspersed with selected topics such as instrumental methods, photochemistry, literature of organic chemistry, natural and synthetic polymers, heterocycles, terpenes and alkaloids.
name: CHEM 3202
prereq_text: CHEM 3201 or equivalent.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Organic Chemistry II

desc: A laboratory-based course including advanced concepts and techniques in organic synthesis, structure determination, and the rates and mechanisms of reactions. Students are responsible for literature surveys, acquisition of theoretical background, and design of experimental procedures.
name: CHEM 3205
prereq_text: CHEM 2204 or CHEM 2206 and CHEM 3201.
subject: CHEM
title: Experimental Organic Chemistry

desc: Advanced instrumentally based techniques of analysis. Emphasis on identification and quantitation of low-level contaminants in environmental matrices using chromatographic and spectroscopic methods, including sampling, cleanup, measurement and reporting of results.
name: CHEM 3305
prereq_text: CHEM 2302 or CHEM 2303.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Analytical Chemistry Laboratory

desc: Students carry out a laboratory research project supervised by a Chemistry faculty member. A research report must be submitted by the last day of classes for evaluation by the Chair and Faculty supervisor; expectations of student performance and evaluation exceed that of CHEM 2400.
name: CHEM 3400
prereq_text: restricted to Honours students having third-year standing in a Chemistry program with an overall CGPA of 10.0 or higher, and approval of the Chair and a Faculty supervisor.
subject: CHEM
title: Independent Research II

desc: Chemistry, structure and function of nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids. Thermodynamics of biological systems, chemical mechanisms and organic transformations. Intended for Chemistry Majors.
name: CHEM 3401
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 and CHEM 2204.
subject: CHEM
title: Physical Aspects of Biochemistry

desc: Symmetry, identification of Raman and infrared active vibrations, symmetry-adapted molecular orbital theory of polyatomic molecules, electron deficient bonding, bonding in coordination complexes, solid state bonding, ionic lattices. Laboratory will introduce the student to a range of synthetic techniques and physical methods of characterization.
name: CHEM 3503
prereq_text: CHEM 2501.
subject: CHEM
title: Inorganic Chemistry I

desc: Physical properties of coordination complexes, ligand substitutions and electron transfer reaction mechanisms, organometallic chemistry: bonding, nomenclature and catalysis. Laboratory will introduce the student to a range of synthetic techniques and physical methods of characterization.
name: CHEM 3504
prereq_text: CHEM 3503.
subject: CHEM
title: Inorganic Chemistry II

desc: Symmetry, identification of Raman and infrared active vibrations, symmetry-adapted molecular orbital theory of polyatomic molecules, electron deficient bonding, bonding in coordination complexes, solid state bonding, ionic lattices.
name: CHEM 3507
prereq_text: CHEM 2501.
subject: CHEM
title: General Inorganic Chemistry I

desc: Physical properties of coordination complexes, ligand substitutions and electron transfer reaction mechanisms, organometallic chemistry: bonding, nomenclature and catalysis.
name: CHEM 3508
prereq_text: CHEM 3503 or CHEM 3507.
subject: CHEM
title: General Inorganic Chemistry II

desc: Nanoscale units, bulk vs. nanoproperties, electrons, atoms and ions, metals, band structure, electrical conduction, biosystems, molecular devices, quantum mechanics and optics, tools for measuring nanostructures. Production of nanostructures: self assembly, nanoscale crystal growth, polymerization. Applications to sensors, magnets, electronics, drug delivery. Toxicology of nanostructures.
name: CHEM 3600
prereq_text: CHEM 3100.
subject: CHEM
title: Introduction to Nanotechnology

desc: Uses of chemistry in a number of industries: fertilizers, electrochemical, metallurgical, petrochemical, pulp and paper, plastics, pharmaceutical. Interaction of chemistry with economic, political, engineering, environmental, health, legal considerations. Guest lecturers.
name: CHEM 3700
prereq_text: (BIOC 2300 or CHEM 2103) and one of CHEM 2207 or CHEM 2203.
subject: CHEM
title: Industrial Applications of Chemistry

desc: Inorganic and organic environmental pollutants: their toxicology, production, use pattern and known effects on the environment. Aspects of risk and regulation. Chemistry involved in water and sewage treatment.
name: CHEM 3800
prereq_text: CHEM 2207 or CHEM 2203 or CHEM 2800.
subject: CHEM
title: The Chemistry of Environmental Pollutants

name: CHEM 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: CHEM
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Principles of Group Theory as applied to Chemistry. Point groups, character tables, symmetry orbitals, molecular orbitals, aromaticity, allowed and forbidden reactions, sandwich complexes. Selection rules in spectroscopy, molecular vibrations.
name: CHEM 4100
prereq_text: CHEM 3102.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Physical Chemistry I

desc: Statistical thermodynamics, energy states, equilibrium, partition functions for diatomic molecules. Chemical kinetics: rate laws, solution of differential equations, transition state theory, bimolecular reactions in gases and in solution, chain reactions, catalysis, atmospheric chemical reactions and photochemistry.
name: CHEM 4102
prereq_text: CHEM 3102.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Physical Chemistry II

desc: Surface structure, thermodynamics and kinetics, specifically regarding adsorption/desorption and high vacuum models. Nanoscale structures and their formation, reactivity and characterization. Thin films, carbon nanotubes, self-assembled monolayers and supramolecular aggregates.
name: CHEM 4103
prereq_text: CHEM 3600 and CHEM 3107.
subject: CHEM
title: Surface Chemistry and Nanostructures

desc: An overview of methods used in nanotechnology. Principles of scanning probe techniques ranging from surface physics to biology. State of the art methods to create nanostructures for future applications in areas such as nanolithography, nanoelectronics, nano-optics, data storage and bio-analytical nanosystems.
name: CHEM 4104
prereq_text: CHEM 3600 and CHEM 3107.
subject: CHEM
title: Physical Methods of Nanotechnology

desc: Biological and synthetic macromolecules related to nanoscale phenomena. Challenges and opportunities associated with natural and synthetic polymers on the nanoscale. Molecular recognition, self-assembled nanostructures, scaffolds and templates, functional nanomaterials, amphiphilic architectures, nanocomposites, and nanomachines. Applications to sensing, biomaterials, drug delivery, and polymer based devices.
name: CHEM 4201
prereq_text: CHEM 3600 or permission of the department.
subject: CHEM
title: Macromolecular Nanotechnology

desc: Topics include 2-dimensional 1H and 13CNMR spectroscopy and structure determination of complex organic molecules.
name: CHEM 4202
prereq_text: CHEM 3201.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Organic Chemistry I

desc: The application of reactions to the synthesis or organic molecules. Emphasis on design of synthetic sequences, new reagents, and stereoselectivity. Topics include advanced methods for synthesis and reactions of alkenes, carbonyls, and enolates, functional group interconversion, oxidation and reduction, protecting groups, rearrangements, and metal-catalyzed cross-coupling.
name: CHEM 4203
prereq_text: CHEM 3201 and CHEM 3202.
subject: CHEM
title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry

desc: Introduction to basic principles of polymer chemistry, industrial and synthetic polymers, different types of polymerization and polymer characterization. Study of commodity plastics, engineering thermoplastics, and specialty polymers, with emphasis on their synthesis.
name: CHEM 4204
prereq_text: CHEM 3201 or equivalent.
subject: CHEM
title: Organic Polymer Chemistry

desc: The application of frontier molecular orbital theory (HOMO-LUMO interactions) to organic reactions, including thermal and photochemical cycloadditions of pi-systems (including 1,3-dipoles) and rearrangements. Reactions of radicals and carbenes; conformational analysis, stereochemical effects, and methods for the determination of reaction mechanisms.
name: CHEM 4205
prereq_text: CHEM 3202 and CHEM 3503 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: CHEM
title: Reactivity and Mechanism in Organic Chemistry

desc: A survey of the major classes of natural products with respect to their structural elucidation, synthesis, biosynthesis and bioactivity, with emphasis on compounds that have medicinal importance.
name: CHEM 4206
prereq_text: CHEM 3201 and CHEM 3202,.
subject: CHEM
title: Natural Products Chemistry

desc: Trace and ultratrace analytical chemistry. Sampling and sample preservation. The problems of the blank. Trace and ultratrace analysis. Sampling and sample preparation. Atomic absorption, fluorescence and emission spectroscopy.
name: CHEM 4301
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 and one of CHEM 2302 or CHEM 2303.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Analytical Chemistry I

desc: Solutions and separations in analytical chemistry. Stability of aqueous solutions of standards and samples. Complex formation, multi-step and competing equilibria and their application to the design of selective methods of separation and determination. Electroanalytical techniques. Electroanalytical chemistry of aqueous solutions. Phase equilibria and solvent extraction.
name: CHEM 4302
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 and one of CHEM 2302 or CHEM 2303.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Analytical Chemistry II

desc: Detailed breakdown of the physical, electrical and chemical operation of mass spectrometers. Applications in MS ranging from the analysis of small molecules to large biological macromolecules. Descriptions of the use of mass spectrometry in industry as well as commercial opportunities in the field.
name: CHEM 4304
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 or BIOC 2300, and one of CHEM 2302 or CHEM 2303.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Applications In Mass Spectrometry

desc: Overview of environmental chemistry and toxicology principles including chemical sources, fate, and effects in the environment. Examining organic reactions occurring in abiotic environments and biological systems, and studying aspects of toxicant disposition and biotransformation. Emphasis on contemporary problems in human health and the environment.
name: CHEM 4305
prereq_text: CHEM 2203 or CHEM 2207, and CHEM 2800 or CHEM 2103, or BIOC 3101 or permission of the department.
subject: CHEM
title: Environmental Chemistry and Toxicology

desc: Important elements of rational drug design. Ligand-receptor interactions, structure-activity relationships, molecular modeling of pharmacophores, structure and mechanism-based approaches to drug design. Enzyme inhibition in chemotherapy and design of anti-viral drugs.
name: CHEM 4406
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 and (CHEM 2203 or CHEM 2207), BIOC 3101 and (BIOC 3102 or BIOC 3008).
subject: CHEM
title: Pharmaceutical Drug Design

desc: Polymer architectures; Flexible and rigid rod polymers; Rotational isomeric states (RIS); Molecular mechanics, Ramachandran Map, Helix parameters; internal and external parameters; regular and random coil structures; molecular dynamics; calculation of end-to-end distance, NMR chemical shifts; conformational entropy and properties.
name: CHEM 4407
prereq_text: MATH 1107 and CHEM 2204 or permission of the department.
subject: CHEM
title: Polymer Modeling

desc: A study of nuclear stability and decay; chemical studies of nuclear phenomena. Applications of radioactivity.
name: CHEM 4502
prereq_text: CHEM 2302, CHEM 2303, and CHEM 3100, or permission of the Department.
subject: CHEM
title: Radiochemistry

desc: A quantitave basis for ligand field theory; unreal and real wavefunctions of d-orbitals; derivation of the energies of d-orbitals using variational principle, secular determinants, and ligned field operators; the effect of ligand field on free ion term symbols, wavefunction descriptions of terms symbols; applications.
name: CHEM 4503
prereq_text: CHEM 3504 and CHEM 3101.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Inorganic Chemistry I

desc: Reactivity of inorganic coordination compounds. Thermodynamic and kinetic factors affecting reactivity. Industrial and biochemical processes catalyzed by metal coordination compounds. Experimental methodologies, data analysis and rate law evaluation used to obtain reaction mechanisms leading to improved methods of catalysis.
name: CHEM 4504
prereq_text: CHEM 3504 or equivalent.
subject: CHEM
title: Advanced Topics in Inorganic Chemistry II

desc: Spectroscopic techniques (i.e. UV-visible NIR, IR, EPR) and electrochemistry methods that are used to study photochemical and thermal intermolecular and intramolecular electron transfer in transition metal complexes are presented. Electron transfer theory and redox-active (non-innocent) ligands are discussed.
name: CHEM 4505
prereq_text: CHEM 3504.
subject: CHEM
title: Application of Physical Methods to Electron Transfer Chemistry

desc: A topic of current interest in any branch of chemistry. Only one special topics course may be presented for credit.
name: CHEM 4700
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: CHEM
title: Special Topics in Chemistry

desc: Properties of natural atmospheric constituents; biogeochemical cycles involving gases; chemical reactions in the atmosphere; anthropogenic atmospheric pollutants (e.g., chlorofluorocarbons, sulphur and nitrogen oxides, photochemical smog sources and effects on the biosphere. Relation between the structure of molecules and their spectral and reactive properties.
name: CHEM 4800
prereq_text: CHEM 2103 or CHEM 2800.
subject: CHEM
title: Atmospheric Chemistry

desc: Students conduct an independent research study using library resources, and prepare a critical review and study proposal on a topic approved by a faculty supervisor. A written report and oral poster presentation of the work are required before a grade can be assigned.
name: CHEM 4907
prereq_text: fourth year standing in an Honours Chemistry program and permission of the department.
subject: CHEM
title: Honours Essay and Research Proposal

desc: Senior students in Honours Chemistry carry out a research project under the direction of one of the members of the Department. A written report and an oral presentation of the work are required before a grade can be assigned.
name: CHEM 4908
prereq_text: any two of CHEM 3106, CHEM 3107, CHEM 3205, CHEM 3305 and CHEM 3504 and permission of the department.
subject: CHEM
title: Research Project and Seminar

desc: An introduction to multiple approaches to studying childhood and youth through a diverse range of historical periods and cultural contexts. Students will apply an interdisciplinary lens to explore the ways that children and youth have been discussed, researched, and understood.
name: CHST 1003
prereq_text: None
subject: CHST
title: Introduction to Childhood and Youth Studies

desc: An examination of the philosophies, purposes, methods, techniques, and issues of childhood and youth studies through engagement with children and youth in campus and community settings. Students will make connections to theoretical and curriculum frameworks and current debates and perspectives.
name: CHST 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Experiential Learning in Childhood and Youth Studies

desc: An introduction to the foundations of research involving children and youth. Students will learn research paradigms and strategies for designing and conducting research with children and young people. Ethical considerations and the involvement of children as co-researchers will be emphasized.
name: CHST 2003
prereq_text: second-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Introduction to Research Methods in Childhood and Youth Studies

desc: Introduction to the critical study of children’s literature.
name: CHST 2011
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Children's Literature

desc: A comprehensive interdisciplinary overview of key issues, research, and theoretical developments in the study of childhood and youth. Students will explore the different and often conflicting conceptualizations of adolescence and examine youth theories and their implications.
name: CHST 3000
prereq_text: Third year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Conceptualizing Adolescence in Childhood and Youth Studies

desc: Analysis of selected topics relevant to theory, research, and practice involving children and youth. The choice of topics will vary from year to year. Students should consult with the Institute regarding the topic offered.
name: CHST 3002
prereq_text: Third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Special Topics in Child Studies

desc: Developments and advances in theories of human development and their applications. Population-based models of child development, bio-ecological frameworks, and epigenetic theories with emphasis on interdisciplinary frameworks relating to childhood and youth.
name: CHST 3003
prereq_text: Third year standing in the Childhood and Youth Studies Program or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Theoretical Advances in Developmental Sciences

desc: This seminar is designed for students who wish to complete an Honours research project in their 4th year. Students will select a topic of study, investigate methodological and ethical considerations, and implement the key steps involved in designing rigorous research projects in diverse settings.
name: CHST 3101
prereq_text: CHST 2003 or CHST 2000 (no longer offered), and third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Research Seminar

desc: A critical examination of philosophical, ideological, and discursive perspectives on childhood and youth. Students will analyze normative constructs reproduced in developmental discourses and research, particularly concerning gender, racism, disability, and oppressive practices.
name: CHST 3103
prereq_text: Third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Critical Approaches to Child Development

desc: An analysis of the ways children construct social relations through cultures and systems of representations. Students will investigate how children’s knowledges and identities are constructed through their relationships with the world and develop theoretical and practical approaches for working with children from diverse cultures.
name: CHST 3201
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Children's Knowledges, Cultures, and Representations

desc: A study of historical, contemporary, global, and local conversations about the professional field of early childhood education and care and its diverse practices and contexts. Topics may include reconciliation, anti-racist pedagogies, asset-based practices, inclusiveness, caring in context, and critical reflection.
name: CHST 3202
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Reconceptualizing Early Childhood Education and Care

desc: An exploration of youth cultures and participation in local, national, and global contexts. Students will examine youth engagement and advocacy, including definitions of citizenship, theories of resistance, the construction of “youth” as a social category, and the impact of technology and social media.
name: CHST 3203
prereq_text: Third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Youth Culture and Activism

desc: An examination of the ways in which childhood, children, and youth have been represented in creative literature (fiction, poetry, drama, and/or creative nonfiction).
name: CHST 3204
prereq_text: third-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Literary Representations of Childhood and Youth

desc: An examination of historical and contemporary issues, debates, and methodologies pertaining to the studies of race, ethnicities, and racialization in childhood and youth studies. Students will also theorize the intersectionality of race, racism, racialization, racial and ethnic formations, nationalism, and colonialism in a contemporary context.
name: CHST 3205
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Race, Childhood, and Youth

desc: An introduction to the concepts of policy and practice and how these are influenced by history, economy, geography, and culture. Topics may include provincial, national, and international economic, social, and educational policies concerning children and youth.
name: CHST 3302
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Children, Policy, and Practice

desc: This course examines children’s rights from a range of historical, cultural, and global perspectives. Topics may include the rights for Indigenous children, children with disabilities, female, trans and queer children, children in armed conflict and refugees in Canada and transnational contexts.
name: CHST 3303
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies.
subject: CHST
title: Children’s Rights

desc: Drawing on theory and research in disabled children’s childhood studies, sociology of childhood, disability studies, and girlhood studies, this course examines the discursive and material constructions of disabled youth and childhood in transnational contexts in relation to emerging neo-colonial, neo-imperialist, and neo-liberal ideologies.
name: CHST 3304
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies or Disability Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Disability and Childhood: Transnational Perspectives

desc: An introduction to indigenous perspectives and contexts, both historical and contemporary, in relation to practice with Indigenous children, youth, families, and communities. Students will explore critical theory and necessary protocols for respectful entry into child and youth care practice within Indigenous contexts.
name: CHST 3305
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies or Indigenous Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Childhood and Youth in Indigenous Contexts

desc: Students will learn to apply their knowledge pertaining to children and youth to a policy- or practice-oriented work environment. Students will complete a term paper and other assignments documenting gains in experiential knowledge. Graded SAT/UNS.
name: CHST 3904
prereq_text: students with third- or fourth-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies may apply to the Undergraduate Advisor for permission.
subject: CHST
title: Service-Learning in Community Settings

desc: In-depth analysis of theoretical, empirical, and applied topics related to children and youth in Canada and/or internationally. Topics may include poverty and social inequality, child and youth health, social media and social change. This course is repeatable when the topic changes.
name: CHST 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Advanced Topics in Child Studies

desc: Students will analyze the history of the figure of ‘the African child’ using a range of visual, sources from colonial officials, anthropologists, historians, advertisers, charity and development workers, and African children themselves.
name: CHST 4003
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: CHST
title: History of 'The African Child'

desc: An examination of the ways that educational discourses construct and perpetuate marginalization of disadvantaged individuals across historical, political, and educational contexts. Students will explore inclusive and exclusive approaches to education and care and how these discursive and material conditions shape the learning experiences of children.
name: CHST 4004
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Theories of Inclusion in Childhood and Youth Education

desc: A critical examination how popular culture, including consumer culture and digital media, mediates the identities, aspirations, and experiences of children and youth. Students will engage in critical dialogue about media culture and ideology and use cultural production to explore counter-narratives to problematic media representations.
name: CHST 4101
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Children, Youth, and Popular Culture

desc: An examination of the ways that queer and trans youth have been conceptualized in research, media, literature, policy, and education. A range of multimedia sources will be used to explore the ways queer and trans youth are using language to render themselves intelligible.
name: CHST 4102
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies or Women's and Gender Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: CHST
title: Queer and Trans Youth

desc: A reading or research course for students who wish to investigate a particular topic of interest within Childhood and Youth Studies. Students may not take more than one credit of Independent Study in their total program.
name: CHST 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies and IIS Co-Director approval.
subject: CHST
title: Independent Study

desc: Interdisciplinary research project for students in the Honours Research Project stream. Projects will be completed under the supervision of a CHST faculty member. Students must contact the CHST Program Advisor to request approval to register in this course.
name: CHST 4908
prereq_text: CHST 3101, fourth-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies with a Major CGPA of 10.0 or higher, and permission of the CHST Program Advisor.
subject: CHST
title: Honours Research Project

desc: For students with no knowledge of Mandarin. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. Placement test for non-literate speakers of other Chinese languages. Not open to students already literate in any Chinese language. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: CHIN
title: First-Year Mandarin Chinese I

desc: Continuation of first-year Mandarin Chinese. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 1020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 1010, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: First-Year Mandarin Chinese II

desc: For students with no knowledge of Mandarin Chinese. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. Placement test for non-literate speakers of other Chinese languages. Not open to students already literate in any Chinese language. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 1110
prereq_text: None
subject: CHIN
title: Intensive First-Year Mandarin Chinese

desc: Further study of Mandarin Chinese to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 2010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 1020 or CHIN 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Second-Year Mandarin Chinese I

desc: Continuation of second-year Mandarin Chinese. Further study of Mandarin Chinese to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 2020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 2010 or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Second-Year Mandarin Chinese II

desc: Further study of Mandarin Chinese to reach a more advanced level of ability in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 2110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 1020 or CHIN 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Intensive Second-Year Mandarin Chinese

desc: Continuation of the study of Mandarin Chinese to reach a more advanced level, including ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 3010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 2020, or CHIN 2110, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Third-Year Mandarin Chinese I

desc: For students who have attained Mandarin Chinese proficiency in an informal setting, this course provides an opportunity to build on their existing language skills and to develop them in a formal academic setting. The course will formalize grammar awareness and enhance Mandarin Chinese literacy skills.
name: CHIN 3015
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Mandarin Chinese for Heritage Speakers

desc: Continuation of third-year Mandarin Chinese. Progress toward reaching a more advanced level, including ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 3020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 3010 or CHIN 3015, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Third-Year Mandarin Chinese II

desc: Development of speaking and writing abilities more complex than those used in daily communication. Development of language use for specific purposes and in specific contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 4010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 3020, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese I

desc: Continuation of fourth-year Mandarin Chinese. Further development of speaking and writing abilities more complex than those used in daily communication. Development of language use for specific purposes and in specific contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains. Compulsory attendance.
name: CHIN 4020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 4010, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese II

desc: Further study of Mandarin Chinese to reach a more advanced level, aimed at developing speaking and writing abilities more complex than those used in daily communication. Development of language use for specific purposes in contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains.
name: CHIN 4210
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 4020, or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Functional Contemporary Mandarin Chinese I

desc: Continuation of CHIN 4210. Further development of speaking and writing abilities more complex than those used in daily communication. Development of language use for specific purposes in contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains.
name: CHIN 4220
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in CHIN 4210 or permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Functional Contemporary Mandarin Chinese II

desc: Selected topics in Chinese culture and society. Repeatable once for credit when topic varies. Taught in English.
name: CHIN 4380
prereq_text: Third-year standing in the Minor in Mandarin Chinese, or permission of the instructor.
subject: CHIN
title: Topics in Chinese Culture and Society

desc: Research in a topic in Mandarin Chinese language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: CHIN 4900
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in the Minor in Mandarin Chinese, grade of C or higher in CHIN 4020 or equivalent, and permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Independent Study

desc: Research in a topic in Mandarin Chinese language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: CHIN 4901
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in the Minor in Mandarin Chinese, grade of C or higher in CHIN 4020 or equivalent, and permission of the School.
subject: CHIN
title: Independent Study

desc: Engineering geometry and spatial graphics. Fundamentals of surveys. Digital surveying tools; total station, GPS. Computer-Aided Drafting (CAD). Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Spatial referencing. Building Information Modelling (BIM). Integrated design using digital tools. Field exercises using software to process and evaluate spatial data.
name: CIVE 2004
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering or (GEOM 1004 for students in BSc in Geomatics).
subject: CIVE
title: GIS, Surveying, CAD and BIM

desc: Technical issues involved in architectural design of buildings from ancient times to the present. Technological innovation and materials related to structural developments, and the organization and design of structures. Basic concepts of calculus, equilibrium, and mechanics of materials.
name: CIVE 2005
prereq_text: ARCC 2202.
subject: CIVE
title: Architectural Technology 2

desc: Virtual work. Friction. Relative motion of particles. Kinematics of a rigid body: translation, rotation; general plane motion; absolute and relative motion. Kinetics of a rigid body: equations of motion; work-energy; impulse-momentum; conservation of momentum and energy. Conservative forces and potential energy.
name: CIVE 2101
prereq_text: MATH 1004, MATH 1104 and second-year status in Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Engineering Mechanics

desc: Stress and strain. Stress-strain relationship: Hooke's law. Torsion of circular shafts. Bending moment and shear force distribution. Flexural stresses. Deflection. Shear stress in beams. Stresses in thin- walled cylinders. Transformation of 2D stress and strain: Mohr's circle. Buckling of columns.
name: CIVE 2200
prereq_text: MATH 1004 and second-year status in Engineering for B.Eng. or CIVE 2005 for B.A.S. with Concentration in Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: CIVE
title: Mechanics of Solids I

desc: Introduction to material science. Structure of atoms. Crystallography. Crystal Imperfections. Characteristics, behaviour and use of Civil Engineering materials: steel, concrete, asphalt, wood, polymers, composites. Specifications. Physical, chemical and mechanical properties. Quality control and material tests. Fatigue. Corrosion. Applications in construction and rehabilitation of structures.
name: CIVE 2700
prereq_text: second year status for students in an Engineering program or second year standing in a B.A.S. major in Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: CIVE
title: Civil Engineering Materials

desc: Shear flow. Definition of shear centre, Saint Venant and warping torsional constants. Behaviour, governing differential equations and solutions for torsion, beam-columns, lateral torsional buckling of doubly symmetric beams, axially loaded doubly symmetric, singly symmetric and asymmetric columns. Failure criterion, fatigue and fracture.
name: CIVE 3202
prereq_text: CIVE 2200.
subject: CIVE
title: Mechanics of Solids II

desc: Concepts and assumptions for structural analysis: framed structures; joints; supports; compatibility and equilibrium; stability and determinacy; generalized forces and displacements. Principle of Virtual Work: unknown force calculations; influence lines. Complementary Virtual Work: displacement calculations, indeterminate analysis. Introduction to the Stiffness Method of Analysis.
name: CIVE 3203
prereq_text: CIVE 2200 and MATH 1004.
subject: CIVE
title: Introduction to Structural Analysis

desc: Building systems and structural form. Design Philosophy and design process. Limit states design. National Building Code of Canada. Determination of dead, live, snow, wind, and earthquake loads.
name: CIVE 3204
prereq_text: CIVE 2200.
subject: CIVE
title: Introduction to Structural Design

desc: Introduction to CAN/CSA - S16, design and behaviour concepts; shear lag, block shear, local plate buckling, lateral torsional buckling, instantaneous centre, inelastic strength and stability. Design of tension members, axially loaded columns, beams, beam-columns, simple bolted and welded connections.
name: CIVE 3205
prereq_text: CIVE 2200 and CIVE 2700. Recommended prerequisite: CIVE 3204.
subject: CIVE
title: Design of Structural Steel Components

desc: Introduction to CAN/CSA - A23.3; design and behaviour concepts; flexural analysis at service loads; shear, bond, Whitney stress block, under, over reinforced behaviour, ultimate strength. Flexural design of singly reinforced, doubly reinforced T-beams, one-way slabs. Shear design for beams. One-way, two-way slab systems, columns.
name: CIVE 3206
prereq_text: CIVE 2200 and CIVE 2700. Recommended prerequisite: CIVE 3204.
subject: CIVE
title: Design of Reinforced Concrete Components

desc: Methods of heritage documentation including hand recording, photography, rectified photography, total station, gps, photogrammetry, and laser scanning. Non-destructive testing techniques; environmental assessment tools for determining air quality and energy efficiency. Multidisciplinary teams for all project work.
name: CIVE 3207
prereq_text: third-year status in B.Eng. in Architectural Conservation and Sustainability Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Historic Site Recording and Assessment

desc: Soil composition and soil classification. Soil properties, compaction, seepage and permeability. Concepts of pore water pressure, capillary pressure and hydraulic head. Principle of effective stress, stress-deformation and strength characteristics of soils, consolidation, stress distribution with soils, and settlement. Laboratory testing.
name: CIVE 3208
prereq_text: third-year status in Engineering, or permission of the department. Additional recommended background: ERTH 2404 or equivalent.
subject: CIVE
title: Geotechnical Mechanics

desc: Building envelope design and analysis; applied heat transfer and moisture transport; solar radiation; hygrothermal modelling; control of rain, air, vapour, and heat; materials for wall, window, curtain wall, roof, and foundation systems; building envelope retrofit case studies; building code; envelope construction.
name: CIVE 3209
prereq_text: MAAE2400 and third-year status in B.Eng. Architectural Conservation and Sustainability Engineering or in Civil Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Building Science

desc: Transportation and the socio-economic environment; modal and intermodal systems and components; vehicle motion, human factors, system and facility design; traffic flow; capacity analysis; planning methodology; environmental impacts; evaluation methods.
name: CIVE 3304
prereq_text: third-year status in Engineering, or permission of the Department.
subject: CIVE
title: Transportation Engineering and Planning

name: CIVE 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: CIVE
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Review of basic structural concepts. Betti's law and applications. Matrix flexibility method, flexibility influence coefficients. Development of stiffness influence coefficients. Stiffness method of analysis: beams; plane trusses and frames; space trusses and frames. Introduction to the finite element method.
name: CIVE 4200
prereq_text: CIVE 3203.
subject: CIVE
title: Matrix Analysis of Framed Structures

desc: Introduction to the theory and application of finite element methods. The relationship with virtual work, Rayleigh-Ritz, system of linear equations, polynomial interpolation, numerical integration, and theory of elasticity is explored. Isoparametric formulations of structural and plane elements are examined. Geotechnical and nonlinear problems are introduced.
name: CIVE 4201
prereq_text: CIVE 2200 and fourth year status in engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Finite Element Methods in Civil Engineering

desc: Structural design in timber. Properties, anatomy of wood, wood products, factors affecting strength and behaviour, strength evaluation and testing. Design of columns, beams and beam-columns. Design of trusses, frames, glulam structures, plywood components, formwork, foundations, connections and connectors. Inspection, maintenance and repair.
name: CIVE 4202
prereq_text: CIVE 2200, CIVE 2700 and third-year status in B.Eng.
subject: CIVE
title: Wood Engineering

desc: Strength of soils, steady state seepage, flownets and piping. Stress distribution in soils. Earth pressures: at rest, active and passive. Design of flexible and rigid retaining structures. Stability of excavations, slopes and embankments. Settlement of foundations. Bearing capacity of footings.
name: CIVE 4208
prereq_text: CIVE 3208.
subject: CIVE
title: Geotechnical Engineering

desc: Highway planning; highway location and geometric design; traffic engineering; highway capacity; soil classifications; subgrade and base materials; highway drainage; frost action; structural design of rigid and flexible pavements; highway economics and finance; maintenance and rehabilitation.
name: CIVE 4209
prereq_text: Fourth year status in engineering. Recommended prerequisites: CIVE 2004, CIVE 3304 and CIVE 3208.
subject: CIVE
title: Highway Engineering

desc: A critical study of the theories in soil mechanics and their application to the solution of geotechnical engineering problems. Field investigations, laboratory and field testing, shallow foundations, special footings, mat foundations, pile foundations and excavations. Discussion of new methods and current research.
name: CIVE 4301
prereq_text: CIVE 4208.
subject: CIVE
title: Foundation Engineering

desc: Reinforced concrete shear and torsion design. Two-way slab design by Direct Design and Equivalent Frame Method. Behaviour and design of slender reinforced concrete columns. Prestressed concrete concepts; flexural analysis and design; shear design; anchorage zone design; deflection and prestress loss determination.
name: CIVE 4302
prereq_text: CIVE 3202, CIVE 3203 and CIVE 3206.
subject: CIVE
title: Reinforced and Prestressed Concrete Design

desc: A systematic approach to urban planning; urban sprawl; data collection; forecasting; standards; space requirements; land use; zoning; transportation; land development; site selection; land capability; layout; evaluation; housing; urban renewal and new towns.
name: CIVE 4303
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering, second-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism), or permission of the Department.
subject: CIVE
title: Urban Planning

desc: Fluid flow fundamentals. Hydraulics of pipe systems. Open channel flow. Prediction of sanitary and storm sewage, flow rates. Design of water distribution systems, culverts, sanitary and storm sewers. Pumps and measuring devices. Hydraulic and flow control structures.
name: CIVE 4307
prereq_text: MAAE 2300.
subject: CIVE
title: Municipal Hydraulics

desc: Behaviour and design of open web steel joists, steel and composite decks, composite beams and columns, stud girders, and plate girders. Design of moment connections, base plates and anchor bolts, and bracing connections. Stability of rigid and braced frames. Design for lateral load effects.
name: CIVE 4308
prereq_text: CIVE 3205 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Behaviour and Design of Steel Structures

desc: Systems approach to project planning and control. Analysis of alternative network planning methods: CPM, precedence and PERT; planning procedure; computer techniques and estimating; physical, economic and financial feasibility; implementation feedback and control; case studies.
name: CIVE 4400
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Construction/Project Management

desc: Introduction to structural design in masonry. Properties of masonry materials and assemblages. Behaviour and design of beams, walls and columns. Selected topics including veneer wall systems, differential movement, workmanship, specifications, inspection, maintenance and repair. Lowrise and highrise building design.
name: CIVE 4403
prereq_text: CIVE 3204, CIVE 3206 and fourth-year status in Engineering or permission of the Department.
subject: CIVE
title: Masonry Design

desc: Introduction to fundamentals of municipal engineering. Water quality: physical, chemical and biological parameters. Water treatment: softening mixing, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, disinfection, fluoridation. Biological processes. Wastewater treatment: primary, secondary and tertiary treatment. Sludge disposal and wastewater reuse. Solid waste management.
name: CIVE 4407
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Municipal Engineering

desc: Advanced software development for Civil Engineering applications. Examples may be chosen from surveying, transportation, geotechnical and/or structural engineering. Software technologies include object-oriented programming, data base management, Internet-based applications and graphical user interfaces.
name: CIVE 4500
prereq_text: Fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Computer Methods in Civil Engineering

desc: Deterioration mechanisms for concrete, timber, steel and masonry structures. Identification of design deficiencies; criteria for selection and design of rehabilitation systems. Design techniques to reduce deterioration in new construction and historical structures.
name: CIVE 4601
prereq_text: CIVE 3207 and fourth-year status in B.Eng. in Architectural Conservation and Sustainability Engineering.
subject: CIVE
title: Building Pathology and Rehabilitation

desc: Understanding fire-structure interaction and the concepts of fire severity and resistance; behaviour of steel, concrete, and timber buildings exposed to fires; compartment fire dynamics; correlations and computer models to predict fire dynamics; fire retardants; laboratory-scale fire experiments; performance-based approach for building fire safety design.
name: CIVE 4614
prereq_text: MAAE 2400 and fourth-year status in Engineering, or permission of the Department.
subject: CIVE
title: Building Fire Safety

desc: A research project in engineering analysis, design or development carried out by individual students or small teams, for an opportunity to develop initiative, self-reliance, creative ability and engineering judgment and is normally intended for students with high CGPAs and an interest in graduate studies.
name: CIVE 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering and permission of the department.
subject: CIVE
title: Engineering Research Project

desc: Student carries out a study, analysis, and solution of an engineering problem which results in a written final report. Carried out under close supervision of a faculty member. Intended for students interested in pursuing graduate studies. Requires supervising faculty member and proposal from student.
name: CIVE 4917
prereq_text: permission of the Department and completion of, or concurrent registration in, CIVE 4918.
subject: CIVE
title: Undergraduate Directed Study

desc: Teams of students develop professional level experience through a design project that incorporates fundamentals acquired in previous mathematics, science, engineering, and complementary studies courses. A final report and oral presentations are required.
name: CIVE 4918
prereq_text: ECOR 3800 and fourth-year status in Engineering. Certain projects may have additional requirements.
subject: CIVE
title: Design Project

desc: Introduction to the study of Greek antiquity and the discipline of Classics and its methodologies. Greek culture and society are set in their historical contexts and studied through readings from representative ancient authors (in English translation) and through the art and architecture of the period.
name: CLCV 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Survey of Greek Civilization

desc: Introduction to the study of Roman antiquity and the discipline of Classics and its methodologies. The culture and society are set in their historical context and studied through readings from representative ancient authors (in English translation) and through the art and architecture of the period.
name: CLCV 1003
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Survey of Roman Civilization

desc: Elementary study of an ancient language.
name: CLCV 1004
prereq_text: Permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Elementary Language Tutorial I

desc: Elementary study of an ancient language.
name: CLCV 1005
prereq_text: Permission of the department.
subject: CLCV
title: Elementary Language Tutorial II

desc: Introduction to the history, theory and practice of field archaeology. Excavations from all time periods and global regions will be discussed. Focus will be placed on excavation methods and technology, including dating, that enhance understanding of sites both on land and underwater.
name: CLCV 1008
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Introduction to Archaeology I

desc: Continues the examination of various aspects of field archaeology begun in CLCV 1008. This course places greater focus on recent approaches to the interpretation of remains. These include environmental, cognitive and bioarchaeological approaches.
name: CLCV 1009
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Introduction to Archaeology II

desc: Intermediate study of an ancient language.

subject: CLCV
title: Intermediate Language Tutorial II

subject: CLCV
title: Greek and Roman Epic

desc: An examination of the genres of tragedy and comedy in Greco-Roman antiquity.
name: CLCV 2010
prereq_text: second year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Greek and Roman Drama

desc: Examination of Ancient Greek and Latin roots of technical terms found in the sciences, engineering, and medicine.
name: CLCV 2100
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Scientific and Medical terminology

desc: A study of religion in ancient Greece.
name: CLCV 2103
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Greek Religion

desc: A study of religion in ancient Rome.
name: CLCV 2104
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Roman Religion

desc: The Greek tradition from its pre-Socratic beginnings to Hellenistic and Roman philosophy (Cynicism, Epicureanism, Stoicism, Scepticism); focus on Socrates, Plato and Aristotle. Its conservation and reappropriation in the Middle Ages and Renaissance.
name: CLCV 2105
prereq_text: None
subject: CLCV
title: Greek Philosophy and the Western Tradition

desc: The art, architecture and archaeology of ancient Greece. Vase painting, sculpture, architecture, town planning and analogous arts.
name: CLCV 2303
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Greek Art and Archaeology

desc: The art, architecture and archaeology of the ancient Romans. Vase painting, sculpture, architecture, town planning and analogous arts are studied.
name: CLCV 2304
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Roman Art and Archaeology

desc: The development and application of ancient science and technology in the fields of ancient engineering, machinery, metallurgy, transport, building, agriculture and Hippocratic medicine; the social position of craftsmen and artisans, the attitude of intellectuals to science and manual labour, the effects of slavery.
name: CLCV 2305
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department. This course is suitable for students with no previous knowledge of Greece or Rome.
subject: CLCV
title: Ancient Science and Technology

desc: A study of classical mythology, emphasizing its use in Greek and Roman literature and its place in classical art and religion. There is some discussion of classical myths in terms of contemporary interpretations of myth.
name: CLCV 2500
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Classical Mythology

desc: The history of ancient Greece from the Bronze Age through the Archaic period.
name: CLCV 2902
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of unit.
subject: CLCV
title: History of Ancient Greece I

desc: The history of ancient Greece from the classical period to Alexander.
name: CLCV 2903
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: History of Ancient Greece II

desc: The history of ancient Rome from early Rome to the end of the Republic.
name: CLCV 2904
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: History of Ancient Rome I

desc: The history of ancient Rome from the end of the Republic to the coming of Islam.
name: CLCV 2905
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: History of Ancient Rome II

desc: A study of a selected topic in ancient history, literature, languages, culture, archaeology and/or technology.
name: CLCV 2906
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Classical Civilization

desc: A study of a selected topic in ancient history.
name: CLCV 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Topics in Ancient History

desc: A study of the pre-Socratic philosophers and of the Sophists and Socrates.
name: CLCV 3001
prereq_text: CLCV 2105 or PHIL 2005 or permission of the Philosophy department.
subject: CLCV
title: Early Greek Philosophy

desc: A study of a selected topic in classical civilization.
name: CLCV 3003
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Topics in Classical Civilization

desc: The study of major developments - administrative, ecclesiastical, cultural and societal - of the later Roman Empire.
name: CLCV 3010
prereq_text: a 2000-level CLCV course.
subject: CLCV
title: The Later Roman Empire

desc: A study of philosophers, texts, problems and issues in ancient philosophy, generally with a focus on Plato and Aristotle.
name: CLCV 3011
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in PHIL and second-year standing, or permission of the Philosophy department.
subject: CLCV
title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy

desc: Study of a period or theme in Greek History.
name: CLCV 3201
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in CLCV courses (or equivalent) or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Greek History

desc: Study of a period or theme in Roman History.
name: CLCV 3202
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in CLCV courses (or equivalent) or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Roman History

name: CLCV 3215
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: CLCV
title: Ancient Greek Science

desc: Students will participate for a minimum of three weeks on an archaeological field project (i.e., excavation or survey) relevant to the Greek and Roman world. They will learn archaeological documentation and the analysis, recording, and processing of finds.
name: CLCV 3301
prereq_text: CLCV 1008 and CLCV 1009 or CLCV 2300 and permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Field Work I: Greek and Roman World

desc: A study of period or theme in the art and archaeology of Ancient Greece. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: CLCV 3306
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Greek Art

desc: A study of a period or theme in the art and archaeology of the ancient Romans. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: CLCV 3307
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Roman Art

desc: This course combines academic study in Canada with first hand examination of museum collections and sites of the ancient world, normally in Greece and Italy. Course content varies from year to year.
name: CLCV 3400
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in Greek and Roman Studies, any level (CLCV, GREK, or LATN. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Greek and Roman Studies Abroad

desc: A study of an author or topic in Greek literature. Contents of this course vary from year to year.
name: CLCV 3701
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in CLCV courses (or equivalent) at second year level or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Greek Literature

desc: A study of an author or topic in Roman literature.
name: CLCV 3702
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in CLCV courses (or equivalent) at second year level or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Studies in Roman Literature

desc: Students participate for a minimum of three weeks in a position of responsibility (for example, as a trench supervisor or lab assistant) on an archaeological field project relevant to the Greek and Roman world.
name: CLCV 4000
prereq_text: CLCV 3300 and permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: CLCV
title: Field Work II: Greek and Roman World

desc: Intended for Honours students in History and Classics who should normally be in the third and fourth-years.
name: CLCV 4210
prereq_text: CLCV 2902 (HIST 2902), CLCV 2903(HIST 2903) or CLCV 2904 (HIST 2904), CLCV 2905 (HIST 2905) or CLCV 3201 or CLCV 3202 or permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Topics in Ancient History

name: CLCV 4800
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Greek and Roman Studies B.A. program, or permission of the department.
subject: CLCV
title: Seminar in Greek and Roman Studies

name: CLCV 4801
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Greek and Roman Studies B.A. program, or permission of the department.
subject: CLCV
title: Seminar in Greek and Roman Studies

desc: These courses consist of supervised readings and research projects in a specific area of Classical Civilization to be chosen in consultation with the Honours Supervisor.
name: CLCV 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing and permission of the unit.
subject: CLCV
title: Directed Readings and Research

desc: This mandatory course introduces Co-op students to the Co-operative Education Program, job search, application, and interview processes while preparing students for the transition from university to a professional work environment. Graded SAT/UNSAT.
name: COOP 1000
prereq_text: Restricted to co-op students.
subject: COOP
title: Co-op Preparation

desc: Challenges faced in understanding the mind, and some of the approaches cognitive science has brought to bear on them. Topics may include the nature of knowledge, how we learn, the extent to which human thinking is rational, biases in thinking, and evolutionary influences on cognition.
name: CGSC 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: CGSC
title: Mysteries of the Mind

desc: Introduction to computational methods, with an emphasis on programming. Topics and assignments will focus on applications in cognitive science. No prior computing experience required.
name: CGSC 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: CGSC
title: Computational Methods in Cognitive Science

desc: An integrated background of the discipline of Cognitive Science, with an historical overview (1940's onward) and examination of the extent to which the discipline has assimilated the collective knowledge of contributing disciplines (e.g., psychology, philosophy, linguistics, artificial intelligence and neuroscience).
name: CGSC 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing and FYSM 1607 or CGCS 1001, or permission of the Department.
subject: CGSC
title: Theories in Cognitive Science

desc: Selected topics in cognitive science covered from the perspectives of psychology, computer science, linguistics, philosophy, and other related disciplines. Students may be required to complete independent research projects.
name: CGSC 2002
prereq_text: CGSC 1001 or FYSM 1607, second year standing, or permission of the Department. Restricted to students enrolled in B.Cog.Sc. programs.
subject: CGSC
title: Methods in Cognitive Science

desc: An examination of the significance and role of philosophy in cognitive science. Topics may include: philosophical methods for studying the mind, prospects for naturalizing consciousness and intentionality, assessing competing models of the mind.
name: CGSC 3004
prereq_text: CGSC 2001 and PHIL 2501, and third-year standing.
subject: CGSC
title: Philosophy and Cognitive Science

desc: An examination of research findings on cognitive processes. Topics may include attention, speech perception, memory, intelligence, reasoning, learning, working memory, reading, and mathematics.
name: CGSC 3201
prereq_text: third-year standing, and CGSC 2001 or PSYC 2700.
subject: CGSC
title: Cognitive Processes

desc: Issues related to language and cognitive science are examined through a detailed consideration of selected topics.
name: CGSC 3301
prereq_text: third-year standing, and CGSC 2001.
subject: CGSC
title: Language and Cognitive Science

desc: Issues related to the role of cognitive neuroscience research in cognitive science are examined through a detailed consideration of selected topics.
name: CGSC 3501
prereq_text: third-year standing and CGSC 2001.
subject: CGSC
title: Cognitive Neuroscience

desc: An introduction to the contribution of artificial intelligence and computer modeling of cognitive processes to cognitive science.
name: CGSC 3601
prereq_text: third-year standing and CGSC 2002 and (CGSC 1005 or COMP 1005). Restricted to students enrolled in B.Cog.Sc. Honours.
subject: CGSC
title: Artificial Intelligence and Cognitive Science

desc: Exploration of the roles of human and artificial cognition in the digital humanities. Topics may include virtual and augmented reality as applied to the humanities, cognitive issues in hypertext and hypermedia; linguistic and philosophical considerations in digital media, cognitive narratology, and artificial intelligence.
name: CGSC 3704
prereq_text: CGSC 1001; CGSC 2001 or DIGH 2001; and third-year standing.
subject: CGSC
title: Cognitive Science and the Digital Humanities

desc: Major theories and empirical approaches within Cognitive Science are examined through a detailed consideration of selected topics. Students are required to complete independent research projects to prepare for their fourth-year honours theses.
name: CGSC 3908
prereq_text: third year standing, CGSC 2001 and CGSC 2002, and enrolment in B. Cog. Sc. Honours with a CGPA in the major requirements of 8.0.
subject: CGSC
title: Honours Seminar in Cognitive Science

name: CGSC 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: CGSC
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Introduction to the field of cognitive modelling. Different modelling systems and how to evaluate them against human data; how to create cognitive models using the ACT-R cognitive architecture.
name: CGSC 4601
prereq_text: third year standing, CGSC 2001, and (CGSC 1005 or COMP 1005).
subject: CGSC
title: Cognitive Modelling in Cognitive Science

desc: A reading or research course for selected students who wish to investigate a particular topic of interest. Normally students may not offer more than one credit of independent study in their total program (including independent study credits taken through other departments).
name: CGSC 4801
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department.
subject: CGSC
title: Independent Study

desc: A reading or research course for selected students who wish to investigate a particular topic of interest. Normally students may not offer more than one credit of independent study in their total program (including independent study credits taken through other departments).
name: CGSC 4802
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department.
subject: CGSC
title: Independent Study

desc: The topic of this course will vary from year to year. Students may register in more than one section of CGSC 4900 but may register in each section only once.
name: CGSC 4900
prereq_text: each section will have its own prerequisites and permission of the department if is required.
subject: CGSC
title: Special Topics in Cognitive Science

desc: Interdisciplinary thesis. In developing a thesis, students must consult the Undergraduate Supervisor. Only the Undergraduate Supervisor can assign a supervisor or grant approval to register in this course. Faculty regulations governing Honours Research Essays and Honours Theses apply.
name: CGSC 4908
prereq_text: fourth year standing, CGSC 3908, and enrolment in B.Cog.Sc. Honours with a major CGPA of 8.0.
subject: CGSC
title: Honours Thesis

desc: Interdisciplinary project. Students engage in one or more group research projects.
name: CGSC 4909
prereq_text: 4th year standing, enrolment in B. Cog. Sc. Honours.
subject: CGSC
title: Honours Project

desc: An exploration of past and present media, patterns of change, and key approaches to their study.
name: COMS 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: COMS
title: Foundations in Communication and Media Studies

desc: An exploration of communication and media in relation to contemporary political, technological and cultural issues, with a focus on Canada.
name: COMS 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: COMS
title: Current Issues in Communication and Media

desc: The development of communication theory in the context of major social, economic and cultural periods and events. Emphasis on the central debates and traditions that have shaped and defined the field.
name: COMS 2003
prereq_text: COMS 1001 and COMS 1002, or JOUR 1001 and JOUR 1002, and second-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Theoretical Foundations in Communication and Media Studies

desc: Introduction to the scientific method as interpreted through major traditions in Communication and Media Studies. The course addresses the relationship between theory and evidence, research design, ethics and data management.
name: COMS 2004
prereq_text: COMS 1001 and COMS 1002, or JOUR 1001 and JOUR 1002, and second year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Introduction to Communication Research

desc: How big data and small data shape society. Databases as a form of media. Topics may include: data policy and regulation, the politics and ethics of big data, data and decision-making, and data as discourse.
name: COMS 2200
prereq_text: Second-year standing or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Big Data and Society
