desc: How business, government, and civil society actors have used media messages to persuade, influence, and manipulate the public. The impacts of propaganda on individuals and society, the roles of different media technologies in facilitating propaganda, and public resistance to propaganda.
name: COMS 2300
prereq_text: COMS 1001 or COMS 1002 or JOUR 1001 or JOUR 1002 or PAPM 1000, and second-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication as Propaganda

desc: How expert knowledge (particularly scientific, medical, and technical) is communicated in the public realm. Topics may include scientific advances and new technologies, health risks, environmental/ climate change, and cultural/ideological positioning of science.
name: COMS 2500
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Science

desc: A survey of laws that affect the Canadian media including the development of freedom of expression, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and statutory and common-law limitations on freedoms of the press, including publication bans, libel and contempt of court.
name: COMS 2501
prereq_text: COMS 1001 or COMS 1002 or JOUR 1001 or JOUR 1002 or PAPM 1000, and second-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media Law

desc: Some of the central topics in the study of language and communication as pursued by linguists and philosophers, including the nature of meaning, the connections between language, communication and cognition, and language as a social activity.
name: COMS 2504
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: COMS
title: Language and Communication

desc: An introduction to the major industries, institutions, regulatory frameworks and key organizations responsible for cultural production in Canada.
name: COMS 2600
prereq_text: COMS 1001 or COMS 1002 or JOUR 1001 or JOUR 1002, and second-year standing in Communication and Media Studies, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Culture

desc: An introduction to global media and communication, with an emphasis on debates about media power and expansion, digitalization, technology transfer, and societal implications/changes. Students will investigate historical and contemporary contexts of global and transnational communication through a variety of approaches and perspectives.
name: COMS 2700
prereq_text: COMS 1001 or COMS 1002 or JOUR 1001 or JOUR 1002, and second-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Global Media and Communication

desc: An introduction to basic statistical methods in media and communication studies.
name: COMS 3001
prereq_text: COMS 2004, or PAPM 2000, and third-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Quantitative Research in Communication

desc: An introduction to interpretive methods in media and communication studies.
name: COMS 3002
prereq_text: COMS 2004, or PAPM 2000, and third-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Qualitative Research in Communication

desc: Introduction to the field of political management. The institutional, legislative and ethical context in which party strategists, campaign managers, pollsters, lobbyists and civil society operate. Related administrative and communications skills.
name: COMS 3100
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: COMS
title: Introduction to Political Management

desc: Examines the theoretical frameworks and major issues and debates relating to media industries and institutions in Canada and internationally.
name: COMS 3108
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media Industries and the Network Society

desc: Examines the relationship between media, communication, and identity categories. The course explores identity formation as a cultural phenomenon including questions of race, ethnicity, gender, class, and sexuality.
name: COMS 3109
prereq_text: third-year standing and enrollment in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations and streams) or in the Minor in Critical Race Studies, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication, Culture and Identity

desc: Examines the relationship between various kinds of communication and political activity in a variety of contexts. Case studies will be drawn from speeches, political campaigns, and debates, using a variety of media forms, from photographs to web sites.
name: COMS 3302
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Political Communication

desc: A critical analysis of major constructs and basic mechanisms of advertising, social marketing and other aspects of consumer culture. The course examines the social, political-economic and cultural implications of consumer culture.
name: COMS 3308
prereq_text: third-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Critical Studies in Advertising and Consumer Culture

desc: A critical examination of key aspects of public relations, including histories of PR, media representations of PR, gender and public relations, and the role of PR in business, politics and civil society.
name: COMS 3310
prereq_text: third-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Critical Perspectives of Public Relations

desc: Provides a historical overview of the development of media technologies, and an understanding of the place of media within the political, regulatory, and legal activities of different international regions (e.g., Europe, Asia, Africa, Latin America, etc.).
name: COMS 3311
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media and Communication in Regional Contexts

desc: Explores ethical problems and controversies relating to research in media and communication. Focuses on rights and responsibilities of researchers and practitioners as relates to media consumers, producers, and professional communicators in an age when communication circulates quickly within and across borders and other boundaries.
name: COMS 3400
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Ethical Controversies in Media and Communication

desc: Examines historical and contemporary issues in the regulation of communication practices and institutions in Canada.
name: COMS 3401
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations),or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communications Regulation in Canada

desc: Examines the relationship between communication technology and society, including factors that contribute to changes in the collection, storage and distribution of information and their cultural implications.
name: COMS 3403
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication, Technology and Culture

desc: An introduction to the structure and history of the music industries.
name: COMS 3404
prereq_text: second year standing.
subject: COMS
title: Music Industries

desc: Examines the role of audiences in contemporary media industries. Topics include history of audience studies, ratings and the audience commodity, active audience theory, and media fandom.
name: COMS 3406
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media Audiences and Users

desc: The comparative study of one or more media organizations and/or types of media content with reference to their operation, audiences, and impacts.
name: COMS 3407
prereq_text: Third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Comparative Media Studies

desc: Examines the central importance of visual imagery in contemporary media, culture and everyday life. Draws connections between historical/contemporary explanations of ‘the visual,’ and how texts and technologies reflect the context and cultural values of the environments that produce them, and the challenges for regulation.
name: COMS 3410
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Visual Media and Communication

desc: Examines links between media and activism through the lens of past and present social movements and protest events. Addresses leading theories that help conceptualize various types of activist movements, with a focus on the role of media in shaping activist identity and political opportunity.
name: COMS 3411
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Alternative Media and Social Activism

desc: The concept of health as a sociocultural phenomenon; the many ways that health issues are communicated, defined, represented, and framed.
name: COMS 3412
prereq_text: third year standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Health

desc: Examines theoretical debates and issues facing the field of Communication and Media Studies today.
name: COMS 3500
prereq_text: COMS 2003 and third-year standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations and streams), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Current Issues in Communication and Media Theory

desc: A selected topic not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topic varies from year to year. Check with the Communication and Media Studies program regarding the topic offered.
name: COMS 3800
prereq_text: third-year standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Special Topic in Communication and Media Studies

name: COMS 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: COMS
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Examines the development of theory and methods related to discourse and its use in the analysis of images and texts.
name: COMS 4004
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Discourse

desc: Students will work in a team-based environment to carry out empirical research in support of current faculty-led projects. In addition to learning advanced research techniques, students will develop project management and collaborative research skills.
name: COMS 4006
prereq_text: COMS 3001 or COMS 3002, and fourth-year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Professional Communication Research

desc: Critical examination of the ways religion mediates communicative practices, engages with media technologies, and is mediated in mainstream or popular culture. Topics may include: secularization and post-secularization; the politics of representation; religious organizations as communicative actors; fundamentalism.
name: COMS 4305
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media and Religion

desc: Media representations of conflict such as war and terrorism, and how they influence the collective imagination.
name: COMS 4306
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media and Conflict

desc: Examines the histories, key actors, issues and trends in political communication, including the shift of government communication from information to promotion, its reliance on publicity practices, issues and crisis management, and implications for democratic citizenship.
name: COMS 4307
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Politics, Communication, and the Publicity State

desc: Examines environmental, animal, and earth observing media and pays special attention to the production of visual materials. The course explores the influence of media systems on the production, dissemination, and meaning of environmental observations and looks at sites of contemporary environmental contention.
name: COMS 4311
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing and enrollment in Communication and Media Studies or in the Minor in Environmental and Climate Humanities, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Environmental Communication

desc: Examines crises and risks from the perspective of communication. The course explores the role of various media in shaping risk perceptions and constructions of crisis, the politics of crisis and risk management, symbolic dimensions in crisis construction, and ethical dilemmas.
name: COMS 4312
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Crisis and Risk Communication

desc: Issues in the past, present and future of film, television and related media. Screens are examined as media that represent and shape values and culture, as technologies that are produced and purchased, and as objects that are regulated through policy.
name: COMS 4313
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Screen Studies

desc: How communication occurs in conjunction with the built environment, with special attention to cultural artefacts such as houses, schools, factories, prisons, office buildings, roads, parks, and the urban (and suburban) environment. Various models, theories, and philosophies of the built environment are considered.
name: COMS 4315
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and the Built Environment

desc: Overview of Indigenous global media exploring film and film festivals, television networks, media arts, and the Internet. We will discuss struggles over mediated self-representation as well as debates over what constitutes Indigenous media relating to aesthetics, community affiliation, and identity.
name: COMS 4316
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Indigenous Media in Global Contexts

desc: Critical and institutional approaches to the expansion of digital media in the context of international media regulation, globalization, media concentration and ownership, and the global flows of networked communication and information.
name: COMS 4317
prereq_text: Fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Digital Media and Global Network Society

desc: This hands-on course teaches students how to develop, design, and execute a public affairs strategy. Emphasis on understanding the interaction between public institutions and stakeholders and how effective public affairs strategies can be designed to help organizations achieve goals through public or opinion leader persuasion.
name: COMS 4337
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Public Affairs Strategies

desc: Public interest and policy battles over critical internet resources and implications for development of the internet, citizens’ rights and freedoms, the economy, and democratic culture; common carriage, privacy, security and surveillance, access, speech rights, and diversity of information sources.
name: COMS 4401
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Global Internet Policy and Governance

desc: Key approaches to the study of media as industries and how economics, markets and technologies intersect with social choices, politics and power to shape how decisions are made about the design, ownership, organization and control of media.
name: COMS 4403
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Digital Media Industries

desc: How notions of identity are changing as we conduct our lives through networked media and communication such as social media, online search, the Internet of Things, and wearable devices. Subjectivity, personhood, posthumanism, algorithmic control, and privacy.
name: COMS 4405
prereq_text: Fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: The Networked Self

desc: The contemporary open government movement; how communication can be used to improve governance and to foster a more collaborative relationship between governments and citizens. Access to information, the challenges of open data, expectations of transparency, and models of citizen engagement/consultation.
name: COMS 4406
prereq_text: Fourth-year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM and BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Open Government and Communication

desc: Theoretical perspectives, ethical problems, and contemporary issues relevant to communication and data studies. Students will critically examine the rise of ‘big data’ and ‘datafication’ as socio-technical phenomena that have become a crucial part of our communication landscape.
name: COMS 4407
prereq_text: Fourth-year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Critical Data Studies

desc: Contemporary trends affecting creative work in cultural industries. How careers in the arts, culture and media are increasingly desirable as a way for individual workers to find personal fulfillment and as a means of reinvigorating post-industrial economies.
name: COMS 4408
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Creative Work

desc: Critical examination of the history, development, and expansion of mobile media and its impact on culture, connectivity, and practice; locative media practices, geo-coding, wireless communication, mobile technologies, and user experience in everyday life.
name: COMS 4410
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Mobile Media

desc: The ways in which computerized algorithms engage in the traditional work of culture: the sorting, classifying, and hierarchizing of people, places, objects, and ideas to produce new habits of thought, conduct, expression, and material outcomes.
name: COMS 4411
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Algorithmic Culture

desc: Games as media. The history of gaming and mediated play in terms of technology and form, industry, labour, gender and subcultural practice.
name: COMS 4412
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BPAPM related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Game Studies

desc: This workshop introduces practice-based tools and techniques relevant in contemporary professional communication, such as basic web development, podcasting, and digital photography.
name: COMS 4501
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Co.M.S. Honours and permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Digital Media Production

desc: In this workshop students learn to write compelling stories for the digital age. They engage with examples of great storytelling across print and online platforms, from magazines and newspapers to blogs and podcasts, to gain a deeper understanding of what makes some stories stand out.
name: COMS 4502
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Co.M.S. Honours and permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Storytelling in the Digital Age

desc: This workshop introduces a range of methods and practices in data mining and analytics. Techniques include data and text mining, data analysis (including sentiment and social network analysis), data visualization and modeling. Opportunity to work with analytics and mapping software on students' own projects.
name: COMS 4503
prereq_text: COMS 3001 and fourth-year standing in B.Co.M.S. Honours and permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Visualizing Social Media: Hashtags, keywords, & conversations

desc: This workshop introduces the challenges of conceptualizing and conducting public consultations. This includes audience or participant selection, a range of consultation techniques and formats, marketing and communication, analysis, as well as an awareness of policies and regulations governing consultations.
name: COMS 4504
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Co.M.S. Honours and permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Engaging the Public: Stakeholders, participation & consultation

desc: In this workshop students develop skills in professional written communication, such as press releases, blogs, op-eds, policy briefs, and speeches. Students will also hone their public speaking skills presenting their written work in different formats.
name: COMS 4505
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Co.M.S. Honours and permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Professional Writing and Speaking

desc: This workshop introduces the stages of event management for potential community partners. This includes conceptualization, marketing and sponsorships, production and financing, to risk management.
name: COMS 4506
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Co.M.S. Honours and permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Event Management and Community Partnerships

desc: Historical and contemporary ways in which children and youth relate to the media and popular culture.
name: COMS 4602
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Children, Youth and Media

desc: The impact of various forms of diasporic communication on the shaping of contemporary national and international society.
name: COMS 4603
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Diaspora and Communication

desc: Critical examination of the intersection of media and gender, including constructions of femininity, masculinity, and other issues of sexuality.
name: COMS 4604
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media, Gender and Sexuality

desc: Critical examination of how issues of race and ethnicity intersect with contemporary media.
name: COMS 4605
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Media, Race and Ethnicity

desc: Key theories and concepts that have shaped the study of global media and its impact on popular cultures around the world.
name: COMS 4606
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations), or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Global Media and Popular Culture

desc: Food in and as communication. Food and identity, food and culture, food environments, food systems, food politics, and food and community development.
name: COMS 4607
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Communication and Food

desc: How hearing and listening practices have changed over time, and the role of sound technology in shaping our understanding of each other, our world, and ourselves.
name: COMS 4608
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Sound Studies

desc: A selected topic not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topic varies from year to year. Check with the Communication and Media Studies program regarding the topic offered.
name: COMS 4800
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing in Communication and Media Studies or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: COMS
title: Special Topic in Communication and Media Studies

desc: The Honours Research Essay (HRE) provides eligible students with an opportunity to complete an independent research essay under the supervision of a faculty member. The HRE must be completed over two consecutive academic terms, beginning in the fall term.
name: COMS 4908
prereq_text: fourth year honours standing in Communication and Media Studies (including BGInS related specializations), with a CGPA of 10.0 or higher, or permission of the Undergraduate Supervisor.
subject: COMS
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: Development of competence in written and oral communication in computer science. Focus on professional written documents (reports, technical descriptions, manuals, proposals, memos, letters) and related oral work (oral communication in university and workplace settings). Attendance and participation are compulsory.
name: CCDP 2000
prereq_text: enrolment in Bachelor of Computer Science and successful completion of all ESLR requirements. This course may not be taken concurrently with any ESLA course.
subject: CCDP
title: Communication Skills for Computer Science Students

desc: Development of competence in written and oral communication in relation to network design, development, and management. Focus on technical reports, proposals, and other related project documents; formal and informal oral presentations.
name: CCDP 2004
prereq_text: restricted to students with second-year standing in the B.I.T. degree program.
subject: CCDP
title: Communication Skills for NET

desc: Development of competence in written and oral communication in engineering. Focus on professional written documents (proposals, technical explanations, research reports, summaries); written responses to engineering communications; related oral work. Attendance and participation are compulsory.
name: CCDP 2100
prereq_text: restricted to students with second-year standing in the Bachelor of Engineering program. All ESL requirements must be successfully completed; this course may not be taken concurrently with any ESLA course. Not repeatable for credit when successfully completed with a grade of C or higher.
subject: CCDP
title: Communication Skills for Engineering Students

desc: Development of competence in written and oral communication related to multimedia design. Needs analyses, use-case scenarios, development and management of content, technical reports, and related project documents; oral presentations.
name: CCDP 3003
prereq_text: restricted to students with second-year standing in the B.I.T. degree program.
subject: CCDP
title: Communication Skills for IMD

desc: Development of competence in written and oral communication in relation to information resource management. Focus on reports, proposals, technical documentation and other related project documents. Also covers formal and informal oral presentations.
name: CCDP 3006
prereq_text: restricted to students with second-year standing in the B.I.T. degree program.
subject: CCDP
title: Communication Skills for IRM

desc: Development of competence in written and oral communication. Focus on technical reports, proposals, and other related project documents; formal and informal oral presentations.
name: CCDP 3008
prereq_text: Restricted to students with second-year standing in the B.I.T. degree program.
subject: CCDP
title: Communication Skills for OSS

desc: An introduction to computational thinking and its applications to the arts and social sciences. Students will gain computational thinking skills by exploring data representation, basic programming concepts, a selection of algorithms, and advanced usage of software packages for the arts and social sciences.
name: COMP 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Computational Thinking for Arts and Social Science Students

desc: A first course in programming, emphasizing problem solving and computational thinking. Topics include pseudocode, variables, conditionals, iteration, arrays, objects, functions, sorting, searching, and simulation.
name: COMP 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Computer Science I

desc: A second course in programming emphasizing problem solving and computational thinking in an object-oriented language. Topics include abstraction, mutable data structures, methods, inheritance, polymorphism, recursion, program efficiency, testing and debugging.
name: COMP 1006
prereq_text: COMP 1005 or COMP 1405.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Computer Science II

desc: Math for building 3D games. Points, vectors, normals. Dot and cross products. Transformations and inverses in left- and right-handed systems. Uses for controlling objects, cameras, and texture manipulation. Bounding boxes, planes, frustums for collision detection and visibility, fast billboarding techniques, point and sphere sweeping. Quaternions.
name: COMP 1008
prereq_text: one Grade 12 university preparation mathematics course.
subject: COMP
title: Math for Game Programmers

desc: A first course in programming for B.C.S. students emphasizing problem solving and computational thinking. Topics include pseudocode, variables, conditionals, iteration, arrays, objects, functions, sorting, searching, and simulation.
name: COMP 1405
prereq_text: restricted to students registered in the B.C.S. program, combined Honours in Computer Science and Mathematics, Honours Computer Mathematics, and Honours Computer Statistics.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Computer Science I

desc: A second course in programming for BCS students, emphasizing problem solving and computational thinking in an object-oriented language. Topics include abstraction, mutable data structures, methods, inheritance, polymorphism, recursion, program efficiency, testing and debugging.
name: COMP 1406
prereq_text: COMP 1005 or COMP 1405. Restricted to students registered in the B.C.S. program, combined Honours in Computer Science and Mathematics, Honours Computer Mathematics, and Honours Computer Statistics.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Computer Science II

desc: Introduction to computer game programming interfaces. Topics may include: game balance and level design; storytelling and narrative; basic game architecture; sprite-based games and isometric games; representation of scenes; user interaction; architecture of game consoles; development tools for game consoles; interaction with game peripherals.
name: COMP 1501
prereq_text: COMP 1005 or COMP 1405.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Computer Game Design

desc: Introduction to developing mobile applications using the Mac OS X platform. Topics include: the Objective-C programming language; development tools; framework API's; and the Quartz graphic system. Extensive practical experience with development for Apple mobile devices such as the iPhone.
name: COMP 1601
prereq_text: COMP 1005 or COMP 1405.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Mobile Application Development

desc: Introduction to discrete mathematics and discrete structures. Topics include: propositional logic, predicate calculus, set theory, complexity of algorithms, mathematical reasoning and proof techniques, recurrences, induction, finite automata and graph theory. Material is illustrated through examples from computing.
name: COMP 1805
prereq_text: one Grade 12 university preparation mathematics course.
subject: COMP
title: Discrete Structures I

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. This course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the B.C.S.
name: COMP 1910
prereq_text: Permission of the School and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the BCS.
name: COMP 1911
prereq_text: COMP 1910 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: Introduction to system-level programming with fundamental OS concepts, procedures, primitive data types, user-defined types. Topics may include process management, memory management, process coordination and synchronization, inter-process communication, file systems, networking, pointers, heap and stack memory management, and system/library calls.
name: COMP 2401
prereq_text: (COMP 1006 or COMP 1406 or SYSC 2004) with a minimum grade of C-.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Systems Programming

desc: Introduction to the design and implementation of abstract data types and to complexity analysis of data structures. Topics include: stacks, queues, lists, trees and graphs. Special attention is given to abstraction, interface specification and hierarchical design using an object-oriented programming language.
name: COMP 2402
prereq_text: (COMP 1006 or COMP 1406 or SYSC 2004) with a minimum grade of C-.
subject: COMP
title: Abstract Data Types and Algorithms

desc: Introduction to object-oriented software development, with emphasis on the design and implementation of maintainable, reusable software. Topics include abstraction, modularity, encapsulation, and an introduction to design patterns.
name: COMP 2404
prereq_text: COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Software Engineering

desc: Introduction to Internet application development; emphasis on computer science fundamentals of technologies underlying web applications. Topics include: scripting and functional languages, language-based virtual machines, database query languages, remote procedure calls over the Internet, and performance and security concerns in modern distributed applications.
name: COMP 2406
prereq_text: (COMP 1006 or COMP 1406 or SYSC 2004) with a minimum grade of C-.
subject: COMP
title: Fundamentals of Web Applications

desc: Topics may include: user interaction in multiplayer games, representation of animated scenes, tools for game character development, special effects, sound programming, game AI, motion planning and control, collision detection and physics, digital rights management.
name: COMP 2501
prereq_text: COMP 1501, COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-, and MATH 1104.
subject: COMP
title: Computer Game Design and Development

desc: Development of applications for mobile environments taking advantage of gesture-based input and using location and presence services. Topics include introduction to low-level network services and mobile platforms, description of architectural patterns, principles of mobile development and interaction styles for network service usage.
name: COMP 2601
prereq_text: COMP 1601.
subject: COMP
title: Mobile Applications

desc: An introduction to the field of mobile robots and their applications from a computer science perspective. The course will discuss common robot programming architectures and strategies. Students will build various robot configurations and experiment with a variety of sensors using behavior-based programming.
name: COMP 2801
prereq_text: (COMP 1006 or COMP 1406 or SYSC 2004) with a minimum grade of C-.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Robotics

desc: A second course in discrete mathematics and discrete structures. Topics include: counting, sequences and sums, discrete probability, basic statistics, recurrence relations, randomized algorithms. Material is illustrated through examples from computing.
name: COMP 2804
prereq_text: COMP 1805 with a minimum grade of C-, or permission of the School of Computer Science for those in Combined Honours in Computer Science and Mathematics.
subject: COMP
title: Discrete Structures II

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the B.C.S.
name: COMP 2910
prereq_text: COMP 1911 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the BCS.
name: COMP 2911
prereq_text: COMP 2910 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: Operating system implementation course stressing fundamental issues in design and how they relate to modern computer architectures. Assignments involve the modification and extension of a multitasking operating system.
name: COMP 3000
prereq_text: COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C- and (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100).
subject: COMP
title: Operating Systems

desc: The structure, organization and design of the phases of a compiler are considered: lexical translators, syntactical translators, scope handlers, type checkers, code generators and optimizers. Components of a compiler will be implemented.
name: COMP 3002
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100).
subject: COMP
title: Compiler Construction

desc: Development of object-oriented software systems: theory and practice. Topics include: Computer ethics, software development processes, requirement specification, class and scenario modeling, state modeling, UML, design patterns, traceability. Students are to complete a team project.
name: COMP 3004
prereq_text: COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-, (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) with a minimum grade of C-, and (COMP 2406 or SYSC 4504).
subject: COMP
title: Object-Oriented Software Engineering

desc: Introduces students to concepts of database management systems, database design and file structures. Topics include: entity-relationship modeling and object oriented database design, data models (relational, network and object oriented), the relational algebra, SQL, normalization theory, physical data organization, object oriented databases and OQL.
name: COMP 3005
prereq_text: COMP 1805 with a minimum grade of C-, and either COMP 2402 or (SYSC 2004 and SYSC 2100).
subject: COMP
title: Database Management Systems

desc: An introduction to alternative programming paradigms such as functional, constraint-based, concurrent, and logic programming.
name: COMP 3007
prereq_text: COMP 1805 with a minimum grade of C-, and either COMP 2402 or (SYSC 2004 and SYSC 2100).
subject: COMP
title: Programming Paradigms

desc: Fundamentals of the underlying theories, design principles, development and evaluation practices of human-computer interaction (HCI). Topics may include: theories of interaction, user interface frameworks, desktop, web, mobile, and immersive applications, usability inspection and testing methods, and qualitative and quantitative approaches to HCI research.
name: COMP 3008
prereq_text: (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and (COMP 2406 or SYSC 4504).
subject: COMP
title: Human-Computer Interaction

desc: An overview of computer graphics covering rendering, modeling, and animation. Topics include geometric primitives and modeling; image formation algorithms such as ray tracing and the Z-buffer; lighting, shading, and texture; and introduction to physics-based animation and character animation.
name: COMP 3009
prereq_text: COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-, (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100), MATH 1007, and MATH 1104.
subject: COMP
title: Computer Graphics

desc: Principles and tools used in Artificial Intelligence. Fundamentals of Knowledge Representation and Reinforcement Learning and Nature-Based computing. Methods for non-adversarial problem solving including non-exhaustive and heuristic-based strategies for searching the state space. Methods for adversarial problem solving, modeled as two-person and multi-person games.
name: COMP 3106
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100) and (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and COMP 2804.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence

desc: Practical aspects of cryptography. Pseudo random number generation, symmetric cryptography (stream and block ciphers), modes of operation, hash functions, message and entity authentication protocols, zero knowledge, pitfalls deploying public-key encryption and digital signatures, key distribution, secret-sharing.
name: COMP 3109
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100) and COMP 2804.
subject: COMP
title: Applied Cryptography and Authentication

desc: This is an introductory course to the field of Network Computing. Topics include: Protocol Architectures and Internetworking, Types of Networks, Communication Protocols, End-System and Network Traffic Management, Structure of Routing and Congestion Control.
name: COMP 3203
prereq_text: COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-, and (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100).
subject: COMP
title: Principles of Computer Networks

desc: Technical communication for computer science majors, concentrating on writing scientific papers and technical reports. Principles of clarity and precision in writing and communication. Practical exercises and readings from recent technical publications will be used.
name: COMP 3301
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100) and (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110).
subject: COMP
title: Technical Writing for Computer Science

desc: This practical interdisciplinary course will provide a broad overview of bioinformatics in which computer science and mathematics are applied to solve problems in molecular biology. Topics include gene prediction, sequence alignment, phylogeny, molecular interactions, macromolecular structure prediction and biological databases.
name: COMP 3308
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200, or permission of the Biochemistry Institute.
subject: COMP
title: Bioinformatics

desc: Applications of formal logic in computer science. Symbolic logics such as classical predicate calculus are used to represent domain knowledge, to model computational problems and to solve them by means of automated reasoners. Applications include artificial intelligence, software engineering, data management and hardware verification.
name: COMP 3400
prereq_text: COMP 2804.
subject: COMP
title: Computational Logic and Automated Reasoning

desc: Mathematical concepts of 3D engines. Topics may include: illumination and visibility determination; quaternions; homogeneous coordinates; transforms; ray tracing; bump mapping; portal systems; polygonal techniques; shadows; and linear and rotational physics.
name: COMP 3501
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100) and (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and COMP 2501.
subject: COMP
title: Foundations of Game Programming and Computer Graphics

desc: Algorithm design techniques for modern data sets arising in, for example, data mining, web analytics, epidemic spreads, search engines and social networks. Topics may include: data mining, hashing, streaming, clustering, recommendation systems, link analysis, dimensionality reduction, online, social networking, game theoretic and probabilistic algorithms.
name: COMP 3801
prereq_text: COMP 2804 with a minimum grade of B+.
subject: COMP
title: Algorithms for Modern Data Sets

desc: Theoretical aspects of computer science. Topics include: formal languages and automata theory, computability theory.
name: COMP 3803
prereq_text: COMP 2804.
subject: COMP
title: Introduction to Theory of Computation

desc: An introduction to the design and analysis of algorithms. Topics include: divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, linear programming, greedy algorithms, graph algorithms, NP-completeness.
name: COMP 3804
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100) and either COMP 2804 or (MATH 2007 and MATH 2108).
subject: COMP
title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms I

desc: Enumeration: inclusion and exclusion, recurrence relations, generating functions and applications. Graph theory: connectivity, planarity, Hamilton paths and Euler trails. Error-correcting codes. Designs and finite geometries. Symmetry and counting.
name: COMP 3805
prereq_text: MATH 2100 or a grade of B or higher in MATH 2108 or MATH 3101.
subject: COMP
title: Discrete Structures and Applications (Honours)

desc: Incorporation of basic numerical methods into efficient, reliable software. The course includes examination of existing software systems, e.g. linear systems, non-linear systems, optimization, or differential equations.
name: COMP 3807
prereq_text: A grade of C- or higher in COMP 3806 or MATH 3806.
subject: COMP
title: Mathematical Software

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the B.C.S.
name: COMP 3910
prereq_text: COMP 2911 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the B.C.S.
name: COMP 3911
prereq_text: COMP 3910 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

name: COMP 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: COMP
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: An advanced course emphasizing the principles of distributed operating systems including networking protocols, distributed file systems, remote IPC mechanisms, graphical user interfaces, load balancing, and process migration. Case studies include current "standards" as well as novel systems under development.
name: COMP 4000
prereq_text: (COMP 3000 or SYSC 4001) and (COMP 3203 or SYSC 4602).
subject: COMP
title: Distributed Operating Systems

desc: Overview of distributed computing. Topics include: computational models, communication complexity, design and analysis of distributed algorithms and protocols, fault-tolerant protocols, synchronous computations. Applications may include: communication in data networks, control in distributed system (e.g., election, distributed mutual exclusion), manipulation of distributed data (e.g., ranking).
name: COMP 4001
prereq_text: COMP 1805 with a minimum grade of C-, COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-, and (COMP 2406 or SYSC 4504).
subject: COMP
title: Distributed Computing

desc: The design and implementation of game engines for real-time 3D games including topics such as camera control, environmental effects, articulated models, terrain, vegetation, collision detection, particles, emitters, triggers, portals, waypoints, mirrors, and shadows.
name: COMP 4002
prereq_text: COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110.
subject: COMP
title: Real-Time 3D Game Engines

desc: Concepts and architectures of transaction processing systems and on-line transaction processing, with emphasis on data integration systems. Transaction properties and models, embedded-SQL, active rules, consistency maintenance, serializability, concurrency control, recovery, data integration systems and federated databases, introduction to transactions in web services and workflow systems.
name: COMP 4003
prereq_text: (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and COMP 3005.
subject: COMP
title: Transaction Processing Systems

desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of Software Quality Assurance. Topics include: equivalence partitioning, test-driven testing, unit testing patterns, refactoring, software metrics, requirements engineering, scenario modeling and acceptance testing, model-based testing, state machine testing, software testing theory and tools.
name: COMP 4004
prereq_text: COMP 3004.
subject: COMP
title: Software Quality Assurance

desc: Introduction to parallel architectures, programming languages and algorithms for processor clusters and multi-core processors. Distributed memory architectures, cluster computing, message passing parallel programming, multi-core processors, shared memory parallel programming, use of thread libraries, parallel performance analysis.
name: COMP 4009
prereq_text: (COMP 2402 or SYSC 2100) and (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and COMP 2804.
subject: COMP
title: Programming for Clusters and Multi-Core Processors

desc: The basic ideas and techniques of computer vision. The central theme is reconstructing 3D models from 2D images. Topics include: image formation, image feature extraction, camera models, camera calibration, structure from motion, stereo, recognition, augmented reality, image searching.
name: COMP 4102
prereq_text: (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and (MATH 1104 or MATH 1107).
subject: COMP
title: Computer Vision

desc: A subset of topics in Artificial Intelligence that emphasize algorithms and statistical models that rely on patterns and inference. Some topics include decision trees, dimension reduction, ensemble methods, Support Vector Machines, some of the fundamental aspects of Neural Networks, and clustering.
name: COMP 4105
prereq_text: COMP 3106 and (MATH 1104 or MATH 1107).
subject: COMP
title: Machine Learning

desc: Theory and application of Neural Networks to problems in machine learning. Topics include explanation of the representation, transformation and compression of data, biological models, Hebbian learning and the Perceptron. Modern neural network architectures, including feed forward, recurrent, convolutional and generative adversarial are introduced.
name: COMP 4107
prereq_text: COMP 3106 and (MATH 1104 or MATH 1107).
subject: COMP
title: Neural Networks

desc: Introduction to information security in computer and communications systems, including network, operating systems, web and software security; Passwords, authentication applications, privacy, data integrity, anonymity, secure email, IP security, security infrastructures, firewalls, viruses, intrusion detection, network attacks.
name: COMP 4108
prereq_text: (COMP 3000 or SYSC 4001) and COMP 3109.
subject: COMP
title: Computer Systems Security

desc: Application of computational techniques to support business activities, such as decision making, business understanding, data analysis, business process automation, learning from data, producing and using data-centric business models, ontology-based data access and integration, data quality assessment and cleaning and use of contextual data.
name: COMP 4111
prereq_text: COMP 3005.
subject: COMP
title: Data Management for Business Intelligence

desc: Through recent advances in navigation systems, mobile devices, and new software such as Mapquest and Google Earth, GIS is becoming increasingly important and exciting from a CS perspective. This course lays the algorithmic foundations to understand, use and further this technology.
name: COMP 4202
prereq_text: COMP 3804 or MATH 3804.
subject: COMP
title: Computational Aspects of Geographic Information Systems

desc: An introduction to wireless networks covering both networking issues and security aspects of modern wireless environments. Fundamentals of mobile LANs, ad hoc, sensor networks, secure routing, searching, clustering, multicasting, localization, mobile IP/TCP, confidentiality, key establishment, authentication, broadcasting, RFIDs, and rogue attacks.
name: COMP 4203
prereq_text: COMP 3203 or SYSC 4602.
subject: COMP
title: Wireless Networks and Security

desc: Convergence of social and technological networks. Interplay between information content, entities creating it and technologies supporting it. Structure and analysis of such networks, models abstracting their properties, techniques link analysis, search, mechanism design, power laws, cascading, clustering and connections with work in social sciences.
name: COMP 4206
prereq_text: COMP 1805, (COMP 2401 with a minimum grade of C-) and (COMP 2406 or SYSC 4504).
subject: COMP
title: Evolving Information Networks

desc: Modeling and simulation of metabolic and regulatory networks towards understanding complex and highly dynamic cellular systems. Biotechnological applications include metabolic engineering, synthetic biology, and drug discovery.
name: COMP 4308
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 or permission of the Biochemistry Institute.
subject: COMP
title: Computational Systems Biology

desc: A practical course on advanced facilities of game engines. Such facilities include notions such as physics engines, shadow mapping, lighting with thousands of lights, relief mapping, ambient occlusion, water flow, deferred rendering, occlusion culling, water effects, mirrors, and screen space reflection.
name: COMP 4501
prereq_text: COMP 3501.
subject: COMP
title: Advanced Facilities for Real-Time Games

desc: Introduction to the principles and practice of creation, delivery and analysis of multimedia content in web-based systems. Topics include analysis of webs of documents, social network analysis, recommender systems and problems of trust, reputation and influence in e-commerce systems.
name: COMP 4601
prereq_text: (COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and (COMP 2406 or COMP 2601 or SYSC 4504).
subject: COMP
title: Intelligent Web-based Information Systems

desc: Introduction to virtual communities, overlay networks and social networking. Topics include architectural principles for heterogeneous social networking platforms, trust and reputation as social concepts, agent-based computing, and extraction of trends and patterns from information exchanged between community members.
name: COMP 4602
prereq_text: ((COMP 2404 or SYSC 3010 or SYSC 3110) and (COMP 2406 or SYSC 4504)) or COMP 2601.
subject: COMP
title: Social Networking

desc: Recursive functions and computability, algorithms, Church's thesis, Turing machines, computational logic, NP-completeness.
name: COMP 4803
prereq_text: MATH 2100 or COMP 3805 or permission of the School.
subject: COMP
title: Computable Functions

desc: A second course on the design and analysis of algorithms. Topics include: advanced recurrence relations, algebraic complexity, advanced graph algorithms, amortized analysis, algorithms for NP-complete problems, randomized algorithms.
name: COMP 4804
prereq_text: COMP 3804 or MATH 3804.
subject: COMP
title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms II

desc: Finite automata and regular expressions, properties of regular sets, context-free grammars, pushdown automata, deterministic context-free languages. Turing machines, the Chomsky hierarchy. Undecidability, intractable problems.
name: COMP 4805
prereq_text: COMP 3805 or MATH 3106 or MATH 3158 (or MATH 3100) or permission of the School.
subject: COMP
title: Theory of Automata

desc: Study of matrix inversion techniques; techniques of finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors, solution of systems of linear equations; direct and indirect methods, their comparison and error analysis; applications in optimization and other areas.
name: COMP 4806
prereq_text: MATH 2152 or MATH 1102 (no longer offered) or MATH 2107; and MATH 2000 and COMP 3806, or permission of the School.
subject: COMP
title: Numerical Linear Algebra

desc: Selected topics in Computer Science offered by members of the School of Computer Science.
name: COMP 4900
prereq_text: permission of the School of Computer Science.
subject: COMP
title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science

desc: Independent study under the supervision of a member of the School of Computer Science, open only to students in the B.C.S. program. Students are required to obtain their supervisor's written approval prior to registration and are limited to two such courses in their program.
name: COMP 4901
prereq_text: permission of the School of Computer Science.
subject: COMP
title: Directed Studies

desc: Under the supervision of a faculty member, Honours students complete a major Computer Science project in fourth year. Permission to register is granted once an approved project proposal is submitted to the Department. See deadlines and details on the School web site.
name: COMP 4905
prereq_text: registration in the B.C.S. Honours program or one of the Combined Computer Science Honours programs and permission of the School of Computer Science.
subject: COMP
title: Honours Project

desc: An independent research project under the direct supervision of a faculty advisor. Permission to register is granted once an approved project proposal is submitted to the School of Computer Science. Evaluation is based on a written thesis and a poster presentation.
name: COMP 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in a B.C.S. Honours program with a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in the major and permission of the School of Computer Science.
subject: COMP
title: Honours Thesis

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the B.C.S.
name: COMP 4910
prereq_text: COMP 3911 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: The internship exposes students to industrial software development via placement in a local enterprise. The course may only be taken by students participating in one of the School's industrial partnerships and can only be used as a free elective in the B.C.S.
name: COMP 4911
prereq_text: COMP 4910 and registration in internship option.
subject: COMP
title: Internship

desc: Overview of the field, including the foundational approaches of criminology and criminal justice, crime as an object of study; criminal law and criminality in Canada; (neo) classical, aetiological and social reaction perspectives; alternative criminologies.
name: CRCJ 1000
prereq_text: None
subject: CRCJ
title: Introduction to Criminology and Criminal Justice

desc: Comprehensive survey of the plurality of criminological theories, from phrenology to contemporary theories concerned with issues related to crime and punishment. Students are encouraged to develop critical and reflexive thinking on various criminological issues and theories.
name: CRCJ 2100
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000 and second-year standing.
subject: CRCJ
title: Criminological Theories

desc: Survey of contemporary criminological and criminal justice issues, ranging from criminalization, crime prevention, and surveillance strategies to debates about the criminal justice system, punishment, and reintegration. Specific topics will vary from year to year.
name: CRCJ 2200
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000 and second-year standing.
subject: CRCJ
title: Contemporary Issues in Criminology & Criminal Justice

desc: Methods used conducting quantitative research. Topics include measuring and manipulating variables, reliability, validity, sampling, experimental, quasi-experimental designs and ethics.
name: CRCJ 3001
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000 and third-year standing in the B.A Honours program in Criminology and Criminal Justice.
subject: CRCJ
title: Quantitative Methods in Criminology

desc: Methods used conducting qualitative research. Topics include field research, interviewing, ethnographic research, content analysis and ethics.
name: CRCJ 3002
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000 and third-year standing in the B.A Honours program in Criminology and Criminal Justice.
subject: CRCJ
title: Qualitative Methods in Criminology

desc: Theories and case studies addressing contemporary efforts to police the world of (in)securities. Emphasis on Canadian dynamics within these broader transformations.
name: CRCJ 3100
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, third-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Policing (in)Security

desc: This course explores issues related to Indigenous peoples, the criminal justice system and community with an emphasis on Indigenous scholarship and perspectives on criminology and crime.
name: CRCJ 3200
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, INDG 1010, or INDG 1011, third year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Indigeneity, Coloniality, and Crime

desc: The topics of this course may vary from year to year, and are announced in advance of registration.
name: CRCJ 3201
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, third-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Selected Criminological Topics

desc: The topics of this course may vary from year to year, and are announced in advance of registration.
name: CRCJ 3202
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, third-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Selected Criminological Topics

desc: Through a field placement in an agency setting, students are provided the opportunity to obtain practical involvement in various aspects of criminal justice. In the seminar class, discussions, presentations and assignments integrate applied, theoretical and empirical knowledge. CRCJ 3901 may not be repeated.
name: CRCJ 3901
prereq_text: Third-year standing in a B.A. in Criminology and Criminal Justice, including all of the 1000- and 2000- level requirements in the Major CGPA, and permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Practicum in Criminology I

desc: Through a field placement in an agency setting, students are provided the opportunity to obtain practical involvement in various aspects of criminal justice. In the seminar class, discussions, presentations and assignments integrate applied, theoretical and empirical knowledge. CRCJ 3902 may not be repeated.
name: CRCJ 3902
prereq_text: Third-year Honours standing in Criminology and Criminal Justice, including all of the 1000- and 2000- level requirements in the Major CGPA, and permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Practicum in Criminology II

desc: Examination of a special topic in criminology. Topics to be announced in advance of registration each year.
name: CRCJ 4001
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Special Topics in Criminology

desc: Examination of a special topic in criminology. Topics to be announced in advance of registration each year.
name: CRCJ 4002
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Special Topics in Criminology

desc: This course will explore the jury system in Canada and other countries. Jury selection, deliberation, and instructions will be discussed, in addition to a number of legal and extra-legal influences on jury decision-making.
name: CRCJ 4100
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Psychology of the Jury

desc: This seminar explores the policing of consensual sexual practices, paying particular attention to the theorization of consent, harm, liberation and agency in a sexual and legal context.
name: CRCJ 4200
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Policing Sex

desc: Introduction to social control from early theorizations linking social control to the genesis of the self, to preoccupations with the sorting of humans and the guiding of their conducts, including contemporary engagements with moralization, penal intensification, sovereign exceptionality, and immigration control.
name: CRCJ 4300
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Social Control

desc: This course examines the relationship between sensations, emotions, affect, crime, criminalization, social control, and penality. It questions the rational/emotional binary and investigates how shame, humiliation, fear, panic, pain, pleasure, disgust, empathy and revenge, relate to offender motivation, criminalization, victimization, adjudication, and punishment.
name: CRCJ 4400
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Crime, Emotions, and The Senses

desc: A participatory class that explores how social and artist movements engage with issues of justice and injustice. Features group work, some off-campus classes during course hours, guest speakers.
name: CRCJ 4500
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Art of (in)Justice

desc: This introductory seminar on the sociology of punishment proposes an overview of theoretical perspectives animating its contemporary forms. This overview prepares the ground for a survey of contemporary scholarship and issues in the sociology of punishment.
name: CRCJ 4600
prereq_text: CRCJ 1000, CRCJ 2100, fourth-year standing, and enrollment in a B.A. or Minor in Criminology and Criminal Justice, or by permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Sociologies of Punishment

desc: A research project conducted under the direct supervision of a faculty adviser from Criminology and Criminal Justice, Psychology, Law or Sociology. Mandatory workshops and symposiums are scheduled during the year.
name: CRCJ 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.A. Honours program in Criminology and Criminal Justice with a CGPA of 10.00 or better in the Major and permission of the Institute.
subject: CRCJ
title: Honours Thesis

desc: Foundations and central tenets of critical race theory, its interdisciplinary debates, applications, and evolutions. Historical roots of oppression, white settler-colonialism, understanding of privilege and power, social construction of race, socio-political conditions producing systemic and institutional racism, intersections with sexism, homophobia, transphobia, classism, and ableism.
name: CRST 2001
prereq_text: One of WGST 1808, DBST 1001, HUMR 1001, FYSM 1402 or FYSM 1403, OR permission of the Institute.
subject: CRST
title: Introduction to Critical Race Studies

desc: Interdisciplinary seminar on race, colonialism and feminisms including theories of racial and cultural difference, structures of privilege and power, and forms of resistance. Intersectional theoretical approaches to anti-colonial and feminist analyses of racial subjugation, and engagements with Black, Indigenous and women of colour feminisms.
name: CRST 4001
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing and 1.0 credit in Women's and Gender Studies or permission of the Institute of Women's and Gender Studies.
subject: CRST
title: Advanced Critical Race Studies

desc: An introduction to the principal debates in and approaches to the Digital Humanities.
name: DIGH 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Introduction to Digital Humanities

desc: A multidisciplinary survey of core theories, methodologies and tools within the Digital Humanities. Assignments will include collaborative work and applied projects.
name: DIGH 2002
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Digital Humanities: Theory and Method

desc: Principal theories and methods used by Science and Technology Studies (STS) scholars to examine the social and cultural shaping of technology. The substantive focus of the course is on the design, development, production, diffusion, consumption and use of technology.
name: DIGH 2035
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or ANTH 1001 or ANTH 1002.
subject: DIGH
title: Technology, Culture and Society

desc: An examination of various approaches to analyzing digital media and their role in the production and consumption of contemporary cultural forms and practices. Students will reflect upon their use of digital media and the influence they have on their lives and popular culture, more generally.
name: DIGH 2705
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or ANTH 1001 or ANTH 1002.
subject: DIGH
title: Popular Culture in the Digital Age

desc: A multidisciplinary course focused on the social, economic and political dimensions of the book in its manuscript, print and digital forms.
name: DIGH 3001
prereq_text: third-year standing, or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: The Book in the Digital Age

desc: Principal theories and methods used by Science and Technology Studies scholars to examine the social construction of scientific knowledge. Topics may include the demarcation of science from non-science, the relationship between experts and laypersons, and the study of scientific controversies.
name: DIGH 3035
prereq_text: DIGH 2035 or SOCI 2035 and third-year standing.
subject: DIGH
title: Science, Culture and Society: Social Studies of Science

desc: Exploration of the roles of human and artificial cognition in the digital humanities. Topics may include virtual and augmented reality as applied to the humanities, cognitive issues in hypertext and hypermedia; linguistic and philosophical considerations in digital media, cognitive narratology, and artificial intelligence.
name: DIGH 3704
prereq_text: CGSC 1001; CGSC 2001 or DIGH 2001; and third-year standing.
subject: DIGH
title: Cognitive Science and the Digital Humanities

desc: The digital representation of history, exploring the approaches, issues, and methods of working in this environment. Topics may include gaming, virtual environments, digital research tools, public digital history. (Field e).
name: DIGH 3812
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: DIGH
title: Digital History

desc: This course applies the creative use of information and media/computing technologies to address the digital cultural heritage issues of public historians, archaeologists, and anthropologists. Topics may include webscraping, data mining, designing and implementing research databases, and visual storytelling of those results. (Field e).
name: DIGH 3814
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: DIGH
title: Crafting Digital History

desc: A study of current issues and debates in Digital Humanities.
name: DIGH 4001
prereq_text: DIGH 2002 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Studies in Digital Humanities

desc: A study of new developments in digital media and culture, and how they affect our understanding of literary modes, genres and textuality, including notions of authorship and reading strategies. Topics will vary from year to year.
name: DIGH 4002
prereq_text: DIGH 2002 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Digital Culture and the Text I

desc: A study of new developments in digital media and culture, and how they affect our understanding of literary modes, genres and textuality, including notions of authorship and reading strategies. Topics will vary from year to year.
name: DIGH 4003
prereq_text: DIGH 2002 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Digital Culture and the Text II

desc: This workshop will provide students with the opportunity to complete an individual or collaborative capstone project in the Digital Humanities.
name: DIGH 4004
prereq_text: DIGH 2002 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Digital Humanities Workshop

desc: Practical experience gained by working on projects under the supervision of the staff of a participating public- or private-sector institution or organization, including a final written assignment or equivalent project. A maximum of 1.0 practicum credit may be applied towards degree requirements.
name: DIGH 4005
prereq_text: DIGH 2002 and fourth-year standing, or permission of the College of Humanities.
subject: DIGH
title: Digital Humanities Practicum

desc: Challenging negative stereotypes of disability by allowing students the opportunity to explore disability through many different venues including history, theory, culture, ethics, policy and disability rights. Reframing disability from personal tragedy to issues of oppression, access, inclusion and equality.
name: DBST 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: DBST
title: Introduction to Disability Studies

desc: Interdisciplinary approach to the debates and theories that challenge the normative values, knowledge sources, and cultural representations of disablement in society.
name: DBST 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing and DBST 1001.
subject: DBST
title: Disabling Society

desc: The complex legal, policy and discursive frameworks that shape the lives of persons with disability and the history of the emergence of the disability rights movement as a scholarly and activist challenge to, and renegotiation of, those frameworks.
name: DBST 3001
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: DBST
title: Disability Studies: Policy and Activism

desc: Course engages contemporary disability theory, culture, and activism to consider bodily difference and its relation to the workings of power and social control, accessibility, normalization, ableism, and medicalization. Students will gain an understanding of the contemporary debates, theories, and methodologies of critical disability studies.
name: DBST 3060
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: DBST
title: Critical Disability Studies

desc: A critical introduction to Deaf community and culture as they relate to a social model of disability, to ethnicity, and to issues of diversity and inclusion. Discourse analysis of research and policy in education for Deaf students from early childhood and beyond.
name: DBST 3301
prereq_text: third-year standing in Linguistics or Applied Linguistics and Discourse Studies or enrolment in the Minor in Disability Studies.
subject: DBST
title: Introduction to Deaf Studies

desc: Drawing on theory and research in disabled children’s childhood studies, sociology of childhood, disability studies, and girlhood studies, this course examines the discursive and material constructions of disabled youth and childhood in transnational contexts in relation to emerging neo-colonial, neo-imperialist, and neo-liberal ideologies.
name: DBST 3304
prereq_text: third-year standing in Childhood and Youth Studies or Disability Studies.
subject: DBST
title: Disability and Childhood: Transnational Perspectives

desc: Essays, discussions, and/or examinations based on a bibliography constructed by the student in consultation with an instructor.
name: DBST 3900
prereq_text: third or fourth-year standing in the Disability Studies Minor and a CGPA of 9.0 or higher.
subject: DBST
title: Independent Study

desc: Origin of the Earth, concepts of geological time, and exploration of the interaction and duration of geological processes that shape the surface to deep interior of our planet, the climate, and formation of rocks and earth resources.
name: ERTH 1006
prereq_text: a 4U/M level in Advanced Functions and at least one of Biology, Chemistry, Earth and Space Sciences or Physics are recommended. This course is for students who are enrolled in the Faculty of Science.
subject: ERTH
title: Exploring Planet Earth
