prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering and ELEC 3500 or permission of the Department.
subject: ELEC
title: Advanced Digital Integrated Circuit Design

desc: Overview of sensor technologies with emphasis on devices suitable for integration with silicon integrated circuits. Sensor design and fabrication principles including signal conditioning; discussion of automotive, biomedical, and other instrumentation applications.
name: ELEC 4709
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: ELEC
title: Integrated Sensors

desc: At the discretion of the Engineering Faculty Board, a course dealing with selected advanced topics of interest to students in Biomedical and Electrical, Communications, Computer Systems, Electrical and Software Engineering and Engineering Physics may be offered.
name: ELEC 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: ELEC
title: Special Topics

desc: Student teams develop professional-level experience by applying, honing, integrating, and extending previously acquired knowledge in a major design project. Lectures are devoted to discussing project-related issues and student presentations. A project proposal, interim report, oral presentations, and a comprehensive final report are required.
name: ELEC 4907
prereq_text: ELEC 3907, ECOR 3800, ECOR 4995 (may be taken concurrently) and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: ELEC
title: Engineering Project

desc: Student teams develop professional-level experience by applying, honing, integrating, and extending previously acquired knowledge in a major design project approved for Engineering Physics. Lectures devoted to discussing project-related issues and student presentations. A project proposal, interim report, oral presentations, and comprehensive final report are required.
name: ELEC 4908
prereq_text: ECOR 3800, fourth-year status in Engineering and ECOR 4995 (may be taken concurrently). Certain projects may have additional prerequisites or corequisites.
subject: ELEC
title: Engineering Physics Project

desc: Technology, society and the environment. Graphical design communication: sketching, graphical projections; CAD. Managing data: statistical methods; spreadsheets. Design analysis: matrix programming software; symbolic computer algebra systems. Design process: proposals; reports; presentations; reporting software.
name: ECOR 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: ECOR
title: Introduction to Engineering

desc: Software development as an engineering discipline, using a modern programming language. Language syntax and semantics. Tracing and visualizing program execution. Program style and documentation. Testing and debugging tools and techniques.
name: ECOR 1041
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Computation and Programming

desc: Introduction to designing and implementing numerical algorithms. Container data types: sequences, sets, maps. Modules. Data files. Incremental, iterative development of programs. Number systems: binary, decimal. Digital representation of integers and floating point numbers.
name: ECOR 1042
prereq_text: ECOR 1041 with a minimum grade of C- and MATH 1004 (may be taken concurrently). This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Data Management

desc: Electrical Quantities (Voltage, Charge, Current, Power). Conservation of charge and energy. Mathematical models of simple devices. Elementary circuit theory for passive elements. Thévenin's and superposition theorem. Signal filtering and amplification. Time and frequency domain. Circuit design and simulation.
name: ECOR 1043
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Circuits

desc: Mechatronics applications. Analog to digital signal conversion. Control systems and PID controllers. Input devices, including sensors. Data collection and processing. Output devices, including displays, actuators, and motors. Project design and economics. Environmental Impact of mechatronics engineering. System failures and failsafe design.
name: ECOR 1044
prereq_text: ECOR 1041 with a minimum grade of C- and ECOR 1043 with a minimum grade of C-. This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Mechatronics

desc: Cartesian vector representation of forces. Components of forces. Particle equilibrium and free body diagrams. Moments and cross product. Centre of gravity and centroids. Rigid body equilibrium.
name: ECOR 1045
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Statics

desc: 2D truss analysis (method of joints/sections). Normal stress/strain and shear stress/strain. 2D frames and machines. Internal loads - normal, shear and moment at a point. Shear and moment diagrams.
name: ECOR 1046
prereq_text: ECOR 1045 with a minimum grade of C-. This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Mechanics

desc: Graphs and sketches, flow charts, block diagrams. Visual presentation, projection and perspectives of objects. 3D sketching. Free hand drawing. Reading engineering drawings and schematics. Introduction to scaling, dimensioning and tolerancing. Introduction to CAD.
name: ECOR 1047
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Visual Communication

desc: Kinematics and kinetics of a particle. Principle of work and energy. Conservation of energy, conservative forces, potential energy. Principles of impulse and momentum, conservation of momentum for a system of particles.
name: ECOR 1048
prereq_text: ECOR 1045 with a minimum grade of C-. This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Dynamics

desc: Software development as an engineering discipline, using a modern programming language. Tracing and visualization of program execution. Testing and debugging. Data management: digital representation of numbers; numerical algorithms; storing data in files; container data types: sequences, sets, maps.
name: ECOR 1051
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Fundamentals of Engineering I

desc: Electrical Quantities. Conservation of mass and energy. Mathematical models of simple devices. Elementary circuit theory for passive elements. Signal filtering and amplification. Time and frequency domain. Circuit design and simulation. Digital and analog signals. Mechatronics applications. Output devices. System failures and failsafe design.
name: ECOR 1052
prereq_text: ECOR 1051 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: ECOR
title: Fundamentals of Engineering II

desc: Components of forces. Particle equilibrium and free body diagrams. Moments and cross product. Centre of gravity and centroids. Rigid body equilibrium. 2D Truss analysis (method of joints/sections). Normal stress/strain and Shear stress/strain. 2D frames and machines.
name: ECOR 1053
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Fundamentals of Engineering III

desc: Engineering drawings and schematics. Graphs and sketches, flow charts, block diagrams. Computer‐assisted design. Kinematics/Kinetics of a particle. Principles of work and energy. The Engineering Profession and Act. Organization and time management. Project management. Business, entrepreneurship and intellectual property.
name: ECOR 1054
prereq_text: ECOR 1053 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: ECOR
title: Fundamentals of Engineering IV

desc: Overview of professional activities oriented to the student's discipline of study: Architectural Conservation and Sustainability. Civil and Environmental. Aerospace and Mechanical. Electrical. Engineering Physics. Computer Systems, Communications and Software. Biomedical (Electrical and Mechanical). Sustainable and Renewable Energy.
name: ECOR 1055
prereq_text: This course may not be taken concurrently with ESLA 1300 or ESLA 1500.
subject: ECOR
title: Introduction to Engineering Disciplines I

desc: Selected lectures designed to provide students with exposure to the breadth of Engineering disciplines.
name: ECOR 1056
prereq_text: None
subject: ECOR
title: Introduction to Engineering Disciplines II

desc: Professional Engineers Act. Engineering documentation. History of the profession. Engineering practice: system life cycle, practice within the discipline, designing with others. Health and safety. Engineering Ethics, Equity and Diversity. Introduction to engineering law : Business, Entrepreneurship and Intellectual Property.
name: ECOR 1057
prereq_text: None
subject: ECOR
title: Engineering Profession

desc: Introduction to mechanics. Scalars and vectors. Concurrent forces: resultant and components. Statics of particles. Moments and couples. Force system resultants. Rigid body equilibrium. Frames and machines. Internal forces. Kinematics and kinetics of particles. Conservation theorems: work-energy; impulse-momentum. Centroids and centres of gravity.
name: ECOR 1101
prereq_text: MATH 1004 and MATH 1104.
subject: ECOR
title: Mechanics I

desc: Introduction to engineering problem solving. Defining and modeling problems, designing algorithmic solutions, using procedural programming, selection and iteration constructs, functions, arrays, converting algorithms to a program, testing and debugging. Program style, documentation, reliability. Applications to engineering problems; may include numerical methods, sorting and searching.
name: ECOR 1606
prereq_text: None
subject: ECOR
title: Problem Solving and Computers

desc: Statistics and the design of engineering experiments. Basic exploratory data analysis. Central limit theorem. Hypothesis testing: t-test, chi-square test, type-I and type-II errors, multiple-comparison problem. Statistical bias. Design of experiments: randomization, blocking and replication, randomized blocking designs, factorial design. Statistical software packages.
name: ECOR 2050
prereq_text: 2nd Year Status in Engineering.
subject: ECOR
title: Design and Analysis of Engineering Experiments

desc: Numerical algorithms and tools for engineering and problem solving. Sources of error and error propagation, solution of systems of linear equations, curve fitting, polynomial interpolation and splines, numerical differentiation and integration, root finding, solution of differential equations. Software tools.
name: ECOR 2606
prereq_text: MATH 1005 and (ECOR 1606 or SYSC 1005) and (ECOR 1010 or ELEC 1908).
subject: ECOR
title: Numerical Methods

desc: Students will be asked to reflect on their skills, strengths and weaknesses as preparation for the professional practice course. Engineering students must submit samples of their writing and communications (including, for example, laboratory reports and professional memos).
name: ECOR 2995
prereq_text: None
subject: ECOR
title: Engineering Portfolio

desc: Introduction to engineering economics; cash flow calculations; methods of comparison of alternatives; structural analysis; replacement analysis; public projects; depreciation and income tax; effects of inflation; sensitivity analysis; break-even analysis; decision making under risk and uncertainty.
name: ECOR 3800
prereq_text: third-year status in Engineering or (ECOR 1051, ECOR 1052, ECOR 1053 and ECOR 1054).
subject: ECOR
title: Engineering Economics

desc: Presentations by faculty and external lecturers on the Professional Engineers Act, professional ethics and responsibilities, practice within the discipline and its relationship with other disciplines and to society, health and safety, environmental stewardship, principles and practice of sustainable development. Communication skills are emphasized.
name: ECOR 4995
prereq_text: ECOR 2995 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: ECOR
title: Professional Practice

desc: The first half of an introduction to the principles, styles, and structures of effective writing, including essay writing. Course offered only in Nunavut as part of Certificate in Nunavut Public Service Studies Program.
name: ENGL 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Writing and Language I

desc: The second half of an introduction to the principles, styles, and structures of effective writing, including essay writing. Course offered only in Nunavut as part of Certificate in Nunavut Public Service Studies Program.
name: ENGL 1003
prereq_text: ENGL 1002.
subject: ENGL
title: Writing and Language II

desc: A practical and intensive overview of English grammar designed for students who want to improve their understanding of grammar for their own writing and reading. This is not an ESL course.
name: ENGL 1008
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: English Grammar: Fundamentals

desc: Introduction to the study of literature from a global perspective. Students will be exposed to writers from various locations and to methods for studying literature across national boundaries.
name: ENGL 1009
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Literature in Global Context

desc: An intensive writing course focusing on the formulation and construction of a literary essay.
name: ENGL 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Writing Essays about Literature

desc: The rhetorical principles, skills, and structures necessary for the kind of writing done at the university level. Clear and effective composition as a mode of research, discovery, analysis, and persuasion. Students pursuing the English major or minor should take ENGL 1010 instead of ENGL 1020.
name: ENGL 1020
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Effective Writing

desc: An introductory course whose readings focus on the intersections between literature, law, and criminality. Topics will vary. Consult the English Department website for the current topic.
name: ENGL 1100
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Literature, Law, and Criminality

desc: An introductory course whose readings focus on the intersections between literature, science, and technology. Topics will vary. Consult the English Department website for the current topic.
name: ENGL 1200
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Literature, Science, and Technology

desc: An introductory course whose readings focus on the intersections between literature, psychology, and the mind. Topics will vary. Consult the English Department website for the current topic.
name: ENGL 1300
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Literature, Psychology, and the Mind

desc: An introductory course whose readings focus on the intersections between literature, art, and culture. Topics will vary. Consult the English Department website for the current topic.
name: ENGL 1400
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Literature, Art, and Culture

desc: An introduction to the practice of creative writing, focusing on poetry, the short story, creative non-fiction, and drama. Emphasis is also placed on contextualizing creative writing as an academic discipline, a mode of self-expression, and a professional industry.
name: ENGL 1500
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Introduction to Creative Writing

desc: An introductory course whose readings focus on the intersections between literature and magic. Topics will vary. Consult the English Department website for the current topic.
name: ENGL 1600
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Literature and Magic

desc: An introduction to drama studies, combining attention to theatre history, conventions, and devices, with attention to theatrical practice, and interpretation of selected dramatic texts. Students will develop a vocabulary for speaking and writing with confidence about theatrical productions, theatre practice, and dramatic texts.
name: ENGL 1609
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Introduction to Drama Studies

desc: An introduction to literature and culture in the context of the environmental humanities and climate change.
name: ENGL 1700
prereq_text: None
subject: ENGL
title: Climate Change and the Humanities

desc: An introduction to theories and methods of literary analysis. Through the study of literature, theory, and criticism, students will explore disciplinary history, critical terms, textual analysis, and research methods.
name: ENGL 2005
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Theory and Criticism

desc: A literary study of myths and symbols from oral traditions to contemporary forms through selected interdisciplinary and theoretical approaches.
name: ENGL 2008
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Myth and Symbol

desc: An introduction of the critical study of children’s literature.
name: ENGL 2011
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Children's Literature

desc: An examination of the genre of epic in Greco-Roman antiquity, including a close reading of translations of Homer and Vergil.
name: ENGL 2012
prereq_text: second year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: ENGL
title: Greek and Roman Epic

desc: Study of a selected topic related to popular culture.
name: ENGL 2100
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Topics in Popular Culture

desc: A historical and critical study of the novel.
name: ENGL 2103
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Introduction to the Novel

desc: A course dealing with the rudiments of theatrical performance: voice, movement, improvisation, interpretation. Exercises are based upon examples drawn from classical and contemporary repertoires.
name: ENGL 2104
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Drama Workshop

desc: A historical study of the English language, its structure, variety, and cultural contexts, with an introduction to grammatical terminology and constructions.
name: ENGL 2105
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: History of the English Language

desc: An introduction to the critical study of popular fiction. Topics will vary but may include popular narrative forms such as fantasy, horror, mystery, romance, Young Adult (YA) fiction, etc.
name: ENGL 2106
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Topics in Popular Fiction

desc: A study of the history and traditions of science fiction, speculative fiction, fantasy, and utopia, covering various periods, nationalities, genres, and/or media.
name: ENGL 2107
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Science Fiction

desc: Representations of women and the construction of femininity in selected literary texts, the position of women as readers and authors, and the impact of feminist criticism on literary analysis.
name: ENGL 2108
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Women and Literature

desc: How literature represents, reproduces, and resists cultural notions of gender and sexuality. Topics may include: gender and sexuality in relation to literary history, production, and reception; literature by/about “deviant” or subcultural sexualities and genders.
name: ENGL 2109
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Gender, Sexuality and Literature

desc: This course not only surveys theories about the imagination and creativity but also teaches various rhetorical exercises and strategies for sparking inventive thinking and new ideas to fire the writing process. Consult the English Department's website for detailed information.
name: ENGL 2200
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department. Students in English may take this course only as a free elective.
subject: ENGL
title: Creativity, Imagination, and Writing

desc: This course introduces majors and non-majors to a selection of known and unknown "masterpieces." Texts may be grouped to explore specific themes. Requirements include a variety of assignments but no formal essay. Consult the English Department's website for detailed information.
name: ENGL 2201
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department. Students in English may take this course only as a free elective.
subject: ENGL
title: The Pleasures of Reading

desc: Introduction to a sub-category of speculative fiction that spans from traditional ghost stories and tales of the macabre to the “New Weird”: contemporary writing that overthrows the clichés, conventions, and expectations of fantasy, horror, and science fiction.
name: ENGL 2202
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Weird Fiction

desc: A study of the period between 500 and 1500, with attention to cultural, historical, geographical, and literary contexts.
name: ENGL 2301
prereq_text: Second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Literatures and Cultures 500-1500

desc: A study of the period between 1500 and 1700, with attention to cultural, historical, geographical, and literary contexts.
name: ENGL 2302
prereq_text: Second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Literatures and Cultures 1500-1700

desc: An introduction to the principal debates in and approaches to the Digital Humanities.
name: ENGL 2400
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
