desc: A study of a selected topic in postcolonial and/or diaspora literatures and theories. Themes, authors, and geographical and temporal focus will vary.
name: ENGL 4950
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Topics in Postcolonial and Diaspora Lit. and Theory

desc: A study of the literatures produced by Indigenous storytellers and writers, with a focus on the oral tradition and life writing.
name: ENGL 4960
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Indigenous Literatures I

desc: A study of the contemporary period of Indigenous literature, examining the historical and mythic influences on the literature.
name: ENGL 4961
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Indigenous Literatures II

desc: A study of a selected issue in postcolonial and/or diaspora theory.
name: ENGL 4975
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Issues in Postcolonial Theory

desc: A study of a selected topic in postcolonial literature and culture.
name: ENGL 4976
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENGL
title: Issues in Postcolonial Literature

desc: For students with little or no experience with academic English. Introduction to integrated language strategies, critical thinking, and basic research techniques for success at university. Attendance and participation are compulsory.
name: ESLA 1300
prereq_text: placement by an approved English language proficiency test, as determined by the School. Not open to native speakers of English.
subject: ESLA
title: Introductory English as a Second Language for Academic Purposes

desc: For students with moderate experience with academic English. Development and application of academic language conventions, critical thinking and research strategies for success at university. Attendance and participation are compulsory.
name: ESLA 1500
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in ESLA 1300 or placement by an approved English language proficiency test, as determined by the School. Not open to native speakers of English.
subject: ESLA
title: Intermediate English as a Second Language for Academic Purposes

desc: For students needing further refinement of academic English. Analysis and synthesis of academic texts and consolidation of academic language and research practices. Attendance and participation are compulsory.
name: ESLA 1900
prereq_text: grade of C+ or higher in ESLA 1500 or placement by an approved English language proficiency test, as determined by the School. Not open to native speakers of English.
subject: ESLA
title: Advanced English as a Second Language for Academic Purposes

desc: ESP (English for Specific Purposes) for students in Engineering and Industrial Design needing further refinement of academic English. Development of technical communication skills: reports, design projects, schematics, and oral presentations appropriate to academic and professional needs. Attendance and participation are compulsory.
name: ESLA 1905
prereq_text: grade of C+ or higher in ESLA 1500 or placement by an approved English language proficiency test, as determined by the School. Not open to native speakers of English.
subject: ESLA
title: Advanced English as a Second Language for Engineering Students

desc: Strategies for writing academic papers in specific disciplines. Individual sections limited to students from a specified discipline. Not open to native speakers of English.
name: ESLA 1906
prereq_text: permission of the academic unit housing the specified discipline.
subject: ESLA
title: Advanced ESL Writing for Specific Disciplines

desc: For students in designated programs. Designed primarily for students whose first language is not English. Topics to be determined.
name: ESLA 2000
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ESLA
title: English Language Development for Specific Purposes I

desc: For students in designated programs. Designed primarily for students whose first language is not English. Topics to be determined.
name: ESLA 3000
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: ESLA
title: English Language Development for Specific Purposes II

desc: An overview of approaches to environmental and climate change issues in the Humanities. Drawing on a range of disciplinary perspectives, students will engage with material depicting climate change and environmental topics, as well as develop research and communication strategies.
name: EACH 2000
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: EACH
title: Introduction to the Environmental and Climate Humanities

desc: A capstone seminar designed to refine analytic and research skills related to environmental and climate humanities and to provide students with the opportunity to engage in a research or community engagement project, either individually or in groups. Topics vary from year to year.
name: EACH 4000
prereq_text: EACH 2000 and third-year standing.
subject: EACH
title: Seminar in the Environmental and Climate Humanities

desc: Impacts of the environment on architecture; deterioration, freeze/thaw, solar heat, air pollution, moisture; Impacts of architecture on the environment; ecologic footprint, energy consumption, air quality, waste generation; designing with the environment; renewable energy, effective siting and landscape, passive solar energy, natural lighting, energy efficiency.
name: ENVE 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: ENVE
title: Architecture and the Environment

desc: Material and energy balances for reacting and non-reacting systems. Applications in mining, metallurgy, pulp and paper, power generation, energy utilization. Emissions to the environment per unit product or service generated. Introduction to life cycle analysis, comparative products and processes.
name: ENVE 2001
prereq_text: CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1101 or equivalent, and MAAE 2400 (may be taken concurrently), and second-year status in Engineering.
subject: ENVE
title: Process Analysis for Environmental Engineering

desc: The biology of the Bacteria, Archaea, Viruses and Protozoans, from the fundamentals of cell chemistry, molecular biology, structure and function, to their involvement in ecological and industrial processes and human disease.
name: ENVE 2002
prereq_text: BIOL 1103 or CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1101 or equivalent.
subject: ENVE
title: Microbiology

desc: Theoretical aspects of unit operations for water treatment with design applications. Topics include water characteristics and contaminants, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, adsorption, ion exchange, membrane processes, disinfection and disinfection by-products, and management of water treatment residuals. Laboratory procedures: settling operations, filtration, aeration, and adsorption.
name: ENVE 3001
prereq_text: ENVE 3002.
subject: ENVE
title: Water Treatment Principles and Design

desc: Engineered systems for pollution abatement; chemical reaction engineering; reaction kinetics and rate data analysis; design and modeling of reactors; single and multiple reactions; ideal and nonideal reactors; single and multi-parameter models; biochemical reaction engineering; process control. Laboratory procedures: reactor systems performance: Batch, CSTR and PFR.
name: ENVE 3002
prereq_text: CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1101 or equivalent and MATH 2004, and second-year status in Engineering. Additional recommended background: ENVE 2001.
subject: ENVE
title: Environmental Engineering Systems Modeling

desc: A quantitative analysis of natural water systems and the development of these systems as a resource. Components of the hydrologic cycle. Quantitative analysis of stream flow. Probability concepts in water resources. Reservoir design and operation. Hydraulic properties and availability of groundwater. Storm water management.
name: ENVE 3003
prereq_text: third-year status in Engineering.
subject: ENVE
title: Water Resources Engineering

desc: Physical phenomenon governing the transport of contaminants in the environment: diffusion, advection, dispersion, sorption, interphase transfer. Derivation and application of transport equations in air, surface and groundwater pollution; analytical and numerical solutions. Equilibrium partitioning of contaminants among air, water, sediment, and biota.
name: ENVE 3004
prereq_text: CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1101 or equivalent; ENVE 3002.
subject: ENVE
title: Contaminant and Pollutant Transport in the Environment

name: ENVE 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: ENVE
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Landfill design; hydrogeologic principles, water budget, landfill liners, geosynthetics, landfill covers, quality control/quality assurance, clay leachate interaction, composite liner design and leak detection. Landfill operation, maintenance and monitoring. Case studies of landfill design and performance. Geotechnical design of environmental control and containment systems.
name: ENVE 4002
prereq_text: ENVE 3004, CIVE 3208.
subject: ENVE
title: Environmental Geotechnical Engineering

desc: Air pollutants, classification, sources, and effects. Ambient air quality objectives and monitoring. Pollutant formation mechanisms in combustion. Major pollutant categories and control methods. Indoor air quality. Laboratory procedures: emissions from boilers and IC engines, particulate size distribution and control, IAQ parameters.
name: ENVE 4003
prereq_text: MAAE 2400 and fourth-year status in Engineering or permission of the department.
subject: ENVE
title: Air Pollution and Emissions Control

desc: Theoretical aspects of unit operations and processes for wastewater treatment with design applications. Topics include wastewater characteristics, flow rates, primary treatment, chemical unit processes, biological treatment processes, advanced wastewater treatment, disinfection, biosolids treatment and disposal. Laboratory procedures: activated sludge, anaerobic growth, chemical precipitation, disinfection.
name: ENVE 4005
prereq_text: ENVE 3001, ENVE 3002.
subject: ENVE
title: Wastewater Treatment Principles and Design

desc: Theory of flow through porous media. Site investigation: geology, hydrology and chemistry. Contaminant transport. Unsaturated and multiphase flow. Numerical modeling. Site remediation and remediation technologies.
name: ENVE 4006
prereq_text: ENVE 3004 and MAAE 2300. Additional recommended background: ENVE 3003.
subject: ENVE
title: Contaminant Hydrogeology

desc: Municipal, hazardous, and mine waste management. Waste composition and potential impacts, collection and transport, recycling and reuse, biological and thermal treatments, isolation. Integrated waste management planning.
name: ENVE 4101
prereq_text: ENVE 3001, ENVE 3002 and ENVE 3004.
subject: ENVE
title: Waste Management

desc: Canada and U.S. environmental regulations. Framework for Environmental Impact Assessment, survey techniques for impact assessment and EIA review process. Case studies of selected engineering projects. Environmental planning, management of residuals and environmental standards. Risk assessment, policy development and decision-making. Fault-tree analysis.
name: ENVE 4104
prereq_text: ENVE 3004 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: ENVE
title: Environmental Planning and Impact Assessment

desc: Concepts, calculations, modeling; design of green buildings and their components; sustainable sites and landscaping; passive design; building envelope; building materials; daylighting; heating, cooling, and ventilation; building-integrated renewable energy systems; indoor environmental quality; overview of building standards and codes.
name: ENVE 4105
prereq_text: fourth-year status in B.Eng. Architectural Conservation and Sustainability Engineering, Environmental Engineering or Civil Engineering or fourth-year standing in B.A.S. concentration in Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: ENVE
title: Green Building Design

desc: Indoor environmental quality (air quality, thermal, visual, and acoustic comfort); physical and chemical parameters for characterization. Types and sources of indoor air pollution and discomfort; measurement techniques. Heating, ventilation, air conditioning, lighting practices and issues. Modelling of and design for indoor environmental quality.
name: ENVE 4106
prereq_text: fourth year status in B.Eng. Architectural Conservation and Sustainability Engineering or B.Eng. Environmental Engineering or fourth year standing in B.A.S. concentration in Conservation and Sustainability.
subject: ENVE
title: Indoor Environmental Quality

desc: This course provides details on how buildings are designed and operated. The materials provide foundational knowledge to understand building services: mechanical, electrical, plumbing systems with associated controls.
name: ENVE 4107
prereq_text: CIVE 3209, ENVE 4105 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: ENVE
title: Building Services Engineering

desc: Survey of the physical science of climate change, impacts on the built environment, and climate adaptation in engineering. Greenhouse gases, global warming, paleoclimatology, and Earth system responses. Climate change impacts on structural, water, transportation, and energy systems. Climate vulnerability assessment, examples of design adaptation.
name: ENVE 4200
prereq_text: Fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: ENVE
title: Climate Change and Engineering

desc: A research project in engineering analysis, design or development carried out by individual students or small teams, for an opportunity to develop initiative, self-reliance, creative ability and engineering judgment and is normally intended for students with high CGPAs and an interest in graduate studies.
name: ENVE 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year status in Engineering and permission of the department.
subject: ENVE
title: Engineering Research Project

desc: Student carries out a study, analysis, and solution of an engineering problem which results in a written final report. Carried out under close supervision of a faculty member. Intended for students interested in pursuing graduate studies. Requires supervising faculty member and proposal from student.
name: ENVE 4917
prereq_text: permission of the Department and completion of, or concurrent registration in, ENVE 4918.
subject: ENVE
title: Undergraduate Directed Study

desc: Teams of students develop professional level experience through a design project that incorporates fundamentals acquired in previous mathematics, science, engineering, and complementary studies courses. A final report and oral presentations are required.
name: ENVE 4918
prereq_text: ECOR 3800 and fourth-year Status in Engineering. Certain projects may have additional requirements.
subject: ENVE
title: Design Project

desc: The purpose and nature of the program; society's view on the natural and human-modified environment; major environmental issues and their scientific aspects; preparation and presentation of paper and seminars.
name: ENSC 1500
prereq_text: enrolment in the Environmental Science program.
subject: ENSC
title: Environmental Science Seminar

desc: A field-based course introducing students to practical methods in environmental science. Topics will include earth sciences, geography, biology, and chemistry related aspects of environmental sciences and will focus on quantitative techniques to assess environmental impacts and management. A supplementary fee will apply.
name: ENSC 2000
prereq_text: ERTH 1006 and BIOL 1004 or BIOL 1104, CHEM 1001 and CHEM 1002 and permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Environmental Science Field Methods

desc: Environmental impact of mineral, energy and water resource exploitation and impact of hazardous Earth processes such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes and others: their prediction and mitigation.
name: ENSC 2001
prereq_text: None
subject: ENSC
title: Earth Resources and Natural Hazards: Environmental Impacts

desc: Study and application of qualitative and quantitative techniques in environmental science, including study design, data collection and assembly, database manipulation, data analysis, and critically evaluating scientific information.
name: ENSC 2002
prereq_text: STAT 2507 or permission from the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Methods and Analysis in Environmental Science

desc: Theoretical and practical perspectives related to environmental science and management; Emphasis on real-world problems associated with human activities and development of solutions in natural and built environments; Hands-on experience with environmental monitoring and restoration. A supplementary fee will apply.
name: ENSC 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing in Environmental Science or permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Environmental Science and Management: Theory and Practice

desc: Fundamentals of aquatic science. The physical, chemical, and biotic aspects of lake, river, and estuary systems including human impacts, management and conservation.
name: ENSC 3106
prereq_text: third-year standing and a second year science or engineering course.
subject: ENSC
title: Aquatic Science and Management

desc: Major project relating to an issue involving environmental science; effective methods of team research and presentation of group work. May include field work during class time or on weekends.
name: ENSC 3509
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Honours Environmental Science program or permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Group Research in Environmental Science

desc: Specific topics of current interest. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: ENSC 3700
prereq_text: Third year standing in the Environmental Science program or permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Topics in Environmental Science

desc: Independent or group study on the fundamentals of scientific investigation, which may include use of literature, learning of research techniques, and development of a research proposal, in consultation with a Faculty supervisor. May include directed reading, written assignments, tutorials, laboratory or field work.
name: ENSC 3906
prereq_text: Good standing in third year Environmental Science and permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Project Planning for Environmental Research

desc: Practical experience for students enrolled in the Co-operative Option. To receive course credit a student must receive satisfactory evaluations from their work term employer. Written reports describing the work term project will be required. Graded Sat or Uns.
name: ENSC 3999
prereq_text: registration in the Environmental Science Co-operative Option and permission of the Institute. Four-month work term.
subject: ENSC
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Experience working in the environmental science sector, applying academic training to practical environmental issues. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: ENSC 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Environmental Science program.
subject: ENSC
title: Environmental Science Practicum

desc: The regulatory and scientific aspects of environmental management decisions, including risk analysis and mitigation, managing chronic and acute environmental impacts, and conservation of species and landscapes. Students will use real-world case studies to learn traditional and cutting-edge decision-making tools.
name: ENSC 4002
prereq_text: third-year standing in any B.Sc. program or permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Environmental Decisions

desc: This course explores issues of food systems and their sustainability. We will discuss aspects of food systems, including production, distribution, consumption, waste management, and their impact on communities and the environment.
name: ENSC 4003
prereq_text: third year standing in B.Sc. or B.HSc. program or permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Food Systems and the Environment

name: ENSC 4700
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Environmental Science program or permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Topics in Environmental Science

desc: Independent or group study, for fourth-year students to explore a particular project, in consultation with a Faculty supervisor. May include directed reading, written assignments, tutorials, laboratory or field work.
name: ENSC 4901
prereq_text: permission of the Institute. Students normally may not offer more than 1.0 credit of Directed Special Studies in their program.
subject: ENSC
title: Directed Projects

desc: An independent investigation into an aspect of environmental science supervised by a member of the faculty. Approval of the topic and the research schedule must be obtained from the project supervisor and the course coordinator before the last date for registration.
name: ENSC 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Honours Environmental Science program, a major CGPA 8.0 and permission of the Institute.
subject: ENSC
title: Honours Research Project

desc: A critical introduction to the scholarly field of environmental studies, with an emphasis on society-environment entanglements. It is designed to engage with environmental issues. Possible themes include population, scarcity, institutions, commons, risks, hazards, markets, political economy, and the social construction of nature.
name: ENST 1000
prereq_text: None
subject: ENST
title: Introduction to Environmental Studies

desc: Introduction to human geography. Examination of relationships between people, communities, society and the natural environment at local to global scales. Population change, cultural patterns, and historical, economic, political and environmental forces that shape human activity and experiences from place to place.
name: ENST 1020
prereq_text: None
subject: ENST
title: People, Places and Environments

desc: Contemporary and foundational theories, practice and praxis of environmental justice in Canadian and comparative settings. Combine and communicate about aspects of the physical, built and social environments to understand how uneven conditions develop. Strategies and ideas to move towards greater equity and good environmental relationships.
name: ENST 2000
prereq_text: second-year standing in the Environmental Studies program or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental Justice

desc: Individual and collective responses to pressing environmental problems. Innovative ways in which the environment can be protected and restored, taking into consideration socioeconomic, political and cultural factors. Topics include environmental lifestyles, sustainable communities, food systems, environmental design, and political activism.
name: ENST 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing in the Environmental Studies program or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Sustainable Futures: Environmental Challenges and Solutions

desc: Introduction to the research process, from generating questions through to reporting results. Topics include intensive and extensive research approaches; the use of surveys, interviews and other data collection methods; the analysis of qualitative information; and the ethical dimensions of doing research with people and communities.
name: ENST 2005
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in GEOG or ENST at the 1000-level and second-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Introduction to Qualitative Research

desc: Introduction to solving problems using descriptive and inferential statistical methods. Graphical and numerical tools to describe distributions. Probability, sampling and estimates, and hypothesis testing. Fundamentals of spatial statistics and analysis.
name: ENST 2006
prereq_text: None
subject: ENST
title: Introduction to Quantitative Research

desc: An introduction to climate change as a political, economic and socio-cultural phenomenon, including the political-economic and world-historical causes of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions; variations in impact and vulnerability; climate justice and other political movements; global mitigation and adaptation strategies; and proposals for radical systemic change.
name: ENST 2500
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: ENST
title: Climate Change: Social Science Perspectives

desc: Overview of social science perspectives analyzing the relationship of society and the environment. Examination of environmental problems, solutions, conditions, and interventions through the study of concepts, theories, and research drawn from a range of scholarly approaches to questions of nature.
name: ENST 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing in Environmental Studies or permission of the department.
subject: ENST
title: Nature, Environment and Society

desc: Exploration of complexity, dynamics, uncertainty and equity issues underpinning environmental and resource issues; review and appraisal of selected contemporary methods to assess and manage environmental and natural resources.
name: ENST 3022
prereq_text: third-year standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or BGInS Specialization/Stream in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental and Natural Resources

desc: Field research, with a focus on data collection methods, analysis and presentation of findings. Design and conduct research that links the human and biophysical environment. Topics may change from year to year.
name: ENST 3900
prereq_text: GEOG 2005/ ENST 2005 and GEOG 2006/ ENST 2006, third-year Honours standing in Environmental Studies, Geomatics, or Geography, or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Honours Field Course

name: ENST 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: ENST
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: An advanced seminar designed to provide a capstone experience that builds upon and applies the analytical skills and interdisciplinary knowledge acquired in the Environmental Studies program. Topics vary year to year and by course section (see departmental website).
name: ENST 4000
prereq_text: Registration is restricted to students eligible for fourth-year standing in the B.A. (Environmental Studies) Honours program.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental Studies Seminar

desc: External agency setting provides the basis for translating academic training into practical involvement with environmental issues. Observation and involvement in issues and research methods used by professional environmental practitioners.
name: ENST 4001
prereq_text: registration is restricted to students eligible for fourth-year standing in the B.A. (Environmental Studies) Honours program, and permission of the Environmental Studies Co-ordinator.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental Studies Practicum I

desc: External agency setting provides the basis for translating academic training into practical involvement with environmental issues. Observation and involvement in issues and research methods used by environmental practitioners.
name: ENST 4002
prereq_text: restricted to students in the fourth year of the Environmental Studies Honours program, and permission of the Environmental Studies Co-ordinator.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental Studies Practicum II

desc: Principles, scope and purpose of environmental impact assessment, from conceptual and methodological points of view; range of environmental issues, with emphasis on Canadian case studies.
name: ENST 4004
prereq_text: GEOG 3022 or ENST 3022, and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or Environmental Science, or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental Impact Assessment

desc: Students pursue their interest in a selected theme in environmental studies on a tutorial basis with a faculty member.
name: ENST 4005
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Directed Studies in Environmental Studies

desc: Critical examination of the creation, implementation and effectiveness of government policies related to environmental issues. Emphasis on perspectives, actors, institutions and social and economic relationships affecting policy responses to these issues, and on tools for analyzing the implications of specific policy choices.
name: ENST 4006
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Environmental Studies, Geography, or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental Policy Analysis

desc: Selected topics in geography and/or environmental studies.
name: ENST 4007
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in the Department or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Special Topics in Geography and Environmental Studies

desc: A selected topic or field of inquiry concerning natural resource use and environmental change.
name: ENST 4022
prereq_text: GEOG 3022 or ENST 3022 and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or BGInS Specialization in Globalization and Environment, or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Seminar in People, Resources, and Environmental Change

desc: Selected theoretical and applied issues concerning environmental and geographic education.
name: ENST 4050
prereq_text: Third-year honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies, or permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Environmental and Geographic Education

desc: Field observation and methodology in a selected region, special topic or contemporary problem; on an individual or group basis.
name: ENST 4400
prereq_text: third-year Honours standing and permission of the Department.
subject: ENST
title: Field Studies

desc: Working in partnership with local organizations, students apply their geographical knowledge to conduct community-engaged research. Student projects will generate outputs for community partners. Research topics vary year to year.
name: ENST 4450
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: ENST
title: Community-Engaged Research

desc: An independent investigation into a select aspect of environmental studies, supervised by a faculty member. Possible outcomes might include: workshops, audio-visual productions, lay publications, and field projects accompanied by an essay demonstrating the student's capacity to critically reflect on the research project.
name: ENST 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Environmental Studies, a minimum CGPA of 9.00 in the major or permission of the Department, and an approved research topic and adviser.
subject: ENST
title: Honours Research Project

desc: Interdisciplinary research essay on an environmental issue, carried out in consultation with a faculty supervisor. The student must consult with the undergraduate student advisor in selecting a project and a supervisor.
name: ENST 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Environmental Studies, a minimum CGPA of 9.00 in the major or permission of the Department, and an approved research topic and adviser.
subject: ENST
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: An introduction to the study of Europe and Russia, including aspects of the histories, societies, cultures, and politics of the region.
name: EURR 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: EURR
title: Introduction to European and Russian Studies

desc: An interdisciplinary examination of social, political, and economic issues facing Europe, including the countries of the European Union, Eastern Europe, and Russia.
name: EURR 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: EURR
title: Current Issues in European Politics and Society

desc: The position of Europe, the European Union, and the Russian Federation in a global context, including geopolitical, economic, security, and human dimensions.
name: EURR 2002
prereq_text: second year standing.
subject: EURR
title: Europe and Russia in the World

desc: A survey of the literature and cultural texts that have defined Europe. Examination of fiction and non-fiction texts that have contributed to and reflected the development of European culture and society.
name: EURR 3001
prereq_text: second year standing.
subject: EURR
title: Literature and Culture in Europe

desc: A survey of the literature and cultural texts that have defined Russian and neighboring Slavic countries. Examination of fiction and non-fiction texts that have contributed to and reflected the development of Russian and Slavic culture and society.
name: EURR 3002
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: EURR
title: Literature and Culture in Russia and Eurasia

name: EURR 3999
prereq_text: registration in the B.A. European and Russian Studies (Honours) Co-operative option, completion of the Co-op preparation classes offered by the Co-op Office and permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: The relationship between social forces and state structures at both the national and local levels in the USSR and the post-Soviet states.
name: EURR 4002
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Post-Soviet States and Societies

desc: Social issues and policies in the European Union including European identity, democratic legitimacy, nationalist and extremist political movements, Euroscepticism, migration and immigration, social inclusion/exclusion and social models, gender and family policy, regional differentiation.
name: EURR 4003
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Social and Political Perspectives in Europe

desc: Ethnic basis of nationalism in the region. Ethnic politics and trends.
name: EURR 4008
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Nationalism and Ethnic Conflict in Eastern and Central Europe

desc: Processes of nation building in the region examined in terms of a particular country, or set of countries.
name: EURR 4100
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Nation-Building in Central and Eastern Europe

desc: The seminar uses the concept of transition to understand the Balkan encounter with modernity and Europe. Key periods to be examined include the interwar era and the period of communist rule, with an emphasis on political, social and economic themes.
name: EURR 4101
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: The Balkans in Transition – 1918 to 1989

desc: Selected topics in Balkan politics and society since the collapse of communism in 1989, focusing on the democratic transition and the EU accession process. The legacies of communist rule, democratization and the many national questions that still exist in the region.
name: EURR 4102
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: The Balkans since 1989

desc: A study of masterpieces of prose fiction from the Golden Age of Russian literature. Readings will be chosen from writers such as Turgenev, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, Gogol, and/or others. All texts will be studied in English translation.
name: EURR 4103
prereq_text: Third-year standing.
subject: EURR
title: The Great Russian Novel

desc: Issues related to the formation of supra-national decision-making structures in Europe.
name: EURR 4104
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: European Integration and European Security

desc: Selected topics related to European integration in the post-World War II period.
name: EURR 4106
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Selected Topics in European Integration Studies

desc: Domestic conditions in Russia from 2000 to the present and the framing of Russia’s foreign policy and strategic objectives towards the former Soviet republics and other key global actors, including the United States, the European Union, NATO and China.
name: EURR 4107
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Russia’s Regional and Global Ambitions

desc: A seminar focusing on selected topics related to Europe.
name: EURR 4201
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Special Topics in European Studies

desc: A seminar focusing on selected topics related to Russia and neighbouring countries.
name: EURR 4202
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Special Topics in Russian and Eurasian Studies

desc: Evolution and current status of Central Europe from periods of foreign control in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries to independent statehood, with emphasis on national accommodations and conflicts.
name: EURR 4204
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Central Europe, Past and Present

desc: The relationships between political transformation, identity-building, ethnicity, and gender politics in post-communist states, considered in comparison with select countries in Central and/or Western Europe.
name: EURR 4205
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2500, PSCI 3208, PSCI 3209, PSCI 3500, PSCI 3502, PSCI 3704, or PSCI 3705.
subject: EURR
title: Politics of Identity in Europe and the Russian Area

desc: A seminar accompanying an unpaid internship placement to develop workplace and applied policy skills. Relating applied experience to academic literature. Writing skills for an applied policy setting. Internship placement: 12 days over l2 weeks.
name: EURR 4206
prereq_text: open only to fourth-year EURUS B.A. Honours students with a minimum B+ average and placement in an internship position in the same semester or in the previous semester (based on a competitive application process).
subject: EURR
title: Internship and Applied Policy Skills

desc: Examination of the Caucasus and Central Asia, from Chechnya to former Soviet republics of the region, Afghanistan and Chinese Turkestan. Interests of Russia, China, and the United States. Emphasis on underdevelopment, oil and gas, terrorism, Islam.
name: EURR 4207
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Politics of Central Eurasia

desc: The foreign policies of the USSR and of Russia and selected other successor states, with special emphasis on the search for a new security order.
name: EURR 4208
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Foreign Policies of Soviet Successor States

desc: Examination of the South Caucasus (Azerbaijan, Georgia, Armenia), the Russian-held North Caucasus, including Chechnya, and relations with Iran. Emphasis on state and society, oil and gas, transregional communications, interests of western powers, ethnic relations.
name: EURR 4209
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Politics of the Caucasus and Caspian Basin

desc: This course is open only to students in approved summer study options in Europe, particularly the EU Study Tour.
name: EURR 4302
prereq_text: approval of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: EU Summer Study Abroad

desc: History of contemporary Europe from 1945 to present covering both eastern and western halves of the continent and including social, cultural, political, and economic dimensions.
name: EURR 4303
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Contemporary Europe: From Postwar to the European Union

desc: Europe’s role in international migration. Topics to be discussed may include migration and mobility as both assets and challenges for sending, transit, and destination countries, changing geographies of migration, inclusion and exclusion, political mobilization, and responses of European states and other actors.
name: EURR 4304
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Europe and International Migration

desc: Examination of the expansion and downfall of tsarist Russia from the eighteenth century to the revolutionary era and the establishment of Bolshevik rule. Topics include the relationship between the monarchy and subject peoples, social and economic change, and daily life.
name: EURR 4305
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Imperial Russia and the Russian Revolution

desc: Examination of the rise of the Soviet Union to a global power and subsequent tensions that promoted its collapse. The course will analyze Stalinism, the Second World War, the Thaw, and Brezhnev and Gorbachev eras through the lens of the USSR’s citizens.
name: EURR 4306
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: The Soviet Union: Power and Culture

desc: The economic, political, legal, and cultural environment for doing business in the European Union and other regions in Europe. Patterns of foreign trade and investment, market characteristics, science and technology, regulation and European integration, and business culture.
name: EURR 4704
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: EURR
title: The Business Environment in Europe

desc: Tutorials or reading courses on selected topics may be arranged with the permission of the Institute and agreement of the instructor.
name: EURR 4900
prereq_text: permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Tutorial in European and Russian Studies

desc: Tutorials or reading courses on selected topics may be arranged with the permission of the Institute and agreement of the instructor.
name: EURR 4901
prereq_text: permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Tutorial in European and Russian Studies

desc: Tutorials or reading courses on selected topics may be arranged with the permission of the Institute and agreement of the instructor.
name: EURR 4902
prereq_text: permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Tutorial in European and Russian Studies

desc: Individual research project resulting in a major essay, completed under the supervision of a faculty member and evaluated by the supervisor and a second reader. Students should consult with the Supervisor of Undergraduate Studies regarding the topic and supervisor. Institute’s Honours Essay guidelines apply.
name: EURR 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, a CGPA of 9.00 or higher in courses qualifying for credit in European and Russian Studies, and permission of the Institute.
subject: EURR
title: Honours Essay

desc: Introduction to the study of film that emphasizes problems and methods of film analysis through the study of various types of films. Topics relating to the filmmaker, film genre, and film history are covered through a focus on questions of style and technique.
name: FILM 1101
prereq_text: None
subject: FILM
title: Introduction to Film Studies

desc: A seminar in the study of film that emphasizes problems and methods of film analysis through the study of a variety of types of films.
name: FILM 1120
prereq_text: enrolment in a Film Studies major.
subject: FILM
title: Seminar in Film Studies

desc: Introduction to major film theories and analytical practices. The objective of this course is to familiarize students with the main theories and methods of analysis that have been developed for the study of film.
name: FILM 2001
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120 and second-year standing; or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Film Theory and Analysis I

desc: Building on the skills acquired in FILM 2001, this course considers specific debates in film theory, and provides students with advanced methods for film analysis.
name: FILM 2002
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, and FILM 2001, and second-year standing; or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Film Theory and Analysis II

desc: The organization of the production, distribution and exhibition practices of various film industries. May include an examination of the relationship between a national film industry and its television industry.
name: FILM 2101
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: The Film Industry

desc: An examination of the work of individual filmmakers, of documentary styles and of organizations and institutions in the context of the history of documentary film making, including documentaries made for television. Non-fiction films other than documentaries may be considered.
name: FILM 2106
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: The Documentary

desc: This course examines the film production of specific countries in order to determine the themes, the styles, and the character of a national cinema.
name: FILM 2201
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: National Cinema

desc: Various practices and movements in the history of Japanese cinema, ranging from the silent era to the current digital age.
name: FILM 2202
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Japanese Cinema

desc: The development of cinema culture and film production in the Scandinavian countries, from the golden age of Scandinavian silent cinema to contemporary Nordic noir.
name: FILM 2203
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Scandinavian Cinema

desc: A critical examination of films and other audiovisual media created by Indigenous artists, such as independent films, genre films, documentaries, web series, installations, and video games.
name: FILM 2204
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: FILM
title: Indigenous Cinema and Media

desc: A critical examination of Canadian cinema and media and how it relates to other aspects of Canadian culture.
name: FILM 2206
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120 or second-year standing; or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Canadian Cinema

desc: A detailed study of the themes, the characteristic style, development and influence of one or more directors.
name: FILM 2401
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Authorship in Film and Media

desc: This course examines questions of generic form, drawing examples from world cinema.
name: FILM 2601
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Film Genres

desc: Historical survey of world cinema primarily from 1895 to 1945, examining the forms, structures and stylistic conventions of various periods and nations.
name: FILM 2606
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, and second-year standing, or permission of the discipline.
subject: FILM
title: History of World Cinema I

desc: Historical survey of world cinema primarily since 1945, examining the forms, structures and stylistic conventions of various periods and nations.
name: FILM 2607
prereq_text: FILM 2606 or ENGL 2600 or permission of the discipline.
subject: FILM
title: History of World Cinema II

desc: Introduction to the basic principles of film and media practice. Emphasis may change from year to year, focusing alternately on narrative, experimental, animation or documentary techniques. This course is intended for Film Studies majors only.
name: FILM 2801
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120.
subject: FILM
title: Film and Media Practice I

desc: Introduction to the video game as a popular media form, an emerging aesthetic, and a social and cultural practice. Topics include: history of video games; game form; game industry; narrative; art and design; interactivity; theories of play.
name: FILM 2809
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: The Video Game

desc: Theoretical implications of documentary film and documentary television practice.
name: FILM 3105
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000-level and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Questions of Documentary Practice

desc: Studies in various aspects of American cinema with emphasis on historical and critical issues.
name: FILM 3206
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in American Cinema

desc: Studies in various aspects of Canadian cinema. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: FILM 3209
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Canadian Cinema

desc: A study of selected topics in gender and cinema with emphasis on critical and historical questions.
name: FILM 3301
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000-level and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Cinema, Gender, and Sexuality

desc: The use of music in film, from the silent era to the present day. Techniques, styles and theory of film music through the examination of selected scenes.
name: FILM 3402
prereq_text: None
subject: FILM
title: Film Music

desc: Building on the skills acquired in FILM 2000, this course provides a critical study of advanced film theories. Topics may include aesthetics, ideological criticism, film and philosophy, and theories of technology and historiography.
name: FILM 3506
prereq_text: FILM 2001 and FILM 2002 and third-year standing; or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Film Theory

desc: Studies of aspects of the history of world cinema. Topics will vary from year to year and may include the examination of film movements, styles and genres, and/or comparative study of national, regional and/or world-wide trends.
name: FILM 3608
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Film History

desc: Major figures and movements in African cinema around such categories as the colonial, the anti-colonial, the postcolonial, the diasporic, the continental, race, Afro-futurism, and world cinema, interrogating in the process the very category of “African cinema”.
name: FILM 3609
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in FILM and third year standing or permission of instructor.
subject: FILM
title: African Cinema

desc: A study of selected topics in animation, video or experimental film.
name: FILM 3701
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Animation, Video, and Experimental Film

desc: Consideration of topics in film/video archival or curatorial practice, including questions related to cultural policy, exhibition, conservation, and interrelationship of media. Students are expected to bear all travel and other costs arising from required visits to local facilities.
name: FILM 3800
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Film/Video Archival or Curatorial Practice

desc: Practical and conceptual approaches to film studies from the point of view of film and media practice. Emphasis may change from year to year, focusing alternately on narrative, experimental, animation or documentary techniques.
name: FILM 3801
prereq_text: FILM 2001 and FILM 2801.
subject: FILM
title: Film and Media Practice II

desc: The technological development of cinema. Topics may include advances in sound and colour processes, digital effects, exhibition technologies and new media.
name: FILM 3808
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Cinema and Technology

desc: History, aesthetics, and theories of digital media and culture. Key concepts in digital media studies, including: digital cinema, interactive documentaries, viral videos, web series, emerging immersive platforms.
name: FILM 3809
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Analyzing Digital Media

desc: Questions related to sound in film and media such as: how is sound used to create narratives and emotions? How does sound affect our experience of actual and fictional worlds?.
name: FILM 3810
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Sound in Film and Media

desc: Selected topics and issues not ordinarily treated in the third-year course program.
name: FILM 3901
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 2000 level, and third-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Film Studies

desc: An intermediate workshop involving regular assignments in writing for film.
name: FILM 3902
prereq_text: a 2000-level creative writing workshop or permission of the instructor. Permission to register in this course requires the student to submit a portfolio. Instructions can be found at Carleton.ca/English.
subject: FILM
title: Screenwriting Workshop

desc: Study of various methodologies for critical, theoretical and historical research in film studies.
name: FILM 4001
prereq_text: FILM 2002, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000-level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Research and Critical Methodologies

desc: Selected aspects of the audio-visual cultures of the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
name: FILM 4002
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Moving Image Culture

desc: A study of a selected topic in national cinema.
name: FILM 4201
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Selected Topics in National Cinemas

desc: Theoretical and critical study of the film festival as a phenomenon shaping our understanding of film culture, institutions, history and forms. Issues examined may include festivals as sites of cultural legitimation; as spectacle; their political economy; curation/programming; case studies of film festivals around the world.
name: FILM 4203
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Film Festivals and World Cinema

desc: Selected topics in philosophical approaches to the study of film, and an examination of the relations between film theory and philosophical aesthetics.
name: FILM 4301
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Topics in Film and Philosophy

desc: A study of questions of authorship in the cinema, concentrating on one or more filmmakers.
name: FILM 4401
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Selected Topics in Film Authorship

desc: A study of a selected topic in film theory.
name: FILM 4501
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Selected Topics in Film Theory

desc: Practical experience through working on specific projects under the supervision of staff at a museum, gallery, archive, or production company in the Ottawa area. A maximum of 0.5 credit Film Studies practica courses may be offered in fulfilment of Film Studies requirements. Graded SAT/UNS.
name: FILM 4805
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Film Studies, a CGPA of 9.00 or higher in Film Studies, and permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Practicum in Film and Film Studies

desc: Selected topics in film studies not ordinarily available in the regular course program. The choice of topic or topics will vary at least every two years and will be announced well in advance of the registration period.
name: FILM 4901
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, 1.0 credit in FILM at the 3000 level, and fourth-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: FILM
title: Special Topic

desc: For students who wish to study a specific topic. Proposed projects must be approved by the Program Committee. Written request outlining the project must be submitted by the first day of the term. An essay is the usual assignment.
name: FILM 4904
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Film Studies and a CGPA of 10.00 or higher in Film Studies.
subject: FILM
title: Independent Study

desc: An introduction to the major tools and policy problems of economics. Economic analysis is applied to a variety of contemporary problems such as pollution, poverty, the control of monopoly, unemployment, inflation and international economic problems.
name: FYSM 1003
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B. Econ. or B.G.In.S. program. This course is an intensive version of ECON 1000 geared to students seeking a more in-depth and interactive introduction to economics.
subject: FYSM
title: Introduction to Economics

desc: Introduction to active literary reading skills, focusing on at least three literary genres including poetry, prose, and drama, with attention to literary, social, historical, and political contexts. This course is writing attentive. Strongly recommended for English majors. Consult English Department website for annual topics.
name: FYSM 1004
prereq_text: Normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Reading Literatures and Cultures

desc: Where we live affects who we are. The role of geographic location and environment on human perception, behaviour, and well-being, viewed at scales ranging from local to global; methods of collecting and interpreting information about location.
name: FYSM 1101
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Location is Everything

desc: Arguments that have been used to defend differing positions on rights issues, past and present. The validity of contending arguments; social factors influencing wide-spread acceptance of popular views.
name: FYSM 1104
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Human Rights: Issues and Investigations

desc: Academic writing and study skills through examination of the literacy and social interaction required for various media. Reading and writing on and for the Web and other forms of computer-mediated communications and cooperative work compared with writing for academic purposes.
name: FYSM 1105
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Reading the Web

desc: An investigation of important issues relating to the Greek and Roman worlds. Themes will be drawn from literature, history, art, religion and social life. All texts are in English.
name: FYSM 1106
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Issues in Classics

desc: Struggles over social and economic inequality in the city, and their relationship to processes of urbanization and global change. Theories and case studies explaining how urban lives and form are shaped by social movements and urban politics. Broad introduction to critical urban geography.
name: FYSM 1107
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Social Justice and the City

desc: The causes and consequences of environmental change; emphasis on the interactions of nature and human behaviour. Ways in which the environment can be protected and restored. Environmental issues that affect our own communities.
name: FYSM 1108
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Sustainable Environments

desc: The creation and expression of social identities through language: gender, age, ethnic and social background.
name: FYSM 1204
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Language and Identity

desc: The role of language in maintaining and contesting power relations in domains such as the media, education, advertising, and politics. How meanings are made and exchanged through language in different situations.
name: FYSM 1205
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Language and Power

desc: Selected topics in the study of philosophy. Topics offered may vary from year to year and will be announced in advance of the registration period by the Department of Philosophy.
name: FYSM 1210
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B. Econ., or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Special Topics in Philosophy

desc: An examination of the following: What is logical thinking? Does God exist? Are values relative? Do we have responsibilities? What is a just society? Do we have free will? What is the mind? What is the nature of reality?.
name: FYSM 1211
prereq_text: None
subject: FYSM
title: Looking at Philosophy

desc: Philosophical problems associated with such topical issues as feminist, critical race and disability theories; atheism vs. theism; the meaning of life; moral relativism vs. moral objectivism; egoistic vs. non-egoistic ethics; euthanasia, abortion, capital punishment and environmental ethics; legal paternalism; freedom of the will.
name: FYSM 1212
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Contemporary Moral, Social, and Religious Issues

desc: Introductory communication and media studies seminar. Topics offered may vary from year to year and will be announced in advance of the registration period by the Communication and Media Studies program.
name: FYSM 1217
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program. (This course is not the equivalent of COMS 1000).
subject: FYSM
title: Selected Topics in Communication and Media Studies

desc: The major figures and developments in philosophy from the early Greeks to the present. A primarily descriptive and comparative approach, through critical reasoning is included for comprehending philosophic development. Provides a background from which to understand the philosophical aspects of other disciplines.
name: FYSM 1300
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: History of Philosophy

desc: Theories, research and applications of psychology from the perspective of different cultures and sub-cultures. The validity of psychology across society; how it defines and changes people, and how it reflects and engineers particular social values and norms.
name: FYSM 1306
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S program.
subject: FYSM
title: Diversity in Psychological World Views

desc: Theories, research, and practical applications of psychology to the criminal justice system. Topics may include eyewitness testimony, prediction of violence, classification and rehabilitation of offenders, victim studies, and judicial decision making.
name: FYSM 1307
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S program.
subject: FYSM
title: Psychology and Criminal Justice

desc: The psychology of human motivation. Everyday concepts such as laziness in relation to diverse theories and explanations of motivation such as drive-reduction, sociobiology, personal goals, self-actualization and spiritual awareness.
name: FYSM 1308
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S program.
subject: FYSM
title: Motivating Humans

desc: Psychology is the scientific study of our thoughts, feelings and behavior. Course examines a selected topic in psychology. The specific topic will vary from year to year and will be announced in advance of the registration period.
name: FYSM 1310
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A, B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Selected Topics in Psychology

desc: Theories, research, and applications of Cognitive Psychology. Research projects will familiarize students with the scientific method used to study pattern recognition, attention, memory, language and thinking.
name: FYSM 1400
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A, B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Cognition: A Scientific Exploration of the Mind

desc: Issues relating to the development of and interaction among cultural communities, with major emphasis on the realities of "doing multiculturalism in Canada." Research teams; organized seminars with volunteers from Canadian cultural and community groups.
name: FYSM 1401
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Multiculturalism in Canada

desc: Emphasis on the development of writing, research and analytical skills through the intensive examination of selected topics in women's studies (e.g. popular culture, media, representation and identity, communications, women's writing, motherhood, sexuality, health, technology, law, politics). Specific themes will vary from year to year.
name: FYSM 1402
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.

title: Issues in Women's and Gender Studies

desc: Examination of a selected historical topic in a small-class setting. The development of writing, research, analytical, and oral communication skills necessary for success in upper-level university courses is emphasized. Topics will vary from year to year. (Field will depend on topic).
name: FYSM 1405
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A, B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM

desc: The fundamental political, judicial and administrative institutions that made Canada a unique nation. Students will learn how government institutions are dealing with preservation and maintenance of Canadian cultural and social values.
name: FYSM 1406
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: How Ottawa Works: Exploring National Institutions

desc: An introduction to the diversity of the French language and of French-language literatures and cultures throughout the francophone world, including Europe, Canada, the Caribbean, Africa and the Middle East. The course is conducted in French. For French majors and students who have completed the placement.
name: FYSM 1408
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of B.A, B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: French on the World Stage

desc: Interdisciplinary analysis of social change and how people change Canada, through an examination of movements like environmentalism, feminism, peace, and antiracism. Examination of broader efforts to reshape Canadian society, including culture-jamming and change through popular culture.
name: FYSM 1409
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Social Change in Canada

prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Selected Topics in Legal Studies

desc: The role of contemporary cultural forms in everyday life. Focus on the culture/power relationship with attention to the ways that popular forms such as television, film, music, and tourism facilitate or work against the cultural and economic interests of different societal groups.
name: FYSM 1503
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Contemporary Culture in Everyday Life

desc: Inquiry into the relation between human societies and the material environment which they inhabit and use. Focus is on the ways in which groups create the environments in which they live and the ways in which those environments influence and reproduce the groups.
name: FYSM 1504
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.

Focus on the philosophical, professional, and ethical distinctions between scholarly and applied sociology.
name: FYSM 1505
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A., B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S. program.
subject: FYSM
title: Introduction to Applied Sociology

name: FYSM 1506

subject: FYSM
title: Topics in the Study of Societies

desc: How do you cope with stress? We live in a stressful world, and how we cope has implications for our happiness and well-being. We will examine theory and research on how stress affects our lives, how people cope, and what it means to be well-adjusted.
name: FYSM 1508
prereq_text: normally restricted to students entering the first year of a B.A, B.Cog.Sc., B.Co.M.S., B.Econ. or B.G.In.S program.
subject: FYSM
title: Stress, Coping and Well-being

desc: An examination of how language and other symbol systems are used to portray and make arguments about ecology and the global environment, with a particular focus on climate change.

title: Understanding Environmental Discourse
