desc: Overview of the food industry. Production, processing, product development, packaging, chemistry, analysis, microbiology. Elements risk assessment, policy making and regulation.
name: FOOD 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: FOOD
title: Introduction to Food Science

desc: Roles of nutrients, lipids, proteins, carbohydrates, fluids and electrolytes. Digestion, absorption, transport, energy metabolism. Disorders including diabetes, cardiovascular disease and osteoporosis. Nutrition through the life cycle.
name: FOOD 2001
prereq_text: CHEM 1002, BIOL 1103.
subject: FOOD
title: Principles of Nutrition

desc: Principles of major techniques used in food processing and preservation. Processing of specific food groups including cereals, oilseeds, dairy, beverages and frozen foods. Effects of processing on physico-chemical, rheological, and sensory characteristics. Role of research and development in food industry.
name: FOOD 2002
prereq_text: FOOD 1001.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Processing

desc: Regulation of the Canadian food industry including regulators, regulatory powers, the process of enacting laws/regulation and food safety requirements. Food composition, standardization, advertising, labeling, packaging, ingredients, additives, and fortification requirements. Inspection, enforcement and compliance powers and policies.
name: FOOD 2003
prereq_text: Second year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Regulation of the Canadian Food Industry

desc: Principles of effective scientific communication for scientific and non-scientific audiences. Applicable to laboratory reports, literature reviews, posters, presentations, and briefing notes.
name: FOOD 2004
prereq_text: FOOD 1001 and second-year standing in Food Science or Chemistry.
subject: FOOD
title: Scientific Communication in Food Science

desc: Chemistry of the major components of foods such as proteins, lipids, carbohydrates and of the minor components such as enzymes, vitamins and various additives and their relationships to food stability and degradation.
name: FOOD 3001
prereq_text: FOOD 1001, FOOD 2001, CHEM 2204, BIOC 2200.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Chemistry

desc: In-depth principles and practices of food proximate analysis. Introductory concepts of food adulteration and detection. Major techniques such as chromatography, colorimetry, spectroscopy, rheology.
name: FOOD 3002
prereq_text: FOOD 1001, FOOD 2001, FOOD 3001.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Analysis

desc: An introduction to the materials used for food packaging, including their chemical and physical characteristics. Interactions of these materials with food products, and their effects on shelf life of food.
name: FOOD 3003
prereq_text: FOOD 2002.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Packaging and Shelf Life

desc: Principles of food engineering. Unit operation in food processing, heat and mass transfer, material balances, fluid mechanics.
name: FOOD 3004
prereq_text: FOOD 2002 and MATH 1007.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Engineering

desc: Foodborne diseases, microbial growth and survival, food spoilage, food fermentation. Techniques for detecting and quantifying microorganisms in foods.
name: FOOD 3005
prereq_text: FOOD 1001, FOOD 2001, BIOL 2303.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Microbiology

desc: Provides practical experience for students enrolled in the Co-operative option. Students must receive satisfactory evaluations from their work term employer. Written and oral reports will be required. Graded as Sat or Uns.
name: FOOD 3999
prereq_text: Registration in the Food Science Co-operative Education option and permission of the Department.
subject: FOOD
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Factors affecting quality in manufacturing and processing of foods and principles of quality control and quality assurance. Sampling plans and statistical methods. Applications of physical, chemical, biological and microbiological tests in quality control. Quality systems and standards.
name: FOOD 4001
prereq_text: FOOD 2002, FOOD 2003, and third or fourth year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Quality Control

desc: Official methods to identify food contaminants and adulterated foods. Includes agricultural chemicals, veterinary drugs, toxins, metals, and allergens. Interpretation of results in the context of current Canadian and international food safety regulations.
name: FOOD 4002
prereq_text: BIOC 3101 or CHEM 3205 or CHEM 3305, and third or fourth year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Analysis of Food Contaminants

desc: Focus on the ever-changing and evolving issues in Canadian food governance, regulation and policy. Topical food safety, governance, policies, enforcement, trade and import/export issues and developments.
name: FOOD 4102
prereq_text: FOOD 2003, and third or fourth year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Current Issues in Canadian Food Governance, Regulation and Policy

desc: The role of risk management in providing science-based approaches to solving food safety problems. Risk management models and practical applications in critical risk management. An examination of actual risk assessments. Risk communication is addressed.
name: FOOD 4103
prereq_text: BIOC 3101, and third or fourth-year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Safety Risk Assessment

desc: Metabolism of macronutrients in the human body. Detailed catabolic and anabolic reactions of carbohydrates, lipids and proteins. Regulatory control points in healthy and diseased states. Discussion of the literature pertaining to nutrition, metabolism and chronic disease.
name: FOOD 4201
prereq_text: FOOD 2001, BIOC 3101 and fourth year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Advanced Nutrition and Metabolism

desc: Animal and plant-based sources of micronutrients. Metabolism of vitamins and minerals in the human body and associated diseases throughout the life cycle. Micronutrient supplementation to promote human health.
name: FOOD 4202
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200 and third or fourth year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Micronutrients and Health

desc: Study of the bioactive components of functional foods and natural health products, for the improvement of health and nutrition. Sources and chemistry of bioactives, mechanisms of actions, process technology, efficacy and safety. Role of research and development in industry in commercialization of new products.
name: FOOD 4203
prereq_text: BIOC 2200 or BIOL 2200 or BIOL 2201, and third or fourth year standing.
subject: FOOD
title: Functional Foods and Natural Health Products

desc: Principles of toxicology as they apply to endogenous plant toxicants, endogenous animal poisons, mycotoxins, pesticide residues, veterinary drugs, food additives, heavy metals, and toxicants produced as a result of processing.
name: FOOD 4301
prereq_text: BIOC 3101, FOOD 3001 and fourth-year standing in Food Science.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Toxicology

desc: Active learning in areas that include information literacy, critical evaluation of scientific literature, written and oral communication, evaluation and interpretation of results, statistics and data management. Emphasizes transferable skills that are most appropriate for non-research career paths.
name: FOOD 4905
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in Food Science and a minimum of 1.5 credits in FOOD at the 3000 level.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Science Honours Workshop

desc: Students conduct an independent research study using library resources, and prepare a critical review and study proposal on a topic approved by a faculty supervisor. A written report and an oral poster presentation of the work are required before a grade can be assigned.
name: FOOD 4907
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in the Food Science program, a minimum of 1.5 credits in FOOD at the 3000 level, minimum Major CGPA of 8.0, and permission of the department.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Science Honours Essay and Research Proposal

desc: Students in Food Science carry out a research project under the direction of a faculty member. A written report and an oral presentation of the work are required before a grade can be assigned.
name: FOOD 4908
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in the Food Science program, a minimum of 1.5 credits in FOOD at the 3000 level, minimum Major CGPA of 8.0, and permission of the department.
subject: FOOD
title: Food Science Research Project

desc: This course is designed for absolute beginners in the language. Classes use audio-visual methods, and emphasis is given to the spoken language. Introduction to reading and writing. Compulsory attendance. Limited enrolment. No auditors. Oral interaction required.
name: FREN 1001
prereq_text: placement test on Carleton Central before registering.
subject: FREN
title: French 1

desc: Taught in French for students who have had exposure to French but who have difficulty using it in day-to-day communication. Emphasis on oral expression and comprehension; development of reading and writing skills. Oral practice, presentations, interviews, cultural activities, grammar. Compulsory attendance, participation. Oral interaction required.
name: FREN 1002
prereq_text: Grade of C or higher in FREN 1001 or placement test on Carleton Central before registering.
subject: FREN
title: French 2

desc: Taught in French. Emphasis on speaking, listening, reading and writing skills. Oral presentations, discussions, interviews, reading of novels and magazine articles, listening activities, grammar exercises, compositions. Attendance and participation are compulsory. Limited enrolment. No auditors. Oral interaction required.
name: FREN 1100
prereq_text: Grade of C or higher in FREN 1002 or placement test on Carleton Central before registering.
subject: FREN
title: French 3

desc: Taught in French. For students with low intermediate writing skills in French. Improvement of spelling, grammar, sentence-structure and vocabulary. Study of the processes involved in the production of a variety of texts. Introduction to the use of references. Self-correction. Attendance, participation compulsory. Oral interaction required.
name: FREN 1110
prereq_text: Grade of C or higher in FREN 1002 or placement test on Carleton Central before registering.
subject: FREN
title: French 3: Writing

desc: Taught in French. For non-francophone students. Advanced speaking, listening, reading and writing skills. Advanced level reading from various sources, including literary texts. Grammar exercises, essays, oral presentations. Attendance and participation are compulsory. Limited enrolment. No auditors. Oral interaction required.
name: FREN 2100
prereq_text: Grade of C or higher in FREN 1100 or FREN 1110 or placement test on Carleton Central before registering.
subject: FREN
title: French 4

desc: Taught in French. For students with intermediate French writing skills. Refinement of spelling, grammar, sentence-structure and vocabulary; accuracy and textual organization. Essay-writing. Use and referencing of various sources. Self-correction. Attendance and participation compulsory. Oral interaction required.
name: FREN 2110
prereq_text: Grade of C or higher in FREN 1100 or FREN 1110 or placement test on Carleton Central before registering. First week: compulsory placement. Limited enrolment. No auditors.
subject: FREN
title: French 4: Writing

desc: Survol historique des littératures d'expression française : principaux auteurs, grands mouvements, évolution des genres. Initiation aux méthodes et notions d'analyse littéraire.
name: FREN 2202
prereq_text: FREN 1100 or FREN 1110 with a grade of C or higher or permission of the Department. This course may be taken concurrently with FREN 2100 or FREN 2110.
subject: FREN
title: Introduction aux études littéraires 1

desc: Survol historique des littératures d'expression française au Québec et au Canada : principaux auteurs, grands mouvements, évolution des genres. Initiation aux méthodes et notions d'analyse littéraire.
name: FREN 2203
prereq_text: FREN 1100 or FREN 1110 with a grade of C or higher or permission of the Department. This course may be taken concurrently with FREN 2100 or FREN 2110.
subject: FREN
title: Introduction aux études littéraires 2

desc: Étude de la structure et du fonctionnement du système linguistique à travers l'analyse de données du français (de France et du Canada). La construction du sens, des sons au discours; code oral et écrit.
name: FREN 2401
prereq_text: FREN 1100 or FREN 1110 with a grade of C or higher or permission of the Department. This course may be taken concurrently with FREN 2100 or FREN 2110.
subject: FREN
title: Introduction à la linguistique française

desc: Travaux pratiques pour développer l’aisance et la fluidité dans l’expression orale. This course is not suitable for francophones.
name: FREN 2701
prereq_text: Grade of C or higher in FREN 1100 or FREN 1110 or placement test on Carleton Central before registering.
subject: FREN
title: Travaux pratiques en français oral

desc: Initiation aux techniques et pratiques de la réflexion universitaire : documentation (bibliothèque, bases de données, bibliographies critiques), lecture (analyse, synthèse et évaluation critique de textes de savoir) et réflexion (cadre théorique, méthode d'analyse, pratique du discours raisonné).
name: FREN 3050
prereq_text: FREN 2202, FREN 2203 and FREN 2401, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Compétences critiques

desc: Analyse et pratique réfléchie des formes de la grammaire dans le discours: Structures des phrases, marques d’accord, concordance des temps, prépositions et compléments, homonymie et homographie, faux amis et anglicismes. Développement des techniques efficaces d’autocorrection et maîtrise d’outils informatisés.
name: FREN 3060
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203 or FREN 2401, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Perfectionnement de la grammaire par la pratique

desc: Étude d'une sélection de textes, tirés de divers genres, permettant d'explorer les origines de la littérature française : oralité et écriture; chansons de geste; courtoisie; récits de voyages; littérature de la cour; humanisme. Différentes approches théoriques du texte littéraire.
name: FREN 3212
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Des manuscrits aux belles-lettres : de la littérature médiévale à l'humanisme

desc: Étude des 17e et 18e siècles : raison et universalisme, encyclopédisme, construction et représentation de l'altérité, colonialisme et esclavagisme. Analyse d'importants développements littéraires : essai et conte philosophiques, théâtre et critique sociale, évolution du discours romanesque. Approches théoriques du texte littéraire.
name: FREN 3213
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Du Baroque aux Lumières

desc: Étude de quelques grands mouvements ayant rythmé la vie des lettres francophones : romantisme, réalisme, naturalisme, symbolisme, surréalisme, modernisme. La littérature de la décolonisation et l'émergence de la littérature canadienne-française. Analyse des genres et de leur évolution. Approches théoriques du texte littéraire.
name: FREN 3214
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Révolutions, avant-gardes et ruptures : du 19e siècle aux années 1950

desc: Études des principales orientations définissant les littératures francophones contemporaines depuis la fin de la Seconde Guerre mondiale : littérature engagée, existentialisme, nouveau roman. Littérature du Québec et du Canada français. Littératures postcoloniales, émergentes, transnationales. Approches théoriques du texte littéraire.
name: FREN 3215
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Les ères du soupçon : contemporanéités de la littérature

desc: Étude approfondie d’une problématique dans le champ des études littéraires. Lectures critiques, réflexion théorique et études d’œuvres littéraires. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 3216
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Problématique littéraire

desc: Étude approfondie d’un(e) auteur(e) ou groupe d’auteur(e)s et de leur œuvre. Lectures critiques, théoriques et littéraires. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 3217
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Œuvre et auteur-e(s)

desc: Étude approfondie d’un genre ou mouvement littéraire. Conditions d'émergence (contextes: historique, social, artistique, etc). Textes théoriques et manifestes. Principaux représentants. Influence (continuations, ruptures). Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 3218
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Genre et mouvement

desc: Présentation et application de diverses approches théoriques du texte littéraire ou étude approfondie d’une approche théorique particulière (analyses structurelles, méthodes d'interprétation, contextualisation sociohistorique, poétique, etc.).
name: FREN 3251
prereq_text: FREN 2202 and FREN 2203, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Introduction aux méthodes d'analyse littéraire

desc: Étude empirique et théorique des éléments et systèmes phonétiques et phonologiques du français. Processus segmentaux et suprasegmentaux, structures syllabiques et prosodiques. Problèmes classiques de la phonologie française.
name: FREN 3411
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Phonétique et phonologie du français

desc: Étude de la forme des unités lexicales et grammaticales du français et de leur portée signifiante. Analyse du système flexionnel du français et des mécanismes de formation des mots.
name: FREN 3412
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Morphologie du français

desc: Études de la structure et des composantes de la phrase: mots et syntagmes. Analyse syntaxique de la phrase simple et complexe. Modèle hiérarchique de l’organisation de la phrase.
name: FREN 3413
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Syntaxe du français

desc: Le français, une réalité hétérogène. Approche variationiste, qualitative et quantitative, de l'étude du français dans ses dimensions dialectales, sociales et stylistiques. Variations intra-individuelles et entre individus. Facteurs externes de la variation interne du français. Diversités du français.
name: FREN 3414
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Sociolinguistique du français

desc: Évolution interne de l'histoire du français et de ses influences externes. De sa naissance, présumée et réelle, à ses états actuels. Les langues contributrices. Contacts linguistiques. Dynamiques du changement linguistique. Véhicularisation et vernacularisation. Idéologies de la langue française.
name: FREN 3415
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Histoire du français

desc: Présentation des variétés de français parlé dans le monde, principalement à l’extérieur du Canada. Étude des aspects historiques et sociopolitiques de la diffusion du français. Analyse des traits linguistiques propres aux variétés. Colonisation, créolisation, emprunt linguistique, variation régionale, aménagement linguistique.
name: FREN 3416
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Le français dans le monde

desc: Présentation des variétés de français parlé au Canada. Étude des aspects historiques et sociopolitiques de l’implantation du français en Nouvelle-France. Variétés laurentienne et acadienne. Analyse des traits linguistiques. Enjeux sociolinguistiques. Contact des langues, bilinguisme, minorités linguistiques.
name: FREN 3417
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Le français au Canada

desc: Étude d’un thème particulier en linguistique française. Le contenu varie selon l’année. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 3451
prereq_text: FREN 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Thème en linguistique

desc: Perfectionnement de l'expression écrite au moyen d'un apprentissage appliqué de la traduction. Analyses des principales interférences syntaxiques, sémantiques et discursives entre le français et l'anglais. Approfondissement des pratiques de textualisation: cohérence et cohésion, idiomatisation, registres, paraphrase, considérations stylistiques, etc. Approche privilégiant le texte pragmatique.
name: FREN 3511
prereq_text: one FREN course at the 2000-level, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Expression écrite et traduction

desc: Techniques avancées d'expression orale. This course is not suitable for francophones.
name: FREN 3701
prereq_text: one FREN course at the 2000 level, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Français oral

desc: Techniques avancées d'expression écrite.
name: FREN 3702
prereq_text: one FREN course at the 2000-level, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Français écrit

desc: Initiation aux études des programmes au Canada et ailleurs. Processus d'acquisition des habiletés d'expression et de compréhension. Survol des théories passées et actuelles. Appréciation et critique de pratiques pédagogiques.
name: FREN 3900
prereq_text: one FREN course at the 2000-level, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Apprentissage et enseignement du français langue seconde

name: FREN 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: FREN
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Développement d’un projet individuel supervisé en littérature ou en linguistique, amorcé dans un cours antérieur. Raffinement de l’expression et des idées. Présentation publique des résultats.
name: FREN 4060
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the BA Honours in French.
subject: FREN
title: Projet de recherche supervisé

desc: Analyse de problématiques liées à la francophonie littéraire. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4212
prereq_text: FREN 2202, FREN 2203 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Littératures francophones

desc: Étude approfondie portant sur un ou plusieurs aspects des littératures d'expression française au Canada. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4213
prereq_text: FREN 2202, FREN 2203 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Littérature québécoise et canadienne d'expression française

desc: Étude approfondie d'un thème, d'un mouvement, d'un genre dans le champ littéraire. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4214
prereq_text: FREN 2202, FREN 2203 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Genre et mouvement

desc: Étude de questions contemporaines dans le domaine littéraire. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4215
prereq_text: FREN 2202, FREN 2203 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Problématiques contemporaines

desc: Topics in French language, literature or linguistics. Application of language skills in a francophone context. Topic and location may vary; consult Departmental website.
name: FREN 4300
prereq_text: None
subject: FREN
title: Experiential learning in French and Francophone studies

desc: Études des variétés du français, dans ses dimensions spatiales. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4412
prereq_text: FREN 2401 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Diversité du français

desc: Étude du français, dans ses dimensions historiques. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4413
prereq_text: FREN 2401 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Diachronie du français

desc: Étude du français, dans ses dimensions morphologiques, syntaxiques ou phonologiques. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4414
prereq_text: FREN 2401 and FREN 3050, or permission of the department.
subject: FREN
title: Analyse du français

desc: Étude des variations internes de la langue, dans ses dimensions orales et écrites. Contenu variable selon les années : consulter le site web du département de français. Repeatable for credit when the topic changes.
name: FREN 4415
prereq_text: FREN 2401 and FREN 3050, or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Variation du français

desc: Initiation à différents principes et approches méthodologiques de la traduction. Analyse de texte appliquée à la traduction, repérage raisonné des difficultés, typologie des fautes de traduction, étude de divers procédés, documentation, terminologie et révision. Approche privilégiant une typologie textuelle variée.
name: FREN 4511
prereq_text: FREN 3511 or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Traduction : méthodologie et pratique

desc: Special topics in an aspect of French studies under the supervision of a faculty member.
name: FREN 4801
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Tutorial A

desc: Special topics in an aspect of French studies under the supervision of a faculty member.
name: FREN 4802
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Tutorial B

desc: Approfondissement de considérations théoriques et pratiques reliées à l’enseignement et l’apprentissage du français comme langue seconde. Analyse de composantes pédagogiques générales et en contexte, applications didactiques. Évaluation, critères et standards. Le contenu précis de ce cours varie selon les années. Consulter le site Web.
name: FREN 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FREN
title: Thème choisi en apprentissage et enseignement du français langue seconde

desc: Development of reading skills, especially relating to academic texts. Basic French grammar and vocabulary. Given in English. Open to beginners. No auditors.
name: FINS 2105
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: French Reading I

desc: Training in basic comprehension of spoken French, through the study of selected and edited video and audio material. Oral documents in French; analyses, discussion, reporting and testing in English. No auditors.
name: FINS 2205
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Oral Comprehension I

desc: This course surveys geographical, historical, demographic, cultural, political and social developments in Québec, relations with English Canada and debates on identity and nationalism. This course is also offered in French as CDNS 2511/FINS 2511.
name: FINS 2510
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Introduction to Québec Society (English version)

desc: Ce cours exclusivement en ligne permettra de découvrir et d'analyser des référents dominants de la trame historique du Québec de même que les débats entourant l'identité et le nationalisme et les relations avec le Canada anglais.
name: FINS 2511
prereq_text: niveau de deuxième année ou permission de L'École d'études canadiennes.
subject: FINS
title: Introduction à la société et à la culture québécoises (version française)

desc: Reading knowledge for academic purposes. Advanced reading strategies. Individual reading in the student's specialization. Given in English. No auditors.
name: FINS 3105
prereq_text: FINS 2105 or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: French Reading II

desc: Advanced training and practice in the comprehension of authentic oral materials in French. Individual assignments in the student's specialization. Oral documents in French; analysis, discussion, reporting and testing in English and French. No auditors.
name: FINS 3205
prereq_text: FINS 2205 or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Oral Comprehension II

desc: Topics may vary from year to year. Consult the Web site.
name: FINS 3405
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: French for Special or Professional Purposes I

desc: Topics may vary from year to year. Consult the Web site.
name: FINS 3406
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: French for Special or Professional Purposes II

desc: Topics may vary from year to year. Consult the Web site.
name: FINS 3407
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: French for Special or Professional Purposes III

desc: Exploration of intercultural encounters between French and English Canadians in political, popular and “official” cultures, through an examination of media, art, music, literature, cinema and the built environment.
name: FINS 3550
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Interfaces between English and French Canadian Cultures

desc: Students may take a third-year course offered in the Department of French while submitting course work in English. This course does not count towards any degree program in French.
name: FINS 3801
prereq_text: third-year standing and permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Selected Topics in French A

desc: Advanced seminar focusing on selected aspects of Québec history, society, culture and/or politics.
name: FINS 4510
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and CDNS 3500, FINS 3500 or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Québec Studies

desc: Students may take a fourth- or fifth-year special topic seminar offered in the Department of French while submitting written work in English. This course does not count towards credit in any degree program in French.
name: FINS 4801
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Selected Topics in French A

desc: Students may take a fourth- or fifth-year special topic seminar offered in the Department of French while submitting written work in English. This course does not count towards credit in any degree program in French.
name: FINS 4802
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: FINS
title: Selected Topics in French B

desc: Principles, processes and interactions in the Earth's environment emphasizing the flow of energy and matter within global systems. Atmospheric and oceanic processes, earth surface processes and biogeochemical cycling. Case studies on the interaction between human activity and the natural environment.
name: GEOG 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOG
title: Global Environmental Systems

desc: Introduction to human geography. Examination of relationships between people, communities, society and the natural environment at local to global scales. Population change, cultural patterns, and historical, economic, political and environmental forces that shape human activity and experiences from place to place.
name: GEOG 1020
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOG
title: People, Places and Environments

desc: Introduction to the study of cities, urbanization and suburbanization. Geography of urban experience, development and change across an urbanizing planet. Urbanization processes, patterns and issues in different cities and regions; the relationships among urban areas.
name: GEOG 1023
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOG
title: Introduction to Cities and Urbanization

desc: Introduction to the research process, from generating questions to reporting results. Topics include intensive and extensive research approaches; the use of surveys, interviews and other data collection methods; the analysis of qualitative information; and the ethical dimensions of doing research with people and communities.
name: GEOG 2005
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in GEOG or ENST at the 1000-level and second-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Introduction to Qualitative Research

desc: Introduction to solving problems using descriptive and inferential statistical methods. Graphical and numerical tools to describe distributions. Probability, sampling and estimates, and hypothesis testing. Fundamentals of spatial statistics and analysis.
name: GEOG 2006
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOG
title: Introduction to Quantitative Research

desc: Introduction to climate, weather and the hydrological cycle. Physical properties of the atmosphere, radiation and energy balances, global circulation, atmospheric moisture and precipitation, weather systems and forecasting, mechanisms of climate change.
name: GEOG 2013
prereq_text: GEOG 1010 or ERTH 1006 or ISCI 1001.
subject: GEOG
title: Weather and Water

desc: Introduction to geomorphology. Weathering, slope and fluvial processes within drainage basins, and glacial and periglacial processes.
name: GEOG 2014
prereq_text: GEOG 1010 or ERTH 1006 or ISCI 1001.
subject: GEOG
title: The Earth's Surface

desc: Introduction to world biomes and in-depth analysis of the distribution and development of Canada’s major ecosystems including the boreal forest, temperate forest, tundra, grasslands, wetlands, and aquatic environments; Current issues in ecosystem science and conservation such as agricultural management, forestry and urban ecology.
name: GEOG 2020
prereq_text: GEOG 1010 or ERTH 1006 or ERTH 1010 or ISCI 1001.
subject: GEOG
title: Ecosystems of Canada

desc: Geographical perspectives on the uneven power relationships and politics that shape urban lives and urban space. Key topics may include housing and segregation, planning for sustainable cities, urban social movements, urban inequality and changing livelihoods.
name: GEOG 2023
prereq_text: GEOG 1023, or second-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: GEOG
title: Cities, Inequality and Urban Change

desc: Globalization and global environmental change as linked processes. Geographical analysis of economic, cultural and political transformations acting at global, national and local scales. Choices and constraints underlying economic, social and environmental sustainability.
name: GEOG 2200
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Global Connections

desc: Introduction to social and cultural geography, including how theories of space, place, landscape, power, and knowledge can be used to understand the geographic dimensions of social and cultural life. Topics include culture and identity, migration and transnationalism, nature, gender, sexuality, race, colonialism, consumption, and work.
name: GEOG 2300
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Space, Place and Culture

desc: An introduction to climate change as a political, economic and socio-cultural phenomenon, including the political-economic and world-historical causes of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions; variations in impact and vulnerability; climate justice and other political movements; global mitigation and adaptation strategies; and proposals for radical systemic change.
name: GEOG 2500
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Climate Change: Social Science Perspectives

desc: Exploration of the geographical backgrounds to selected issues of current public interest, through geography's perspective of integrating human and physical environments. Issues selected will be structured from the global through the national/regional to the local, identifying the interdependencies among the scales.
name: GEOG 2600
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOG
title: Geography Behind the Headlines

desc: Field research, with a focus on data collection methods, analysis and presentation of findings. Design and conduct research that links the human and biophysical environment. Topics may change from year to year.
name: GEOG 3000
prereq_text: GEOG 2005/ENST 2005 and GEOG 2006/ENST 2006, third-year Honours standing in Geography, Geomatics or Environmental Studies, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Honours Field Course

desc: Theory and methods used in qualitative approaches to research in human geography; hands-on experience and discussion of beliefs and claims underlying scholarly work. Ethical and practical dilemmas confronting researchers. Gathering and interpreting qualitative information; representing knowledge.
name: GEOG 3001
prereq_text: GEOG 2005 or ENST 2005.
subject: GEOG
title: Doing Qualitative Research

desc: Quantitative methods used in geographical research: multiple correlation and regression, principal component/factor analysis, spatial statistics, cluster analysis, and a review of other selected techniques. Computer-based analysis.
name: GEOG 3003
prereq_text: GEOG 2006 or ENST 2006 or STAT 2507 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Quantitative Geography

desc: Selected topics concerning human geography not usually included in regular course offerings. Topic varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department for more information.
name: GEOG 3009
prereq_text: GEOG 1020 or ENST 1020 and third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Special Topics in Human Geography

desc: Field and laboratory approaches, methodologies and techniques in physical geography. Field projects will be undertaken to collect data for analysis, evaluation and presentation.
name: GEOG 3010
prereq_text: GEOG 2006 or ENST 2006 or STAT 2507 and GEOG 2013 or GEOG 2014 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Field Methods in Physical Geography

desc: Examination of culture, identity and place over time. Colonial and other historical processes that have shaped societies from place to place; relationships between cultural groups and their natural surroundings; gender, ethnicity, nationality and other dimensions of identity; impacts of globalization.
name: GEOG 3021
prereq_text: GEOG 2300 and third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Geographies of Culture and Identity

desc: Exploration of complexity, dynamics, uncertainty and equity issues underpinning environmental and resource issues; review and appraisal of selected contemporary methods to assess and manage environmental and natural resources.
name: GEOG 3022
prereq_text: third-year standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or BGInS Specialization/Stream in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Environmental and Natural Resources

desc: Introduces the study of cities as "systems of cities", the political economy of linkages between urban places located unevenly in space, and "cities as systems". Case studies of socio-cultural, political and economic relations within biophysical and built environments.
name: GEOG 3023
prereq_text: GEOG 2023 and third-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: GEOG
title: Cities in a Global World

desc: Geographical analysis of processes of globalization: theoretical frameworks, historical context and contemporary challenges.
name: GEOG 3024
prereq_text: GEOG 2200 and third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Understanding Globalization

desc: Geographical analysis of key questions facing a selected region of the world. Attention will focus on selected topics within one or more regions and their related global context.
name: GEOG 3025
prereq_text: third-year standing in a B.A. program or BGInS Specialization/Stream in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Geographies of Selected Regions

desc: Selected topic concerning the geography of Canada. Topic varies from year to year.
name: GEOG 3026
prereq_text: GEOG 1020 or ENST 1020 and second-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Topics in the Geography of Canada

desc: Guided and independent geographic field research, with a focus on data collection methods, and analysis and presentation of findings. Consists of an excursion outside of the Ottawa region. A supplementary charge may apply.
name: GEOG 3030
prereq_text: third-year Honours standing in Geography or BGInS Specialization in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Regional Field Excursion

desc: Geomorphological agents of landscape change at the Earth's surface, emphasizing the role of water, ice and wind in erosion and deposition; use of geomorphic indicators in studies of environmental change. A supplementary charge may apply.
name: GEOG 3102
prereq_text: GEOG 2014 and third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Geomorphology

desc: Principles of hydrology at local and watershed scales, emphasizing: soil moisture regimes; field data collection and analysis of surface water or snow and ice conditions; hydrologic processes in cold environments; and regional runoff regimes in Canada.
name: GEOG 3103
prereq_text: GEOG 2013 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Watershed Hydrology

desc: Contemporary and past controls on distribution of plants and animals at global, regional and local scales; significance of these distributions.
name: GEOG 3104
prereq_text: GEOG 1010 or BIOL 2600, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Principles of Biogeography

desc: The global climate system, with emphasis on global change variability over the historical and modern periods; the changing composition of the atmosphere and its impact on climate; analysis and interpretation of climatic and atmospheric data; modeling of climate systems.
name: GEOG 3105
prereq_text: GEOG 2013 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Climate and Atmospheric Change

desc: Fundamentals of aquatic science. The physical, chemical, and biotic aspects of lake, river, and estuary systems including human impacts, management and conservation.
name: GEOG 3106
prereq_text: third-year standing and a second-year science or engineering course.
subject: GEOG
title: Aquatic Science and Management

desc: The physical and chemical properties of soils; soil-water relationships, weathering processes, soil mineralogy, cation exchange, soil pH. A plant-oriented perspective predominates.
name: GEOG 3108
prereq_text: GEOG 2013 or GEOG 2014 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Soil Properties

desc: Factors influencing human health in an ecological framework involving population structure, habitat, and behaviour. Changes in the distribution of communicable and degenerative diseases are portrayed as being related to historical and contemporary development and globalization processes. Sources, types and characteristics of geographically referenced health information.
name: GEOG 3206
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: GEOG
title: Health, Environment, and Society

desc: Analysis of the relationships between people and environment in selected regions in the South (Africa, Asia, Latin America). Emphasis on sustainable livelihoods and local action in relation to broader socio-economic and political processes. Regions selected vary from year to year.
name: GEOG 3209
prereq_text: third-year standing and ENST 2000 or ENST 2001 or GEOG 2200 or GEOG 2300 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Sustainability and Environment in the South

desc: Geographical approaches to economic development and difference at local, regional and global scales. Critical historical, cultural, social and political economic perspectives on 'development', including theories of the state, colonial power, and development institutions. Spatial dynamics and environmental impacts of economic activity.
name: GEOG 3404
prereq_text: GEOG 2200 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Geographies of Economic Development

desc: The physical characteristics, historical geography, economic resources, settlement patterns and problems and the future development of Arctic and Subarctic lands, focusing primarily on Canada.
name: GEOG 3501
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Geographies of the Canadian North

desc: The distributional aspects of population attributes; areal patterns of population characteristics and their spatial variations associated with differences in the nature of places; migratory movements within the framework of spatial models of interactions between locations.
name: GEOG 3700
prereq_text: GEOG 2200 or GEOG 2300, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Population Geography

name: GEOG 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOG
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Field observation and methodology in a selected region; individual or group basis.
name: GEOG 4000
prereq_text: third-year Honours standing and permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Field Studies

desc: Principles, scope and purpose of environmental impact assessment, from conceptual and methodological points of view; range of environmental issues, with emphasis on Canadian case studies.
name: GEOG 4004
prereq_text: GEOG 3022 or ENST 3022, and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or Environmental Science, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Environmental Impact Assessment

desc: Students pursue their interest in a selected theme in geography on a tutorial basis with a member of the Department.
name: GEOG 4005
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Directed Studies in Geography

desc: Selected topics in geography and/or environmental studies.
name: GEOG 4007
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in the Department of permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Special Topics in Geography and Environmental Studies

desc: An examination of cold region hydrologic processes via experimental and observational studies; analysis of hydrologic data and application of hydrologic models.
name: GEOG 4013
prereq_text: GEOG 3103.
subject: GEOG
title: Cold Region Hydrology

desc: Processes that control the fluxes and reservoirs of biologically active chemical constituents on land, in the atmosphere, and in the oceans. Interactions between biogeochemical cycles and the Earth's climate; impact of land use and fossil fuel emissions on biogeochemical cycles and global change.
name: GEOG 4017
prereq_text: GEOG 3108 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Global Biogeochemical Cycles

desc: Selected topic or field of inquiry concerning the geographic dimensions of culture, identity and place.
name: GEOG 4021
prereq_text: GEOG 3021 and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Seminar in Culture, Identity and Place

desc: A selected topic or field of inquiry concerning natural resource use and environmental change.
name: GEOG 4022
prereq_text: GEOG 3022 or ENST 3022 and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or BGInS Specialization in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Seminar in People, Resources and Environmental Change

desc: A selected topic or field of inquiry concerning urban geography.
name: GEOG 4023
prereq_text: GEOG 3023 and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies or BGInS Specialization in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Seminar in Special Topics on the City

desc: A selected issue or topic related to globalization.
name: GEOG 4024
prereq_text: GEOG 3024 and fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or BGInS Specialization in Globalization and Environment or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Seminar in Globalization

desc: Major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, including history of geographic thought, geographic responses to social and political movements and debates, and geographic engagement with contemporary critical theory.
name: GEOG 4040
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Geographic Thought

desc: Selected theoretical and applied issues concerning environmental and geographic education.
name: GEOG 4050
prereq_text: third-year Honours standing in Geography or Environmental Studies, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Environmental and Geographic Education

desc: Multidisciplinary scientific study of the changes in the physical environment of the Earth during the last two million years and methods of studying recent Earth history, with focus on current research.
name: GEOG 4101
prereq_text: third year standing in a B.Sc. program, or a third year Science Geography Elective or a third year ERTH course, or permission of the Department. Note: GEOG 3105 is recommended.
subject: GEOG
title: Two Million Years of Environmental Change

desc: A quantitative analysis of natural water systems and the development of these systems as a resource. Components of the hydrologic cycle. Quantitative analysis of stream flow. Probability concepts in water resources. Reservoir design and operation. Availability of groundwater. Storm water management.
name: GEOG 4103
prereq_text: permission of the Department. Recommended background: MAAE 2300.
subject: GEOG
title: Water Resources Engineering

desc: The formation of microclimates near the Earth's surface; energy and water flows; the interaction of atmospheric processes with the physical properties of surfaces.
name: GEOG 4104
prereq_text: GEOG 2013 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Microclimatology

desc: Distribution, development, and degradation of permafrost in Canada; thermal and hydrologic regime of permafrost terrain; development of landforms in permafrost regions; geotechnical consideration in northern construction.
name: GEOG 4108
prereq_text: GEOG 3108 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Permafrost

desc: Transportation and the socio-economic environment; modal and intermodal systems and components; vehicle motion; human factors, system and facility design; traffic flow; capacity analysis; planning methodology; environmental impacts; evaluation methods.
name: GEOG 4304
prereq_text: third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Transportation Engineering and Planning

desc: History, theories, and practice of urban planning, as well as the policies, plans, and programs developed and implemented in diverse communities. Course topics may include the integration of community development and social planning, urban design, transportation and infrastructure, and environmental management.
name: GEOG 4323
prereq_text: GEOG 3023 and fourth-year standing in Geography or Environmental Studies, or permission of the department.
subject: GEOG
title: Urban and Regional Planning

desc: Experience in an employment environment through field placement. Observation and involvement in issues and research methods used by professional geographers. May be taken for credit in addition to GEOG/GEOM 4408.
name: GEOG 4406
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Geomatics and permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Practicum I

desc: Experience in an employment environment through field placement. Observation and involvement in issues and research methods used by professional geographers May be taken for credit in addition to GEOG/GEOM 4406.
name: GEOG 4408
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Geography or Geomatics and permission of the Department.
subject: GEOG
title: Practicum II

desc: Working in partnership with local organizations, students apply their geographical knowledge to conduct community-engaged research. Student projects will generate outputs for community partners. Research topics vary year to year.
name: GEOG 4450
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: GEOG
title: Community-Engaged Research

desc: A research project based on a modeling, laboratory or field problem. The project is supervised by a member of the department and a written thesis and poster must be submitted.
name: GEOG 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in B.Sc. Geography, and an approved research topic and adviser.
subject: GEOG
title: Honours Research Project

desc: Independent design and implementation of a research project leading to the submission of a research thesis. Students work with an individual faculty adviser. The subject for research is decided upon in consultation with the supervisor.
name: GEOG 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in B.A. Geography or B.Globalization and International Studies, a minimum CGPA of 9.00 in the major or permission of the Department, and an approved research topic and adviser.
subject: GEOG
title: Honours Research Thesis

desc: Introduction to the creation and use of maps using a variety of geospatial tools to better understand and resolve physical, social and environmental problems. Overview of geomatics (cartography and map design, geographic information systems, GPS, remote sensing).
name: GEOM 1004
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOM
title: Maps, Satellites and the Geospatial Revolution

desc: Computer programming for geomatics students focusing on storage, manipulation, management, visualization and analysis of geospatial data; Essential coding concepts and best practices including variables, loops, and conditional statements; programmatic handling of raster and vector data structures; batch geoprocessing and map production; GIS tool customization.
name: GEOM 2005
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOM
title: Introduction to Geospatial Programming

desc: Storage, visualization, manipulation and analysis of vector geospatial data. Vector geoprocessing including buffering, overlays and topological analysis; feature classification and cartographic representation; managing coordinate reference systems for vector layers; selected applications of vector GIS such as urban planning, environmental and resource management and socio-economic mapping.
name: GEOM 2007
prereq_text: GEOM 1004 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Points, Lines and Polygons

desc: Storage, visualization, manipulation, and analysis of gridded geospatial data; 3D raster visualization; digital terrain analysis; interpolation and filtering; raster geoprocessing and projections; selected topics in raster GIS such as least-cost path analysis, natural hazard assessment, pollution mapping, hotspot analysis for crime and disease mapping.
name: GEOM 2008
prereq_text: GEOM 1004 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Pixels and Grids

desc: Principles and methods of remote sensing; visual interpretation of air photos and satellite imagery; digital image processing, analysis and classification for thematic mapping; introduction to various active and passive remote sensing imagery types such as optical, hyperspectral, RADAR and LiDAR.
name: GEOM 3002
prereq_text: GEOM 2008 and third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Introduction to Remote Sensing

desc: An advanced course in geospatial analysis theory and practice; geoprocessing; geo-visualization; geostatistics; spatial modelling; working with spatio-temporal data structures; advanced site-suitability and network analysis; intermediate GIS tool customization.
name: GEOM 3005
prereq_text: GEOM 2007 and GEOM 2008.
subject: GEOM
title: Geospatial Analysis

desc: Principles of and issues in cartography, cartographic communication and map design; practical aspects of cartographic representation using multimedia and online/interactive mapping.
name: GEOM 3007
prereq_text: GEOM 2007 or GEOM 2008 or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Cartographic Theory and Design

name: GEOM 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: GEOM
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: A seminar focusing on selected topics in geomatics including advanced theory and/or application.
name: GEOM 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Geomatics or permission of the department.
subject: GEOM
title: Special Topics in Geomatics

desc: Advanced image enhancement; land cover classification for thematic mapping; biophysical modeling; applications in resources, environment, and urban mapping.
name: GEOM 4003
prereq_text: GEOM 3002 and Honours standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Remote Sensing of the Environment

desc: Students pursue their interest in a selected theme in Geomatics on a tutorial basis with a member of the Department.
name: GEOM 4005
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Directed Studies in Geomatics

desc: Advanced methods and techniques in GIS applications including: positional and attribute error analysis, multiple criteria decision making, interpolation, elevation modeling and ortho-imaging, and spatial pattern measurement.
name: GEOM 4008
prereq_text: GEOM 3005 and Honours standing.
subject: GEOM
title: Advanced Topics in Geographic Information Systems

desc: Project design and customization, application development within a GIS, digital atlas compilation and geomatics education.
name: GEOM 4009
prereq_text: GEOM 3005 and (COMP 1006 or GEOG 3003), or permission of the department.
subject: GEOM
title: Applications in Geographic Information Systems

desc: Experience in an employment environment through field placement. Observation and involvement in issues and research methods used by professional geographers. May be taken for credit in addition to GEOG/GEOM 4408.
name: GEOM 4406
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Geomatics or Geography and permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Practicum I

desc: Experience in an employment environment through field placement. Observation and involvement in issues and research methods used by professional geographers. May be taken for credit in addition to GEOG/GEOM 4406.
name: GEOM 4408
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Geomatics or Geography and permission of the Department.
subject: GEOM
title: Practicum II

desc: Candidates for B.Sc. with Concentration in Geomatics undertake a research project within their area of specialization. The project is supervised by a member of the department and a written report must be submitted. The candidate may be examined orally on the report.
name: GEOM 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in BSc Geomatics, and an approved research topic and adviser.
subject: GEOM
title: Honours Research Project

desc: Independent design and implementation of a research project leading to the submission of a research thesis. Students work with an individual faculty adviser. The subject for research is decided upon in consultation with the supervisor.
name: GEOM 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in B.A. Geomatics, a minimum CGPA of 9.00 in the major or permission of the Department, and an approved research topic and adviser.
subject: GEOM
title: Honours Research Thesis

desc: For students with no knowledge of German. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: GERM 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: GERM
title: First-Year German I

desc: Continuation of first-year German. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.

prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 1010, or permission of the School.
