name: GERM 1110
prereq_text: None
subject: GERM
title: Intensive First-Year German

desc: For students with no prior knowledge of German who would like to develop the skills to read a variety of German texts, including passages from scholarly journals, reports, online newspaper or magazine articles.
name: GERM 2000
prereq_text: None
subject: GERM
title: Reading in German I

desc: Further study of German to reach a more advanced level of ability in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: GERM 2010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 1020, GERM 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Second-Year German I

desc: Continuation of second-year German. Further study of German to reach a more advanced level of ability in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: GERM 2020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 2010, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Second-Year German II

desc: Further study of German to reach a more advanced level of ability in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: GERM 2110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 1020, GERM 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Intensive Second-Year German

desc: A continuation of Reading in German I. Further development of reading skills in German.
name: GERM 3000
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 2000 or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Reading in German II

desc: Continuation of the study of German to reach a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: GERM 3110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 2020, GERM 2110, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Intensive Third-Year German

desc: Advanced spoken and written German with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: GERM 4110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 3110, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Intensive Fourth-Year German

desc: Development of language use for specific purposes in contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains.
name: GERM 4215
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 4110, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: German for Specific Purposes

desc: Selected topics in German-speaking cultures and societies. Development of advanced language skills.
name: GERM 4380
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in GERM 4110, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Topics in German-speaking Cultures

desc: Research in a topic in German language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: GERM 4900
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in the Minor in German, grade of C or higher in GERM 4110 or equivalent, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Independent Study

desc: Research in a topic in German language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: GERM 4901
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in the Minor in German, grade of C or higher in GERM 4110 or equivalent, or permission of the School.
subject: GERM
title: Independent Study

desc: Introduction to political, social, cultural, economic and military developments in global and international history.
name: GINS 1000
prereq_text: Enrolment in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Global History

desc: Introduction to the evolution of the international system, including the rise of the state, sovereignty, and the challenge of international cooperation. The role of international law in addressing global issues such as human rights, security and trade.
name: GINS 1010
prereq_text: Enrolment in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: International Law and Politics

desc: Introduction to the intersection of globalization processes with social and cultural diversity as examined through ethnography and ethnographic methods. Topics may include cultural survival, growing economic inequality, ecological vulnerabilities, health practices, human rights, and shifting racialized, gendered, religious, ethnic, and national identities.
name: GINS 1020
prereq_text: Enrolment in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Ethnography, Globalization and Culture

desc: Introduction to key questions and issues in development studies, taught from an inter-disciplinary perspective.
name: GINS 1100
prereq_text: None
subject: GINS
title: Global Development

desc: This mandatory course introduces BGInS students to the International Experience Requirement (IER) and to the various policies and procedures associated with it. Graded SAT/UNS.
name: GINS 1300
prereq_text: first-year standing in BGInS.
subject: GINS
title: International Experience Requirement Preparation

desc: Introduction to global ethical issues, focusing on alternative lines of ethical argument. Topics may include poverty and unequal development, climate change, war and terrorism, reparations for colonialism and slavery, international relief services, ill effects of globalization, trafficking and forced labour, democracy and global governance.
name: GINS 2000
prereq_text: Second-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Ethics and Globalization

desc: An introduction to the world economy, international trade and finance, and economic development. Social and economic implications for both rich and poor countries of lowered barriers to the international flows of goods, services, capital, labour, and information in the age of globalization.
name: GINS 2010
prereq_text: Second-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Globalization and International Economic Issues

desc: A study of the global dynamics of the contemporary literary imagination and literary production; literature as cultural practice; the politics of literary circulation; the politics of language and translation.
name: GINS 2020
prereq_text: second-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Global Literatures

desc: Advanced analysis of global and international theories from a variety of perspectives, including realism, liberalism, postmodernism, constructivism, post-structuralism, literary and critical approaches.
name: GINS 3010
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Global and International Theory

desc: Examination of the relationship between individual places and global social and environmental processes. The changing nature of regions, states and political boundaries in the context of political and economic globalization and international migration. Social science perspectives on climate change vulnerability, adaptation and mitigation.
name: GINS 3020
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Places, Boundaries, Movements and Global Environmental Change

desc: Student teams work on a project related to global and international studies. Lectures are devoted to discussing group project-related issues and student presentations. A project proposal, a series of project reports and oral presentations, and a comprehensive final report are required.
name: GINS 3100
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: GINS
title: Global and International Group Project

desc: An experiential learning opportunity combining volunteer work abroad with classroom instruction on the Carleton campus. Through experiential engagement outside Canada, together with critical reflection, students will learn about the challenges and rewards of global engagement.
name: GINS 3200
prereq_text: third year standing.
subject: GINS
title: Experiential Learning Abroad

desc: Based at a partner university around the world, and taught by a Carleton faculty member, the course will include lectures, seminars, guest speakers, field visits and group research projects to examine a topic in global and international studies. Topic and location will change annually.
name: GINS 3300
prereq_text: third-year standing and approval by the BGInS Program Director.
subject: GINS
title: Global and International Studies Abroad: Selected Topics

desc: Placement for six weeks with a global and international focus.
name: GINS 3900
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: International Placement

desc: Placement for twelve weeks with a global and international focus.
name: GINS 3901
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: International Placement

desc: Placement for six weeks with a global and international focus for students outside of the BGInS Program.
name: GINS 3930
prereq_text: Third-year standing and minimum CGPA of 9.0.
subject: GINS
title: Carleton International Placement

desc: Placement for twelve weeks with a global and international focus for students outside of the BGInS Program.
name: GINS 3931
prereq_text: Third-year standing and minimum CGPA of 9.0.
subject: GINS
title: Carleton International Placement

name: GINS 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: GINS
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Examination of key debates in global and international studies from a variety of disciplinary and interdisciplinary perspectives. Integration of knowledge from different areas of emphasis in global studies. A major research paper is required that undertakes to focus theoretical insight on practical concerns.
name: GINS 4090
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in B.G.In.S.
subject: GINS
title: Honours Seminar in Global and International Studies

desc: A tutorial on selected topics in which seminars are not available.
name: GINS 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in B.G.In.S. and permission of the Program Director.
subject: GINS
title: Tutorial in Global and International Studies

desc: Individual research project resulting in a major essay, completed under the supervision of a faculty member and evaluated by both the supervisor and an appointed reader. B.G.In.S. regulations apply.
name: GINS 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in B.G.In.S. with a CGPA of 9.00 or higher, or permission of the Program Director.
subject: GINS
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: Theories, concepts and issues in international relations, global politics and global political economy. Topics may include conflict and intervention, peace and security, international institutions, human rights, gender, culture, globalization, multinational corporations, foreign policy, environmental issues, international development, and relations between rich and poor countries.
name: GPOL 1500
prereq_text: first-year standing in the Global Politics Specialization or Stream of the B.G.In.S. degree.
subject: GPOL
title: Debates in Global Politics

desc: Themes and debates in comparative politics, especially as they relate to the study and practice of Global Politics.
name: GPOL 2500
prereq_text: second-year standing in the Global Politics Specialization or Stream in the BGInS degree.
subject: GPOL
title: Debates in Comparative Politics

desc: Themes and issues with a global and comparative focus, examining the role of key actors and applying theories and knowledge gained in previous Global Politics courses.
name: GPOL 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Global Politics program or third-year standing in the Global Politics Specialization or Stream in the BGiNS degree.
subject: GPOL
title: Themes in Global and Comparative Politics

desc: The internship provides students with an opportunity to work with and study an organization whose institutional focus is on some international or regional aspect. Students will write a research paper on a topic related either to the organization or to the focus of the organization.
name: GPOL 3100
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Global Politics program or third-year standing in the Global Politics Specialization of the BGInS degree with a CGPA in the major of 9.00 or higher, or permission of the Department.
subject: GPOL
title: Internship in Global Politics

desc: Individual research project resulting in a major essay, completed under the supervision of a faculty member. The Honours Research Essay is evaluated by the supervisor and an appointed reader. Students are responsible for locating a faculty member willing to supervise the essay. Departmental regulations apply.
name: GPOL 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Global Politics with a CGPA of 9.00 or fourth-year standing in the Global Politics Specialization in the BGInS degree with a CGPA in the major of 9.00 or higher, or permission of the Department.
subject: GPOL
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: A course for beginners in ancient Greek, designed to give students a grasp of basic grammatical forms and vocabulary (with reference to English derivatives) through the reading of continuous Greek.
name: GREK 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: GREK
title: Introduction to Greek I

desc: A course for students with some previous knowledge of the language: study of grammatical forms and constructions; acquisition of reading skills.
name: GREK 1006
prereq_text: GREK 1005 or equivalent.
subject: GREK
title: Introduction to Greek II

desc: Further study of the language; introduction to the reading of ancient Greek authors.
name: GREK 2200
prereq_text: GREK 1006 or equivalent.
subject: GREK
title: Intermediate Greek I

desc: Continued study of the language; reading of selected prose and poetry by ancient Greek authors; development of translation skills.
name: GREK 2201
prereq_text: GREK 2200 or equivalent.
subject: GREK
title: Intermediate Greek II

desc: Reading and critical discussion of selections from ancient Greek.
name: GREK 3900
prereq_text: GREK 2200, GREK 2201 or equivalent.
subject: GREK
title: Advanced Greek I

desc: Reading and critical discussion of selections from ancient Greek.
name: GREK 3901
prereq_text: GREK 2200, GREK 2201 or equivalent.
subject: GREK
title: Advanced Greek II

name: GREK 4900
prereq_text: None
subject: GREK
title: Directed Study

name: GREK 4901
prereq_text: None
subject: GREK
title: Directed Study

desc: Introduction to what comprises a healthy body and mind, and what leads to illness and disease. Biomedical, psychosocial, and epidemiological approaches to current issues in the field of health. Policy and cultural/environmental contexts.
name: HLTH 1000
prereq_text: None
subject: HLTH
title: Fundamentals of Health

desc: Health and illness will be considered from an interdisciplinary perspective, including biomedical, cultural, psychosocial and environmental.
name: HLTH 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: HLTH
title: Principles of Health I

desc: Introduction to using library, database and/or bioinformatics resources to develop informed verbal, non-verbal and written communication within the context of healthcare, public health and health research. Concepts in ethical scholarship, proper use of sources and plagiarism will be introduced.
name: HLTH 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: HLTH
title: Health Science Communication

desc: An introduction to quantitative and qualitative methods and designs in health sciences research. Basic research skills will also be provided, including regulatory aspects of conducting research, information literacy skills, evaluating published research and other sources of evidence in the digital age.
name: HLTH 2001
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 or HLTH 1001.
subject: HLTH
title: Health Research Methods and Skills

desc: Introduction to the causes, natural history, and pathophysiology of common human diseases of various organ systems. Diseases related to structural and functional changes at the molecular, cellular and organ level.
name: HLTH 2002
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 and BIOL 1103 or HLTH 2020.
subject: HLTH
title: Molecular and Cellular Pathology

desc: Overview of the social determinants of health, ranging from early life experiences, poverty, social status, migration, and the physical environment. The relation between social determinants and environmental vulnerabilities, health behaviours, illness prevalence, treatment outcomes, and access to health care.
name: HLTH 2003
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 or HLTH 1001.
subject: HLTH
title: Social Determinants of Health

desc: Introduction to the pathogenic microorganisms, including fungal, bacterial, viral and prion. Biochemical, genetic, pathological and epidemiological aspects in the human context; their interaction with host defense systems and strategies for antibiotic and vaccine development.
name: HLTH 2004
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 and BIOL 1103 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Microbiology and Virology

desc: An overview of the history of medicine, its relationship to society, medical and health terminology, introduction to organ systems, diseases, illnesses and their diagnoses, current events in health and medicine.
name: HLTH 2020
prereq_text: HLTH 1001 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Principles of Health II

desc: Overview of issues in global health with focus on low- and middle-income countries. Key indicators and determinants of global health, implementation and evaluation of global programs, challenges of research and interventions in under served areas, and key players in addressing global health issues.
name: HLTH 3101
prereq_text: HLTH 2001 and HLTH 2003, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Global Health

desc: The health conditions of Indigenous peoples in different regions of the world; social and biological factors that contribute to greater risk and poor health; strategies of Indigenous peoples to restore health to their peoples.
name: HLTH 3102
prereq_text: HLTH 2001 and HLTH 2003, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Indigenous Health in a Global World

desc: The history of Canada’s health care system. The model of financing and intergovernmental responsibilities. Current and emerging policy debates facing our health care system, and the role of scientific evidence in decision-making and policy development.
name: HLTH 3103
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 or HLTH 1001, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Health Policy and Canada's Health Care System

desc: The general principles of health regulatory policies in Canada. The role of scientific evidence in developing legislation and regulations at different levels, including probable levels of risk, standards of evidence, cost-benefit analysis, ethical considerations, psychosocial factors influencing risk management and compliance, and evolving technologies.
name: HLTH 3104
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 or HLTH 1001, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Regulatory Issues and Human Health

desc: Basic concepts of epidemiologic study designs and measures; inferences that are fundamental to the identification of causes and prevalence of diseases. Specialized issues within epidemiology including gene-environment interactions and the clustering of specific disease phenotypes.
name: HLTH 3201
prereq_text: STAT 2507 and HLTH 2001, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Epidemiology

desc: Basic processes relevant to the immune system; the relationship between immune activity and functioning as related to the development of particular pathologies, such as virally-related illness, autoimmune disorders, inflammatory illnesses, and interactions with social and economic factors that promote immune-related disturbances.
name: HLTH 3302
prereq_text: HLTH 2002 and BIOL 2200 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Immunity and Immune-Related Disorders

desc: Advanced concepts in cell signaling and function, cell injury and death, tissue structure and wound healing and repair. This course will integrate genetic, biochemical and physiological mechanisms that contribute to health and disease.
name: HLTH 3303
prereq_text: HLTH 2002.
subject: HLTH
title: Molecular and Cellular Pathology II

desc: Epidemiological, psychological and physiological basis for disease in childhood and adolescence. Topics will be discussed from a global and Canadian perspective and include the medicalization of these diseases.
name: HLTH 3401
prereq_text: HLTH 2002 and HLTH 2003 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Diseases of Childhood

desc: Aging is accompanied by increased illness related to cardiovascular, immune and neurodegenerative processes. This course assesses the fundamental mechanisms that determine these pathological conditions. Molecular mechanisms and psychosocial determinants; intervention and therapeutic strategies.
name: HLTH 3402
prereq_text: HLTH 2002 and HLTH 2003 or permission of department.
subject: HLTH
title: Diseases of Aging

desc: The role of gender on psychosocial and biological mechanisms that alter the course of disease and treatment; health issues unique to women (e.g., reproductive and maternal health); the role of gender across cultures.
name: HLTH 3403
prereq_text: HLTH 2002 and HLTH 2003, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Gender and Health

desc: The psychosocial and biological mechanisms that interact to influence health outcomes. Cultural, political, socioeconomic, and psychological factors that can impact the biological mechanisms underlying both mental and physical health; epigenetic and genetic alterations; implications for psychosocial interventions.
name: HLTH 3404
prereq_text: HLTH 2002 and HLTH 2003 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Psychosocial and Biological Interactions in Health

desc: An interdisciplinary view of disability and chronic health conditions, including risk factors, prevalence, and the trajectory of such conditions. Functional impact based on life stage. Strategies for health promotion, prevention, accommodations, treatment, and rehabilitation.
name: HLTH 3503
prereq_text: HLTH 2002 and HLTH 2003 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Disability and Chronic Health Conditions

desc: These courses enable students to develop an understanding of the current state of research and practice in Health Sciences. They provide the opportunity to bring together knowledge from other courses, and for skills development including teamwork, communication and critical thinking.
name: HLTH 3901
prereq_text: third-year standing and above in the BHSc program, an overall CGPA of at least 8.5 and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Emerging Issues in Health Sciences I

desc: These courses enable students to develop an understanding of the current state of research and practice in Health Sciences. They provide the opportunity to bring together knowledge from other courses and for skills development, including teamwork, communication and critical thinking.
name: HLTH 3902
prereq_text: third-year standing and above in the BHSc program, an overall CGPA of at least 8.5 and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Emerging Issues in Health Sciences II

desc: These courses enable students to develop an understanding of the current state of research and practice in Health Sciences. They provide the opportunity to bring together knowledge from other courses and for skills development, including teamwork, communication and critical thinking.
name: HLTH 3903
prereq_text: third-year standing and above in the BHSc program, an overall CGPA of at least 8.5 and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Emerging Issues in Health Sciences III

desc: These courses enable students to develop an understanding of the current state of research and practice in Health Sciences. They provide the opportunity to bring together knowledge from other courses and for skills development, including teamwork, communication and critical thinking.
name: HLTH 3904
prereq_text: third-year standing and above in the BHSc program, an overall CGPA of at least 8.5 and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Emerging Issues in Health Sciences IV

desc: These courses enable students to develop an understanding of the current state of research and practice in Health Sciences. They provide the opportunity to bring together knowledge from other courses and for skills development, including teamwork, communication and critical thinking.
name: HLTH 3905
prereq_text: third-year standing and above in the BHSc program, an overall CGPA of at least 8.5 and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Emerging Issues in Health Sciences V

desc: Contemporary issues and debates in global health governance and effects on health monitoring and outcomes at individual and population levels. Historical patterns of global health, its regulatory framework, principal coordinating mechanisms and emerging challenges, and implications of globalization and international trade policies.
name: HLTH 4101
prereq_text: HLTH 3101, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Global Health Governance

desc: Overview of new and emerging health technologies, including medical and assistive devices, diagnostics and screening, genetics, reproduction, tissue regeneration, imaging, and health informatics. Health technology assessment methods and issues. Regulatory, ethical and social implications; considerations in the developing world.
name: HLTH 4102
prereq_text: HLTH 1000 or HLTH 1001 and third-year standing or higher, or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: New Health Technologies

desc: Statistics concepts and procedures used in the analysis of health data; techniques commonly used to analyze data collected from different types of epidemiological and experimental study designs; how to interpret and present statistical findings.
name: HLTH 4201
prereq_text: HLTH 3201 and STAT 2507 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Applied Health Statistics

desc: Introduction to concepts, principles and processes of evaluating health care programs and interventions. Methodological tools including needs assessment, project management skills, use of health information management databases. Issues in communication with stakeholders, including change management and decision making.
name: HLTH 4202
prereq_text: HLTH 2001 and STAT 2507 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Health Program Evaluation Tools and Methods

desc: Factors that influence disease processes, including viruses, bacteria, protozoa, fungi and infectious agents, how these agents come to have the effects that they do in a given individual, how they spread within and how to limit their spread.
name: HLTH 4301
prereq_text: HLTH 2004 and HLTH 3302 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Pandemics and Infectious Disease

desc: Inflammatory and hormonal processes and their relevance to disease states. Immune-related disorders, heart disease and stroke, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, psychiatric conditions, and neurodegenerative disorders. The contribution of psychosocial and genetic factors to diseases.
name: HLTH 4302
prereq_text: HLTH 3302 or BIOL 4200 or BIOC 4200 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Inflammatory and Endocrine Factors in Diseases

desc: Introduction to pharmacological principles, xenobiotics and their interactions within living systems. Topics include biological mechanisms of action of xenobiotics on macromolecules, cells and their effects on various organ systems. Social, legal and governmental policies will be discussed.
name: HLTH 4303
prereq_text: HLTH 3303 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Fundamentals in Pharmacology and Toxicology

desc: Advanced cellular and molecular mechanisms governing host-pathogen interactions and their contribution to disease. Exploration of immune signaling and recognition, virulence factors, antimicrobial resistance and research techniques used in this field.
name: HLTH 4304
prereq_text: HLTH 2004 and HLTH 3302 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Host-Pathogen Interactions

desc: The integrated genetic, physiologic and environmental events occurring in early life that impact pregnancy, fetal/infant development and disease risk throughout the lifecourse, with a focus on the mechanisms driving these events.
name: HLTH 4401
prereq_text: HLTH 2003 and HLTH 3302 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Maternal and Perinatal Determinants of Health

desc: Congenital and acquired disabilities related to sensory organs and processes, including visual and hearing impairments, vestibular and balance disorders, reflex problems, and others. Interdisciplinary approach to causes, mechanisms, accessibility, accommodations and interventions.
name: HLTH 4502
prereq_text: Either 1) HLTH 3503 and (BIOL 2005 or BIOL 3305 or BIOL 3306), or 2) NEUR 3206, or 3) permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Disabilities and Disorders Related to Sensory Nervous System

desc: Biomedical and psychosocial factors associated with trauma-related illnesses, stressors, injuries and disabilities, including traumatic brain injury, spinal cord injury, fractures, amputations, burns, post-traumatic stress disorder, and others. Short- and long-term considerations for care and rehabilitation.
name: HLTH 4503
prereq_text: HLTH 3503 and (BIOL 2005 or BIOL 3305 or BIOL 3306) or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Trauma-related Disability and Impairments

desc: Introduction to environmental and occupational health; detection, assessment, management and mitigation of chemical, physical and biological hazards.
name: HLTH 4601
prereq_text: HLTH 3104 or permission of the department.
subject: HLTH
title: Environmental Pollution and Health

desc: The application of knowledge translation in the formulation of policy and the development of skills required to maximize the impact of scientific findings through real world programs and policies and communication skills for diverse audiences.
name: HLTH 4701
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and permission of the Department of Health Science and permission of the instructor.
subject: HLTH
title: Knowledge Translation

desc: Independent study, open to third- and fourth-year students to explore a particular health related topic, in consultation with a Faculty supervisor. May include directed reading, written assignments, tutorials, laboratory or field work.
name: HLTH 4901
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in the B.H.Sc. program, in addition to permission of the Faculty supervisor and the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Directed Studies in Health

desc: Independent critical review and research proposal on a health- related topic, using library, database and/or bioinformatics resources, under the supervision of the course instructor. Seminar topics include identification and critical review of resources, development of scientific writing skills, and formulation of health science-related research.
name: HLTH 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.H.Sc. Honours and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Capstone course – Research Essay

desc: A collaborative project on a health related topic. Students, working together as a team, will complete a research project and develop communication and research skills under the supervision of the faculty supervisor. Evaluation will be based on a written report and oral presentation.
name: HLTH 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.H.Sc. Honours program, one of HLTH 3901, HLTH 3902, HLTH 3903, HLTH 3904 or HLTH 3905, a major CGPA of at least 9.0, and permission of the Faculty supervisor and the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Capstone Course – Group Research Project

desc: Field placement providing practical experience in a health-related field. Placements may be in institutional or community settings, governmental or non-governmental organizations. Sites may vary each year. Evaluation based on a written report and an oral presentation.
name: HLTH 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.H.Sc. Honours, one of HLTH 3901, HLTH 3902, HLTH 3903, HLTH 3904 or HLTH 3905, a major CGPA of at least 9.0 and permission of the Department of Health Sciences.
subject: HLTH
title: Capstone Course – Field Placement and Research Project

desc: An independent health related research project under the direct supervision of a faculty member. Evaluation will be based on a written thesis and oral poster presentation (oral or poster).
name: HLTH 4910
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Sc. Honours Health Sciences, one of HLTH 3901, HLTH 3902, HLTH 3903, HLTH 3904 or HLTH 3905, a major CGPA of at least 10.0, and permission of the Faculty advisor and the Department of Health Sciences. Permission will depend, in part, on capacity, such that meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee enrollment in this research thesis course.
subject: HLTH
title: Honours Individual Research Thesis

desc: A survey of the major events, ideas and movements that have shaped Europe from Antiquity to the 21st century. (Field a or b).
name: HIST 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: The Making of Europe

desc: An introduction to some of the major ideological, political, diplomatic, military, social, cultural and economic developments that have shaped contemporary Europe. (Field b).
name: HIST 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Europe in the 20th Century

desc: A historical introduction to northern Canada from pre-contact times to the present. Open only to students in the Nunavut Public Administration certificate program. (Field c).
name: HIST 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of Northern Canada

desc: This course explores how colonialism and conflict altered peoples, cultures, and places in what came to be called Canada from pre-contact to the first age of industrialization. Course covers subjects including imperialism, Indigenous-settler relations, slavery, migration, and government, providing context for contemporary issues.(Field c).
name: HIST 1301
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Conflict and Change in Early Canadian History

desc: This course explores how major political, economic, legal, social, and cultural changes shaped modern-day Canada from the late 1800s to the present. It provides context for contemporary issues, including colonialism, redress, reconciliation, race relations, migration and urbanization, globalization, technology, and the environment. (Field c).
name: HIST 1302
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Rethinking Modern Canadian History

desc: This course will follow the global community from 1400 to the present exploring how global connections, movements and trends have shaped our world with a particular focus on the non-western world. (Field a or d).
name: HIST 1707
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: World History

desc: A lecture course on a special topic, theme, or period. Topic varies from year to year. (Field will depend on topic).
name: HIST 1900
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Topics in History

desc: The history of medieval Europe from the fourth to the fifteenth century. (Field a).
name: HIST 2000
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Medieval Europe

desc: A broad examination of Western thought and culture in the 19th century with a focus on Europe and emphasis on major thinkers and intellectual, ideological, and cultural movements. The course is intended for students from varied disciplinary backgrounds. (Field e).
name: HIST 2102
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Modern Thought and Culture: the Nineteenth Century

desc: A broad examination of Western thought and culture in the 20th century with a focus on Europe and emphasis on major thinkers and intellectual, ideological, and cultural movements. The course is intended for students from varied disciplinary backgrounds. (Field e).
name: HIST 2103
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Modern Thought and Culture: the Twentieth Century

desc: A survey of the major social, political and cultural developments in continental Europe from the 14th to the 17th centuries. (Field a).
name: HIST 2204
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Early Modern Europe 1350-1650

desc: A survey of the major social, political and cultural developments in continental Europe during the 17th and 18th centuries. (Field a).
name: HIST 2206
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Early Modern Europe 1600-1800

desc: A study of critical episodes in the history of continental Europe during the nineteenth century. Themes may include the struggles for democracy in France, modernizing reform in Russia, and national unification in Italy and Germany. (Field b).
name: HIST 2207
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Nineteenth-Century Europe

desc: An historical survey of political experiences in Canada. (Field c).
name: HIST 2301
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Canadian Political History

desc: A thematic exploration of how the spaces of home, work, and play have been historically produced, understood, and experienced in Canada. (Field c).
name: HIST 2304
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Social and Cultural History of Canada

desc: From ancient civilizations to the era of Independence, this class follows conquest, colonization and development of national identity in the countries of Latin America. (Field d).
name: HIST 2308
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Colonial Latin America

desc: From the Wars of Independence until the end of the twentieth century, this class follows the emergence of Latin American nations, their economies, politics, culture and international relations. (Field d).
name: HIST 2309
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Modern Latin America

desc: A survey of Canadian history considering nature, landscape and geography. Topics include the history of energy regimes and climate change; Indigenous ecological knowledge; colonization and settlement; resource extraction; commodity production; environmental policies and movements.(Field c or e).
name: HIST 2311
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Environmental History of Canada

desc: The Indian Ocean is one of the oldest maritime highways in the history of humanity and also an epicentre of global economy in the pre-modern world. The aim of the course is to familiarize students with the non-Western antecedents of modern global history. (Field d).
name: HIST 2312
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of the Indian Ocean World

desc: A survey of United States politics and society from the American Revolution to the Civil War. (Field c).
name: HIST 2401
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of the United States to 1865

desc: A survey of United States politics and society from Reconstruction to the era of globalization. (Field c).
name: HIST 2402
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of the United States from 1865

desc: A survey of significant political and social developments in Britain from the 15 th to the 18 th century. (Field a).
name: HIST 2501
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Early Modern Britain

desc: A survey of significant political and social developments in Britain from the 18 th to the late 20 th century. (Field b).
name: HIST 2502
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Modern Britain

desc: An introductory study of women's and gender history. Themes may include sexuality, masculinity, women's activism, consumer culture, religion, and reproductive rights. Geographic and temporal focus varies from year to year. (Field e).
name: HIST 2506
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Introduction to Women's and Gender History

desc: A study of the major political, social, cultural, and economic developments in France since 1889. Topics may include the Dreyfus Affair, the First and Second World Wars, Republican political culture, colonialism and decolonization, youth culture and protest, and historical memory and commemoration. (Field b).
name: HIST 2508
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: France since 1889

desc: The social, cultural, and political history and impact of German nationhood. Topics include the rise of social democracy and the feminist movements, alliance and empire building, scientific racism, sexology, and the emancipation and assimilation of German Jews into the body politic. (Field b).
name: HIST 2510
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: 19th-Century Germany

desc: A survey of social, cultural, and political tensions and developments in Germany from World War One to the Fall of the Berlin Wall. (Field b).
name: HIST 2511
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: 20th-Century Germany

desc: A survey of Russian history from the rise of Kievan Rus in the 10th century to post-Soviet Russia in the 21st, with emphasis on political systems and the lives of ordinary people. (Field a or b).
name: HIST 2600
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of Russia

desc: Ancient African cultures and civilizations, the trans-Saharan trade system, and the trans-Atlantic and Indian Ocean slave trades from 600 BCE to the 19th century. (Field d).
name: HIST 2706
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Ancient and Pre-Colonial Africa

desc: The conquest and colonization of African polities by the European imperial powers from the late 19th century, the 20th century wars of decolonization, and the emergence of independent African nations, including their economies, politics, and culture. (Field d).
name: HIST 2707
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Modern Africa

desc: Introduction to the history of the Caribbean that examines the indigenous populations, the role of colonialism and slavery in the construction of plantation societies, the impact of emancipation, and the social, cultural, economic, and political dynamics of the Caribbean in the post-emancipation period. (Field d).
name: HIST 2710
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Introduction to Caribbean History

desc: A thematic study of the experience of war and its consequences. The European country or region to be studied, will vary from year to year. (Field b).
name: HIST 2802
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: War and Society in Modern Europe, 1789-1914

desc: A thematic study of the experience of war and its consequences. The European country or region to be studied, will vary from year to year. (Field b).
name: HIST 2803
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: War and Society in Modern Europe, 1914-1950

desc: A survey of Japanese history from the legendary beginning of the country in 660 B.C. to the end of World War Two. (Field a or d).
name: HIST 2806
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of Japan

desc: Lectures and workshops on historical methods and materials. Topics will include the discovery, evaluation, use and analysis of documents in historical context, non-documentary evidence, statistics, and bibliographical tools.
name: HIST 2809
prereq_text: open only to History majors with at least second-year standing.
subject: HIST
title: The Historian's Craft

desc: Historical representation in the public arena and public engagement with the past, including archives, museums, films, novels, and video games. This course will involve online work, collaborative projects, and field trips. (Field e).
name: HIST 2811
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Public History from Memory to Museums

desc: A lecture course on a special topic, theme, or period in public history. Topic varies from year to year. (Field e).
name: HIST 2812
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Special Subject in Public History

desc: The history of ancient Greece from the Bronze Age through the Archaic period. (Field a).
name: HIST 2902
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: HIST
title: History of Ancient Greece I

desc: The history of ancient Greece from the classical period to Alexander. (Field a).
name: HIST 2903
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: HIST
title: History of Ancient Greece II

desc: The history of ancient Rome from early Rome to the end of the Republic (Field a).
name: HIST 2904
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: HIST
title: History of Ancient Rome I

desc: The history of ancient Rome from the end of the Republic to the coming of Islam. (Field a).
name: HIST 2905
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit.
subject: HIST
title: History of Ancient Rome II

desc: A lecture course on a special topic, theme, or period. Topic varies from year to year. (Field will depend on topic).
name: HIST 2910
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Special Subject in History

desc: Major findings and discussions about the role of science and technology in the past. Topic and time period will vary. (Field a, b, or e).
name: HIST 2912
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Science and Technology in History

desc: Explores the history of oil from the ancient period to the present day. The course uses a transnational approach designed to introduce students to the interconnected histories of oil in countries across the world. (Field e).
name: HIST 2913
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: History of Oil

desc: A study of a selected topic in ancient history. (Field a).
name: HIST 3000
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Topics in Ancient History

desc: Considering opportunities offered by historical feature film in the representation of the past, focusing on how historical themes and subjects have been treated in feature films, cinematic uses of the past, the role of film in shaping public memory and understanding the past. (Field e).
name: HIST 3001
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: History at the Movies

desc: A general examination of the life of European ruling elites from the ninth to the 13th century, with special reference to the Anglo-Norman and French experiences of noble power, conduct, and prestige. (Field a).
name: HIST 3005
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Medieval Aristocratic Life

desc: A general examination of European religious life from the fourth to the fourteenth centuries, with special reference to the cultural and intellectual worlds of medieval monks, nuns, and clerics. (Field a or e).
name: HIST 3006
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Medieval Religious Life

desc: A general examination of medieval European intellectual life during the High and Late Middle Ages, with special reference to its setting in the cathedral school and university. (Field a or e).
name: HIST 3007
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Medieval Intellectual Life

desc: Study of a period or theme in Greek History. (Field a).
name: HIST 3009
prereq_text: CLCV 2902 and CLCV 2903 or HIST 2902 and HIST 2903 or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: HIST
title: Studies in Greek History

desc: The study of major developments - administrative, ecclesiastical, cultural and societal - of the later Roman Empire. (Field a).
name: HIST 3010
prereq_text: a 2000-level Classical Civilization course.
subject: HIST
title: The Later Roman Empire

desc: Study of a period or theme in Roman History. (Field a).
name: HIST 3101
prereq_text: CLCV 2904 and CLCV 2905 or HIST 2904 and HIST 2905 or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit is required to repeat this course.
subject: HIST
title: Studies in Roman History

desc: Examination of the archival turn in historical and theoretical perspective with an emphasis on sexuality, race, and gender as subjectivities in queer, trans, and colonial archives.
name: HIST 3102
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HIST
title: Queer(ing) Archives

desc: The political and cultural history of Europe in the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, with emphasis on the Italian Renaissance and its diffusion into England and France. (Field a).
name: HIST 3105
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Renaissance Europe

desc: Sexuality in Western society, Middle Ages to the present. Themes include attitudes and behaviour; regulation of sexuality; gender; heterosexuality and homosexuality; prostitution; pornography; the politics of sex: stresses continuities and changes and the understanding of sexuality in contexts of place, class, gender, culture. (Field a).
name: HIST 3106
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Social History of Sexuality

desc: Alcohol in Western society from Ancient times to the present. Production, trade, and consumption of alcohol; religious and social significance; class, gender, and health; drinking cultures; policies toward drunkenness, and alcoholism. Specific topics include comparative trends, temperance movements, and prohibition. (Field e).
name: HIST 3109
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Social History of Alcohol

desc: Food in its agrarian, economic and cultural context from late antiquity to the nineteenth century; production, distribution, and consumption; health, diet and manners; the religious significance of food; food in art; the rise of the restaurant; the birth of gastronomy. (Field e).
name: HIST 3110
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: The Cultural History of Food

desc: History of humanitarian activities and agencies, both governmental and non-governmental, with particular attention to Canadian involvement. The first half is devoted to early humanitarian traditions, the second to specific agencies such as the Red Cross, Oxfam, Christian Aid, Save the Children and UNICEF. (Field e).
name: HIST 3111
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: History of Humanitarian Aid

desc: A survey of the French Revolution (1789-99) focusing on attempts to regenerate France and the French through political, economic and cultural reforms. Themes include nationalism, republicanism, violence, legal reform, property redistribution, education, population and family policy, gender, and religion. (Field b).
name: HIST 3113
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Revolution and Society in France, 1789-1799

desc: The role of childhood and youth in modern history. Topics may include children’s and young people’s relationship to work, education, play, sexuality, the welfare state, war, politics, delinquency, leisure, migrations, and popular culture. (Field e).
name: HIST 3115
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Childhood and Youth in History

desc: History of disability including the representation and understanding of disability as it changes over time and as it is portrayed and experienced in changing cultural contexts. (Field e).
name: HIST 3116
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history or in Disability Studies.
subject: HIST
title: History of Disability

desc: The ways in which the human body has been viewed, interpreted, controlled, tended, healed, exercised, measured, pleasured, clothed, and reproduced to create representations of social, political, and cultural relationships. Regions and periods will vary.(Field e).
name: HIST 3120
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: History of the Body

desc: The place of business in Canadian society, economics and politics. The internal dynamics of Canadian business (organization, strategy, the rise of the manager), and its external implications (competition, foreign investment, business-government relations). (Field c).
name: HIST 3205
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Canadian Business History

desc: An exploration of selected topics in the history of one of Canada's regions. Topic varies from year to year. (Field c).
name: HIST 3206
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Place and Politics in Canadian History

desc: Introduction to urban growth and development in Canada. The historical basis of the urban pattern and its influence in Canada and the internal structure and institutions of Canadian cities. Ottawa is used as a case study. (Field c).
name: HIST 3209
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Canadian Urban History

desc: The Enlightenment as a movement to establish a scientific approach to investigating human society. The focus is on Britain as the leading commercial society. Course work concentrates on close readings of primary texts. Representative figures include David Hume, Adam Smith, Mary Wollstonecraft. (Field e).
name: HIST 3213
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: The Enlightenment

desc: An intellectual and cultural history of Enlightenment and post-Enlightenment study of human society. Course work concentrates on close reading of significant primary texts. Representative figures include Burke, Kant, Malthus, Mill, Tocqueville. (Field e).
name: HIST 3214
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: The Enlightenment and Its Aftermath

desc: The history of Greek physical science from the Presocratics to Ptolemy. (Field a or e).
name: HIST 3215
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Ancient Greek Science

desc: The history of astronomy and physics from Copernicus to Newton. (Field b or e).
name: HIST 3216
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: The Scientific Revolution

desc: Varieties of European imperialism from the early modern period to the present. The role of imperialism and anti-imperialism in the development of globalization and European modernity. Comparison of various empires and the transnational linkages between them. (Field b).
name: HIST 3217
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Empire and Globalization

desc: A survey of Canadian economic history from the sixteenth century to the present. (Field c or e).
name: HIST 3220
prereq_text: ECON 1000 or FYSM 1003, or permission of the Department.
subject: HIST
title: Canadian Economic History

desc: An examination of the economic development of North America or Europe or other possible selected sets of countries. Countries examined vary from year to year. (Field e).
name: HIST 3230
prereq_text: ECON 1001 and ECON 1002, or ECON 1000 or FYSM 1003, or permission of the Department.
subject: HIST
title: Selected Topics in Economic History

desc: A social, economic, political, cultural and intellectual history of Quebec with emphasis on the development of Quebec nationalism. (Field c).
name: HIST 3301
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Quebec Since 1800

desc: An examination of diplomatic, economic, cultural and military relations, with particular attention to the twentieth century. (Field c).
name: HIST 3304
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Canada-United States Relations

desc: The history of the relationship between the criminal law system and society. Changing issues in the criminal law and the nature of institutional responses, covering medieval to early nineteenth-century England and nineteenth to early twentieth-century Canada. (Field e).
name: HIST 3305
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Crime and State in History

desc: The development of Canadian attitudes and policies toward international affairs, with emphasis on the 20 th century. (Field c).
name: HIST 3306
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Canada's International Policies

desc: A historical survey of relations between humans and other animals. Topics may include history of domestication; hunting; display of animals in zoos, museums and wildlife films; biotechnology; animal welfare movements; companion species; animals as symbols; question of animal agency. (Field c or e).
name: HIST 3310
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Animals in History

desc: An examination of aspects of the social, cultural, and political history of African-American women since the eighteenth century. (Field c or e).
name: HIST 3406
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: African-American Women

desc: The development of popular culture in the United States. Focusing on a selected theme or time period, the course will examine how popular culture both shaped and reflected broader historical and social developments. Topics may include music, theatre, public entertainments, movies, and television. (Field c).
name: HIST 3410
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Popular Culture in the U.S.

desc: The intellectual, social, and cultural production of the United States, focusing on, among other things, a series of creative tensions: tradition versus modernity; rural versus urban; white versus black; masculine versus feminine; homogenous versus cosmopolitan. (Field c).
name: HIST 3412
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Ideas, Culture, and Society in U.S. History

desc: A history of the United States, focusing on the interactions along and across its borders with Mexico, Canada, and the Pacific Rim. This course examines the contests that emerged over colonization, migration, and American state-making. (Field c).
name: HIST 3413
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: The United States and Its Borderlands

desc: The history of the US in a global context. Time period will vary, topics could include world revolutions, imperialism and decolonization, immigration, transnational flows of ideas and people, war, peace, urbanization, capitalism, international law, and the environment. (Field c).
name: HIST 3414
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: The United States in the World

desc: A study of migration and settlement in Canada from the 17th century to the present. (Field c).
name: HIST 3500
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Migration and Diaspora in Canada

desc: Selected issues in the history of women in Canada. Themes include women and war, aboriginal women's history, sexuality, the women's movement, immigration, and motherhood. Attention will be paid to the social construction of gender and the intersections of gender with class, ethnicity, race. (Field c).
name: HIST 3505
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Women in Canada

desc: A course that critically engages with programs designed to assist the settlement and integration of newcomers to Canada as well as the lived experiences of immigrants and ethnic and diasporic groups in the Canadian context. (Field c).
name: HIST 3507
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: An Immigrant’s Guide to Canada

desc: A survey of indigenous histories in northern North America from earliest times to the present. The course will cover pre-contact histories; military, economic, social, and cultural encounters with newcomers; indigenous experiences with settler colonialism; and the struggle over decolonization. (Field c).
name: HIST 3510
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Indigenous Peoples of Canada

desc: Key themes in the history of North America’s indigenous peoples. Topics may include land and treaties, religious encounters, the law, cultural identity, and transnational indigenous experiences(Field c).
name: HIST 3511
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Themes in Indigenous History

desc: History of insanity from the eighteenth to the twentieth century.Themes include changing public and medical understandings of madness, patients' experiences and artistic portrayals of mental hospital life, cultural representations of madness in various media, and the history of the asylum. (Field e).
name: HIST 3515
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course, or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Madness in Modern Times

desc: Exploration of gender, sexuality, and women’s history in Modern Europe. (Field b or e).
name: HIST 3604
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Europe

desc: An examination of the Aztec social system, culture, religion, and philosophy both before and after the Spanish conquest. (Field a or d).
name: HIST 3704
prereq_text: A 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Aztecs

desc: A history of the Protestant and Catholic Reformations of the sixteenth century, with special emphasis on the theological disputes of the protagonists and the impact of these disputes on the social, political and cultural developments of the era. (Field a).
name: HIST 3708
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Reformation Europe

desc: Key themes in the making of the Caribbean. Topics may include slavery and emancipation, Indian and Chinese migration, colonialism, the independence movement, and race relations. (Field d).
name: HIST 3710
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Themes in Caribbean History

desc: An examination of the social and cultural history of Mexico from indigenous cultures to the problems of the 20th century. Themes include the continuities of indigenous structures, national identity, wars and political violence, and gender. (Field d).
name: HIST 3712
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Mexico: Aztecs to Narcos

desc: An exploration of gender and sexualities in Latin America from the pre-conquest period to the end of the twentieth century. (Field d or e).
name: HIST 3713
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Gender and Sexuality in Latin America

desc: An examination of the experiences of different Jewish communities before, during, and after the Holocaust. Issues to be discussed include antisemitism, relations with non-Jewish neighbors, perpetrator motivation, local collaboration, resistance, postwar trials, and memory. (Field b).
name: HIST 3714
prereq_text: a 2000-level History course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in History.
subject: HIST
title: Holocaust Encounters

desc: Key themes in South Asian history. Topics may include the Mughal empire, the British colonial era, the creation and development of states in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka, and various 20th century historical phenomenon. (Field d).
name: HIST 3715
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Themes in South Asian History

desc: An exploration of gender and sexualities in Africa from the beginning of colonial rule until the beginning of the 21st century. (Field d or e).
name: HIST 3717
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Gender and Sexuality in Africa

desc: Examines causes, major events and consequences of the war. Themes include: the war as part of the Scramble for Africa, emergence of settler nationalism, British “scorched earth policy", establishment of concentration camps, importance of gender, African involvement, international responses, and long-term effects. (Field d).
name: HIST 3719
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: South African War, 1899-1902

desc: A survey of international history from the First World War to the outbreak of the Second World War, focusing on peacemaking, inter-war diplomacy, anti-imperialism, global capitalism, migration, labour, and the origins of the Second World War. (Field b).
name: HIST 3800
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: International History 1914-41

desc: A survey of international history from the Second World War to the end of the Cold War that examines the conflict over the reconstruction of the postwar world, including decolonization, emergence of the European Union, and other dimensions of global order and disorder. (Field b).
name: HIST 3801
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: International History 1941-90

desc: A political history of China from the 1911 Revolution to the present. Emphasis on the development of Chinese communism and the People's Republic since 1949. (Field d).
name: HIST 3805
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Twentieth-Century China

desc: A political, intellectual and economic history of Japan in the twentieth century, concentrating on the period since the end of the Pacific War. (Field d).
name: HIST 3806
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Japan Since 1945

desc: An historical research project in a museum or public institution in the Ottawa area conducted under the supervision of the external institution and the History Department. Work includes reading, reports, and meetings. Students should be prepared to devote one day a week to the project.
name: HIST 3807
prereq_text: third-year standing in a History program, a CGPA of 9.00 or better in history courses, and permission of the Department.
subject: HIST
title: Practicum in History

desc: An examination of how historical narratives have been produced in relation to sites of public memory. The public presentation of history through a wide range of themes, which may include museum exhibits, commemorations and popular culture. (Field e).
name: HIST 3809
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Historical Representations

desc: An examination of a wide range of theoretical approaches to history, and a critical reflection on history as a discipline.
name: HIST 3810
prereq_text: HIST 2809 or permission of the Department.
subject: HIST
title: Historical Theory

desc: An examination of questions concerning the nature and value of historical inquiry and the meaning of the course of history. (Field e).
name: HIST 3811
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: History of Historical Thought

desc: The digital representation of history, exploring the approaches, issues, and methods of working in this environment. Topics may include gaming, virtual environments, digital research tools, public digital history. (Field e).
name: HIST 3812
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Digital History

desc: Historical encounters across geographical regions and ways in which historians studied them. Categories of “national,” “international,” “transnational,” “world,” and “global” history will be evaluated. Themes include: imperialism, postcolonialism, the environment, migration, trade, religion, the body, war, culture, disease. (Field d or e).
name: HIST 3813
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history including at least 0.5 credit in Field d courses (Asia, Africa, the Caribbean, and Latin America).
subject: HIST
title: Problems in Global and Transnational Histories

desc: This course applies the creative use of information and media/computing technologies to address the digital cultural heritage issues of public historians, archaeologists, and anthropologists. Topics may include webscraping, data mining, designing and implementing research databases, and visual storytelling of those results. (Field e).
name: HIST 3814
prereq_text: a 2000-level history course or third-year standing and 1.0 credit in history.
subject: HIST
title: Crafting Digital History

desc: A class-based group historical research project done in collaboration with an external institution under the supervision of the institution and the Department. Work includes readings, reports, and meetings. Students should be prepared to devote one full day per week to the project. (Field e).
name: HIST 3815
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in a History program and permission of the Department.
subject: HIST
title: Group Practicum

desc: Taking a specific historical topic as its focus, this course examines how historians have applied a wide range of theoretical approaches in order to understand and interpret that topic's historical significance. Topics will vary.
name: HIST 3820
prereq_text: HIST 2809, or permission of the unit.
subject: HIST
title: Explorations in Historical Theory

subject: HIST
title: Topics in European History

prereq_text: HIST 3810, fourth-year standing in Honours History or permission of the Department.

desc: The seminar uses the concept of transition to understand the Balkan encounter with modernity and Europe. Key periods to be examined include the interwar era and the period of communist rule, with an emphasis on political, social and economic themes.
name: HIST 4605
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and one of PSCI 3704, PSCI 3208, PSCI 3209, HIST 2600; or permission of the Department.

desc: History of contemporary Europe from 1945 to present covering both eastern and western halves of the continent and including social, cultural, political, and economic dimensions.
name: HIST 4606
prereq_text: HIST 3810, fourth-year standing in Honours History or permission of the Department.
subject: HIST
title: Contemporary Europe: From Postwar to the European Union

desc: Examination of the expansion and downfall of tsarist Russia from the eighteenth century to the revolutionary era and the establishment of Bolshevik rule. Topics include the relationship between the monarchy and subject peoples, social and economic change, and daily life.
name: HIST 4607
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: Imperial Russia and the Russian Revolution

desc: Examination of the rise of the Soviet Union to a global power and subsequent tensions that promoted its collapse. The course will analyze Stalinism, the Second World War, the Thaw, and Brezhnev and Gorbachev eras through the lens of the USSR’s citizens.
name: HIST 4608
prereq_text: None
subject: HIST
title: The Soviet Union

desc: Human rights from an interdisciplinary perspective. Topics may include the foundations and nature of rights, roots of inequality and oppression, aboriginal rights, racism, women and rights, sexual orientation, state and corporate power, economic exploitation, the environment and rights, warfare, torture, and social movements.
name: HUMR 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: HUMR
title: Introduction to Human Rights

desc: Historical overview of the theoretical and philosophical approaches underlying the human rights movement and relevant to the normative ideals and aspirations of human rights and to the strategies of their implementation.
name: HUMR 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Human Rights: Theories and Foundations

desc: Historical and contemporary analysis of surveillance, security, and regulation of sexuality, race, class, and gender. Students will critically examine how ‘subversives’ were created through discourse and administrative logics such as policy and law.
name: HUMR 2102
prereq_text: second year standing or permission from the Institute.
subject: HUMR
title: Sexuality, Gender, and Security

desc: The study of power from a critical, transnational perspective; the impact on human rights of different forms and modalities of power, including those emanating from the state and corporations and those implicated in socio-economic and other hierarchical relations.
name: HUMR 2202
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Power Relations and Human Rights

desc: Human rights issues in various cultural contexts concerning sex and/or gender, with attention to sexual minorities such as gay, lesbian, and transgendered persons. Forms of discrimination against sexual minorities and the mechanisms and strategies for redress.
name: HUMR 2301
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Human Rights and Sexualities

desc: Canada is home-in-exile to many who have faced severe and often life-threatening political repression such as imprisonment, torture, surveillance, population transfer, etc. This course examines the impacts on survivors of political repression, and strategies used to overcome its legacies.
name: HUMR 2401
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Political Repression

desc: The underlying conditions and developments of historical and contemporary social and political movements; specific social movements such as civil rights or gay rights.
name: HUMR 2502
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Social and Political Movements

desc: This advanced seminar will cover current and topical issues and/or debates in human rights, and will enable students to engage in focused discussions and analyses of these issues. Topics will vary from year to year.
name: HUMR 3001
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Special Topics in Human Rights

desc: “The right to the city” as an emerging focus of advocacy and analysis in urban movements for social justice around especially the local and transnational dimensions of the “right to the city” movement.
name: HUMR 3002
prereq_text: third year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Right to the City

desc: This course problematizes human rights paradigms and critically examines the limitations of the political within liberal democracies. Bringing together theory and politics, alternative approaches to activism are explored. Topics may include struggles grounded in radical democracy, anti-capitalism, and social justice perspectives.
name: HUMR 3202
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Human Rights and Resistance

desc: The forms and effects of systemic race-based human rights abuses. Topics may include immigration and refugee policies and practices, anti-apartheid regimes, racial profiling, the racial politics of "nationhood" and armed conflict, civil rights and resistance movements in differing cultural contexts.
name: HUMR 3301
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Racialization, Racism and Human Rights

desc: The impact of cultural and religious traditions on gender, race, ethnicity and sexuality. Topics may include debates related to power dynamics, historical issues, geopolitics, and cultural relativism.
name: HUMR 3302
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Culture, Religion, and Women's Human Rights

desc: This course examines children’s rights from a range of historical, cultural, and global perspectives. Topics may include the rights for Indigenous children, children with disabilities, female, trans and queer children, children in armed conflict and refugees in Canada and transnational contexts.
name: HUMR 3303
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Children's Rights

desc: A critical approach to the study of disability rights that explores the intersections of disability with race, sexuality, gender, colonialism, ‘health’, and other discourses.
name: HUMR 3304
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Disability Rights

desc: Case studies in persecution and/or genocide in different cultural contexts. The social, political, and legal conditions that have enabled the institutional or state-sanctioned persecution of targeted groups, and the circumstances that had an impact on their decline.
name: HUMR 3401
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Histories of Persecution and Genocide

desc: The development of social, economic and cultural rights, including rights to housing, healthcare, education and employment. Topics may include the international geopolitics of the historical tension between these rights and civil and political rights.
name: HUMR 3501
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Social, Economic and Cultural Rights

desc: Overview of critical debates on environmental issues from a global social justice perspective. Topics may include corporate mining, food sovereignty, poverty, economic exploitation, Indigenous cosmologies and environmental justice, militarization and environmental degradation, privatization of water and climate change.
name: HUMR 3503
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Global Environmental Justice

desc: Through a social-scientific analysis of AIDS, this course explores HIV/AIDS as a case study for understanding the politics of public health. Students will critically interrogate the authority of science and explore avenues for democratizing biomedicine and public health policy in various national and policy contexts.
name: HUMR 3504
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Public Health and Human Rights

desc: The relationship between citizenship and human rights; how large groups of people, including non-citizens and refugees, are excluded from entitlements to rights. Why human rights rest on citizenship, and with what implications.
name: HUMR 4201
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Citizenship and Human Rights

desc: Critical analyses of human rights through an examination of transgender subjectivities. The systemic erasure of trans people within society and the struggles of some activists to normalize trans identities.
name: HUMR 4302
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: HUMR
title: Transgender Human Rights
