title: Remote Sensing

desc: Introduction to topics in computer vision, including: fundamentals of image formation, camera imaging geometry, f camera models, camera calibration, structure from motion, feature detection and matching, depth and stereo, image stabilization, image classification, automated alignment, scene understanding, recognition, and image searching.
name: OSS 4009
prereq_text: OSS 4006 or PLT 4006 (no longer offered).
subject: OSS
title: Computer Vision

desc: Research project develops students' ability to direct own learning and pursue advanced study in variety of subjects. Select topic, perform literature search, theoretical background, preliminary measurements, calculations, and design. Present findings in a preliminary thesis. Encourage writing technical papers. Research opportunities with industry and academia.
name: OSS 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: OSS
title: OSS Capstone Project

desc: Introduction to Web development. Combining graphics, text, audio, and video to create Web sites; developing different, major working Web sites on an individual basis and in groups, using valid HTML5, cascading style sheets (CSS3), JavaScript and XML structures.
name: ITEC 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Web Development

desc: Overview of interactive multimedia design: user-centred and web design, mark-up languages, project management, design processes for video games, visual effects in movies, ethics, current trends in the field.
name: ITEC 1100
prereq_text: For students not enrolled in CSIT programs.
subject: ITEC
title: Introduction to Interactive Media Design

desc: Introduction to basic concepts of procedural programming and algorithm design in C. Topics include: basic variables, functions, operators, program control with iteration and conditionals, I/O operations, text and file processing, structures, arrays, pointers, debugging, algorithmic thinking and pseudocode, computer architecture, operating systems, and libraries.
name: ITEC 1400
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Introduction to Programming and Problem Solving

desc: Introduction to basic concepts of object-oriented scripting and algorithm design in Python. Topics include: basic variables, functions, operators, program control with iteration and conditionals, I/O operations, text and file processing, arrays, tuples, lists, debugging, algorithms and pseudocode, computer architecture, operating systems, and libraries.
name: ITEC 1401
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Introduction to Scripting and Problem Solving

desc: Issues involving the back-end organization of information focusing on databases and database design, server-side scripting, the structured query language (SQL), digital rights management, and watermarking.
name: ITEC 2000
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Multimedia Data Management

desc: Web-based data visualization techniques and systems. Good design practices for visualization, tools for visualization of data from a variety of fields, and programming of interactive web-based visualizations focusing on JavaScript, CSS, SVG and the D3 library.
name: ITEC 2100
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Data Visualization

desc: Introduction to object-oriented programming and algorithm design in C++. Topics include code and data encapsulation using classes and objects, inheritance, polymorphism, object-oriented design, data and code abstraction, program efficiency, user interface objects, event-driven systems, and an introduction to linked-lists and searching.
name: ITEC 2400
prereq_text: ITEC 1400.
subject: ITEC
title: Intermediate Programming

desc: Introduction to advanced object-oriented scripting and algorithm design in Python. Topics include class design and encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism, object-oriented design, data and code abstraction, program efficiency, user interface objects, event-driven systems, and an introduction to linked-lists, sorting, and searching.
name: ITEC 2401
prereq_text: ITEC 1401.
subject: ITEC
title: Intermediate Scripting

desc: The craft of digital storytelling, creating compelling online and game-engine packages. Using a variety of narrative formats, interactive tools, and digital content, including blogs and RSS feeds, developing an in-depth story using leading edge technologies and techniques.
name: ITEC 3100
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Immersive Storytelling

desc: This course deals with the essentials of physics-based animations and dynamics; topics include basics of animation mechanics, collision detection, particle systems, and dynamic systems (cloth, fluid, and hair).
name: ITEC 4007
prereq_text: IMD 3002 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: Dynamics and Physics-Based Animation

desc: This course covers the elements of rigging and advanced character animation; topics include the basics of forwards/inverse kinematics, controls, and weighting, essentials of human and creature rigging, retargeting, face and body motion capture, and motion studies for advanced keyframe animation.
name: ITEC 4009
prereq_text: IMD 3002 and IMD 3900 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: Rigging and Advanced Character Animation

desc: This course covers the essentials of Visual FX and compositing, topics include camera setups (motion control systems), set issues, match-moving, image-based lighting, chroma-keying and object extraction, colour correction, 2D tracking, and rotoscoping.
name: ITEC 4010
prereq_text: IMD 3002 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: Visual Effects and Compositing

desc: This course covers the basics of artificial intelligence in games and animation, including behaviour and crowd systems (e.g. boids, reciprocal velocity obstacles, social forces, agent-based modelling, cellular automata), path finding and route planning, as well as procedural animation systems.
name: ITEC 4011
prereq_text: BIT 2400 or ITEC 2401 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: Artificial Intelligence for Digital Media

desc: A detailed look at web application frameworks, focusing client and server-side frameworks that enable more advanced user interactions, including configuration, understanding functionality, and develop with them effectively.
name: ITEC 4012
prereq_text: ITEC 1005 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: Web Application Frameworks

desc: User experience (UX) of interactive systems, including product and service design, usability and UX research. Emphasis on accessibility, with topics including creating accessible systems for users with a range of abilities, accessibility standards, and validation of designs in a practical context.
name: ITEC 4014
prereq_text: IMD 3004 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: User Experience Design and Accessibility

desc: Introduces the concepts of digital audio & music specifically how it relates to digital media (games, film, mobile, etc). Topics include, digital audio recording, multitrack production and mixing, foley effects, musical interference and intonations, signal processing for effect, time & spatial variations, and studio recording.
name: ITEC 4015
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Digital Audio and Music

desc: Design, development, and evaluation of virtual and augmented reality systems. Topics include VR/AR history, applications, hardware (display and input devices), software, interaction techniques for navigation, selection, manipulation, human factors, and empirical validation. Projects will use modern 3D game engines and VR/AR devices.
name: ITEC 4016
prereq_text: IMD 2006 and IMD 3002 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: Virtual and Augmented Reality

desc: This course deals with physically-based rendering methods and techniques in the global illumination field; topics include the rendering equation, ray and path tracing, radiosity rendering, photon mapping, final gather methods, materials and shaders, as well taking a look at non-photo-realistic rendering.
name: ITEC 4017
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Photo and Non-Photo-Realistic Rendering

desc: This course deals with the programming of the Graphics Processing Unit (GPU); topics include real-time rendering, shaders, and other advanced programming techniques that utilise single-instruction / multiple thread parallel processing units.
name: ITEC 4018
prereq_text: BIT 2400 or equivalent.
subject: ITEC
title: GPU Programming and Real-Time Rendering

desc: This course covers the basics of being a director in a digital storytelling environment, including the basics of direction, dealing with actors, following scripts, and dealing with elements of cinematography; including lighting, cameras, shade, and shadow.
name: ITEC 4019
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Directing and Cinematography for Digital Storytelling

desc: The course deals with the creation, development, and use of assets for digital environments; with specific focus on the workflows associated with scene construction and architectural modelling for a variety of real-time and non-real-time systems.
name: ITEC 4020
prereq_text: None
subject: ITEC
title: Environment and Architectural Modelling

desc: Assignment(s) reviewing current research topics.
name: INSC 3907
prereq_text: at least 0.5 credit at the 3000-level or higher (may be taken concurrently) and permission of the Institute Director.
subject: INSC
title: Topics in Integrated Science

desc: The student, under the supervision of a faculty member, prepares a study in the focus areas of the student's program. Prior to or immediately upon registration, the student must consult with the ISI Director for topic approval and course regulations.
name: INSC 3909
prereq_text: at least 0.5 credit at the 3000-level or higher (may be taken concurrently) and permission of the Institute Director.
subject: INSC
title: Independent Study

desc: A review of current research, and a research proposal, under the supervision of a faculty advisor. (Note: the research project is not actually carried out.) Graded on the literature review, the research proposal, and an oral defense. The student arranges for a faculty advisor.
name: INSC 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in Honours Integrated Science and permission of the Institute.
subject: INSC
title: Honours Essay and Research Proposal

desc: Under the supervision of a faculty adviser, the student carries out a research project in the IS areas of study. Prior to or immediately upon registration, the student must consult with the ISI Director for topic approval and course regulations.
name: INSC 4908
prereq_text: permission of the Institute Director.
subject: INSC
title: Honours Project

desc: An introductory course emphasizing the development of writing, research, and analytical skills through the concentrated investigation of selected topics in Public Affairs. Topics will be offered by various Departments within the Faculty of Public Affairs. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: IPAF 1001
prereq_text: permission of the Department within the Faculty of Public Affairs.
subject: IPAF
title: Investigations in Public Affairs

desc: Related approaches to collecting, interpreting, and presenting quantitative information in the context of specific public policy issues such as immigration, globalization, discrimination, health care, and the environment. Development of fundamental logical, numerical, and statistical skills.
name: IPAF 2000
prereq_text: open to students in any program other than those leading to one of the following degrees: B.Com., B.C.S., B.Eng., B.I.B., B.I.D., B.Math., B.Sc.
subject: IPAF
title: Quantitative Approaches to Policy Analysis

desc: Specialized topics in the area of public affairs. Topics vary from year to year and are posted at carleton.ca/fpa in advance of the registration period.
name: IPAF 2800
prereq_text: Normally restricted to students in the second year of a B.P.A.P.M., B.G.In.S., B.Econ, B.J., B.Co.M.S., B.S.W., or B.A. program in the Faculty of Public Affairs.
subject: IPAF
title: Selected Topics in Public Affairs

desc: Specialized topics in the area of public affairs. Topics vary from year to year and are posted at carleton.ca/fpa in advance of the registration period.
name: IPAF 3800
prereq_text: Normally restricted to students in the third year of a B.P.A.P.M., B.G.In.S., B.Econ, B.J., B.Co.M.S., B.S.W., or B.A. program in the Faculty of Public Affairs.
subject: IPAF
title: Selected Topics in Public Affairs

desc: Seminar on a specialized topic in the area of public affairs. Topics will vary from year to year and are posted at carleton.ca/fpa in advance of the registration period.
name: IPAF 4800
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: IPAF
title: Selected Topics in Public Affairs

desc: This course gives students an opportunity to participate in a research project designed by a faculty member. Students gain work experience, learn new materials, and acquire research-oriented skills. Course expectations, learning outcomes and evaluation criteria are established by the supervising faculty member.
name: IPAF 4900
prereq_text: third year honours standing, GPA of 9.5 and permission of department.
subject: IPAF
title: Research Experience Course

desc: The nature of the biosphere: scientific bases of important environmental issues; evolution of life; properties and dynamics of populations and ecosystems; biodiversity; introduction to identification skills; sustainability of renewable resources, including food. Not acceptable for credit in a Bachelor of Science program.
name: ISCI 1001
prereq_text: a knowledge of Grade 10 advanced level Mathematics will be assumed.
subject: ISCI
title: Introduction to the Environment

desc: Fundamental concepts and their environmental application for the non-science student: properties of atoms and molecules, chemical reactions, nuclear processes, mechanics, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism; applications to energy production and consumption.
name: ISCI 2000
prereq_text: ISCI 1001 or GEOG 1010 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISCI
title: Natural Laws

desc: Air and water pollution; global climatic change; waste management; industrial chemicals; sources and uses of energy; nuclear energy and radiation; risk assessment of technological hazards. Acceptable only as a free elective in a Bachelor of Science program.
name: ISCI 2002
prereq_text: ISCI 2000 or ISCI 1002 or two experimental science grade 12 U/M courses or one first year university experimental science credit.
subject: ISCI
title: Human Impacts on the Environment

desc: What is interdisciplinarity and what are the challenges and opportunities of collaboration within and across disciplines in science and beyond? Topics include types of biases, public datasets and science communication.
name: ISAP 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: ISAP
title: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Science

desc: Exploring the role of interdisciplinarity in discovery and innovation, and discussion of selected issues facing society and the role of science. Topics include finding information, collaboration and science communication tools.
name: ISAP 1002
prereq_text: ISAP 1001.
subject: ISAP
title: Seminar in Interdisciplinary Science

desc: What is science and the scientific method? Topics include the scientific method, credible sources of information, knowledge gaps, the impact of scientific discoveries, and discussion of their local and global implications.
name: ISAP 2001
prereq_text: ISAP 1002 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Foundations in Critical Inquiry

desc: Exploring how research is conducted. Topics include publicly available databases, the role of communication in research, stakeholders and participants, and the process of identifying knowledge gaps and developing research questions.
name: ISAP 2002
prereq_text: ISAP 2001 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Research Principles for Interdisciplinary Science

desc: Development of strategies for obtaining and analyzing data. Topics include: survey of publicly available science-data resources; identification of coincidental, correlational and causal relationships; statistical data-analysis techniques; concepts of risk and error propagation in measured and calculated values. Applications in the physical and biological sciences.
name: ISAP 3001
prereq_text: ISAP 2002, COMP 1005 and STAT 2507 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Principles and Applications in Data Analysis

desc: Application of skills from Interdisciplinary Science and Practice (ISAP) courses to develop a research proposal. Topics include: research ethics; identification of stakeholders; inclusive consultation, collaboration and dissemination strategies.
name: ISAP 3002
prereq_text: ISAP 2002 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Applications in Interdisciplinary Research

desc: How is science perceived and how has science been communicated? Students will use case studies to assess examples of science communication with varying outcomes. Topics include the principles of effective science communication, the range of tools available, and knowing the audience.
name: ISAP 3003
prereq_text: ISAP 2002 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Science Communication

desc: Exploration of how science-related policy is developed and the impact of policy on science. Topics include policy frameworks, stakeholder roles, power relationships, commercialization and the funding of science.
name: ISAP 3004
prereq_text: ISAP 3003 or permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Science Policy

subject: ISAP
title: Topics in Interdisciplinary Science

name: ISAP 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: ISAP

desc: Specific topics of current interest. Topics may vary from year to year.

subject: ISAP
title: Topics in Interdisciplinary Science

desc: Independent or group study, open to third- and fourth-year students to explore a particular topic, in consultation with a Faculty supervisor. May include directed reading, written assignments, tutorials, laboratory or field work.
name: ISAP 4901
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Interdisciplinary Science and Practice (ISAP) program and permission of the instructor.
subject: ISAP
title: Directed Studies

desc: Students will collaborate on a project that addresses a real-world issue in a team environment. Focus includes: design and completion of a research project; development of communication, critical inquiry, data analysis and research skills; and the opportunity to develop initiative, creativity and self-reliance.
name: ISAP 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Interdisciplinary Science and Practice (ISAP) Honours program and permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Capstone Course - Group Research Project

desc: A substantial, independent essay or research proposal-based critical review and research proposal, using library, database and/or bioinformatic resources, under the direct supervision of the instructor. Topics include identification and critical review of resources, development of writing skills and formulation of research question and strategy.
name: ISAP 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Interdisciplinary Science and Practice (ISAP) Honours program.
subject: ISAP
title: Capstone Course - Research Essay

desc: An independent research project under the direct supervision of a faculty adviser. Evaluation is based on a written thesis and a poster presentation.
name: ISAP 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Interdisciplinary Science and Practice (ISAP) Honours program, a major CGPA of 9.0 or higher, and permission of the Institute.
subject: ISAP
title: Capstone Course - Individual Research Project

desc: Examination of topics of interest to a number of disciplines, along with various methods and styles of thought used to study them. Students will synthesize the various perspectives. Open only to students in Directed Interdisciplinary Studies and Child Studies.
name: DIST 3901
prereq_text: third-year standing in Child Studies or Directed Interdisciplinary Studies.
subject: DIST
title: Themes in Interdisciplinary Inquiry

desc: An examination of one or more interdisciplinary topics selected by faculty to present interdisciplinary thought and research not available elsewhere in the university curriculum.
name: DIST 3902
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: DIST
title: Selected Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies

desc: Individual or small-group tutorial related to the theme of a Directed Interdisciplinary Studies program. Written permission from the Director of Interdisciplinary Studies is required before registering; please contact the DIS administrator.
name: DIST 4901
prereq_text: for Directed Interdisciplinary Studies students with fourth year Honours standing and a CGPA of 9.00 or better or permission of the Institute.
subject: DIST
title: Directed Reading

desc: Individual or small-group tutorial related to the theme of a Directed Interdisciplinary Studies program. Written permission from the Director of Interdisciplinary Studies is required before registering; please contact the DIS administrator.
name: DIST 4902
prereq_text: for Directed Interdisciplinary Studies students with fourth year Honours standing and a CGPA of 9.00 or better or permission of the Institute.
subject: DIST
title: Directed Reading

desc: An examination of one or more interdisciplinary topics selected by faculty to present interdisciplinary thought and research not available elsewhere in the university curriculum.
name: DIST 4904
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: DIST
title: Selected Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies

desc: Fieldwork related to the theme of a Directed Interdisciplinary Studies program. A proposal with a fieldwork research question and a supervisor must be approved prior to registration. A paper relating the fieldwork to the student's DIS program must be submitted. Graded as Sat/Uns.
name: DIST 4905
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Directed Interdisciplinary Studies or permission of the Institute.
subject: DIST
title: Directed Interdisciplinary Studies Fieldwork I

desc: Fieldwork related to the theme of a Directed Interdisciplinary Studies program. A proposal with a fieldwork research question and a supervisor must be approved prior to registration. A paper relating the fieldwork to the student's DIS program must be submitted. Graded as Sat/Uns.
name: DIST 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Directed Interdisciplinary Studies or permission of the Institute.
subject: DIST
title: Directed Interdisciplinary Studies Fieldwork II

desc: Interdisciplinary research project designed to develop research and writing skills. Topics must be approved by the Program Coordinator also charged with marking the essay.
name: DIST 4907
prereq_text: fourth year standing.
subject: DIST
title: Honours Essay

desc: Interdisciplinary project for Honours Directed Interdisciplinary Studies students. In selecting a project, students must consult with the D.I.S. Program Coordinator. Students will work closely with a supervisor. Approval from the Program Coordinator to register for this course is necessary.
name: DIST 4908
prereq_text: fourth year standing in the B.A. Honours Directed Interdisciplinary Studies program and a 9.0 CGPA or higher.
subject: DIST
title: Honours Project

desc: Analysis of international policy processes relevant to governments, non-governmental organizations, international organizations and multinational corporations, drawing upon theories of international relations, political science, law and economics. Emphasis on analytical and normative aspects of public policy processes in international relations.
name: INAF 3001
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in the International Studies Specialization.
subject: INAF
title: Understanding Policy in a Global Context

desc: Applications of policy analysis to specific international problems with an emphasis on institutions, multiple levels of governance, the role of non-governmental actors, and complex interconnected policy issues. Cases are drawn from international problems such as security, economics, development, the environment, migration, and health.
name: INAF 3002
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in the International Studies Specialization, and successful completion of INAF 3001.
subject: INAF
title: Applied Policy in a Global Context

desc: An interdisciplinary course examining selected issues and policies in the area of conflict and conflict management. Topics include subjects such as sources and causes of conflict, conflict mediation, and peacekeeping and peacebuilding.
name: INAF 4101
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in the International Relations and Conflict Concentration of the International Policy Studies Specialization, or permission from Kroeger College and NPSIA.
subject: INAF
title: Topics in Conflict and Conflict Management

desc: An interdisciplinary course examining selected issues and policies in the area of security and intelligence. Topics include subjects such as intelligence oversight and privacy, comparative defence and security policy, terrorism, and counterterrorism.
name: INAF 4201
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in the Security and Intelligence Concentration of the International Policy Studies Specialization or permission from Kroeger College and NPSIA.
subject: INAF
title: Topics in Security and Intelligence

desc: An interdisciplinary course examining selected issues and policies in the area of rights and human development. Topics include subjects such as food security, access to water, income distribution and inequality, health and education.
name: INAF 4301
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in the Rights and Human Development Concentration of the Development Policy Studies Specialization, or permission from Kroeger College and NPSIA.
subject: INAF
title: Topics in Rights and Human Development

desc: An interdisciplinary course examining selected issues and policies in the area of globalization and global economic relations. Topics include trade and development, multinationals and corporate social responsibility, debt and finance, intellectual property, and migration.
name: INAF 4401
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in the Global Economic Relations Concentration of the Development Policy Studies Specialization, or permission from Kroeger College and NPSIA.
subject: INAF
title: Topics in Global Economic Relations

desc: This course charts a history of the fourth estate in the West from the invention of the printing press to the ascendance of networked digital communication, focusing on the political, economic and technological contexts that have shaped the news media as institutions and industries.
name: JOUR 1001
prereq_text: for Journalism Honours students only.
subject: JOUR
title: Foundations: Journalism in Context

desc: The course introduces students to the concepts, issues and challenges in the contemporary Canadian media environment that will shape their professional role as practicing journalists. It will also provide students with an initial opportunity to practice some basic journalistic skills.
name: JOUR 1002
prereq_text: for Journalism Honours students only.
subject: JOUR
title: Foundations: Practicing Journalism in a Diverse Society

desc: Journalism’s evolution as community creator and guardian of democracy; its greatest scoops and worst misdeeds. From ancient news-sharing to 21st-century expression in blogs, tweets and investigative masterpieces, this course surveys ethical, political and economic contexts of journalism. Not open to Journalism majors.
name: JOUR 1003
prereq_text: None
subject: JOUR
title: Discovering Journalism: Traditional Tales to Tweets

desc: Activists, imposters and innovators increasingly crowd in on traditional journalism’s role of presenting reliable news and fair discussion. How is public awareness now shaped – and misshaped – and how must journalism reshape, update and defend its borders to serve communities better?.
name: JOUR 2003
prereq_text: JOUR 1001, JOUR 1002, JOUR 1003, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Delivering Journalism: Innovators v. Imposters

desc: Examination of the work of individual film makers, of documentary styles and of organizations and institutions in the context of the history of documentary film making, including documentaries made for television. Non-fiction films other than documentaries may be considered.
name: JOUR 2106
prereq_text: FILM 1101 or FILM 1120, or second-year standing, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: JOUR
title: The Documentary

desc: Introduction to the techniques journalists use to gather information quickly, accurately and ethically, and to present reports and features in clear, engaging ways. Newsroom exercises provide experience in reporting, writing, editing and using digital tools, including photography and social media.
name: JOUR 2201
prereq_text: JOUR 1001 and JOUR 1002 and second year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism program.
subject: JOUR
title: Fundamentals of Reporting

desc: An introduction to the digital tools and social media journalists use to gather, verify and present material to audiences. Lab exercises provide experience producing photographs, audio, and video for journalistic storytelling and the use of social media tools and platforms for reporting and publishing.
name: JOUR 2202
prereq_text: JOUR 1001 and JOUR 1002 and second year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism program. Students must be enrolled in this course concurrently with JOUR 2201.
subject: JOUR
title: Digital Journalism Toolkit

desc: A survey of laws that affect the Canadian media. Specific areas include the development of freedom of expression, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and statutory and common law limitations on freedoms of the press, including publication bans, libel and contempt of court.
name: JOUR 2501
prereq_text: JOUR 1001, JOUR 1002, COMS 1001, COMS 1002, or JOUR 1003 and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information, or enrollment in the Communication and Policy Studies specialization of the Bachelor of Public Affairs and Policy Management, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Media Law

desc: Theoretical implications of documentary film and documentary television practice.
name: JOUR 3105
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in Film Studies at the 2000-level, or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Questions of Documentary Practice

desc: In this workshop students will build on the principles and practices of audio journalism to produce stories and audio in various formats suitable for radio and digital publication. Note: JOUR 3207 and JOUR 3208 may not be taken in the same term.
name: JOUR 3207
prereq_text: JOUR 2201, JOUR 2202, and JOUR 2501 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: JOUR
title: Audio Journalism

desc: In this workshop students will build on the principles and practices of video journalism to produce stories and video in various formats suitable for television and digital publication. Note: JOUR 3207 and JOUR 3208 may not be taken in the same term.
name: JOUR 3208
prereq_text: JOUR 2201, JOUR 2202, and JOUR 2501 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: JOUR
title: Video Journalism

desc: Long-form journalistic writing skills development; techniques for thorough investigation of timely public issues. Study of outstanding feature and investigative writing examples. Students will pursue their own reporting projects.
name: JOUR 3225
prereq_text: JOUR 2201, JOUR 2202, and JOUR 2501 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: JOUR
title: Reporting in Depth

desc: Further development of digital journalism skills. Students will produce journalism for online audiences using formats including written and spoken language, still and moving images.
name: JOUR 3235
prereq_text: JOUR 2201, JOUR 2202, and JOUR 2501 with a grade of C or higher in each.
subject: JOUR
title: Digital Journalism

desc: Ethical issues related to production and dissemination of news and other forms of content as they relate to digital environments. Different approaches to ethical decision-making and their application in contemporary settings.
name: JOUR 3300
prereq_text: JOUR 2201, JOUR 2202 and JOUR 2501 with a grade of C or higher in each, or JOUR 1003, JOUR 2003 and JOUR 2501 with a grade of C or higher in each and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information.
subject: JOUR
title: Media Ethics in a Digital World

desc: Examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses.
name: JOUR 3400
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Selected Topic in Journalism

desc: Examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses.
name: JOUR 3401
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism, or third-year standing and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Selected Topic in Journalism

desc: Examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses.
name: JOUR 3402
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism, or third-year standing and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Selected Topic in Journalism

desc: The comparative study of one or more media organizations and/or types of media content with reference to their operation, audiences, and impacts.
name: JOUR 3407
prereq_text: third-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Comparative Media Studies

desc: Changes occurring in the media, in the public’s relationship with the media and how journalists and news organizations respond. Practical issues and challenges in the professional life of a journalist.
name: JOUR 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism or in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design, or fourth-year standing and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information, or fourth-year standing in the Strategic Public Opinion stream of the Communication and Policy Studies specialization of the Bachelor of Public Affairs and Policy Management.
subject: JOUR
title: Journalism Now - and Next

desc: A workshop designed to give students instruction in digital reporting and publishing as they produce stories from across the city and beyond.
name: JOUR 4003
prereq_text: JOUR 3235 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons.
subject: JOUR
title: The Digital Hub: Advanced Multimedia

desc: A workshop designed to give students instruction in audio journalism as they produce stories from across the city and beyond.
name: JOUR 4004
prereq_text: JOUR 3207 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons.
subject: JOUR
title: The Digital Hub: Advanced Audio

desc: A workshop designed to give students instruction in video journalism as they produce stories from across the city and beyond.
name: JOUR 4005
prereq_text: JOUR 3208 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons.
subject: JOUR
title: The Digital Hub: Advanced Video

desc: Examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses. Seminar three hours a week.
name: JOUR 4100
prereq_text: None
subject: JOUR
title: Special Topic

desc: An examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: JOUR 4101
prereq_text: None
subject: JOUR
title: Special Topic

desc: Examination of a topic not covered in depth in other specialized journalism courses. Topics may vary from year to year. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting, culminating in an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4300
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Special Topic

desc: Core skills development for business journalism: reading financial documents, covering activities of corporations, functioning of stock and other markets, trade policy and the broader economy, focus on contemporary business news and local publicly-traded companies. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting, production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4301
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Business and the Markets

desc: The intersection between business and public policy, from climate change to taxation, pensions, labour and corporate social responsibility. What business does and how the media covers it. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting, production of a related data project as an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4302
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Business and Canadian Society

desc: The culture of health science research and major trends; key challenges confronting researchers and health science journalists around the world. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting, production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4303
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Health and Science

desc: Major trends and research culture in climate and environmental sciences, focusing on key global concerns. Issues facing researchers and journalists. Focus on explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4304
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Environment and Science

desc: Exploration of the unique issues in Canada-U.S. relations, from diplomacy to trade. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4305
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Canada and the U.S.

desc: Diplomacy, war, terrorism, migration, the international economy, development and other issues of interest to journalists who want to write about Canada and international affairs. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4306
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Canada and the World

desc: Workshop equipping students with the skills to move beyond the clichés of sports writing and live event coverage. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4308
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Honours or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Sports and Sport Culture

desc: Students are introduced to arts and culture journalism, exploring issues and trends that are key to understanding and covering the arts and related cultural policy in Canada. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting, culminating in an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4309
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Honours or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Arts and Culture

desc: Areas of law that journalists may encounter along with a practical explanation of how law works. Students gain the language and tools needed to successfully analyze and write about legal issues. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4310
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Honours or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Justice and the Law

desc: Examination of the Supreme Court of Canada, and the role of journalists in covering it. Students attend hearings and gain insight into the court’s role in the making and shaping of Canada. Emphasis on explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4311
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing in B.J. Honours or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Specialized Journalism: Justice and The Supreme Court

desc: Examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses.
name: JOUR 4400
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in B.J. Honours or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Professional Skills: Special Topic

desc: Instruction in telling stories from data. Focus on searching for, analyzing and mapping data, turning numbers into powerful narratives.
name: JOUR 4401
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing.
subject: JOUR
title: Professional Skills: Data Storytelling

desc: Instruction in longform story production. Focus on researching and writing, including the art and craft of writing for magazines.
name: JOUR 4402
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing.
subject: JOUR
title: Professional Skills: Longform Writing

desc: Workshop pairing student teams with non-profit groups that are in need of strategic communication advice. Instruction in planning and implementation.
name: JOUR 4403
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing.
subject: JOUR
title: Professional Skills: Strategic Communication

desc: Workshop preparing students to compete in a market that values the skills and mindset of entrepreneurial media workers.
name: JOUR 4404
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year standing.
subject: JOUR
title: Professional Skills: Freelancing for Media Professionals

desc: Examination of a topic in journalism not covered in depth in other courses.
name: JOUR 4500
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in B.J. Honours or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Investigating Journalism: Special Topic

desc: How social concepts of gender, identity and inequality influence journalism. Theoretical and textual analysis. Historical and contemporary case studies from mainstream and alternative media exploring journalistic expression, professional practices, status and expectations, and cultural representations.
name: JOUR 4501
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in B.J. Hons. or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Investigating Journalism: Gender, Identity and Inequality

desc: For as long as there has been conflict between peoples, there have been those who bear witness and recount their observations. This course examines journalism and conflict with an emphasis on journalistic perspectives but also through discussion of interdisciplinary literature and academic research.
name: JOUR 4502
prereq_text: fourth-year B.J. Honours standing, or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Investigating Journalism: Journalism and Conflict

desc: Students will explore how journalism in Canada has been associated with colonialism, be challenged to confront misrepresentation in the news media, and learn to consider new strategies and ethical frameworks for covering Indigenous peoples in the era of reconciliation.
name: JOUR 4503
prereq_text: third-or fourth-year B.J. Honours standing, or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Investigating Journalism: Journalism, Indigenous Peoples and Canada

desc: A critical examination of the use of journalism as an instrument of international development, historically and currently. To what extent have these efforts been successful? On what grounds are they justified? In what regard have they been instruments of propaganda?.
name: JOUR 4504
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism, or third-year standing and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: JOUR
title: Investigating Journalism: The Media and International Development

desc: In-depth exploration of Canada's government, public policy and politics; parliamentary debate and committee hearings. Explanatory/analytical reporting; production of an extended work of journalism.
name: JOUR 4505
prereq_text: JOUR 3225 with a grade of C or higher and fourth-year B.J. Honours standing, or permission of the School.
subject: JOUR
title: Investigating Journalism: The Power and Politics of Government

desc: Students analyze some major achievements in contemporary journalism, through individual or group research. Students also have the opportunity to acquire background and experience in the managerial aspects and production of print and broadcast journalism.
name: JOUR 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year B.J. (Honours) standing.
subject: JOUR
title: Honours Tutorial

desc: For students with no knowledge of Korean. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: KORE
title: First-Year Korean I

desc: Continuation of first-year Korean. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 1020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 1010, or in LANG 1010 (when the language of instruction was Korean), or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: First-Year Korean II

desc: Further study of Korean to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 2010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 1020, or in LANG 1020 (when the language of instruction was Korean), or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: Second-Year Korean I

desc: Continuation of second-year Korean. Further study of Korean to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 2020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 2010, or in LANG 2010 (when the language of instruction was Korean), or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: Second-Year Korean II

desc: Continuation of the study of Korean to reach a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 3010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 2020 or LANG 2020 (if taken in winter 2017), or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: Third-Year Korean I

desc: Continuation of third-year Korean. Progress toward a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 3020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 3010, or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: Third-Year Korean II

desc: Development of speaking and writing abilities more complex than those used in daily communication. Development of language use for specific purposes and in specific contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 4010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 3020, or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: Fourth-Year Korean I

desc: Continuation of Fourth-Year Korean. Further development of speaking and writing abilities more complex than those used in daily communication. Development of language use for specific purposes and in specific contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains. Compulsory attendance.
name: KORE 4020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in KORE 4010, or permission of the School.
subject: KORE
title: Fourth-Year Korean II

desc: Introductory study of a selected language. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. The language taught will vary from year to year. Compulsory attendance.
name: LANG 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: LANG
title: Introduction to a Language I

desc: Continuation of LANG 1010. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. Compulsory attendance.
name: LANG 1020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in LANG 1010, or permission of the School.
subject: LANG
title: Introduction to a Language II

desc: Introductory study of a selected language. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. The language taught will vary from year to year. Compulsory attendance.
name: LANG 1110
prereq_text: None
subject: LANG
title: Intensive Introduction to a Language

desc: Further study of a selected language to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: LANG 2010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in LANG 1020 or LANG 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: LANG
title: Second-Year Language I

desc: Continuation of second-year of a selected language. Further study of this language to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: LANG 2020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in LANG 2010 or permission of the School.
subject: LANG
title: Second-Year Language II

desc: Further study of a selected language to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. The language taught will vary from year to year. Compulsory attendance.
name: LANG 2110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in LANG 1020 or LANG 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: LANG
title: Continuing Intensive Study of a Language

desc: Supervised autonomous language learning in a language for which second-year instruction is not available. Guidance in compiling a language portfolio (oral and written skills) to document competence equivalent to completion of the 2020 level. Setting learning objectives, selecting materials, developing methods, strategies and learning tools.
name: LANG 2900
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in LANG 1020 or LANG 1110, and permission of the School.
subject: LANG
title: Supervised Autonomous Language Learning

desc: A course for beginners in Latin, designed to give students a grasp of basic grammatical forms and vocabulary (with reference to English derivatives) through the reading of continuous Latin.
name: LATN 1005
prereq_text: None
subject: LATN
title: Introduction to Latin I

desc: A course for students with some previous knowledge of the language: study of grammatical forms and constructions; acquisition of reading skills.
name: LATN 1006
prereq_text: LATN 1005 or equivalent.
subject: LATN
title: Introduction to Latin II

desc: Further study of the language; introduction to the reading of Latin authors.
name: LATN 2200
prereq_text: LATN 1006 or equivalent.
subject: LATN
title: Intermediate Latin I

desc: Continued study of the language; reading of selected prose and poetry by Latin authors; development of translation skills.
name: LATN 2201
prereq_text: LATN 2200 or equivalent.
subject: LATN
title: Intermediate Latin II

desc: Reading and critical discussion of selections from Latin poetry.
name: LATN 3900
prereq_text: LATN 2200, LATN 2201 or equivalent.
subject: LATN
title: Advanced Latin I

desc: Reading and critical discussion of selections from Latin prose.
name: LATN 3901
prereq_text: LATN 2200, LATN 2201 or equivalent.
subject: LATN
title: Advanced Latin II

name: LATN 4900
prereq_text: None
subject: LATN
title: Directed Study

name: LATN 4901
prereq_text: None
subject: LATN
title: Directed Study

desc: An introduction to the history, culture, societies, and literatures of the region. Students will get a broad overview of the region and will be introduced to the disciplines used to study these societies.
name: LACS 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: LACS
title: Introduction to Latin American and Caribbean Studies I

desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the major political, economic, environmental, and geographical issues confronting the region.
name: LACS 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: LACS
title: Introduction to Latin American and Caribbean Studies II

desc: An examination of the major issues confronting Latin America and the Caribbean including democratization, economic integration, indigenous and women’s movements, human rights, social justice, and political change.
name: LACS 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission from Latin American and Caribbean Studies.
subject: LACS
title: Issues in Latin American and Caribbean Studies

desc: Latin America's changing relations with states, international institutions and non-state actors in the Global North and South. Topics may include security, South-South cooperation, trade, investment and transnational migration and drug trafficking.
name: LACS 4819
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission from Latin American and Caribbean Studies.
subject: LACS
title: Latin America and the World

desc: Introduction to legal studies: concepts, sources, nature and functions of law; historical, cultural and constitutional foundations of Canadian legal system; common and civil law traditions; statutory interpretation; precedent; legal institutions; frameworks for analyzing formal and informal conceptions of law and its role in society.
name: LAWS 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: LAWS
title: Introduction to Legal Studies 1

desc: Introduction to legal rules and theoretical approaches for critically understanding the creation, interpretation and enforcement of those rules; the role of judges, juries, lawyers, and lay persons; adjudication and alternative dispute resolution; relationship of law with social change and justice; challenges of access to justice.
name: LAWS 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: LAWS
title: Introduction to Legal Studies 2

desc: Theories and practices of law and social justice. Issues examined may include: civil democracy and repression; global governance and the rule of law; democratic movements and social power; human rights instruments, regimes and remedies; armed conflict; and humanitarian intervention.
name: LAWS 2105
prereq_text: 1.0 credit from LAWS 1001, LAWS 1002, PSCI 1100, PSCI 1200 or HUMR 1001 [1.0] or PAPM 1000 [1.0].
subject: LAWS
title: Social Justice and Human Rights

desc: Origins and scope of the concept of person in law and how concepts of legal personality change over time. Origins and scope of the concept of property and how concepts of property change over time.
name: LAWS 2201
prereq_text: LAWS 1001 and LAWS 1002.
subject: LAWS
title: Persons and Property

desc: The concepts employed by the law for creating and enforcing legal obligations between persons within society, including contract, tort, fiduciary obligation and restitution. Consideration is given to the role of persons and the role of the state in ordering private legal obligations.
name: LAWS 2202
prereq_text: LAWS 1001 and LAWS 1002.
subject: LAWS
title: Obligations

desc: The institutional and social production of criminal law in Canada. Processes, personnel, and agencies in the criminal legal system. The role of discretion and mechanisms of accountability. The accused and the place of the victim. Issues and problems in sentencing and punishment.
name: LAWS 2301
prereq_text: LAWS 1001 and LAWS 1002.
subject: LAWS
title: Criminal Justice System

desc: The legal and social dimensions of criminal liability and responsibility in Canada, including issues and problems surrounding mens rea, actus reus, and the attachment of liability. Excuses and justifications, the Canadian Criminal Code and the role of the Charter in the criminal legal system.
name: LAWS 2302
prereq_text: LAWS 1001 and LAWS 1002.
subject: LAWS
title: Criminal Law

desc: Law relating to the state, society and the constitution, with a focus on the historical framework, federalism, and constitutional reform in Canada.
name: LAWS 2501
prereq_text: 1.0 credit from LAWS 1001, LAWS 1002, PSCI 1100, PSCI 1200, or PAPM 1000 [1.0].
subject: LAWS
title: Law, State and Constitution

desc: Law relating to the state and its relationship to individuals and groups in society, with a focus on the administrative process, basic values and the Charter.
name: LAWS 2502
prereq_text: 1.0 credit from LAWS 1001, LAWS 1002, PSCI 1100, PSCI 1200, or PAPM 1000 [1.0].
subject: LAWS
title: Law, State and Citizen

desc: Examination of the role of law in contemporary international relations. Nature, history and sources of international law; international personality of states; status of international organizations and individuals; creation and effect of international obligations; importance and functions of law in the settlement of international disputes.
name: LAWS 2601
prereq_text: 1.0 credit from LAWS 1001, LAWS 1002, PSCI 1100, PSCI 1200, or PAPM 1000 [1.0].
subject: LAWS
title: Public International Law

desc: Introduction to the legal research process and analysis of legal methodology; finding and analyzing primary and secondary legal sources. Students are strongly encouraged to take this course in the second year of their program.
name: LAWS 2908
prereq_text: LAWS 1001 and LAWS 1002 or LAWS 1000 (no longer offered).
subject: LAWS
title: Methodological Approaches in Legal Studies 1

desc: How the legal process has affected the status of women. Areas of concentration within the Canadian context include the criminal law, citizenship and immigration, education, employment, and welfare and social services.
name: LAWS 3001
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Women and the Legal Process

desc: The enforcement of promises and agreements; basic doctrines and underlying principles of the law of contract are studied from formation of the contract to remedies for breach of contract; role of contract for economic and social purposes is also considered.
name: LAWS 3003
prereq_text: LAWS 2202 and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Contracts

desc: Definitions and goals of regulation; contemporary theories and debates about legal and non-legal approaches to regulation. Approaches studied may include market mechanisms, public agency regulation, self-regulation and governance in co-operation with associations in civil society.
name: LAWS 3005
prereq_text: 1.0 credit from LAWS 2201, LAWS 2202, LAWS 2501, LAWS 2502.
subject: LAWS
title: Law and Regulation

desc: Theory and practice of mediation; historical roots and influences; contrasts with formal litigation and other dispute resolution processes; issues of social and legal control; critiques, including feminist, Marxist and critical race theory; issues of power, gender, race and class; application to contemporary issues and disputes.
name: LAWS 3006
prereq_text: (LAWS 1001 and LAWS 1002) and (1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level or 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level and BUSI 2601).
subject: LAWS
title: Mediation

desc: The concept of law, leading theories of law and related concepts such as rules and obligations, power and authority, coercion, and justice.
name: LAWS 3101
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Philosophy of Law: The Nature of Law

desc: Legal reasoning and analysis of concepts of particular significance to the law, including justice, rights and duties, liability, punishment, ownership and possession.
name: LAWS 3102
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Philosophy of Law: The Logic of the Law

desc: Themes, approaches and debates in the field of law, culture and the humanities. Primary materials considered may include theoretical writings/cultural criticism/literary texts/films/video/photography and music. These texts present different modes and means of inquiring into the assumptions and aspirations that we ascribe to law.
name: LAWS 3103
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Law, Culture, and the Humanities: A Foundation

desc: Theories of law and politics; prominent thinkers and schools of thought; influence on legal and political institutions. Topics include law and ethics, justice and equity, positivism and natural law, state absolutism, codifications, and anthropological and historical theories of law and society.
name: LAWS 3105
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level, or 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level and PSCI 1100.
subject: LAWS
title: Theory of Law and Politics

desc: A study of sociological theories of law as well as the nature of legal institutions. Impacts of legal regulation on various social institutions and on processes of social debate and conflict.
name: LAWS 3106
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Law and Social Regulation

desc: Forms of carrying on business activity: proprietorships, partnerships, corporations and Crown entities. The rights and obligations of such business enterprises both internally and in relation with other persons. The relationship between legal form and economic function. The role of state intervention.
name: LAWS 3201
prereq_text: LAWS 2201 and LAWS 2202.
subject: LAWS
title: Business Enterprise Frameworks

desc: Critical assessment of copyright, patents, trademarks, trade secrets and other forms of intellectual property; regulation and governance of information technology including self-regulation, standard setting, licensing, competition policy and international dimensions.
name: LAWS 3202
prereq_text: 1.0 credit from LAWS 2201, LAWS 2202, LAWS 2501, LAWS 2502.
subject: LAWS
title: Intellectual Property

desc: An examination of the nature and functions of property as a legal and social institution, with particular reference to theories of property, the scope of property interests, and the relationship between individual property rights and the state.
name: LAWS 3203
prereq_text: LAWS 2201 and LAWS 2202.
subject: LAWS
title: The Legal Nature of Property

desc: Need for consumer protection in the provision of goods and services; traditional legal protection by statute and common law; legislative responses to consumer pressures; judicial response in recent Canadian, English and American law; reform of consumer law.
name: LAWS 3205
prereq_text: (LAWS 2202 or BUSI 2601) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Consumer Law

desc: The law relating to banks and banking; the nature of the legal relationship created; legal rights and duties of the parties involved. Consumer and corporate aspects of banking (including computerization and electronic funds transfers); regulations of banking.
name: LAWS 3206
prereq_text: (LAWS 2202 or BUSI 2601) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Banking Law

desc: Topics may include: the international sale of goods, finance of transnational transactions, international carriage of goods, insurance, agency and trading houses; other forms of trade, e.g., counter-trade, foreign investment; settlement of international disputes by litigation and arbitration.
name: LAWS 3207
prereq_text: (LAWS 2202 or BUSI 2601) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: International Transactions

desc: International regulation of trade and investment through bilateral, regional and multilateral treaties and agreements. Topics may include: WTO, NAFTA, the EU, UNCTAD, intergovernmental commodity agreements, dispute settlement.
name: LAWS 3208
prereq_text: (0.5 credit from LAWS 2202, LAWS 2501, LAWS 2601, BUSI 2601) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: International Trade Regulation

desc: History of corrections in Canada in the context of the international evolution of western penal systems, Canadian corrections in the twentieth century and expansion of alternatives to prison after WWII; criminological debates about the theoretical and empirical significance of historical milestones in corrections.
name: LAWS 3209
prereq_text: LAWS 2301 and LAWS 2302.
subject: LAWS
title: Canadian Correctional Policies in Historical Perspective

desc: Principles of legal liability for harm caused to the person or property of others; examination of policy rationales justifying and limiting liability; responsiveness to changing social values and conditions. Particular focus on negligence law; may also consider nuisance, intentional torts and other topics.
name: LAWS 3303
prereq_text: LAWS 2201 and LAWS 2202.
subject: LAWS
title: Torts

desc: The history of the relationship between the criminal law system and society. Changing issues in the criminal law and the nature of institutional responses, covering medieval to early nineteenth-century England and nineteenth to early twentieth-century Canada.
name: LAWS 3305
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level, or 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level and 0.5 credit in HIST at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Crime and State in History

desc: Criminal law process in Canada; structure and use of the process examined for fairness, defects, and possible reform initiatives. Issues concerning gender, race and class bias in the implementation and application of the criminal law.
name: LAWS 3306
prereq_text: LAWS 2301 and LAWS 2302.
subject: LAWS
title: Crime, Law, Process and Politics

desc: A review of the Youth Criminal Justice Act within the framework of the Canadian justice system, with particular emphasis on historical and philosophical developments and objectives. Current topics include: constitutional issues, procedure, confessions, transfers, sentencing options, alternative measures, reviews, and possible amendments.
name: LAWS 3307
prereq_text: LAWS 2301 and LAWS 2302.
subject: LAWS
title: Youth and Criminal Law

desc: This course explores justifications and practices of punishment and social control from a socio-legal perspective. Rationalizations and justifications for punishment are considered. Different forms of punishment and control within the law will be examined as well as different theoretical perspectives of punishment.
name: LAWS 3308
prereq_text: LAWS 2301 and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Punishment and the Law

desc: Legal regulation of the employment relationship; its contractual basis; defining employment; rights and duties of employees and employers; termination of employment; statutory regulation through employment standards legislation, human rights codes, workers' compensation acts, occupational health and safety and related statutes.
name: LAWS 3401
prereq_text: (0.5 credit from LAWS 2201, LAWS 2202, LAWS 2501, LAWS 2502, BUSI 2601) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Employment Law

desc: Role of law in industrial relations; effect of law on collective bargaining relationships; recognition of bargaining agent; regulation of bargaining; administration of the collective agreement; methods of conflict resolution.
name: LAWS 3405
prereq_text: (0.5 credit from LAWS 2201, LAWS 2202, LAWS 2501, LAWS 2502, BUSI 2601) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Labour Law

desc: An investigation of the Canadian constitution. Sovereignty, the nature and units of executive, legislative, and judicial power in Canada as interpreted by the courts. The distribution of powers under the Canadian constitution, including an investigation of contemporary problems of federalism. Problems of judicial review.
name: LAWS 3500
prereq_text: (LAWS 2501 or PSCI 2003) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Constitutional Law

desc: Legal responses to challenges of the information society. Topics may include privacy, surveillance and monitoring, access to information, freedom of expression, control of objectionable content, Charter and human rights issues, and security.
name: LAWS 3501
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Law in the Information Society

desc: The claimed relationship between freedom of expression and Canadian democracy, including the historical development of the right and various limits on it, and the regulatory structures governing contemporary media, criminalized and commercial expression, and use of media in the courtroom.
name: LAWS 3502
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Regulating Freedom of Expression in Canada

desc: Human rights issues and law in Canada; history and present day experiences of discrimination; critical exploration of laws effectiveness in responding to discrimination; meaning(s) of equality and discrimination; focus on Human Rights Codes - interpretation, administration, enforcement with some reference to s.15 of the Charter.
name: LAWS 3503
prereq_text: (0.5 credit from LAWS 2105, LAWS 2302, LAWS 2502) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Equality and Discrimination

desc: The legal situation of aboriginal peoples in Canada. Topics include status, aboriginal rights, treaties, legislative jurisdiction and the constitutional framework, aboriginal claims, and self-government. Comparative references to aboriginal policy in other countries.
name: LAWS 3504
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Law and Aboriginal Peoples

desc: Structure and procedure of Canadian administrative authorities; policy, statutory and judicial environments in which they operate. Topics include techniques for implementing public policy and structuring public authorities; statutory interpretation; procedural safeguards; exercise of statutory discretion; reconciling efficiency and fairness.
name: LAWS 3506
prereq_text: LAWS 2502 and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Administrative Law

desc: Legal/ethical issues in health care regulation. Topics may include: regulation of health professions; economics of health care; informed consent/choice; regulation of drugs, devices and research; medical malpractice and other liability; mental health issues; patient/client records.
name: LAWS 3508
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Health Law

desc: Selected issues in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The topics of this course may vary from year to year, and are announced in advance of registration.
name: LAWS 3509
prereq_text: (0.5 Credit from LAWS 2105, LAWS 2201, LAWS 2302, LAWS 2502) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: The Charter of Rights Topics

desc: The developing international law relating to the protection of human rights. General concepts, rules and institutions. Specific issues include self-determination, aboriginal rights, the refugee problem, and torture. The inherent problems and overall potential of international law.
name: LAWS 3602
prereq_text: (0.5 credit from LAWS 2105, LAWS 2502, LAWS 2601 or HUMR 2001) and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level or PAPM 1000.
subject: LAWS
title: International Human Rights

desc: Nature, character, legal status and jurisdiction of intergovernmental international organizations. Rights and duties of states arising from membership in international organizations. Distinction between international and supra-national institutions. United Nations system, selected subsidiary organs, and specialized agencies; non-governmental organizations at times of crisis.
name: LAWS 3604
prereq_text: LAWS 2601 and 0.5 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level or PAPM 1000.
subject: LAWS
title: International Organizations

desc: Various aspects of environmental law; pollution control, legal actions and remedies; legal foundations for participation in decision-making processes. Social, economic and political forces influencing the formulation and implementation of environmental law. Alternative forms of regulation that may articulate different demands.
name: LAWS 3800
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Law of Environmental Quality

desc: Legal framework surrounding the family and family relationships in Canadian society. Topics include marriage and cohabitation, matrimonial support, custody and access, and dissolution of marriage. State interventions through law; law and change in family structures; equality issues; dispute resolution processes.
name: LAWS 3804
prereq_text: LAWS 2201 and LAWS 2202.
subject: LAWS
title: Law of the Family

desc: The topics of this course may vary from year to year, and are announced in advance of registration.
name: LAWS 3903
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level.
subject: LAWS
title: Selected Legal Topics

desc: The topics of this course may vary from year to year, and are announced in advance of registration.
name: LAWS 3904
prereq_text: 1.0 credit in LAWS at the 2000 level and permission of Department.
subject: LAWS
title: Selected Legal Topics

desc: Advanced approaches to interdisciplinary research and analysis in law and legal studies. Methodological approaches considered will vary by section, and may include theoretical, quantitative, qualitative, literary, or historical approaches.
name: LAWS 3908
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and third-year Honours standing. Honours students are strongly encouraged to take this course in the third year of their program.
subject: LAWS
title: Methodological Approaches in Legal Studies 2

name: LAWS 3999
prereq_text: registration in the B.A. Honours (concentration in Business Law or concentration in Law, Policy and Government) Cooperative Program, completion of Co-op preparation classes offered by the Co-op office and permission of the Department.
subject: LAWS
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Relationship between family law and ideology of the family, gender roles and the reproduction of family structures. Social ramifications of family law; potential for family law reform as an agency of social change.
name: LAWS 4001
prereq_text: LAWS 2908, 0.5 credit from LAWS 3001 or LAWS 3804, and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Law, Family and Gender

desc: The literature comprising feminist perspectives on law; theoretical bases of these perspectives; place of feminist theories within other critiques of law; significance of different feminist theories for equality theory and law reform strategies; unique contributions of the various perspectives.
name: LAWS 4002
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Feminist Theories of Law

desc: Legal nature of the interaction of religion and state within an historical framework. Emphasis on Canada after the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and on religious pluralism and resistance to state intervention in religion. Interdisciplinary readings drawn from legal, historical and theological sources.
name: LAWS 4006
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Religion and State in Canada

desc: Realist and post-realist legal scholarship; emphasis on Canadian, American and British approaches. Topics include the Canadian treatise tradition, American legal realism, empirical approaches to legal problems, the sociological movement in law, critical and Canadian feminist legal scholarship, Marxian theories of law, normative economic theory.
name: LAWS 4100
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Modern Legal Theory

desc: Selected major contemporary theories of justice such as those associated with Rawls, Walzer, and Habermas, with emphasis on both their procedural and substantive elements and their concrete ramifications for law, policy and political practice.
name: LAWS 4101
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 or PAPM 3000 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Contemporary Justice Theories

desc: This course examines selected controversies in rights theories, practices, and/or historiography. Illustrative questions may include: Are rights universal or culturally relative? Can rights be justified after the demise of natural rights philosophy? Do rights undermine difference? Do communities benefit from a rights-based culture?.
name: LAWS 4102
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 or PAPM 3000 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Controversies in Rights Theory

desc: Detailed study of a special topic in philosophy of law.
name: LAWS 4103
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Special Topic in the Philosophy of Law

desc: Detailed study of a special topic in philosophy of law.
name: LAWS 4104
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Special Topic in the Philosophy of Law

desc: Selected theories of global justice as they pertain to legality, which may include questions such as the justice of military force and just war theory, global social justice and global inequality, sovereignty and cosmopolitan conceptions of justice, demands for global democracy and human rights.
name: LAWS 4105
prereq_text: LAWS 2105, LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Global Justice Theory

desc: Examination of how law defines, justifies, and addresses individual, collective and state violence: contemporary and historical case studies; theoretical inquiries into the relationship between law, legality and different forms of violence.
name: LAWS 4106
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 or PAPM 3000 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Law and Violence

desc: Sociological and legal theory accounts of the changing role and function of law in modern society with particular reference to advanced capitalist societies. Topics include: the welfare state and the use of regulatory law; juridification and legalization; counter-trends, deregulation, informalism, legal pluralism.
name: LAWS 4107
prereq_text: LAWS 2908 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Law in Modern Society

desc: Selected topics in international economic law. May include: the legal regulation of international economic activity; methods of dispute settlement; standardization and development of an autonomous international trade law; and selected conventions and institutions governing international economic law.
name: LAWS 4200
prereq_text: LAWS 2908, 0.5 credit from LAWS 3207 or LAWS 3208, and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: International Economic Law

desc: Role, function, and legal regulation of persons managing business enterprises. Status, social responsibility, fiduciary obligations and rights. Control and accountability of managers, obligations owed to the enterprise unit itself, constitutional rights of members, standards imposed by statutory regulation.
name: LAWS 4202
prereq_text: LAWS 2908, LAWS 3201 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Accountability of Management

desc: An examination of selected legal topics relevant to the conduct of electronic commerce. Topics include types of regulation, government support, jurisdiction challenges, contract disputes and consumer protection. Court and alternative dispute resolution policy of Domain Names challenges are also included.
name: LAWS 4204
prereq_text: LAWS 2908, LAWS 2201, LAWS 2202 and fourth-year Honours standing.
subject: LAWS
title: Legal Issues in eCommerce
