desc: Integration of fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, and heat transfer for design of energy conversion systems. Chemical kinetics and mass transfer. Efficient combustion, fuel cells and batteries. Efficient operation and design of engines, power generators, boilers, furnaces, incinerators, and co-generation systems. Emerging energy systems.
name: MECH 4408
prereq_text: MAAE 3400 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: Thermofluids and Energy Systems Design

desc: Review of matrices. Geometric structure and dynamics of linear systems. Controllability and observability. Pole placement design of controllers and observers. Design of regulator and servo systems. Transmission zeros. Eigenstructure assignment. Relationship to frequency or classical control techniques. Computer solutions using MATLAB. Applications.
name: MECH 4501
prereq_text: (MAAE 3500 or SYSC 4505) and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: State Space Modeling and Control

desc: History of robotics and typical applications. Robotic actuators and sensors. Kinematics of manipulators, inverse kinematics, differential relationships and the Jacobian. Manipulator dynamics. Trajectory generation and path planning. Robot control and performance evaluation. Force control and compliance. Applications in manufacturing and other industries.
name: MECH 4503
prereq_text: MAAE 3500 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: An Introduction to Robotics

desc: Finite element methodology with emphasis on applications to stress analysis, heat transfer and fluid flow using the simplest one- and two-dimensional elements. Direct equilibrium, variational and Galerkin formulations. Computer programs and practical applications. Higher order elements.
name: MECH 4604
prereq_text: MAAE 3202 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: Finite Element Methods

desc: Overview of the topics essential to CIMS including integration of design and assembly techniques, numerical analysis, statistical process control and related production technologies within the manufacturing enterprise.
name: MECH 4704
prereq_text: Fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: Integrated Manufacturing - CIMS

desc: Introduction to contemporary computer aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) Topics covered include mathematical representation, solid modeling, drafting, mechanical assembly mechanism design, (CNC) machining. Current issues such as CAD data exchange standards, rapid prototyping, concurrent engineering, and design for X (DFX) are also discussed.
name: MECH 4705
prereq_text: MAAE 2001 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: CAD/CAM

desc: Experimental data, accuracy and uncertainty analysis. Analog systems. Sensors. Signal conditioning. Op-Amps, instrumentation amplifiers, charge amplifiers, filters. Digital techniques. Encoders, A/D D/A converters. Data acquisition using microcomputers. Hardware and software considerations. Interfacing. Applications to measurement of motion, strain, force/torque, pressure, fluid flow, temperature.
name: MECH 4805
prereq_text: ECOR 2050 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: Measurement and Data Systems

desc: Introduction to the integration of mechanical, electronic and software components to build mechatronic devices. Mechanical and electrical systems modeling, simulation and implementation. Basic automation and computer requirements. Design tools and examples of mechatronic applications.
name: MECH 4806
prereq_text: (MAAE 3500 or SYSC 4505) and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MECH
title: Mechatronics

desc: Engineering drawing techniques; fits and tolerances; working drawings; fasteners. Elementary descriptive geometry; true length, true view, and intersection of geometric entities; developments. Assignments will make extensive use of Computer-Aided Design (CAD) and will include the production of detail and assembly drawings from actual physical models.
name: MAAE 2001
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Engineering Graphical Design

desc: Review of kinematics and kinetics of particles: rectilinear and curvilinear motions; Newton's second law; energy and momentum methods. Kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies: plane motion of rigid bodies; forces and accelerations; energy and momentum methods.
name: MAAE 2101
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Engineering Dynamics

desc: Review of Principles of Statics; friction problems; Concepts of stress and strain at a point; statically determinate and indeterminate stress systems; torsion of circular sections; bending moment and shear force diagrams; stresses and deflections in bending; buckling instability.
name: MAAE 2202
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Mechanics of Solids I

desc: Fluid properties. Units. Kinematics, dynamics of fluid motion: concepts of streamline, control volume, steady and one-dimensional flows; continuity, Euler, Bernoulli, steady flow energy, momentum, moment of momentum equations; applications. Fluid statics; pressure distribution in fluid at rest; hydrostatic forces on plane and curved surfaces; buoyancy.
name: MAAE 2300
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Fluid Mechanics I

desc: Basic concepts of thermodynamics: temperature, work, heat, internal energy and enthalpy. First law for closed and steady-flow open systems. Thermodynamic properties of pure substances; changes of phase; equation of state. Second law: entropy. Simple power and refrigeration cycles. Introduction to heat transfer: conduction, convection, radiation.
name: MAAE 2400
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Thermodynamics and Heat Transfer

desc: Materials (metals, alloys, polymers) in engineering service; relationship of interatomic bonding, crystal structure and defect structure (vacancies, dislocations) to material properties; polymers, phase diagrams and alloys; microstructure control (heat treatment) and mechanical properties; material failure; corrosion.
name: MAAE 2700
prereq_text: Second-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Engineering Materials

desc: Kinematic and dynamic analysis of mechanisms and machines. Mechanism force analysis. Static and dynamic balancing. Kinematic and dynamic analysis of cams. Free and forced vibration of single-degree-of-freedom systems. Introduction to multibody dynamics.
name: MAAE 3004
prereq_text: MAAE 2101 and MATH 1005.
subject: MAAE
title: Dynamics of Machinery

desc: Stress and strain transformations: torsion of non-circular sections; unsymmetric bending and shear centre; energy methods; complex stresses and criteria of yielding; elementary theory of elasticity; axisymmetric deformations.
name: MAAE 3202
prereq_text: MAAE 2202 and MATH 1005 (co-req).
subject: MAAE
title: Mechanics of Solids II

desc: Review of control volume analysis. Dimensional analysis and similitude. Compressible flow: isentropic flow relations, flow in ducts and nozzles, effects of friction and heat transfer, normal and oblique shocks, two-dimensional isentropic expansion. Viscous flow theory: hydrodynamic lubrication and introduction to boundary layers.
name: MAAE 3300
prereq_text: MATH 2004 and MAAE 2300.
subject: MAAE
title: Fluid Mechanics II

desc: Gas and vapour power cycles: reheat, regeneration, combined gas/vapour cycles, cogeneration. Heat pump and refrigeration cycles: vapour compression cycles, absorption refrigeration and gas refrigeration. Mixtures of perfect gases and vapours: psychometry and combustion. Principles of turbomachinery.
name: MAAE 3400
prereq_text: MATH 1005 and MAAE 2400.
subject: MAAE
title: Applied Thermodynamics

desc: Introduction to the linear feedback control. Analysis and design of classical control systems. Stability and the Routh-Hurwitz criteria. Time and frequency domain performance criteria, robustness and sensitivity. Root locus, Bode and Nyquist design techniques. Control system components and industrial process automation.
name: MAAE 3500
prereq_text: MATH 3705 and (SYSC 3600 or SYSC 3610).
subject: MAAE
title: Feedback Control Systems

name: MAAE 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: MAAE
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Analysis and prevention of failures in metals; plasticity analysis and plastic collapse; micro-mechanisms of fracture, conditions leading to crack growth and transition temperature effects, fracture mechanics, fatigue, environmentally assisted cracking, non-destructive evaluation and testing.
name: MAAE 4102
prereq_text: MAAE 2202 and MAAE 2700 and fourth-year status in Engineering.
subject: MAAE
title: Materials: Strength and Fracture

desc: Selected advanced topics of interest to Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering students, subject to the discretion of the Faculty of Engineering and Design.
name: MAAE 4902
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: MAAE
title: Special Topics: Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

desc: At the discretion of the Faculty, a course may be offered that deals with selected advanced topics of interest to Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering students.
name: MAAE 4903
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: MAAE
title: Special Topics: Mech & Aero Eng.

desc: Selected advanced topics of interest to Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering students, subject to the discretion of the Faculty of Engineering and Design.
name: MAAE 4904
prereq_text: permission of department.
subject: MAAE
title: Special Topics: Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

desc: At the discretion of the Faculty, a course may be offered that deals with selected advanced topics of interest to Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering students.
name: MAAE 4906
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: MAAE
title: Special Topics: Mech and Aero Eng.

desc: Team project in the design of an aerospace, biomedical, mechanical, or sustainable energy system. Opportunity to develop initiative, engineering judgement, self-reliance, and creativity in a team environment. Results submitted in a comprehensive report as well as through formal oral presentations.
name: MAAE 4907
prereq_text: Fourth-year status in engineering and (completion of or concurrent registration in AERO 4003, AERO 4842, MECH 4003, MECH 4013, or SREE 4001, or permission of Department). Certain projects may have additional prerequisites.
subject: MAAE
title: Engineering Design Project

desc: Study, analysis, and solution of an engineering problem. Results presented in the form of a written report. Carried out under the close supervision of a faculty member. Intended for students interested in pursuing graduate studies. Requires supervising faculty member and proposal from student.
name: MAAE 4917
prereq_text: permission of the Department and completion of, or concurrent registration in, MAAE 4907.
subject: MAAE
title: Undergraduate Directed Study

desc: Theories, origins and evolution of story within society as the digital age shapes the way we construct and consume narratives. How stories are conceived through words, sound and images, and how they resonate with and influence audiences.
name: MPAD 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: MPAD
title: Introduction to Storytelling: The Context

desc: Finding and telling stories in engaging ways using text and basic images. Assignments build basic skills in research, interviewing, writing, storytelling, editing and ethics. How to structure and pitch for publication.
name: MPAD 1002
prereq_text: MPAD 1001.
subject: MPAD
title: Introduction to Storytelling: The Practice

desc: Introduction to visual storytelling through video. Students develop editorial and technical skills to produce video stories that include scripting to images. Students will also learn the basics of video shooting on a range of equipment as well as basic video editing skills.
name: MPAD 2001
prereq_text: MPAD 1002.
subject: MPAD
title: Basics of Visual Communication I

desc: This course expands from video theory and practice to still photography and multimedia projects, with emphasis on hands-on work with a theoretical underpinning, giving students the practical and technical skills to tell stories in multiple formats.
name: MPAD 2002
prereq_text: MPAD 2001.
subject: MPAD
title: Basics of Visual Communication II

desc: Governments use data for tracking. Numbers guide public policy and can become powerful and important stories. Students will gain a theoretical understanding of the promise and pitfalls of data availability alongside the practical skills needed for powerful data-based storytelling.
name: MPAD 2003
prereq_text: MPAD 1002.
subject: MPAD
title: Introductory Data Storytelling

desc: This course tests student baseline skills, then develops writing capabilities tailored to specific media formats. Coursework is based on the principle that the best way to improve technique is through regular writing and timely constructive critiques.
name: MPAD 2004
prereq_text: MPAD 1002.
subject: MPAD
title: Writing for Media

desc: A survey of laws that affect the Canadian media. Specific areas include the development of freedom of expression, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and statutory and common law limitations on freedoms of the press, including publication bans, libel and contempt of court.
name: MPAD 2501
prereq_text: Second-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Media Law

desc: Directed Studies on select topics. Students interested in pursuing this course need to contact a faculty member to discuss a proposed directed study.
name: MPAD 3000
prereq_text: Third year standing in Media Production and Design or permission from the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: MPAD
title: Directed Studies

desc: Social media in storytelling. Theory-based lectures, hands-on course modules, discussions and presentations. Students will learn tactics to apply social media for research, gathering information, finding contacts and promoting their own work.
name: MPAD 3001
prereq_text: MPAD 2004.
subject: MPAD
title: Storytelling and Social Media

desc: Expert sources from Canadian institutions discuss covering the economy, justice, environment and security. How public policy is made, the role of the public and how the media analyze information, develop ideas, and produce stories.
name: MPAD 3002
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design or the Bachelor of Journalism, or third-year standing and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information.
subject: MPAD
title: Civic Engagement and Public Institutions I

desc: Group work building on the fall term course. Production of a public institutions mini-project involving the various development stages that will be employed in the final year capstone project, including the creation of a detailed design document to guide group projects.
name: MPAD 3003
prereq_text: MPAD 3002.
subject: MPAD
title: Civic Engagement and Public Institutions II: Minor Design Project

desc: An examination of ethical issues relating to production of news and other forms of information content, particularly as they relate to digital environments. Discussion of various approaches to ethical decision-making, application in contemporary settings.
name: MPAD 3300
prereq_text: MPAD 2501.
subject: MPAD
title: Media Ethics in a Digital World

desc: The legal use of big data to create content and analyze information. Who owns data; privacy and security implications within a legal landscape fraught with legal concerns and policy challenges.
name: MPAD 3501
prereq_text: JOUR 2501 or MPAD 2501 and third-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design or in the Bachelor of Journalism, or third-year standing and enrollment in the Minor in News Media and Information.
subject: MPAD
title: Internet and Big Data Law

desc: Examination of a topic in storytelling and media not covered in depth in other courses.
name: MPAD 3600
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Special Topic

name: MPAD 3999
prereq_text: MPAD 2002.
subject: MPAD
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Student groups develop a capstone project beginning with story development and planning, completion of a story design document including project description, research, key vistas and sketches or storyboards. Group presentations leading to final media project at the end of second term.
name: MPAD 4000
prereq_text: MPAD 2002, MPAD 3003, ITEC 2100, ITEC 2400 and fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Capstone Project

desc: Changes in the media, the public’s relationship with the media and how journalists, news organizations and other media players respond. Practical issues and challenges in the professional life of an information producer.
name: MPAD 4001
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Media Industries Now and Next

desc: Preparation for freelancing to publications and production houses. Resumes, finding potential buyers, interviews, establishing and marketing an individual as a business, accounting and management and dealing with taxes and benefits. Pitching stories, ideas and services.
name: MPAD 4200
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Freelance Media Survival Skills

desc: Students will choose a topic from a list of journalism options, to be announced each year.
name: MPAD 4300
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Special Topic

desc: Directed study on select topics. Students interested in pursuing this course need to contact a faculty member to discuss a proposed directed study.
name: MPAD 4400
prereq_text: Third year standing in Media Production and Design or permission from the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: MPAD
title: Directed Studies

desc: Examination of a topic in storytelling and media not covered in depth in other courses.
name: MPAD 4500
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Special Topic

desc: How social concepts of gender, identity and inequality influence journalism. Theoretical and textual analysis. Historical and contemporary case studies from mainstream and alternative media exploring journalistic expression, professional practices, status and expectations, and cultural representations.
name: MPAD 4501
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Gender, Identity and Inequality

desc: For as long as there has been conflict between peoples, there have been those who bear witness and recount their observations. This course examines journalism and conflict with an emphasis on journalistic perspectives but also through discussion of interdisciplinary literature and academic research.
name: MPAD 4502
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Journalism and Conflict

desc: Students will explore how journalism in Canada has been associated with colonialism, be challenged to confront misrepresentation in the news media, and learn to consider new strategies and ethical frameworks for covering Indigenous people in the era of reconciliation.
name: MPAD 4503
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: Journalism, Indigenous Peoples and Canada

desc: A critical examination of the use of journalism as an instrument of international development, historically and currently. To what extent have these efforts been successful? On what grounds are they justified? In what regard have they been instruments of propaganda.
name: MPAD 4504
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Media Production and Design program.
subject: MPAD
title: The Media and International Development

desc: An introduction to the Late Antique, Medieval and Early Modern worlds. Organized thematically, students will be introduced to interdisciplinary exploration of core topics.
name: MEMS 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MEMS
title: Discovering the Medieval and Early Modern Past

desc: Continued interdisciplinary study of the Late Antique, Medieval and Early Modern worlds, with a focus on how to develop a deeper analysis of the core topics examined in MEMS 2001.
name: MEMS 3001
prereq_text: MEMS 2001, or permission of the Program Coordinator.
subject: MEMS
title: Researching the Medieval and Early Modern Past

desc: Introduction to the social, cultural, economic and political implications of the movement of people with a multidisciplinary and multiscale approach to topics such as migration and immigration, diaspora identities, global culture, and transnationalism.
name: MGDS 2000
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MGDS
title: Global Migration and Transnationalism

desc: Advanced topics in Migration and Diaspora Studies. Topics vary from term to term.
name: MGDS 4900
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: MGDS
title: Special Topics in Migration and Diaspora Studies

desc: Introduction to issues and methods in the study of music. Development of writing and research skills; methodological approaches in all academic areas of music (historical musicology, ethnomusicology, popular music studies, music theory).
name: MUSI 1000
prereq_text: first-year enrolment in the B.Mus., B.A. Music or B.A. Hons. Music program.
subject: MUSI
title: Introduction to the Study of Music

desc: Western classical music from the medieval period to the present. Major historical periods (Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Modern, Postmodern) are examined through representative music ranging from Gregorian chant to contemporary experimental trends.
name: MUSI 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: MUSI
title: A History of Western Classical Music: Medieval to the Present

desc: History of world popular music from the 19th century until the present. Topics may include the growth of the music industry, the impact of technology, stardom, world music, the role of the press, copyright, censorship, and sexuality.
name: MUSI 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: MUSI
title: Issues in Popular Music

desc: Through musical examples drawn from diverse cultures and historical periods, students develop the ability to describe and analyze different aspects of music and deepen their appreciation of music as a cultural experience. No credit for students in B.Mus, B.A. Honours Music or B.A. Music.
name: MUSI 1003
prereq_text: None
subject: MUSI
title: Understanding Music

desc: An introduction to the rudiments of music and aural training. Successful completion of this course will fulfil the prerequisite for entry into MUSI 1700. Not available to B.Mus. students for credit.
name: MUSI 1107
prereq_text: None
subject: MUSI
title: Elementary Materials of Music

desc: An introduction to the organizational principles underlying tonal music including intervals, scales, rhythm, metre, chords, counterpoint, form, cadences, and harmonic progressions.
name: MUSI 1700
prereq_text: permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Foundations of Music Theory

desc: A study of the harmonic, melodic, rhythmic and formal structures of music of the common-practice period, with emphasis on the development of analytical and written skills of diatonic music.
name: MUSI 1701
prereq_text: MUSI 1700 or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Common Practice I

desc: A study of ear training, sight singing, and basic keyboard skills in relation to classical and popular musics, with emphasis on melodic, harmonic, and formal structures.
name: MUSI 1710
prereq_text: permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Aural Training I

desc: A study of the rhythm of selected classical, popular, and world musics, with emphasis on applied performance, movement, and dictation.
name: MUSI 1711
prereq_text: permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Applied Rhythmic Training I

desc: Individual vocal or instrumental instruction in classical, traditional or popular idioms, in addition to individual performances and group class instruction.
name: MUSI 1900
prereq_text: audition and enrolment in the B.Mus. program; first-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance I

desc: Individual vocal or instrumental instruction in classical, traditional or popular idioms, in addition to individual performances and group class instruction.
name: MUSI 1901
prereq_text: MUSI 1900 and enrolment in the B.Mus. program; first-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance II

desc: Participation in a choral ensemble, by arrangement with the Supervisor of Performance and Practical Studies. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 1912
prereq_text: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble I

desc: A continuation of MUSI 1912. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 1913
prereq_text: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble II

desc: Participation in an instrumental ensemble, by arrangement with the Supervisor of Performance and Practical Studies. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 1914
prereq_text: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble I

desc: A continuation of MUSI 1914. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 1915
prereq_text: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble II

desc: A survey of ragtime and jazz from their roots in pre-twentieth-century black music and white music to contemporary jazz idioms, including an examination of New Orleans jazz and Dixieland, swing, bebop, cool jazz, and free jazz.
name: MUSI 2005
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Introduction to Jazz History

desc: Selected aspects of the development of Anglo-American popular musics from their roots in the nineteenth century until the shifts and tensions which led to the advent of rock-and-roll and soul in the 1950s. Genres to be examined include blues, country, the sentimental ballad, Broadway music.
name: MUSI 2006
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Popular Musics before 1945

desc: Selected aspects of the development of Anglo-American and world popular musics from the advent of rock `n' roll and soul to the present. Early rock `n' roll, British rhythm `n' blues, Motown, West Coast music, punk, heavy metal, new wave, disco and country.
name: MUSI 2007
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Popular Musics after 1945

desc: A survey of musical traditions from various regions of the world, with an emphasis on the sociocultural contexts in which those musics are created and performed.
name: MUSI 2008
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music of the World's Peoples

desc: A comparative and analytical study of music in Asia, including India, China, Korea, Indonesia, Japan, and the Arabic world, through an examination of the music, musical instruments and theoretical systems.
name: MUSI 2009
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music of Asia

desc: The Baroque (1600-1750) was simultaneously shaped by absolutist regimes, competing religions, and an emerging public sphere. Music and culture from Monteverdi to Bach and Handel are investigated in the contexts of power, (geo)politics, religion, aesthetics, gender, socio-economics, dissemination, genre, and compositional practices.
name: MUSI 2102
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Spectacle, Commerce, and Colonization

desc: Peace and revolution, faith and secularism, noble privilege and bourgeois commerce: fundamental contradictions underlying the creative work of Mozart, Haydn, and Beethoven. This course studies their compositions—operas, sacred works, symphonies, chamber music—within the political, social and cultural institutions of their times (ca. 1730-1815).
name: MUSI 2103
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Order, Invention, and Revolution

desc: A survey of European classical music of the 20th century. Idioms to be examined in the socio-political climate of the period include impressionism, expressionism, nationalism, neo-classicism, music of political commitment, contemporary opera and musical theatre, serialism, chance, textural composition, process music and neo-romanticism.
name: MUSI 2107
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Tumult, Innovation, and Pluralism

desc: Introduction to the fundamentals of effective and professional arranging. All aspects of the various instruments of the orchestra and matters having to do with the practicalities of orchestration for both small and large ensembles, and accepted professional standards of score presentation.
name: MUSI 2601
prereq_text: MUSI 1701 and MUSI 1710 and MUSI 1711, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Orchestration and Instrumentation

desc: Introduction to theories and technicalities involved in original creative writing through the preparation of individual assignments; based in the practice of recent music in the Western Classical tradition while allowing for the music of other Western styles and traditions to be addressed.
name: MUSI 2602
prereq_text: MUSI 1701 and MUSI 1710 and MUSI 1711, or permission of the instructor. MUSI 2601 is recommended.
subject: MUSI
title: Composition I

desc: Introduction to the special stylistic features of choral music from the Renaissance to the present as well as to a variety of practical techniques (vocal production, gesture, conducting patterns, diction, etc.).
name: MUSI 2605
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Conducting

desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of electronic music creation, focusing on audio editing, synthesis, sampling, beat-making, signal processing, and sound design, using a variety of professional-grade software packages.
name: MUSI 2608
prereq_text: Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Computer Music I: Fundamentals of Electronic Music Production

desc: Computer-based music-making with an emphasis on collaborative approaches and performance-oriented tools and techniques. Introduces practices of remixing, live sound manipulation, preparation of original material for performance, and the use of hardware controllers in live performance and real-time musical collaboration using mobile technologies.
name: MUSI 2609
prereq_text: Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Computer Music II: Production, Collaboration and Performance

desc: A continuation of the study of the harmonic, melodic, rhythmic and formal structures of music of the common-practice period and early twentieth century, with emphasis on chromaticism and the development of analytical and written skills.
name: MUSI 2700
prereq_text: MUSI 1701 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Common Practice II

desc: A study of the rhythmic, melodic, harmonic and formal structures of popular musics.
name: MUSI 2701
prereq_text: MUSI 1700 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Popular Music Practice

desc: A practical study of rhythm, harmony and melody on the keyboard, with an emphasis on vocal and instrumental accompaniment and the development of improvisation skills in a variety of styles.
name: MUSI 2703
prereq_text: MUSI 1701 and MUSI 1710 and MUSI 1711, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies VI: Practical Keyboard Skills

desc: A continuation of the study of ear training, sight singing, and basic keyboard skills in relation to classical and popular musics, with emphasis on melodic, harmonic, and formal structures.
name: MUSI 2710
prereq_text: MUSI 1701, MUSI 1710.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Aural Training II

desc: A continuation of the study of the rhythm of common-practice and world musics, with emphasis on applied performance, movement, and dictation.
name: MUSI 2711
prereq_text: MUSI 1700, MUSI 1711.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Applied Rhythmic Training II

desc: A continuation of MUSI 1901.
name: MUSI 2900
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI 1901 with a C+ or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance III

desc: A continuation of MUSI 2900.
name: MUSI 2901
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI 2900 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance IV

desc: A continuation of MUSI 1913. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 2912
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble III

desc: A continuation of MUSI 2912. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 2913
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble IV

desc: A continuation of MUSI 1915. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 2914
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble III

desc: A continuation of MUSI 2914. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 2915
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble IV

desc: An examination of various issues related to the study of music in Canada and by Canadians, and an examination of various genres of Canadian music, including art music, folk music, popular music, First Peoples music and music of various immigrant groups.
name: MUSI 3103
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in Canada

desc: A survey of popular musics in Canada from early colonial times to the present. The course will consider a wide range of musical styles and genres, along with related cultural and historical issues.
name: MUSI 3104
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Popular Musics of Canada

desc: Popular musics of the world, including those of Africa, Asia, Central and Eastern Europe, Latin America, the Caribbean and Oceania. Special attention to the interaction between some world popular musics and the Western record industry.
name: MUSI 3106
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Popular Musics of the World

desc: An introduction to the history and theory of classical Indian music including ragas, instruments, rhythm and improvisation.
name: MUSI 3107
prereq_text: second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Classical Indian Music

desc: An examination of various musics, devotional traditions, and shifting cultural and art movements in the region, resulting from processes of globalization, political change, and technological innovation. Course sessions will include close and critical discussion of selected texts, audio-visual examples, and ethnomusicological documentary films.
name: MUSI 3108
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Musics of the Middle East and North Africa

desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of musicology, theory or composition. The course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 3200
prereq_text: permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Special Topics

desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of musicology, theory or composition. The course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 3201
prereq_text: permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Special Topics

desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through courses in theory, musicology, or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 3205
prereq_text: permission of the department, and a minimum GPA of 9.0 in Music.
subject: MUSI
title: Specialized Studies

desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through performance. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 3206
prereq_text: permission of the Department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.
subject: MUSI
title: Specialized Studies in Performance

desc: An examination of the integral role music plays in religion and sacred ritual in different world cultures and religions. Through various case studies, the course broadly considers how sacred soundscapes shape people’s worldviews, identities, and experiences within and outside of their communities.
name: MUSI 3301
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music and Religion

desc: The role of gender in the theory and practice of music in western and non-western cultures.
name: MUSI 3302
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music and Gender I

desc: Literature, practice and theory of music therapy. The use of music (improvisation, the voice, and reception) with various populations, including children and adults with special needs, people in long term care, people with neurological disorders, and in palliative care.
name: MUSI 3303
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Introduction to Music Therapy

desc: A survey of the development of opera from the beginnings to about 1800. The major monuments of Italian, French, German and English opera, by such composers as Monteverdi, Cavalli, Scarlatti, Purcell, Lully, Gluck, Rameau, Mozart and Haydn.
name: MUSI 3400
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: A History of Opera before 1800

desc: A study of romantic and contemporary opera through an examination of selected works from Weber's Der Freischütz to Britten's Peter Grimes, including an investigation of national styles from Wagnerian music drama and Italian verismo to Russian realism and German expressionism.
name: MUSI 3401
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: A History of Opera from 1800 to 1945

desc: The use of music in film, from the silent era to the present day, studying the techniques, styles and theory of film music through the examination of selected scenes.
name: MUSI 3402
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Film Music

desc: An introduction to the structure and history of the music industries.
name: MUSI 3403
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Music Industries

desc: A survey of the styles, works, and artists of the musical theatre genre as well as the artistic elements that comprise musical theatre.
name: MUSI 3405
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Musical Theatre

desc: Origins and development of orchestral music from its beginnings as an independent form in the 18th century to the present. Major symphonies and symphonic poems by composers like Haydn, Beethoven, Liszt, Brahms, Strauss, and Shostakovich. Brief examination of concerto and ballet music.
name: MUSI 3406
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Music: Music for Orchestra

desc: History of chamber music and the cultural contexts within which it rose to prominence in Europe and North America in the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries. Genres by representative composers including the sonata, duos, trios, quartets, quintets, sextets, divertimenti, and works for small chamber orchestra.
name: MUSI 3407
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Music: Chamber Music

desc: This course examines European art music of the nineteenth century, a revolutionary period of socio-political change when inspiration, subjectivity, radical idealism, expressive intensity, cultural nationalism, and the primacy of the individual creative voice were held up as primary aesthetic ideals.
name: MUSI 3408
prereq_text: Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Passion, Imagination, and Iconoclasm

desc: A study of western art music of the 20th century. Musical works, compositional techniques and performance practices are examined in the context of musical innovation, social change, political upheaval, and stylistic pluralism in a rapidly changing “modern” world.
name: MUSI 3409
prereq_text: Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Tumult, Innovation, and Pluralism

desc: Designed to enable students to develop abilities in the writing of original music. The study and appreciation of modern and contemporary styles and techniques are encouraged.
name: MUSI 3602
prereq_text: MUSI 2601, MUSI 2602, and MUSI 2700, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Composition II

desc: An introduction to the techniques of sound synthesis primarily through practical experience at the digital synthesizer and computer. The basics of machine operations, software and computer applications to composition and synthesis. Enrolment is limited.
name: MUSI 3603
prereq_text: Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing and either MUSI 2608 or MUSI 2609, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Computer Music Techniques

desc: Examination of the various applications of digital equipment through the realization of original projects. Students may focus on studio composition, software development or analytic research. Appropriate compositional techniques and problem solving strategies are also discussed. Enrolment is limited.
name: MUSI 3604
prereq_text: second-year standing, and either MUSI 2603 (no longer offered) or MUSI 2608 or MUSI 2609, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Computer Music Projects

desc: Introduction to the practice of conducting Instrumental music from the Classical era to the present as well as to a variety of practical techniques (rehearsal techniques, gesture, conducting patterns, score study, etc.).
name: MUSI 3605
prereq_text: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Conducting

desc: Theoretical, practical and technical requirements of audio production in live settings are explored through lectures, demonstrations and workshops. Students develop skills in critical listening, pre-production planning, microphone selection and placement, signal routing, audio processing, monitoring and mixing for live event venues. Prior experience not required.
name: MUSI 3606
prereq_text: None
subject: MUSI
title: Live Sound

desc: Selected topic in music theory. Topics will change yearly and may include: methods of music analysis, analysis of selected works, styles and structures of common practice or post common practice period, music, modal, tonal, or post-tonal counterpoint, history of music theory.
name: MUSI 3700
prereq_text: MUSI 2700 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Seminar in Theory and Analysis

desc: Techniques of arranging and composition for small and large ensembles will be studied through the examination of selected works drawn from the jazz repertoire. Works will be selected for stylistic and theoretical analysis, for exercises in aural recognition, and for arranging purposes.
name: MUSI 3701
prereq_text: MUSI 2701 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Jazz Styles and Structures

desc: Basic topics in physics and psychoacoustics, with an emphasis on those concepts that are most useful for music performance, analysis, composition, and musicology.
name: MUSI 3702
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Introduction to Physics and Psychoacoustics of Music

desc: Selected forms of improvisation from diverse musical and cultural traditions. In addition to weekly seminar meetings, the class will engage in experiential forms of learning by actively improvising in a weekly performance-oriented seminar.
name: MUSI 3703
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Improvisation in Theory and Practice

desc: A continuation of MUSI 2901.
name: MUSI 3900
prereq_text: third-year standing in B. Mus. and MUSI 2901 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance V

desc: A continuation of MUSI 3900.
name: MUSI 3901
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI 3900 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance VI

desc: A continuation of MUSI 2913. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 3912
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble V

desc: A continuation of MUSI 3912. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 3913
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble VI

desc: A continuation of MUSI 2915. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 3914
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble V

desc: A continuation of MUSI 3914. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 3915
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble VI

desc: This is an optional performance course for B.Mus. students with high academic standing.
name: MUSI 4000
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI 3901, A- or higher average in second- and third-year MUSI performance courses, and permission of the Music performance supervisor.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance VII

desc: This is an optional performance course for B.Mus. students with high academic standing.
name: MUSI 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Mus. standing, MUSI 4000 with A- or higher, and permission of the Music performance supervisor.
subject: MUSI
title: Performance VIII

desc: A graduation recording of substantial duration arranged in consultation with the discipline. A proposal must be submitted one week before the last day for course changes. All recording costs must be borne by the student.
name: MUSI 4002
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI 4000 with a grade of A- or higher, and permission of both the relevant associate music instructor and the music performance supervisor.
subject: MUSI
title: Graduating Demo Recording

desc: Public recital arranged in consultation with the Supervisor of Performance and Practical Studies. An outline of the program must be submitted one week before the last day for course changes.
name: MUSI 4003
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI 4000 with A- or higher, and permission of both the relevant associate music instructor and the Music performance supervisor.
subject: MUSI
title: Graduating Recital

desc: An examination of key issues in the study of jazz including history/historiography, gender, genre, race, politics, identity and performance.
name: MUSI 4005
prereq_text: MUSI 2005 and third-year standing.
subject: MUSI
title: Issues in Jazz Studies

desc: An introduction to current issues in the study of popular music. The course will be organized around a series of case studies.
name: MUSI 4006
prereq_text: third-year standing, MUSI 1002, and at least one of MUSI 2005, 2006, or 2007.
subject: MUSI
title: Issues in the Study of Popular Music

desc: Examination of the life and music of a selected composer, and the historical, social, cultural, and political factors that shaped the context within which they worked. Focus on history, biography, musical style and analysis.
name: MUSI 4007
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: The Composer in Context

desc: Selected readings and discussion of major works in ethnomusicology, focusing on schools of thought and contemporary issues. Introduction to a variety of methods and strategies for ethnomusicological research, including field work, musical transcription and data analysis.
name: MUSI 4102
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theory and Methods in Ethnomusicology

desc: Issues of anthropological, sociological, and analytical significance are examined in the context of selected developments in folklore and ethnomusicological research on Canadian traditions.
name: MUSI 4103
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Ethnomusicology of Canadian Traditions

desc: The context and significance of musical expressions of selected Canadian Indigenous groups and the contributions of individuals in the creation of music and meaning in First Peoples' communities.
name: MUSI 4104
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: First Peoples Music in Canada

desc: Surveying five different geographic regions of Africa, traditional and modern musical styles will be studied through the lens of the global, local and social issues surrounding them.
name: MUSI 4105
prereq_text: third year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Issues and Processes in African Music

desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of either musicology, theory or composition. The course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 4200
prereq_text: permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Special Topics

desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of either musicology, theory or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 4201
prereq_text: permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Special Topics

desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through courses in theory, musicology, or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 4205
prereq_text: permission of the department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.
subject: MUSI
title: Specialized Studies

desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through performance. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 4206
prereq_text: permission of the department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.
subject: MUSI
title: Specialized Studies in Performance

desc: A course designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through courses in theory, musicology or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: MUSI 4209
prereq_text: permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Specialized Studies

desc: The relationship between the social and formal organization of music and the social and formal organization of sexual difference. The role of music in the social construction of gender; the role of gender in the determination of musical style and taste.
name: MUSI 4303
prereq_text: MUSI 3302 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music and Gender II

desc: Examining music’s role in the multifaceted and complex processes of globalization. Drawing on case studies of “world musics”, this course explores how sound and music negotiate histories of post/colonialism, cultural and economic imperialism, and constructions of sameness and difference in “world music” contexts.
name: MUSI 4304
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music and Globalization

desc: An examination of the ways in which music contributes to mental, social and physical wellbeing throughout the world, drawing from the fields of neuroscience, medical ethnomusicology, community music and cross-cultural studies.
name: MUSI 4306
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music and Wellbeing in a Global Context

desc: The music of the “dark ages” is illuminated in the context of politics, spectacle, devotion, celebration, compositional process, manuscript culture, dissemination, musical notation, plague, and courtly love. “Medievalism” is examined as an aesthetic of the era (ca. 400-1400) and as reinterpreted in our modern world.
name: MUSI 4307
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Power, Plague, and Courtly Love

desc: This course brings to life the Renaissance (1400-1600), when music played a vital role in lavish courts, grand cathedrals, and vibrant cities. Madrigals, masses, and motets are examined in the context of politics, religion, gender, manuscript and print culture, rhetoric, art, and architecture.
name: MUSI 4308
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Music in an Age of Devotion, Seduction, and Rebirth

desc: A continuation of MUSI 3602, focusing on the development of creative individual approaches to music composition.
name: MUSI 4602
prereq_text: MUSI 3602, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Composition III

desc: A study of a selected topic in music theory. Topics will change yearly and may include: methods of music analysis; analysis of selected works; styles and structures of common practice or post common practice period music; modal, tonal, or post-tonal counterpoint; history of music theory.
name: MUSI 4700
prereq_text: MUSI 2700 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Theoretical Studies: Advanced Seminar in Theory and Analysis

desc: The art of arranging for small and large jazz ensembles is introduced through analysis of recordings by artists such as Duke Ellington, Fletcher Henderson, Count Basie, Rob McConnell, and Maria Schneider. Topics may include 2-, 3-, and 4-voice writing in a jazz idiom.
name: MUSI 4701
prereq_text: MUSI 3701 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Introduction to Jazz Arranging

desc: Selected advanced topics in the perception and cognition of music. Where appropriate, emphasis will be placed upon areas of overlap between psychological research and issues in aesthetics and cultural theory.
name: MUSI 4702
prereq_text: third-year standing and MUSI 3702, or permission of the department.
subject: MUSI
title: Topics in Music Perception and Cognition

desc: This course deals with the development of writing skills and knowledge of counterpoint as manifest in the Baroque era. Topics may include invention, canon, fugue, dance forms, the compositional language of J. S. Bach, and contrapuntal techniques in the late 18th century and beyond.
name: MUSI 4704
prereq_text: MUSI 2700, or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Tonal Counterpoint

desc: Fundamentals of post-tonal music theory and analysis. Neo-tonal, atonal, twelve-tone and third-stream jazz. Students will develop the critical skills to understand these theoretical tools and be conversant with some of the aesthetic precepts associated with them.
name: MUSI 4705
prereq_text: MUSI 2700 or permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Post-Tonal Theory and Analysis

desc: Practical experience in music-specific projects such as recording studios, librarianship, research, multimedia, etc. at local institutions. A maximum of one credit of practicum may be offered in fulfilment of Music requirements.
name: MUSI 4800
prereq_text: Honours Music registration with third- or fourth-year standing and a B+ or better average in Music courses; and permission of the Practica Supervisor.
subject: MUSI
title: Practicum in Music

desc: Practical experience in music-specific projects such as recording studios, librarianship, research, multimedia, etc. at local institutions. A maximum of one credit of practicum may be offered in fulfilment of Music requirements.
name: MUSI 4801
prereq_text: Honours Music registration with third- or fourth-year standing and a B + or better average in Music courses; and permission of the Practica Supervisor.
subject: MUSI
title: Practicum in Music

desc: The course requires the composition of an original work of substantial proportions, with an accompanying analytical paper. Application to the Discipline for permission to register must be received by September 1.
name: MUSI 4906
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, MUSI 3600 and permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Honours Portfolio in Composition

desc: An Honours research essay of approximately 50 pages. A written outline of the project must be submitted to the Honours committee changes by the first day of classes.
name: MUSI 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, A- or higher average, and permission of the Discipline.
subject: MUSI
title: Honours Essay in Musicology

desc: The course requires the creation of an original work (or works) of substantial proportions using applications in the electronic studios. A high level of independence and originality will be required. Requests to the Discipline for permission to register must be received by September 1.
name: MUSI 4909
prereq_text: permission of the instructor.
subject: MUSI
title: Portfolio in New Media

desc: A continuation of MUSI 3913. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 4912
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble VII

desc: A continuation of MUSI 4912. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B. Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 4913
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Choral Ensemble VIII

desc: A continuation of MUSI 3915. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 4914
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble VII

desc: A continuation of MUSI 4914. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: MUSI 4915
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
subject: MUSI
title: Instrumental Ensemble VIII

desc: Cross-disciplinary survey of current issues in science, providing new science students with an orientation to the study of science at the university level. Structured around seminars, oral and written presentations.
name: NSCI 1000
prereq_text: Restricted to students in the first year of B.Sc. programs or B.A. Biology programs.
subject: NSCI
title: Seminar in Science

desc: Students will work with a health or life science research group and deliver an in-depth narrative on the relevant scientific research, lab dynamics and results.
name: NSCI 4901
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Journalism and at least 3.5 credits completed in the concentration in Health Science, or permission of the School of Journalism and Communication.
subject: NSCI
title: Science Journalism Independent Project

desc: Clinical symptoms of psychiatric disease, including biological, developmental, experiential and environmental factors that contribute to disease. Topics may include depressive disorders, schizophrenia, autism, ADHD, anorexia, narcolepsy, substance abuse, and personality disorders.
name: NEUR 1202
prereq_text: None
subject: NEUR
title: Neuroscience of Mental Health and Psychiatric Disease

desc: Clinical symptoms of neurological disease, including biological, developmental, experiential and environmental factors that contribute to disease. Topics may include stroke, multiple sclerosis, migraine, seizure disorder, Parkinson’s disease, ALS, chronic pain, Alzheimer’s disease and concussion.
name: NEUR 1203
prereq_text: None
subject: NEUR
title: Neuroscience of Mental Health and Neurological Disease

desc: A general introduction to research process within neuroscience. Topics covered include research strategies, methods, and techniques; basic descriptive statistics; research communication; and responsible scientific conduct.
name: NEUR 2001
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: NEUR
title: Introduction to Research Methods in Neuroscience

desc: A general introduction to statistical techniques employed within contemporary neuroscience. Topics covered include basic data analysis using descriptive and inferential statistics (t-tests, ANOVA, correlation, chi-square).
name: NEUR 2002
prereq_text: PSYC 2001 or NEUR 2001.
subject: NEUR
title: Introduction to Statistics in Neuroscience

desc: Introduction to common techniques used in neuroscience research. Brain imaging, animal behaviour, electrophysiology, immunohistochemistry and microscopy, genomics, transgenics, cell culture, and DSM-IV-based clinical assessment.
name: NEUR 2003
prereq_text: one of PSYC 1001, NEUR 1201, NEUR 1202 or NEUR 1203.
subject: NEUR
title: Introduction to Techniques in Neuroscience

desc: Introduction to various forms of scientific writing appropriate to neuroscience, with a focus in fundamental skills in scientific writing.
name: NEUR 2004
prereq_text: second-year standing in a Neuroscience program and one of NEUR 1201, NEUR 1202 or NEUR 1203.
subject: NEUR
title: Fundamentals of Scientific Writing in Neuroscience

desc: Core principles in cellular and molecular neuroscience, including signal transmission along and between neurons, ion channels and transporters, intracellular signaling pathways, and regulation of gene expression.
name: NEUR 2201
prereq_text: Either NEUR 1201 and NEUR 1203, or NEUR 1202 and NEUR 1203, or both BIOL 1103 and BIOL 1104.
subject: NEUR
title: Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience

desc: Core principles in nervous system development from embryogenesis to plasticity in the adult brain. Topics include neural induction, neurogenesis, apoptosis, neuronal migration and axon growth, synaptogenesis and synaptic pruning both under normal conditions and in psychopathology.
name: NEUR 2202
prereq_text: NEUR2201.
subject: NEUR
title: Neurodevelopment and Plasticity

desc: Abnormal brain function associated with mental illness or substance abuse has been commonly depicted in or been the inspiration for important cultural works including movies, music, paintings and literature. The neurobiological basis of creativity in individuals with and without mental illness.
name: NEUR 2801
prereq_text: one of PSYC 1001, NEUR 1201, NEUR 1202 or NEUR 1203.
subject: NEUR
title: Neuroscience and Creativity

desc: Introducing various software for analyzing neuroscience data. Dealing with real data, drawing graphs, application of descriptive and inferential statistics through the general linear model, assumptions of parametric tests, robust statistics, confidence intervals, correlations, use of appropriate statistical methods and interpretation of results.
name: NEUR 3001
prereq_text: PSYC 2001 and PSYC 2002, or NEUR 2001 and NEUR 2002.
subject: NEUR
title: Data Analysis in Neuroscience I

desc: Use of software for analyzing neuroscience data. Statistical techniques typically include nonparametric tests, t tests, and various forms of both ANOVA and regression including robust statistical tests, with a focus on the practical application of appropriate statistical methods and interpretation of results.
name: NEUR 3002
prereq_text: NEUR 3001.
subject: NEUR
title: Data Analysis in Neuroscience II

desc: Offered in the Department of Biology as BIOL 3605. Only those modules dealing with animal behaviour topics may be offered for Neuroscience credit.
name: NEUR 3203
prereq_text: permission of the department.
subject: NEUR
title: Field Course in Animal Behaviour

desc: Overview of chemical neurotransmission and key neurotransmitter systems. A description of licit and illicit drugs covering topics that range from historical perspectives to pharmacology to mechanisms of action in the brain. Discussion of neurochemical basis of psychiatric diseases including anxiety, depression and schizophrenia.
name: NEUR 3204
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or NEUR 2201.
subject: NEUR
title: Neuropharmacology

desc: Exploration of major topics in sensory processing and motor control, with a focus on underlying mechanisms and neurobiological principles. Topics include all sensory systems (such as vision, somatosensation and audition) plus motor system components including lower and upper motor neurons, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.
name: NEUR 3206
prereq_text: NEUR 1201 or both NEUR 1202 and NEUR 1203, and either NEUR 2200 or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Sensory and Motor Neuroscience

desc: Neural systems underlying complex behaviours including emotion, motivation, and sleep, and the role of association cortices in brain function.
name: NEUR 3207
prereq_text: NEUR 3206.
subject: NEUR
title: Systems Neuroscience

desc: Most common mental health diseases have a genetic component. By focusing on specific diseases, this course will discuss how disease susceptibility genes are identified, and describe the genetic, genomic and epigenetic mechanisms through which DNA alterations can predispose to disease.
name: NEUR 3301
prereq_text: BIOL 2104 or BIOL 2107, and NEUR 2200 or NEUR 2201.
subject: NEUR
title: Genetics of Mental Health

desc: Consciousness remains one of the least understood aspects of the nervous system. This course explores neural mechanisms underlying consciousness, changes in consciousness associated with sleep, coma, vegetative states, drugs, and other stimuli, and considers the evolutionary basis of consciousness, and its relationship with awareness.
name: NEUR 3303
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: The Neuroscience of Consciousness

desc: The effects of hormones throughout life at all levels of the nervous system. The role of hormones in mediating behaviours that are both basic (feeding, reproduction and social interactions) and complex (motivation, emotion, learning and memory).
name: NEUR 3304
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Hormones and Behaviour

desc: Exposure to environmental toxins from the air, water or food can interfere with neuronal function, alter neurodevelopment, and damage the brain. This course will explore associations between toxins and diseases such as Parkinson’s disease, multiple sclerosis and depression, focusing on mechanisms underlying development of pathology.
name: NEUR 3401
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Environmental Toxins and Mental Health

desc: Healthy lifestyle choices and positive social interactions can reduce the incidence of pathological conditions such as depression, obesity, cardiovascular disease and impaired immunity. This course focuses on psychosocial and neurobiological mechanisms that underlie the relationship between lifestyle, social interactions and health.
name: NEUR 3402
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Impact of Lifestyle and Social Interactions on Mental Health

desc: Stressful events can have profound repercussions on physical and psychological well-being. This course examines the psychosocial and biological processes by which stressors predispose to both physical (immune-related disorders, diabetes, heart disease) and psychological (acute stress disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety) pathologies.
name: NEUR 3403
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Stress and Mental Health

desc: Perspectives on aging and neurodegeneration from psychosocial and neuroscience points of view. How factors including TBI, stroke and alcohol make the brain vulnerable and contribute to neurodegeneration. Clinical overview of Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, Huntington’s and ALS and the underlying pathology that differentiates these diseases.
name: NEUR 3501
prereq_text: NEUR 2200 or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Neurodegeneration and Aging

desc: Development of the human brain, the generation and differentiation of the various cell types, and the formation of the vast network of neural connections. How neurodevelopmental dysregulation can result in pathologies including dyslexia, ADHD, schizophrenia and autism.
name: NEUR 3502
prereq_text: NEUR 2200, or both NEUR 2201 and NEUR 2202.
subject: NEUR
title: Neurodevelopmental Determinants of Mental Health

name: NEUR 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: NEUR
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Each section of NEUR 4001 deals with a different topic. Topics change yearly. Students may register in more than one section of NEUR 4001 but can register in each section only once.
name: NEUR 4001
prereq_text: NEUR 3200, or NEUR 3204 and NEUR 3206 and NEUR 3207, or permission of the Department.
subject: NEUR
title: Special Topics in Neuroscience

desc: Introduction to the methods used in conducting systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Topics include: conducting literature searches, extracting relevant literature, assessing quality of studies, synthesizing findings across studies, and the statistical methods used to carry out a meta-analysis.
name: NEUR 4002
prereq_text: NEUR 3002 or HLTH 3201 or BIOL 3604 or permission of instructor.
subject: NEUR
title: Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses

desc: Headline research in neuroscience. Topics may include technical and conceptual advances, ethical issues, medical improvement, and social impacts of neuroscience research.
name: NEUR 4200
prereq_text: fourth year standing and one of NEUR 3200, NEUR 3206 or NEUR 3207.
subject: NEUR
title: Seminar on Current Advances in Neuroscience

desc: Recent research in clinical neuroscience including biological, developmental, experiential and environmental factors that contribute to disease. Topics may include depressive disorders, schizophrenia, autism, ADHD, anorexia, narcolepsy, substance abuse, and personality disorders.
name: NEUR 4202
prereq_text: fourth year standing and one of NEUR 3200, NEUR 3206 or NEUR 3207.
subject: NEUR
title: Seminar on Current Research in Neuroscience and Psychiatric Disease

desc: Recent research in neurological disease, including biological, developmental, experiential and environmental factors that contribute to disease. Topics may include stroke, multiple sclerosis, migraine, seizure disorder, Parkinson’s disease, ALS, chronic pain, Alzheimer’s disease and concussion.
name: NEUR 4203
prereq_text: fourth year standing and one of NEUR 3200, NEUR 3206 or NEUR 3207.
subject: NEUR
title: Seminar on Current Research in Neuroscience and Clinical Neurology

desc: Focus on neuroanatomical and molecular mechanisms underlying how mammals adapt to changes and challenges in the environment. Topics include regulation of feeding, energy expenditure, water balance, and temperature regulation.
name: NEUR 4301
prereq_text: NEUR 3304.
subject: NEUR
title: Neurobiology of Energy Homeostasis

desc: Neurobiological processes behind reproductive behaviours in various animal species including humans. Evaluation of data concerning neurobiological differences between sexes, biological determinants of sexual orientation, and relating to neurobiology of sex disorders.
name: NEUR 4302
prereq_text: NEUR 3304.
subject: NEUR
title: Sex and the Brain

desc: The physical and mental health issues of Indigenous people in the context of the cultural, environmental, developmental and biological factors that contribute to comorbid conditions and greater risk and resilience.
name: NEUR 4303
prereq_text: 3rd year standing or above.
subject: NEUR
title: Indigenous Health & Mental Health

desc: Communication between the brain and the immune system; messengers mediating the interaction. How disturbances of immune-brain signaling can lead to disease (multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s) and to changes in mood and cognition.
name: NEUR 4305
prereq_text: NEUR 3200 or NEUR 3207.
subject: NEUR
title: Immune-Brain Interactions

desc: How substance and behavioural addictions impact neural function to ultimately lead to the neuropathology of addiction in vulnerable populations. Contemporary neurobiological theories of addiction will also be addressed.
name: NEUR 4306
prereq_text: NEUR 3204.
subject: NEUR
title: The Neural Basis of Addiction

desc: Advanced experiential learning in neuroanatomy, histology and microscopy.
name: NEUR 4600
prereq_text: NEUR 3200 or both NEUR 3206 and NEUR 3207, fourth-year standing in a Neuroscience program, a minimum Major CGPA of 9.0 and permission of the Department.
subject: NEUR
title: Advanced Lab in Neuroanatomy

desc: Ethical issues of key importance to current neurobiological research. Topics may include the use of animals in research, stem cell research, genetic diagnosis and gene therapy, neuroimaging, and the effect on identity and autonomy of manipulations such as psychopharmaceuticals and psychosurgery.
name: NEUR 4801
prereq_text: NEUR 3200 or both NEUR 3206 and NEUR 3207.
subject: NEUR
title: Neuroethics

desc: A reading or research course for selected students who wish to investigate a particular topic of interest. Normally students may not offer more than one credit of independent study in their total program.
name: NEUR 4900
prereq_text: third- or fourth- year standing and permission of the Department.
subject: NEUR
title: Independent Study

desc: The course will focus on active learning in areas that include written and oral communication, evaluation and interpretation of results, statistics and data management, emphasizing transferable skills that will be most appropriate for non-research career paths.
name: NEUR 4905
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours Neuroscience program and permission of the Department.
subject: NEUR
title: Honours Workshop

desc: This course involves co-developing an Indigenous community-led process or product that addresses a current and specific mental health issue. Involves working in interdisciplinary groups with a community partner.
name: NEUR 4906
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing with a minimum CGPA of 9.0 and a grade of A- or higher in one of NEUR 3401, NEUR 3402 or NEUR 3403 and permission of instructor.
subject: NEUR
title: Translational Approach to Indigenous Community Wellness

desc: An independent essay based critical review and research proposal on a topic in neuroscience, using library resources, under the direct supervision of a Faculty advisor. Evaluation is based on a written report.
name: NEUR 4907
prereq_text: NEUR 3200, or both NEUR 3206 and NEUR 3207, and fourth-year standing in an Honours Neuroscience program, a minimum Major CGPA of 9.0 and permission of the Department.
subject: NEUR
title: Honours Essay and Research Proposal

desc: An independent research project undertaken under the direct supervision of a faculty advisor typically from the Department of Neuroscience. Evaluation is based on a written report and poster.
name: NEUR 4908
prereq_text: NEUR 3200, or both NEUR 3206 and NEUR 3207, and fourth-year standing in an Honours Neuroscience program, a minimum CGPA of 9.0 and permission of the Department.
subject: NEUR
title: Honours Research Thesis

desc: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of Performance Studies. History and theory of public performance. Contemporary public performance in the Canadian context.
name: PIPS 2000
prereq_text: Second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PIPS
title: Theories of Performance in the Public Sphere

desc: The course explores selected modes of performance drawn from a variety of historical periods and traditions. Students learn through seminars and experiential forms of learning in weekly, practice-based discussions and exercises.
name: PIPS 2001
prereq_text: Second-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PIPS
title: Workshop in Contemporary and Historical Modes of Performance

desc: This course gives students an opportunity to research, design, curate, and produce a site-specific performance in the national capital region as part of an interdisciplinary collaborative team.
name: PIPS 3000
prereq_text: Third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PIPS
title: Site-Specific Performance

desc: Innovative uses of analogue and digital technologies in performance contexts. Issues in the design of lighting, audio, screen and interactive technologies related to public spaces, movement and performance.
name: PIPS 3001
prereq_text: Third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PIPS
title: Experimental Uses of Technology in Performance

desc: Course focuses on one selected aspect of performance in the public sphere. Course offerings change from year to year.
name: PIPS 4200
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PIPS
title: Special Topics in Performance and the Public Sphere

desc: The undergraduate practicum provides students an experiential-learning opportunity to apply their knowledge in Carleton Dominion-Chalmers Centre and other organizations and venues in the national capital region.
name: PIPS 4800
prereq_text: Fourth-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PIPS
title: Practicum in Performance Studies

desc: What is metaphysics? Who was Socrates? What is Freedom? This introduction sketches many branches of philosophy and the important problems associated with each. It introduces great philosophers, present and past, and traces enduring philosophical themes.
name: PHIL 1000
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Introductory Philosophy: Fields, Figures and Problems

desc: Introduction to philosophy: the nature of logical thinking; the existence of God; the objectivity of values; the meaning of life; free will, determinism and responsibility; the relation between mind and body; immortality; the possibility of knowledge. This course is not intended for Majors.
name: PHIL 1100
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Looking at Philosophy

desc: An introduction to concerns expressed by the perennial philosophical question, "What is the meaning of life?"
