Students will be familiarized with the major philosophical approaches to life's meaning through a consideration of various contemporary and late modern works in the philosophy of life.
name: PHIL 1200
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: The Meaning of Life

desc: Introduction to a variety of philosophical works, including contemporary, on such topics as: the nature of being, the mental, the external, consciousness, perception, experience, meaning, truth, the nature of knowledge, scientific understanding, and how language and thought represent the world.
name: PHIL 1301
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Mind, World, and Knowledge

desc: Moral theories, atheism or theism, feminism, and free will. Moral arguments concerning abortion, affirmative action, racism, human rights, children's rights, world hunger, capital punishment, euthanasia, censorship, pornography, legal paternalism, animal rights and environmental protection.
name: PHIL 1500
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Contemporary Moral, Social and Religious Issues

desc: An introduction to understanding, assessing, and formulating ethical arguments concerning controversial issues. Particular issues studied may include, world hunger, capital punishment, terrorism, euthanasia, abortion, pornography and hate speech, animal rights, the environment, and topics in theories of race, gender and disability.
name: PHIL 1550
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Ethics and Social Issues

desc: Major figures and developments in philosophy from the early Greeks to the year 1400. Descriptive and comparative approach, providing an understanding of the place of philosophers in the history of thought. Appreciation of critical reasoning is included for comprehending philosophical developments.
name: PHIL 1610
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Great Philosophical Ideas, Part 1

desc: Major figures and developments in philosophy after the year 1400. Descriptive and comparative approach, providing an understanding of the place of philosophers in the history of thought. Appreciation of critical reasoning is included for comprehending philosophical developments.
name: PHIL 1620
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Great Philosophical Ideas, Part 2

desc: A survey of philosophical classics, on themes of romantic love, self-love, altruistic love, sexuality, eroticism and the passion/reason dichotomy, from Plato's Symposium to Foucault's History of Sexuality; and an examination of related contemporary issues in light of these perspectives.
name: PHIL 1700
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Love and Sex

desc: An introduction to the techniques and philosophical implications of formal logic with emphasis on translation of expressions into symbolic form, testing for logical correctness, the formulation and application of rules of inference, and the relation between logic and language. Open to first-year students.
name: PHIL 2001
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Logic

desc: Assessment of reasoning and the development of cogent patterns of thinking. Reference to formal logic is minimal. Practice in criticizing examples of reasoning and in formulating one's own reasons correctly and clearly. Open to first-year students.
name: PHIL 2003
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Critical Thinking

desc: An exploration of ancient philosophy as a search for wisdom and happiness from its Presocratic beginnings in Greece to its development in the Hellenistic world and Imperial Rome. Emphasis on philosophy as a contemplative activity and as a way of life.
name: PHIL 2005
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in PHIL, or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Ancient Philosophy: The Search for Wisdom

desc: Issues drawn from epistemology, metaphysics, philosophy of mind, philosophy of language, and related fields will be examined through careful study of significant philosophical texts after 1900, along with some ensuing debates.
name: PHIL 2010
prereq_text: enrolment in Honours or Combined Honours Philosophy programs, or in philosophy, Ethics, and Public Affairs, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Issues in Theoretical Philosophy

desc: Issues drawn from ethics, social and political philosophy, and related fields will be examined through careful study of significant philosophical texts , along with some ensuing debates.
name: PHIL 2020
prereq_text: enrolment in Honours or Combined Honours Philosophy programs, or in philosophy, Ethics, and Public Affairs, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Issues in Practical Philosophy

desc: An introduction to ethical theories through a study of some of the major figures in moral philosophy, such as Aristotle, Hume, Kant and Mill.
name: PHIL 2101
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: History of Ethics

desc: Philosophical introduction to human rights sources, concepts, justifications, consequences, and challenges to them. Evolution of selected human rights as a) demands made in political struggles; b) declarations supported by moral or political principles and arguments; c) codes ratified and implemented by governments and international organizations.
name: PHIL 2103
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Human Rights

desc: An exploration of ethical issues that arise in the Age of Information. Topics to be discussed may include technology, surveillance and privacy, social media and privacy, social media and cognitive bias, bias in algorithms, AI ethics, intellectual property, and freedom of expression and assembly.
name: PHIL 2106
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Information Ethics

desc: Philosophical investigations of the nature of technology and the influence it has on our relationships with others, the natural world, and ourselves. Key themes may include the relation between technology and science and the role of technology in personal identity, social justice, and well-being.
name: PHIL 2120
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Technology

desc: The evolution of Marx's social and political views in the setting of 18 th - and 19 th - century anarchism, liberalism and conservatism. Themes of humanism, freedom, rights, the state, democracy, alienation, and inequality, primarily as they develop into the theory of historical materialism.
name: PHIL 2201
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Marxist Philosophy

desc: The dialectical materialism of Marx, Engels, and Lenin is compared with traditional materialist, idealist, and mechanist philosophy. Marxist views on issues such as equality, ethical objectivity, human well-being, matter and mind, the existence of God, knowledge versus skepticism, freedom of the will, and justice.
name: PHIL 2202
prereq_text: PHIL 2201 or 0.5 credit in the history of philosophy at the 2000-level or above.
subject: PHIL
title: Topics in Marxist Philosophy

desc: Philosophical issues arising out of the attempt to understand the world scientifically. Topics may include: scientific methodology, revolution, observation, explanation, causation, induction, reduction, the difference between natural and social scientific understanding, realism, instrumentalism, constructivism.
name: PHIL 2301
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science

desc: A study of philosophical issues arising from feminism. The course includes discussions of the historical roots of feminism, the role of reason and emotion, key concepts such as oppression, sexism, equality and difference, feminism and philosophies of race and of disability, and selected moral/political issues.
name: PHIL 2306
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy and Feminism

desc: Topics may include gender and sex in the history of philosophy, intersections between the politics and theories of gender, sexuality, and race, the place of the body in philosophical theory, the influence of gender and sex on science/social science, and queer/trans issues and politics.
name: PHIL 2307
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Gender and Philosophy

desc: An exploration of issues at the nexus of philosophy, children’s literature, and childhood studies. Topics may include an examination of children’s books and young adult literature through a philosophical lens, as well as a critical examination of the “philosophy with children” movement.
name: PHIL 2320
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or second-year standing in a philosophy program, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Children, Literature, and Philosophy

desc: A philosophical exploration of what makes a good human life. Topics may include the role of happiness, well-being, and flourishing in a good life, the relations between these aspects, and the extent to which they depend on luck and social considerations.
name: PHIL 2330
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Happiness, Well-being, and the Good Life

desc: Philosophy is all around us, it permeates culture. This course explores philosophical questions through the lens of popular culture. The material used may include films, shows, music, novels, video games, advertising, comic books, and so on.
name: PHIL 2340
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy and Popular Culture

desc: Major questions in environmental ethics: How should human beings view their relationship to the rest of nature? Is responsible stewardship of the environment compatible with current technology? Must future generations be protected? Do animals, other life forms, endangered species, ecosystems and/or the biosphere have value/rights?.
name: PHIL 2380
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Environmental Ethics

desc: Examination of claims, concepts, theories and methods in parapsychology. Their scientific character and the relation of paranormal phenomena to philosophical issues such as survival of death, human nature, time, space, causality and perception.
name: PHIL 2405
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of the Paranormal

desc: Ethical and political issues in medicine, public health, biotechnology, and the life sciences. Topics may include reproductive ethics, research on human subjects, animal research and treatment, justice and health care, physician-patient relationships, death and the end of life, and genetic engineering.
name: PHIL 2408
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Bioethics

desc: An introduction to major philosophical issues concerning human cognition. Topics may include: the relation of mind to body, knowledge of other minds, the relation of mental states to personhood and personal identity, mental illness, consciousness, intentionality, action, mental realism.
name: PHIL 2501
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy of Mind

desc: Some of the central topics in the study of language and communication as pursued by linguists and philosophers. The nature of meaning; the connections between language, communication and cognition; language as a social activity.
name: PHIL 2504
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Language and Communication

desc: An introduction to features of rational thinking activity, its expression, and its relation to the world, focusing on such topics as predication, truth, negation, necessity, entailment, logical form, or quantification.
name: PHIL 2520
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophical Logic

desc: Philosophical perspectives on personal identity, the self, and the underlying issue of the relationship of the mind to the body. Both philosophical and psychological concepts of identity are discussed, as are related issues such as memory, introspection, and self-knowledge.
name: PHIL 2540
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Personal Identity and the Self

desc: An examination of psychological underpinnings of morality, focusing on studies at the intersection of philosophy, psychiatry, and psychology.
name: PHIL 2550
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Moral Psychology

desc: A study of philosophical issues arising from religion. Topics may include: arguments for and against the existence of God, religious experience, death and the afterlife, miracles, God and evil, the relationship between religion and science, and the relationship between religion and ethics.
name: PHIL 2601
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Religion

desc: An examination of South Asian and East Asian philosophical texts, from the period of the Upanishads and early Buddhism in India to modern philosophical movements. Historical sources may include Hindu, Buddhist, Jain, Confucian or Taoist texts, with a focus on metaphysical, epistemological or ethical themes.
name: PHIL 2700
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Asian Philosophy

desc: Philosophical approaches to the study of art. Topics such as: the nature of art and artistic value; representation and symbolism in art; art and artifice; art and the emotions; art, culture and ideology; post-structuralism and art; theories of creativity; relationship between artworks and audiences.
name: PHIL 2807
prereq_text: None
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Art

desc: Ancient and modern techniques of persuasion from analytical, ethical and jurisprudential perspectives. Objectivity and bias, advertising and public relations ethics, the viability of democracy in the light of pressures on and within the modern mass media.
name: PHIL 2901
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in PHIL or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Truth and Propaganda

desc: A study of philosophers, texts, problems and issues in ancient philosophy, generally with a focus on Plato and Aristotle.
name: PHIL 3000
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and second-year standing, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy

desc: A study of the pre-Socratic Greek philosophers and of the Sophists and Socrates.
name: PHIL 3001
prereq_text: CLCV 2105 or PHIL 2005 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Early Greek Philosophy

desc: European philosophy of the 17 th century. Representative works of writers such as Francis Bacon, Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, and Locke.
name: PHIL 3002
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and second-year standing in a philosophy program, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: 17th Century Philosophy

desc: European philosophy of the 18 th century. Representative works of writers such as Berkeley, Hume, and Kant.
name: PHIL 3003
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and second-year standing in a philosophy program, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: 18th Century Philosophy

desc: European philosophy in the 19 th century. May include Hegel, Marx, Schopenhauer, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Mill.
name: PHIL 3005
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and second-year standing in a philosophy program, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: 19th Century Philosophy

desc: A study of philosophers, texts, problems and issues in any period of European philosophy.
name: PHIL 3009
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Topics in European Philosophy

desc: A study of philosophers, texts, and doctrines beyond the Western tradition. Traditions covered will vary but may include Asian, African, Muslim or Indigenous philosophy, possibly with critical comparison to Western counterparts.
name: PHIL 3010
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Global Philosophical Traditions

desc: Legal reasoning and analysis of concepts of particular significance to the law, including justice, rights and duties, liability, punishment, ownership and possession.
name: PHIL 3102
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Law: The Logic of Law

desc: In the context of the work of such writers as Frege and Bradley, a discussion of early philosophical works of Russell, Moore and Wittgenstein. In addition some early representatives of positivism and pragmatism may be examined.
name: PHIL 3104
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and second-year standing in a philosophy program, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: The Roots of Analytic Philosophy

desc: Fundamental issues concerning the relation between evidence, rationality, and knowledge. Topics may include: skepticism, the nature of belief, the structure of justification, the relative contributions of reason and sense experience to knowledge, innate knowledge, the problem of induction, and the knowledge of other minds.
name: PHIL 3140
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and third-year standing in a philosophy program or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Epistemology

desc: Philosophical issues concerning the fundamental nature of being. Topics may include: time and temporality, space, substance, universals/particulars, identity, causation, freedom/determinism, the nature of norms.
name: PHIL 3150
prereq_text: 0.5 credit in philosophy and third-year standing in a philosophy program, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Metaphysics

desc: Selected topic(s) in the philosophy of science, such as its relationship to values, or in the philosophy of a particular science (such as philosophy of mathematics, philosophy of physics, philosophy of biology, and philosophy of the social sciences).
name: PHIL 3301
prereq_text: PHIL 2301 or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Issues in the Philosophy of Science

desc: A review of the basic techniques of propositional and predicate logic. Natural deduction and consistency trees. Soundness and completeness. Alternative semantics. Extensions to basic logic: identity, modal logic with possible world semantics, three valued systems, deontic logic.
name: PHIL 3306
prereq_text: PHIL 2001 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Symbolic Logic

desc: Critical study of modern ethical theories, their views on the nature of morality and the justification of moral claims. Topics may include utilitarianism, libertarianism, communitarianism, egoism, neo-Kantianism, virtue ethics, social contract ethics, feminist ethics, and moral rights.
name: PHIL 3320
prereq_text: PHIL 2020 or PHIL 2101 or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Contemporary Ethical Theory

desc: A critical examination of selected topics and perspectives in the history of social and political philosophy.
name: PHIL 3330
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Topics in History of Social and Political Philosophy

desc: A critical examination of some contemporary approaches to topics in social and political philosophy, such as liberalism, feminism, contractarianism, Marxism, libertarianism, and communitarianism.
name: PHIL 3340
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: PHIL
title: Topics in Contemporary Social and Political Philosophy

desc: Advanced study of a set of public policy issues, a particular theory or group of theories, or a particular philosopher, concerning philosophical and ethical aspects of public affairs.
name: PHIL 3350
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy, Ethics, and Public Affairs

desc: The course explores issues at the intersection of philosophy and economics, with a special focus on socially and politically relevant issues. Topics may include: efficiency, cooperation, equity and distributive justice, commodification and the moral limits of markets.
name: PHIL 3360
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy, Economics, and Public Policy

desc: Advanced treatment of ethical issues concerning technologies and environments, including: sustainable development, women and the environment, biological diversity, intrinsic or natural value or rights of non-humans, humans' relation to the rest of the natural world, obligations to future generations, liberty versus equality.
name: PHIL 3380
prereq_text: PHIL 1804 or PHIL 2380 and third-year standing, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Environments, Technology and Values

desc: Topics may include theories of aesthetic norms and valuation from ancient Greece onward, or applications of aesthetic theory to various genres of art.
name: PHIL 3450
prereq_text: At least 0.5 credit in philosophy, or HUMS 1000, or ARTH 2807, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Topics in Aesthetics

desc: Philosophical issues arising from cognitive science. Topics may include: the proper methodology for studying the mind, the very possibility of a “science of mind”, the computer model of the mind and reactions to it.
name: PHIL 3501
prereq_text: PHIL 2501 or PHIL 2502 or second-year standing in Cognitive Science, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Cognitive Science

desc: Philosophical thought concerning the relation between mentality and agency. Topics may include: the relation between belief, desire, and behaviour; rationality and normativity; representing and doing; subjectivity and intersubjectivity; physical and psychological laws; mental causation. Authors may include: Wittgenstein, Heidegger, Ryle, Sellars, Anscombe, Davidson, Taylor, McDowell.
name: PHIL 3502
prereq_text: PHIL 2501 or PHIL 2502, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Mind and Action

desc: The study of language use in its conversational and cultural contexts. Topics include: conversational implicature; deixis; the semantics-pragmatics boundary; speaker's reference; speech acts. May include cross-cultural pragmatics.
name: PHIL 3504
prereq_text: third-year standing, and one of FYSM 1206, LALS 1000, LALS 1001, LING 1001, PHIL 2001, PHIL/LALS/LING/COMM/MCOM 2504 or LALS/LING 3505/PHIL 3506; or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Applied Language Studies.
subject: PHIL
title: Pragmatics

desc: Study of language meaning. Lexical meaning and meanings of larger linguistic expressions, including nominal units, verbal units, and sentences. Meaning relationships between utterances. Relationship between linguistic meaning (semantics) and contextual meaning (pragmatics). Basic formal treatments of semantics.
name: PHIL 3506
prereq_text: third-year standing, and one of LALS 1000, LALS 1001, LING 1001, PHIL 2001, PHIL/LALS/LING/COMM/MCOM 2504 or PHIL/LALS/LING 3504; or permission of the Department of Philosophy or School of Linguistics and Applied Language Studies.
subject: PHIL
title: Semantics

desc: An intensive introduction to philosophy of language. Topics may include meaning, reference and truth, speech acts, the nature of concepts, language learning, metaphor, compositionality, context-sensitivity.
name: PHIL 3530
prereq_text: third-year standing, and one of FYSM 1206, LALS 1000, LALS 1001, LING 1001, PHIL 2001, PHIL/LALS/LING/COMM/MCOM 2504 or LALS/LING 3504 or LALS/LING 3505/PHIL 3506; or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Language

desc: Emotions are central to human experience and widely studied in philosophy and science. In order to better understand them and their role in our lives, this course explores philosophical questions about emotions as they arise in philosophy of mind and cognitive science, ethics, and aesthetics.
name: PHIL 3540
prereq_text: PHIL 2501, or permission of the department.
subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Emotions

desc: Essays and/or examinations based on a list of readings provided by the instructor.
name: PHIL 3901
prereq_text: normally restricted to students with at least 3.0 credits in philosophy and with high standing in philosophy courses and permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Independent Study

desc: Essays and/or examinations based on a list of readings provided by the instructor.
name: PHIL 3902
prereq_text: normally restricted to students with at least 3.0 credits in philosophy and with high standing in philosophy courses and permission of the Department.

title: Independent Study

name: PHIL 3903

subject: PHIL
title: Independent Study

name: PHIL 3906
prereq_text: normally restricted to students with at least 3.0 credits in philosophy and with high standing in philosophy courses and permission of the Department.

name: PHIL 3908
prereq_text: normally restricted to students with at least 3.0 credits in philosophy and with high standing in philosophy courses and permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Independent Study

desc: Detailed study of selected philosophers or issues in philosophy before the modern period.
name: PHIL 4003
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in philosophy Before the Modern Period

desc: Detailed study of selected philosophers or issues in philosophy before the modern period.
name: PHIL 4004
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in philosophy Before the Modern Period

desc: Detailed study of selected philosophers or issues in modern philosophy.
name: PHIL 4005
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Modern Philosophy

desc: Detailed study of selected philosophers or issues in modern philosophy.
name: PHIL 4006
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Modern Philosophy

desc: Detailed study of selected philosophers or issues in contemporary philosophy.
name: PHIL 4007
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Contemporary Philosophy

desc: Detailed study of selected philosophers or issues in contemporary philosophy.
name: PHIL 4008
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Contemporary Philosophy

desc: Study of the meaning of words. Topics may include lexical decomposition, meaning variation, lexical relations, and lexical aspect.
name: PHIL 4055
prereq_text: LING 3505 or PHIL 3506.
subject: PHIL
title: Lexical Semantics

desc: Detailed study of a special topic in philosophy.
name: PHIL 4100
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Special Topic

desc: Detailed study of selected issues or the work of selected philosophers in philosophy of language or on philosophical topics in linguistics.
name: PHIL 4210
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth year standing in a Philosophy Honours programme or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Philosophy of Language or Linguistics

desc: Detailed study of selected issues or the work of selected philosophers in philosophy of mind or philosophical aspects of cognition.
name: PHIL 4220
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth year standing in a Philosophy Honours programme or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in philosophy of Mind or Cognition

desc: Detailed study of selected issues or the work of selected philosophers in metaphysics, epistemology, or philosophy of science.
name: PHIL 4230
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth year standing in a Philosophy Honours programme or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Metaphysics, Epistemology, or Philosophy of Science

desc: Detailed study of selected issues pertaining to ethical theory or issues of meta-ethics such as realism, relativism, moral knowledge.
name: PHIL 4300
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Ethical Theory or Meta-Ethics

desc: Detailed study of selected issues in ethics or moral philosophy.
name: PHIL 4320
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Ethics or Moral Philosophy

desc: Detailed study of selected issues in social or political philosophy.
name: PHIL 4330
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL
title: Seminar in Social or Political Philosophy

desc: Detailed study of a special topic in applied ethics.
name: PHIL 4403
prereq_text: eligibility for fourth-year standing in a Philosophy Honours program or permission of the Department.
subject: PHIL

desc: This calculus-based course on classical mechanics covers kinematics, dynamics, gravitation, and oscillatory motion. This is a specialist course for students intending to take further courses in physics.
name: PHYS 1001
prereq_text: Grade 12 Mathematics: Advanced Functions and Grade 12 Mathematics: Calculus and Vectors or equivalent, plus one of MATH 1004 or MATH 1002 or MATH 1052 (the MATH course may be taken concurrently); or permission of the Physics Department. Grade 12 Physics is strongly recommended.
subject: PHYS
title: Foundations of Physics I

desc: An introduction to electricity, magnetism, electromagnetic fields, and wave motion. This is a specialist course for students intending to take further courses in physics.
name: PHYS 1002
prereq_text: PHYS 1001, or PHYS 1003, or PHYS 1007 with a grade of B-; MATH 1004 or MATH 1002 (may be taken concurrently) or MATH 2052 (may be taken concurrently); or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Foundations of Physics II

desc: Mechanics, gravitation, oscillations, and thermodynamics. The application of calculus to solve problems in these areas of physics is introduced. This course is intended for students in the physical sciences and engineering.
name: PHYS 1003
prereq_text: Grade 12 Physics or equivalent, plus Grade 12 Mathematics: Advanced Functions or equivalent, plus one of MATH 1004 or MATH 1002 or MATH 1052 (the MATH course may be taken concurrently). Note that Grade 12 Mathematics: Calculus and Vectors is strongly recommended.
subject: PHYS
title: Introductory Mechanics and Thermodynamics

desc: This calculus-based course introduces potential energy, work, electricity, magnetism, oscillations and waves.
name: PHYS 1004
prereq_text: MATH 1004, ECOR 1101 or ECOR 1053 or (ECOR 1045 and ECOR 1046)(The ECOR courses may be taken concurrently) or PHYS 1001 or PHYS 1003 or PHYS 1007 (a grade of at least B- is required for PHYS 1007), or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Introductory Electromagnetism and Wave Motion

desc: Mechanics, properties of matter, thermodynamics. Applications chosen in part from the life sciences. For students who lack the prerequisites for PHYS 1001 or PHYS 1003, or who do not intend to take upper-year courses in physics.
name: PHYS 1007
prereq_text: (i) Grade 12 Mathematics: Advanced Functions or equivalent, or MATH 0107 (may be taken concurrently); or (ii) Grade 12 Mathematics: Calculus and Vectors or equivalent, or MATH 1007 (may be taken concurrently; or (iii) permission of the Physics Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Elementary University Physics I

desc: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, wave motion and light. Elements of modern physics. Applications chosen in part from the life sciences.
name: PHYS 1008
prereq_text: PHYS 1001 or PHYS 1003 or PHYS 1007.
subject: PHYS
title: Elementary University Physics II

desc: Description of the known stellar, galactic and extra-galactic systems together with the instruments used to study them. Modern ideas concerning the structure, origin and evolution of our own planet. Formation of the Moon - Earth system. Study of the planets in our solar system.
name: PHYS 1901
prereq_text: None
subject: PHYS
title: Planetary Astronomy

desc: Starting with the Sun, the course studies its composition and source of power, then compares our Sun with the other stars in the galaxy and beyond. Modern ideas concerning the structure, origin and evolution of the universe, pulsars and supernovae are examined.
name: PHYS 1902
prereq_text: None
subject: PHYS
title: From our Star to the Cosmos

desc: Examination of the physics behind everyday life. Topics may include transportation, sports, weather and climate, electricity, and sustainable energy. No science background is required. Faculty of Science students may only take this course as a free elective.
name: PHYS 1905
prereq_text: None
subject: PHYS
title: Physics Behind Everyday Life

desc: Introduction to aspects of modern physics relevant to engineering. Thermal radiation. Concepts of relativistic kinematics. Wave-particle duality. Elements of quantum mechanics. Optical and x-ray spectra, lasers. Nuclear physics and applications. Condensed matter physics.
name: PHYS 2004
prereq_text: PHYS 1002 or PHYS 1004 or PHYS 1008 with a grade of B- or better, plus MATH 1004 and MATH 1104 or equivalent. Restricted to B.Eng. students not in the Engineering Physics program. Students in programs other than B.Eng. must obtain permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Modern Physics for Engineers

desc: Equations of motion for a single particle. Harmonic oscillation. Noninertial reference frames. Orbits in a central force field. Motion of systems of particles and of rigid bodies. Introduction to special relativity. Laboratory experiments in classical mechanics and properties of matter.
name: PHYS 2101
prereq_text: PHYS 1001 and PHYS 1002, or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004, alternatively PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 with an overall average of B- or better; MATH 1004 and MATH 1104, or MATH 1002 and MATH 1102.
subject: PHYS
title: Mechanics and Properties of Matter

desc: Geometrical optics. Types of waves, vibrating string and the classical wave equation. General solutions for traveling waves. Superposition and interference, coherence, wave packets, waves in 2 and 3 dimensions. Propagation of electromagnetic waves. Light and physical optics, oscillator model for dispersion, diffraction, polarization, and refraction.
name: PHYS 2202
prereq_text: PHYS 1001 and PHYS 1002, or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004 (PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 are also acceptable provided a minimum average grade of B- is presented); plus MATH 1104 or MATH 1102 or MATH 2152, and MATH 2004 or MATH 2000 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: PHYS
title: Wave Motion and Optics

desc: The observational basis of astronomy. The history of astronomy, properties of light, solar system observations and stellar astronomy.
name: PHYS 2203
prereq_text: PHYS 1002 or PHYS 1004 or permission of the department. PHYS 1008 with a grade of B- or better may also be used if MATH 1004 or MATH 1007 or MATH 1002 or MATH 2052 have been successfully completed.
subject: PHYS
title: Astronomy

desc: Electrostatic field and potential, Gauss’ law. Properties of conductors. Magnetic effects from currents. Motion of charges in electric and magnetic fields. Energy in electric and magnetic fields. Electromagnetic induction. Maxwell’s equations in vacuum using vector differential and integral calculus.
name: PHYS 2305
prereq_text: PHYS 1001, PHYS 1002, or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004, alternatively PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 with an overall grade of B- or higher; MATH 2004 or MATH 2000 (may be taken concurrently).
subject: PHYS
title: Electricity and Magnetism

desc: D.C. and A.C. circuit theory. Resonant circuits. Basic measuring devices, the oscilloscope; impedances, bandwidth, noise; vacuum tubes, transistors, useful approximations for circuit design; feedback, amplifiers, oscillators; operational circuits; digital circuits. Lectures emphasize the physical basis of instrument design. Laboratory emphasizes modern digital instrumentation.
name: PHYS 2306
prereq_text: PHYS 1001, PHYS 1002 or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004, alternatively PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 with an overall grade of B- or better.
subject: PHYS
title: Physics of Electrical and Electronic Measurements I

desc: Introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. Temperature and thermodynamic equilibrium. Work, internal energy and heat; first law. Kinetic theory of gases. Basic probability theory. Microscopic states and entropy. Absolute temperature, reversibility and the second law of thermodynamics. Thermodynamic processes and applications.
name: PHYS 2401
prereq_text: PHYS 1001 and PHYS 1002, or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004, (PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 are also acceptable provided a minimum average grade of B-) ; plus MATH 1004 and MATH 1104 or MATH 1002 (no longer offered) and MATH 1102 (no longer offered), or MATH 2052 and MATH 2152.
subject: PHYS
title: Thermal Physics

desc: The course is designed to provide a logical transition from classical to modern physics. Special relativity. Rutherford scattering, atomic models. Thermal radiation. Photoelectric effect, Compton scattering. Bohr theory of the hydrogen atom. Atomic energy states, optical spectra, lasers. X-rays. Radioactivity. Quantum Mechanics.
name: PHYS 2604
prereq_text: PHYS 1001 and PHYS 1002, or PHYS 1003 and PHYS 1004 (PHYS 1007 and PHYS 1008 are also acceptable provided a minimum average grade of B- is presented); plus MATH 1004 and MATH 1104, or MATH 1002 (no longer offered) and MATH 1102 (no longer offered) or MATH 2052 and MATH 2152.
subject: PHYS
title: Modern Physics I

desc: From classical phenomena to aspects of modern physics and recent advances. Topics may include light and colour, music and sound, cell phones, the galaxy and beyond. No science background is required. Faculty of Science students may only take this course as a free elective.
name: PHYS 2903
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PHYS
title: Physics Towards the Future

desc: Students complete a small number of experiments selected from modern optics, holography, atomic physics, nuclear spectroscopy, radiation, etc. An exercise on literature searches and student seminars on experimental and numerical methods are included.
name: PHYS 3007
prereq_text: PHYS 2202 and PHYS 2604, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Third Year Physics Laboratory: Selected Experiments and Seminars

desc: Students complete a small number of experiments selected from modern optics, holography, atomic physics, nuclear spectroscopy, radiation, etc. Instruction on instrumentation building techniques will be given.
name: PHYS 3008
prereq_text: PHYS 2202 and PHYS 2604, or permission of the department.
subject: PHYS
title: Third Year Physics Laboratory: Selected Experiments and Workshop

desc: Students complete a small number of experiments selected from astronomy, astrophysics, modern optics, holography, atomic physics, nuclear spectroscopy, radiation, etc. At least one astronomy/astrophysics related experiment is required. An exercise on literature searches and student seminars on experimental and numerical methods are included.
name: PHYS 3009
prereq_text: PHYS 2202, PHYS 2604 and PHYS 2203 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Third Year Physics Laboratory: Selected Experiments and Seminars with Observational Astronomy

desc: Introduction to biophysics. Random motion of molecules and diffusion; viscosity and the circulatory system; laws of thermodynamics and physical forces responsible for chemical reactions, molecular self-assembly and recognition; enzyme kinetics and molecular machines; nerve impulse and its propagation.
name: PHYS 3207
prereq_text: PHYS 2604 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Topics in Biophysics

desc: Electrostatics feld and magnetostatics in the presence of matter. Solving Laplace's and Poisson's equations. Multipole expansions. Vector potential. Faraday's laws of induction; Maxwell's equations in matter. Waves in vacuum and dielectric media, guided waves.
name: PHYS 3308
prereq_text: PHYS 2202, PHYS 2604, PHYS 2305, MATH 2004 or MATH 2008, and MATH 3705, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Electromagnetism

desc: Zeroth, First, Second and Third Laws of Thermodynamics; enthalpy, Helmholtz and Gibbs functions and the Maxwell relations; phase transitions; thermodynamics of magnetism; cryogenics cooling by Joule-Thompson effect, adiabatic expansion of a gas, adiabatic demagnetization, helium dilution refrigeration; black body radiation; negative temperatures.
name: PHYS 3402
prereq_text: PHYS 2101 and PHYS 2305, MATH 2007, MATH 2008, MATH 2107 and MATH 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Heat and Thermodynamics

desc: Elements of condensed matter physics, semiconductors, superconductivity. Elements of nuclear physics, fission, fusion, power generation. Introduction to particle physics. Ionizing radiation: production, interactions, detection. Medical physics: radiation biophysics, cancer therapy, imaging.
name: PHYS 3606
prereq_text: PHYS 2604 and PHYS 3701, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Modern Physics II

desc: Elements of condensed matter physics, semiconductors, superconductivity. Modern optics. Elements of nuclear physics, fission, fusion, power generation. Ionizing radiation: production, interactions, detection. Medical physics: radiation biophysics, cancer therapy, imaging.
name: PHYS 3608
prereq_text: PHYS 2604 and PHYS 3701, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Modern Applied Physics

desc: Analysis of interference experiments with waves and particles; fundamental concepts of quantum mechanics, Schrödinger equation; angular momentum, atomic beams; hydrogen atom; atomic and molecular spectroscopy; Pauli principle; simple applications in the physics of elementary particles.
name: PHYS 3701
prereq_text: PHYS 2604, MATH 2000 [1.0] (may be taken concurrently), or MATH 2004 or MATH 2008, and MATH 3705 (may be taken concurrently), or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Elements of Quantum Mechanics

desc: Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics: Poisson brackets, tensors and dyadics; rigid body rotations: introductory fluid mechanics coupled systems and normal coordinates; relativistic dynamics.
name: PHYS 3801
prereq_text: PHYS 2101, PHYS 2202, PHYS 2305, MATH 2007, MATH 2008, MATH 2107, MATH 2401 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Classical Mechanics

desc: Equations of motion for a single particle. Oscillatory Motion. Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of mechanics. Central force motion. Motion of systems of particles and of rigid bodies.
name: PHYS 3802
prereq_text: PHYS 2202, PHYS 2604, and MATH 2004, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Dynamics

desc: Boundary Value problems involving curvilinear coordinates; spherical harmonics, Bessel functions, Green's functions. Functions of a complex variable: analytic functions, contour integration, residue calculus.
name: PHYS 3807
prereq_text: PHYS 2202, MATH 2004, MATH 3705 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Mathematical Physics I

desc: Solution of second-order total differential equations by Frobenius' method. Sturm-Liouville theory. Special functions: Legendre, Bessel. Hermite, Laguerre and associated functions. Partial differential equations: method of separation of variables, eigenfunctions and eigenvalues and eigenfunction expansions. Green's function techniques for solving inhomogeneous partial differential equations.
name: PHYS 3808
prereq_text: PHYS 3807 or MATH 3007 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Mathematical Physics II

desc: Provides practical experience for students enrolled in the Co-operative option. Students must receive satisfactory evaluations from their work term employer. Written and oral reports will be required. Graded as Sat or Uns.
name: PHYS 3999
prereq_text: registration in the Physics Co-operative education option and permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Co-operative Work Term Report

desc: Students complete a small number of experiments selected from modern optics, holography, atomic physics, nuclear spectroscopy, radiation, etc. An exercise on literature searches and student seminars on experimental and numerical methods are included.
name: PHYS 4007
prereq_text: PHYS 3606 (or PHYS 3608) and registration in the Engineering Physics program.
subject: PHYS
title: Fourth-Year Physics Laboratory: Selected Experiments and Seminars

desc: Students complete a small number of experiments selected from modern optics, holography, atomic physics, nuclear spectroscopy, radiation, etc. Instruction on instrumentation building techniques will be given.
name: PHYS 4008
prereq_text: PHYS 3007.
subject: PHYS
title: Fourth-Year Physics Laboratory: Selected Experiments and Workshop

desc: Stellar evolution, including stellar modeling, main sequence stars, red giants and the end states of stars such as neutron stars and black holes. Galactic structure and dynamics. Neutrino astrophysics.
name: PHYS 4201
prereq_text: PHYS 3701, PHYS 3606 or PHYS 3608, and PHYS 2401 or PHYS 4409, or permission of the Department. (PHYS 3606 or PHYS 3608 and PHYS 4409 may be taken concurrently).
subject: PHYS
title: Astrophysics

desc: Observational evidence for the Big Bang. Cosmological space-time, expansion dynamics and contents of the universe. Physical processes in the expanding universe, inflation, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, dark matter, and dark energy.
name: PHYS 4202
prereq_text: PHYS 3701, PHYS 3606 or PHYS 3608, and PHYS 2401 or PHYS 4409, or permission of the Department. (PHYS 3606 or PHYS 3608 and PHYS 4409 may be taken concurrently).
subject: PHYS
title: Cosmology

desc: Fourier transform, convolution. Sampling theorem. Applications to imaging: descriptors of spatial resolution, filtering. Correlation, noise power. Discrete Fourier transform, FFT. Filtering of noisy signals. Image reconstruction in computed tomography and magnetic resonance. Laplace transform. Integral transforms, application to boundary value problems.
name: PHYS 4203
prereq_text: MATH 3705, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Physical Applications of Fourier Analysis

desc: Electromagnetic wave propagation; reflection, refraction; Gaussian beams, guided waves. Laser theory: stimulated emission, cavity optics, modes, gain and bandwidth; atomic and molecular lasers. Mode locking, Q switching. Diffraction theory, coherence, Fourier optics, holography, laser applications. Optical communication systems, nonlinear effects: devices, fibre sensors, integrated optics.
name: PHYS 4208
prereq_text: PHYS 2202, PHYS 3606 (or PHYS 3608), and PHYS 3308 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Modern Optics

desc: Electromagnetic wave propagation in a vacuum, dielectrics, conductors, and ionized gases, reflection, refraction, polarization at the plane boundary between two media; waveguide and transmission line propagation; dipole and quadrupole radiation fields; antenna systems. Electromagnetic mass, radiation pressure. Tensor notation, transformation of the electromagnetic fields.
name: PHYS 4307
prereq_text: PHYS 3308, PHYS 3801, PHYS 3807 and PHYS 3808 (except for Mathematics and Physics Double Honours students), or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Electromagnetic Radiation

desc: Equilibrium statistical mechanics and its relation to thermodynamics. Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics are derived, and applied in appropriate physical situations. Fluctuations. Kinetics and transport processes, including the Boltzmann transport equation and some of its applications.
name: PHYS 4407
prereq_text: PHYS 3402, PHYS 2602 or PHYS 3601, PHYS 3701 or PHYS 3602, PHYS 4707 (may be taken concurrently); or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Physics

desc: The three Laws of Thermodynamics, enthalpy, Helmholtz and Gibbs functions. Equilibrium statistical mechanics and its relation to thermodynamics. Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics.
name: PHYS 4409
prereq_text: PHYS 3701 (may be taken concurrently), MATH 2004 and MATH 3705, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics

desc: An introduction to solid state physics. Topics include crystal structure, phonons and lattice vibrations, conductors, semiconductors, insulators and superconductivity.
name: PHYS 4508
prereq_text: PHYS 3606 or PHYS 3608, and PHYS 3701, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Solid State Physics

desc: Standard Model. Properties of leptons, quarks, hadrons. Fundamental interactions: photon, gluons, W/Z bosons. Higgs boson. Conservation laws, invariance principles, quantum numbers. Decay rates and scattering cross-sections. Quantum electrodynamics and chromodynamics. Resonances. Weak interactions, CKM matrix, parity and CP violation. Neutrino masses and oscillations. Future directions.
name: PHYS 4602
prereq_text: PHYS 4707 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Physics of Elementary Particles

desc: Ground state properties of nuclei. Nuclear models, binding energy, properties of excited nuclei. Alpha, beta and gamma decay. Passage of radiation through matter, detectors. Nuclear reactions, cross sections, fission, fusion. Elements of neutron physics.
name: PHYS 4608
prereq_text: PHYS 3606 or PHYS 3608 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Nuclear Physics

desc: The basic interpretative postulates of quantum mechanics; applications of wave mechanics and operator methods to various quantum mechanical systems; quantum mechanical treatment of angular momentum.
name: PHYS 4707
prereq_text: PHYS 3701 and PHYS 3807 or equivalent, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics I

desc: Scattering theory and application; bound state problems; approximation methods.
name: PHYS 4708
prereq_text: PHYS 4707 or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics II

desc: Special relativity using tensor analysis. Curved spacetime with physics applications which may include the solar system, stars, black holes and gravitational waves. Introduction to differential geometry and Einstein's field equations.
name: PHYS 4804
prereq_text: PHYS 3308, PHYS 3802 and PHYS 3807 or equivalent, or permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to General Relativity

desc: Computational methods used in analysis of experimental data. Introduction to probability and random variables. Monte Carlo methods for simulation of random processes. Statistical methods for parameter estimation and hypothesis tests. Confidence intervals. Multivariate data classification. Unfolding methods. Examples primarily from particle and medical physics.
name: PHYS 4807
prereq_text: third year standing in a physics program and an ability to program in Python, Java, C or C++, and permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Data Analysis Techniques for Physics

desc: Each year, at the direction of the Department, a course on a special topic may be offered.
name: PHYS 4901
prereq_text: permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Special Topics in Physics

desc: Advanced projects of an experimental or theoretical nature with an orientation towards research. A written mid-term progress report is required and also a written and oral report at the conclusion of the project.
name: PHYS 4907
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours Physics program or equivalent, and permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Fourth-Year Project

desc: Advanced projects of an experimental or theoretical nature with an orientation towards research. A written mid-term progress report is required and also a written and oral report at the conclusion of the project.
name: PHYS 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours Physics program or equivalent, and permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Fourth-Year Project

desc: Advanced projects of an experimental or theoretical nature with an orientation towards research. A written mid-term progress report is required and also a written and oral report at the conclusion of the project.
name: PHYS 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in an Honours Physics program or equivalent, and permission of the Department.
subject: PHYS
title: Fourth-Year Project

desc: Introduction to the field of political management. The institutional, legislative and ethical context in which party strategists, campaign managers, pollsters, lobbyists and civil society operate. Related administrative and communications skills.
name: POLM 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: POLM
title: Introduction to Political Management

desc: The different elements of opinion research such as opinion measurement, questionnaire design, interviewing, data analysis and interpretation, and how this helps understand the process by which citizens make decisions about political issues.
name: POLM 4010
prereq_text: POLM 3000.
subject: POLM
title: Polling and Opinion Research

desc: Through applied exercises, case studies and a project with an external organization, students will build knowledge and skills required for advocacy and government relations in the private and voluntary sectors.
name: POLM 4012
prereq_text: POLM 3000.
subject: POLM
title: Advocacy and Government Relations in Canada

desc: Introduction to modern political ideas such as liberty, equality, the rule of law, representation, participation (including gender aspects), the impact of these ideas on political and policy making institutions in Canada; other countries may be examined. Basic research and academic writing skills.
name: PSCI 1100
prereq_text: None
subject: PSCI
title: Democracy in Theory and Practice

desc: Compares politics in selected states and world regions, including political institutions and cultures, development, public policy making, and gender. Global issues and international relations among states, international organizations, and other actors. Basic research and academic writing skills.
name: PSCI 1200
prereq_text: None
subject: PSCI
title: World Politics

desc: Social media, self-driving cars, genetic manipulation: technology is transforming both the human experience and the natural world. This course explores interactions among technological change, the evolution of social and political order, and the transformation of the environment (for example, with climate change).
name: PSCI 1500
prereq_text: None
subject: PSCI
title: Technology, Nature, Power

desc: Introduction to concepts and theories that help explain the complex phenomenon of human migration, including the social and political relevance of different types of migration to Canada and in other regions and the political responses to migration and mobility today.
name: PSCI 1501
prereq_text: None
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Migration

desc: An examination of the cultural, social, and economic context of Canadian politics, including interest groups and social movements, regionalism, language, ethnicity, and gender.
name: PSCI 2002
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Politics and Civil Society

desc: An examination of Canadian political institutions, including federalism, Parliament, the constitution, political parties and the electoral system.
name: PSCI 2003
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Political Institutions

desc: Domestic politics in states of the Global North. Comparison of political and economic regimes, political institutions, actors, political processes and cultures, and patterns of public policy making.
name: PSCI 2101
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Comparative Politics of the Global North

desc: Introduction to domestic politics in post-colonial and developing states of the Global South. Topics may include nationalism, authoritarianism, economic development, revolution, democratization, and the politics of gender, religion, and ethnicity.
name: PSCI 2102
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Comparative Politics of the Global South

desc: An examination of several important aspects of the U.S. political system, including separation of powers, checks and balances, and federalism.
name: PSCI 2200
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Introduction to U.S. Politics

desc: Western political thought from classical times to the Renaissance: Plato, Aristotle, and other thinkers.
name: PSCI 2301
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: History of Political Thought I

desc: Western political thought from the Renaissance: Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau and other thinkers.
name: PSCI 2302
prereq_text: PSCI 2301 or permission of the department.
subject: PSCI
title: History of Political Thought II

desc: Introduction to central concepts and processes involved in public affairs. Exploration of public issues, policy approaches and decision-making structures using theoretical, empirical and applied approaches.
name: PSCI 2401
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Public Affairs Analysis

desc: Introduction to gender and politics of diversity, including how feminist activism and organizing finds expression in the political process and structures of representation such as political parties, legislatures and the state.
name: PSCI 2500
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Gender and Politics

desc: Introduction to theories, concepts and issues in global politics. Topics may include conflict and intervention, peace and security, international institutions, norms and ethics, human rights, gender, culture, and globalization.
name: PSCI 2601
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: International Relations: Global Politics

desc: Introduction to the international political economy. Topics may include contemporary changes in the global political economy, multinational corporations, foreign economic policy, global and regional economic institutions, environmental issues, international development and relations between rich and poor countries.
name: PSCI 2602
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: International Relations: Global Political Economy

desc: Introduction to the logic and design of research. Measurement and inference in qualitative and quantitative political science.
name: PSCI 2701
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Introduction to Research Methods in Political Science

desc: The logic and methods of the quantitative study of politics, with emphasis on the application and interpretation of statistical techniques for data analysis. Students are strongly encouraged to take this course the same year as PSCI 2701.
name: PSCI 2702
prereq_text: PSCI 2701 or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Quantitative Research Methods in Political Science

desc: A comparative examination of the nature of Canadian provincial politics. Topics include: political culture, history, party systems, electoral systems and voting behaviour.
name: PSCI 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Provincial Politics

desc: The evolution of the party system, the growth of major and minor party movements and the electoral process in Canada.
name: PSCI 3004
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Political Parties and Elections in Canada

desc: A survey of the political process and political institutions in Ontario.
name: PSCI 3005
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Ontario Government and Politics

desc: The role of social forces in the Canadian political process, including interest groups, social movements, elites and classes.
name: PSCI 3006
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Social Power in Canadian Politics

desc: The politics of the Canadian constitution. Particular attention to historical and contemporary constitutional reform.
name: PSCI 3007
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Constitutional Politics in Canada

desc: The historical background of African independence, and contemporary struggle for democracy and economic development in Africa.
name: PSCI 3100
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of AFRI 1002, GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500 or PSCI 2102.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Development in Africa

desc: The recurrent crises of war, and political instability in Africa, along with regional and international efforts to resolve them.
name: PSCI 3101
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of War in Africa

desc: The evolving structures and processes of government in (greater) China with particular emphasis on politics in the People's Republic of China and secondary emphasis on Taiwan and Hong Kong.
name: PSCI 3102
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Development of China

desc: The relationship between government structures, society and the economy in Northeast Asia with particular emphasis on Japan and Korea.
name: PSCI 3103
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: State, Society and Economy in Northeast Asia

desc: Ideologies, practices, and legacies of western dominance over Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Examines the complexities of imperial control and the colonial relationship from the nineteenth century to present.
name: PSCI 3105
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Imperialism

desc: Alternate theories of the causes of war. Such alternate perspectives as biological, social and comparative historical approaches, including the results of peace research activities of the past two decades.
name: PSCI 3107
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500 or PSCI 2601.
subject: PSCI
title: The Causes of War

desc: Examines political themes in popular culture. Cultural media may include film, literature, television, music, cartoons/comics, and the news media. Political themes may include war, ethnicity, nationalism, revolution, citizenship, gender and sexuality.
name: PSCI 3108
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Popular Culture

desc: Politics of moral regulation in Canada, the United States and other jurisdictions. The treatment in law and public policy of such human rights issues as: capital punishment, sexual orientation, euthanasia, abortion, new reproductive technologies, racial discrimination, religious and equality rights.
name: PSCI 3109
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of PSCI 2002, PSCI 2003 or PSCI 2101.
subject: PSCI
title: The Politics of Law and Morality

desc: The central role played by the U.S. Constitution in the country's political life, from the Framers to current controversies. Includes issues of race, class and gender.
name: PSCI 3200
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: U.S. Constitutional Politics

desc: The evolution and functioning of political systems in the Middle East region, with emphasis on the problems of political stability, the impact of the West, the role of Islam, and war and peace.
name: PSCI 3203
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Government and Politics in the Middle East

desc: An overview of the evolution of Latin American political systems, including the impact of the European conquest, democratization, economic liberalization, state-civil society relations, gender politics, revolutionary movements, and relations with the United States.
name: PSCI 3204
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Latin America

desc: An introduction to the politics, society and economy of Mexico. Topics include processes of democratization and economic liberalization, human rights, the environment, the role of women, labour, and indigenous peoples, and social policy. Special emphasis on Mexico's role in the North American political economy.
name: PSCI 3205
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2102 or PSCI 2602.
subject: PSCI
title: Mexican Politics

desc: A comparative examination of select controversies over democracy in specific European countries, considered within the context of 20th century historical trends, as well as contemporary political debates.
name: PSCI 3206
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: European Democracies

desc: The process of European integration; the European Union and its institutions; core EU policies, challenges to the integration process (e.g. democratic legitimacy, enlargement); theories of European integration.
name: PSCI 3207
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: The Government and Politics of European Integration

desc: Political development in post-Soviet Russia and Ukraine, including examination of the complicated relationship between the two states. Historical perspectives, institutional context (including federalism) and comparative insights.
name: PSCI 3208
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics in Russia and Ukraine: Power and Contestation

desc: The politics of dramatic political changes, such as revolution, secession, constitutional revision, and systemic reform. The course will include selected historical and comparative cases from Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
name: PSCI 3209
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Reconstruction and Transformation in Europe and Eurasia

desc: An overview of specific aspects of U.S. electoral politics, including presidential and congressional elections, incumbency, the two-party system, campaign spending limits, the role of the media, and voter turnout.
name: PSCI 3210
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Electoral Politics in the U.S.

desc: A study of imaginative prose in which political ideas and/or political settings dominate. Literature as political communication, the impact of literature upon politics, the peculiar value of literature in the study of politics and its shortcomings.
name: PSCI 3300
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics and Literature

desc: A comparative survey of political thought focusing on a range of traditions that may include readings from Aboriginal, African, Chinese, Indian, Jewish, Latin American, Muslim, and Persian perspectives.
name: PSCI 3302
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Comparative Political Thought

desc: Introduction to feminist philosophical responses to sexism, taking into consideration the different waves of feminist discourse. Topics may include the concept of gender; women's diversity and its implications; `intersectionality'; gender, capitalism and the family; and new approaches to feminist knowledge and feminist agency.
name: PSCI 3303
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Feminist Political Theory

desc: Politics of human rights in its historical and cultural context, including: early liberal theories of natural rights; utilitarian and Marxist critiques; contemporary rights debates; different generations of rights; feminism and women's rights; cultural relativism; state sovereignty; and, problems of implementation and enforcement.
name: PSCI 3307
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Human Rights

desc: A survey of trends in modern political thought, including some of liberalism, conservatism, neo-conservatism, Marxist and neo-Marxist socialism, communitarianism, postmodernism and globalization.
name: PSCI 3308
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Modern Political Thought

desc: A survey of ideologies, mainly since 1900, including some of nationalism, utopian socialism, communism, fascism, populism, environmentalism and feminism.
name: PSCI 3309
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Modern Ideologies

desc: A survey of political thought among Muslims, tracing the emergence and influence of juridical, philosophical and administrative approaches to politics on Muslim civilization.
name: PSCI 3311
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: History of Muslim Political Thought

desc: Major Enlightenment thinkers and major themes of Enlightenment political thought. Topics may include reason, religion, toleration, liberty, equality, the foundations of political authority, autonomy, morals, taste, progress, history or commerce.
name: PSCI 3312
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Enlightenment Political Thought

desc: Study of the institutions and dynamics of government in Canada, with emphasis on political context, administrative reforms, policy development and ongoing challenges. Analysis may include federal, provincial and/or municipal levels of government.
name: PSCI 3401
prereq_text: third year standing and one of PSCI 2002, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2401, or PAPM 2000.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Public Administration

desc: Policy communities and policy networks in Canada with particular attention paid to policy issues, the political environment, policy instruments, impact and outcomes.
name: PSCI 3402
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of PSCI 2002, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2401, or PAPM 2000.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Public Policy

desc: The formation and impact of public policy: a variety of political systems as well as a variety of policy areas. Emphasis on developing skills for the analysis of policy formation and impact.
name: PSCI 3405
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2400, PSCI 2401, or PAPM 2000.
subject: PSCI
title: Comparative Public Policy Analysis

desc: The public affairs and issue management strategies of corporations, government departments, and other institutions in Canada from a comparative perspective.
name: PSCI 3406
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Public Affairs and Media Strategies

desc: Theories about the origins and dynamics of public opinion, the ways in which public opinion influences government policy and decision-making, and how decision-makers are able to shape public opinion.
name: PSCI 3407
prereq_text: PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702.
subject: PSCI
title: Public Opinion and Public Policy

desc: Introduction to the field of political management. The institutional, legislative and ethical context in which party strategists, campaign managers, pollsters, lobbyists and civil society operate. Related administrative and communications skills.
name: PSCI 3410
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Introduction to Political Management

desc: Finding and using data to make, manage and evaluate public policy. Emphasis will be on developing data analysis skills, as well as the use and application of substantive theories.
name: PSCI 3411
prereq_text: PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702.
subject: PSCI
title: Data Analysis for Governance: Formal Approaches and Practical Realities

desc: A contemporary approach to the role of gender in political systems of the South. Topics may include gender and development, human rights, social policies, globalization, state-civil society relations, political participation and citizenship.
name: PSCI 3502
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2500 or PSCI 3307.
subject: PSCI
title: Gender and Politics: Global South

desc: Origins, structure and functioning of international institutions with emphasis on the United Nations as well as regional organizations. Topics include peace and security, international aid and development, human rights and the control of global resources.
name: PSCI 3600
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500, PSCI 2601 or PSCI 2602.
subject: PSCI
title: International Institutions

desc: Examination of the major theoretical approaches to the study of international politics. Topics may include realism, liberalism, Marxism, constructivism, feminism, and poststructuralism.
name: PSCI 3601
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500 or PSCI 2601.
subject: PSCI
title: Theories of International Politics

desc: The ideas of classical and contemporary strategic thinkers. International security issues and concepts.
name: PSCI 3603
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Strategic Thought and International Security

desc: The traditions, domestic influences, objectives, capabilities, and decision-making processes, and analysis of selected contemporary issues.
name: PSCI 3606
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500, PSCI 2002, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2601 or PSCI 2602.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Foreign Policy

desc: The evolution of Canadian and U.S. security and defence policy as it pertains to North America. Contemporary issues and development.
name: PSCI 3607
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: North American Security and Defence Policy

desc: Advanced introduction to the politics of human mobility and migration, including attempts by states and other actors to influence migration and mobility and emerging types of governance at the national, regional and global levels.
name: PSCI 3608
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Migration Governance

desc: Drawing on theories of international relations, political economy, and public policy-making, this course examines the global, national and local politics of food production and distribution. Topics include food security, free trade versus fair trade, the environmental sustainability of food systems, food sovereignty and food aid.
name: PSCI 3609
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Global Politics of Food

desc: Patterns of colonialism, evolving political regimes and issues in development and foreign policy in the countries of South Asia, including India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and other member states of SAARC.
name: PSCI 3700
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500 or PSCI 2102.
subject: PSCI
title: Government and Politics of South Asia

desc: The origins and evolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and peace process.
name: PSCI 3702
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500, PSCI 2601 or PSCI 2602.
subject: PSCI
title: Israeli-Palestinian Relations

desc: The main approaches and policy issues in the political economy of advanced industrialized states. The relationship between state and market and the ways in which national states have responded to the pressures of governing in an increasingly interdependent global economy.
name: PSCI 3703
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of GPOL 1500 or PSCI 2602.
subject: PSCI
title: Governing in the Global Economy

desc: A comparative examination of Central and Eastern European states and societies. Topics discussed include political institutions and processes, societal structures and collective identities, patterns of post-communist transformation, the impact of European integration, relations with Russia and post-Soviet States.
name: PSCI 3704
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Government and Politics of Central and Eastern Europe

desc: The significance for political theory of the ancient and medieval controversies over nature/convention, power/knowledge, time/eternity, theory/practice, and science/mysticism. Thinkers such as Homer, the pre-Socratics, Plato and Aristotle, the neo-Platonists, Augustine, and the Scholastics.
name: PSCI 3709
prereq_text: (PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302) or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Ancient and Medieval Political Thought

desc: Environmental issues in contemporary political argument. Topics include: environmental movements and green parties, environmental ethics and animal rights, economic approaches to environmental management, the politics of sustainable development, and the international politics of the environment.
name: PSCI 3801
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Environmental Politics

desc: An examination of the various dimensions and meanings of globalization and its relationship with human rights. The main emphasis will be on the implications of the emerging global economy for economic, social, political and cultural rights.
name: PSCI 3802
prereq_text: third-year standing and one of: GPOL 1500, SOCI 1010 [1.0], ANTH 1003[1.0], ANTH 1010[1.0], ISSC 1001[1.0], PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, LAWS 2105, PHIL 2103 or (ANTH 1001 and ANTH 1002), or (SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002).
subject: PSCI
title: Globalization and Human Rights

desc: The meaning, sources and practice of racialism, as well as efforts to combat it, in a comparative context. Case studies will include South Africa, the United States, and Canada.
name: PSCI 3805
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Race

desc: A lecture course on a selected contemporary topic in Political Science. Topic may vary from year to year and will be announced in advance of the registration period by the Department of Political Science.
name: PSCI 3809
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: PSCI
title: Selected Topics in Political Science

desc: Une programme de lectures choisies et de travaux écrits dans le domaine de specialisation d'un membre du département. Consulter le conseiller des études de premier cycle (Undergraduate supervisor) pour les sujets offerts.
name: PSCI 3900
prereq_text: third-year standing in the Political Science Mention : Français program.
subject: PSCI
title: Études dirigées

desc: One-term internship at The Washington Center in D.C.; options in American politics, international affairs, and other areas. Evaluation by Washington Center faculty, but governed by Carleton University Political Science Department regulations. Graded Sat or Uns.
name: PSCI 3905
prereq_text: selection to The Washington Center Internship Program and one of PSCI 2200, PSCI 3200, or PSCI 3210 and permission of the department.
subject: PSCI
title: Washington Center Internship

desc: Internship gives students the opportunity to work with an organization whose focus relates to politics over a full academic year. Students complete a research paper related to their internship. Students must identify an organization to host the internship and a faculty member to provide supervision.
name: PSCI 3906
prereq_text: third-year Honours standing with a minimum Political Science CGPA of 9.0 or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Full-Year Political Science Internship

desc: Internship gives students the opportunity to work with an organization whose focus relates to politics over one academic term. Students complete a research paper related to their internship. Students must identify an organization to host the internship and a faculty member to provide supervision.
name: PSCI 3907
prereq_text: third-year Honours Standing with a minimum Political Science CGPA of 9.0 or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: One-Term Political Science Internship

name: PSCI 3999
