prereq_text: None
subject: PSCI
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: A seminar focused on selected topics in Canadian government and politics.
name: PSCI 4001
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Topics in Canadian Government and Politics

desc: The role of the mass media in the Canadian political system from a comparative perspective.
name: PSCI 4003
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics and the Media

desc: The evolution and contemporary operation of the Canadian federal system; the social, political, economic, and structural features underlying its operational performance, resilience in crisis, and potential for adaptation.
name: PSCI 4005
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1500, PSCI 2003 or PSCI 2101.
subject: PSCI
title: Canadian Federalism

desc: The role of Parliament and of the individual M.P. in terms of policy making, party discipline, and differing conceptions of representation.
name: PSCI 4006
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Legislatures and Representation in Canada

desc: The state's response to foreign espionage, alleged subversion, terrorism, and counterintelligence. Major focus on the Canadian experience, but with extensive use of materials chronicling the practices of KGB, CIA, BIS, ASIO, MOSSAD, etc.
name: PSCI 4008
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: National Security and Intelligence in the Modern State

desc: Society, culture, economy and politics in Quebec. Special attention to the politically relevant changes since 1960 and the central place of Quebec within the Canadian federation.
name: PSCI 4009
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Quebec Politics

desc: Consideration of prime ministers, premiers, cabinet ministers and senior public service leadership in Canadian politics and government.
name: PSCI 4010
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Executive Power in Canadian Politics

desc: A survey of recent thinking about the state in western societies drawing on perspectives such as those of feminists, Marxists, Weberians, poststructuralists and others. Topics may include: the rise of the modern state, economic governance, the public sphere, citizenship, sovereignty and territoriality.
name: PSCI 4103
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: The Modern State

desc: Different theoretical approaches to the concept of development in the Global South and their relevance for selected countries in Latin America, Africa and Asia.
name: PSCI 4104
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Development in the Global South - Theory and Practice

desc: Topics may include global issues of trade, finance and production, changing patterns of foreign aid, and the role of microfinance, mining, non-governmental organizations, migration, anti-poverty programs and activism in promoting development.
name: PSCI 4105
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Selected Problems in Development in the Global South

desc: The causes and implications of political participation by individuals with special reference to Canada. Topics include citizen participation in campaign and party organizations, political protest movements, interest groups, and community associations.
name: PSCI 4107
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of PSCI 2002, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2700, or (PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702).
subject: PSCI
title: Political Participation in Canada

desc: The genesis and impact of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Particular emphasis on the politics of aboriginal, language, and equality rights.
name: PSCI 4109
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: The Politics of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

desc: The pathology of apartheid, the reasons for its end, and prospects for democratization and development in Southern Africa in the era of globalization.
name: PSCI 4203
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Southern Africa After Apartheid

desc: The conduct and meaning of elections in contemporary states. Attention to the connection of elections to concepts of representation, policy mandates, and political parties, and to electoral systems and referendums.
name: PSCI 4204
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2700, or (PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702).
subject: PSCI
title: Elections

desc: Issues of governance regarding the original peoples of Canada, Mexico and the United States since the European invasion. Contemporary movements for restoration of cultural, political, socio-economic, land and self-governance rights, emphasizing domestic and international strategies.
name: PSCI 4206
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2001, PSCI 2002, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2102, or PSCI 3205.
subject: PSCI
title: Indigenous Politics of North America

desc: The nature of global pressures in Africa, as states go through political and economic change.
name: PSCI 4207
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Globalization, Adjustment and Democracy in Africa

desc: Examination of party and parliamentary democracy in the five principal Anglophone parliamentary democracies: Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Consideration is given to the effects of different electoral systems and institutional arrangements on electoral politics, political participation, and party organization.
name: PSCI 4209
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 2500, PSCI 2003, PSCI 2101, or PSCI 2102.
subject: PSCI
title: Westminster Democracies: Parliaments, Parties and Elections

desc: Examination of the sources and dynamics of political identity through the medium of graphic novels and graphic memoirs. Themes may include collective memory, genocide, prostitution, violent conflict, civil rights, race and ethnicity, revolution, Indigenous issues, mental health, and gender and sexuality.
name: PSCI 4210
prereq_text: fourth year standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Political Identity through Graphic Novels

desc: The art and craft of political opinion writing and social-media engagement. An examination of contemporary online activism, interpersonal and collective online dynamics, and an imparting of the skills required for persuasive and well-researched op-ed writing.
name: PSCI 4211
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Op-Ed Writing and Social Media as Political Engagement

desc: Contemporary secular and religious responses to the challenges of modernity. Readings include writings of Arab, Turkish, and Iranian intellectuals.
name: PSCI 4302
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of (PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302) or PSCI 3311.
subject: PSCI
title: Political Thought in the Modern Muslim Middle East

desc: Examination of Foucault's concept of governmentality and work which has developed this idea, especially the relevance of governmentality for global political studies. Topics may include sovereignty, biopolitics, technopolitics, neoliberalism and citizenship.
name: PSCI 4303
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Governmentality and Politics

desc: An examination of methods adopted by major thinkers in the history of political philosophy, amidst changing understandings of metaphysics and science. Thinkers to be considered may include Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Bacon, Kant, Hegel, Nietzsche, and Heidegger, among others.
name: PSCI 4308
prereq_text: PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302 or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: History of Political Enquiry

desc: An examination of contemporary critiques and developments in modern science and social science. Thinkers to be considered may include Gadamer, Strauss, Oakeshott, Voegelin, Polanyi, Feuerabend, Heidegger, Kojeve, Schmitt, Foucault, and Derrida.
name: PSCI 4309
prereq_text: PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302 or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Contemporary Approaches to Political Enquiry

desc: An exploration of how ancient and modern conceptions of empire differ and how the pursuit of empire abroad can undermine good government at home in political theories including Thucydides, Plato, Aristotle and Xenophon.
name: PSCI 4311
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing and (PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302) or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Political Theories of Democracy and Empire I

desc: An exploration of how ancient and modern conceptions of empire differ and how the pursuit of empire abroad can undermine good government at home in political theories including Machiavelli, Hobbes, Hegel, Tocqueville and Heidegger.
name: PSCI 4312
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing, (PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302) and PSCI 4311 or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Political Theories of Democracy and Empire II

desc: Focus on the main currents of political thought in late and post-modernity; the relation between classical and modern philosophy, tyranny and technology, existentialism and nihilism. Thinkers such as Strauss, Kojeve, Nietzsche, Arendt, Heidegger and Schmitt may be read.
name: PSCI 4316
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing and (PSCI 2301 and PSCI 2302) or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Contemporary Political Theory I

desc: Continues and expands themes examined in PSCI 4316, and will include post-modernism, investigations of technology and globalization, terrorism and trans-humanism. Representative thinkers may include Derrida, Foucault, Deleuze, Bataille, Rosen, Voegelin, Habermas and Steiner.
name: PSCI 4317
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing; PSCI 2301, PSCI 2302 and PSCI4316, or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Contemporary Political Theory II

desc: Critical survey of concepts of political community, including the common good, justice, citizenship, leadership, democracy, and legitimacy, from ancient, modern, and contemporary political theory.
name: PSCI 4318
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Concepts of Political Community I

desc: A continued critical survey of concepts of political community, including the common good, justice, citizenship, statesmanship, democracy, and legitimacy, from ancient, modern, and contemporary political theory.
name: PSCI 4319
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Concepts of Political Community II

desc: Joint implications of contemporary science, technology and demographics for the design of public policy. The main emphasis of the course will be general patterns of change and design relating to public policy.
name: PSCI 4400
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Socio-Technical Change and Public Policy Design

desc: The interaction between social movements, legislatures and courts in formulating reproductive rights policy in Canada, the U.S. and Mexico.
name: PSCI 4403
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Reproductive Rights Policy in North America

desc: An examination of the emergence, development and collapse of institutional collective action in a broad historical framework, with attention to probable future scenarios for change. Readings are taken from anthropology, economics, history and empirical political theory.
name: PSCI 4404
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: The Design and Evolution of Public Institutions

desc: The content and creation of public policy. Focus on the explanation, prediction and design of policy. Perspectives and examples are drawn from a variety of frameworks and from both Canadian and non-Canadian contexts.
name: PSCI 4407
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2400, PSCI 2401, PSCI 3402, PSCI 3405, PSCI 3409 or PAPM 2000.
subject: PSCI
title: Public Policy: Content and Creation

desc: Theories and practice in the management of public affairs, including the environment and administration of the public sector, public opinion, and public communications.
name: PSCI 4408
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Public Affairs Management and Analysis

desc: An examination of the application of organization theory to policy implementation and evaluation for developing and transitional systems, with an emphasis on the role of cultural differences and divergent value systems in development management.
name: PSCI 4409
prereq_text: ECON 3508 and fourth-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program and registration in either the International Studies specialization or the Development Studies specialization or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Issues in Development Management

desc: How globalization affects women's involvement in politics and how they organize to conceptualize and pursue gender justice in official politics; grass roots projects and cultural transformations; ideology; stand-alone movements; and mixed-sex movements like nationalism and democratization.
name: PSCI 4500
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 2500, PSCI 3500, PSCI 3502.
subject: PSCI
title: Gender and Globalization

desc: The relationships between political transformation, identity-building, ethnicity, and gender politics in post-communist states, considered in comparison with select countries in Central and/or Western Europe.
name: PSCI 4501
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2500, PSCI 3208, PSCI 3209, PSCI 3500, PSCI 3502, PSCI 3704, or PSCI 3705.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Identity in Europe and the Russian Area

desc: The relationship between social forces and state structures at both the national and local levels in the USSR and the post-communist states.
name: PSCI 4502
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of EURR 2001, EURR 2002, GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 3208, PSCI 3209, PSCI 3704, PSCI 3705, or HIST 2600.
subject: PSCI
title: Post-Soviet States and Societies

desc: Examination of the Caucasus and Central Asia, from Chechnya to former Soviet republics of the region, Afghanistan and Chinese Turkestan. Interests of Russia, China, and the United States. Emphasis on underdevelopment, oil and gas, terrorism, Islam.
name: PSCI 4503
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Central Eurasia

desc: Examination of the South Caucasus (Azerbaijan, Georgia, Armenia), the Russian-held North Caucasus, including Chechnya, and relations with Iran. Emphasis on state and society, oil and gas, transregional communications, interests of western powers, ethnic relations.
name: PSCI 4504
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of the Caucasus and Caspian Basin

desc: A comparative analysis of processes of democratization. Diverse theoretical approaches to understanding the timing, causes, nature, and limitations of democratization. Examples from Europe and Russia, Latin America, Africa, and Asia.
name: PSCI 4505
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, GPOL 2500, PSCI 2102, PSCI 3100, PSCI 3204, PSCI 3208, PSCI 3209, PSCI 3500, PSCI 3502, PSCI 3704, or PSCI 3705.
subject: PSCI
title: Transitions to Democracy

desc: The efforts of women in North America to increase their political role through public activism, including in party organizations, social movements, legislatures, courts and the executive branch of government.
name: PSCI 4506
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Women and Politics in North America

desc: Selected topics in Balkan politics and society since the collapse of communism in 1989, focusing on the democratic transition and the EU accession process. The legacies of communist rule, democratization and the many national questions that still exist in the region.
name: PSCI 4507
prereq_text: fourth year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: The Balkans since 1989

desc: The foreign policies of the USSR and of Russia and selected other successor states, with special emphasis on the search for a new security order.
name: PSCI 4601
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of EURR 2001, EURR 2002, GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3107, PSCI 3208, PSCI 3209, PSCI 3600, PSCI 3603, PSCI 3703.
subject: PSCI
title: Foreign Policies of Soviet Successor States

desc: Various theoretical approaches to the study of the international political economy, with a focus on historical development and changing international structures.
name: PSCI 4603
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3600, or PSCI 3703.
subject: PSCI
title: Analysis of International Political Economy

desc: Contemporary problems and issues in the international political economy, with particular attention given to advanced industrial countries.
name: PSCI 4604
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3600, or PSCI 3703.
subject: PSCI
title: Selected Problems in International Political Economy

desc: Analysis of feminist approaches to international relations. Substantive issues include the role of women in war and militarization, the gender dimensions of global political economy and gender issues in international development.
name: PSCI 4605
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3500, PSCI 3303 or PSCI 3502.
subject: PSCI
title: Gender in International Relations

desc: The sources, trends and conflicting interpretations of the international roles of the United States since World War II. Foreign policy machinery and processes assessed in terms of the relative importance of perceptions, ideology, self-interest, and domestic and foreign pressures.
name: PSCI 4606
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2101, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3200, PSCI 3201, PSCI 3603, PSCI 3703.
subject: PSCI
title: American Foreign Policy

desc: A seminar examining the evolving relationship between Canada, the United States and Mexico, including political, economic, social, environmental and defence aspects.
name: PSCI 4607
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of North America

desc: A seminar focusing on issues related to the formation of supra-national decision-making structures in Europe.
name: PSCI 4608
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the department.
subject: PSCI
title: European Integration and European Security

desc: A seminar focusing on selected topics related to European integration in the post-World War II period.
name: PSCI 4609
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the department.
subject: PSCI
title: Selected Topics in European Integration Studies

desc: Seminar course that critically engages with innovative policies and instruments under the umbrella of ‘migration management’, and the proliferation of actors (states, international organizations, NGOs, private companies etc) involved in shaping and contributing to migration governance.
name: PSCI 4610
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the department.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Migration Management

desc: Research designs and statistical techniques primarily used in analyzing survey data. Selected topics may vary from year to year. Students doing Honours papers based on micro data are advised to take this course.
name: PSCI 4701
prereq_text: PSCI 2700 or (PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702), or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Intermediate Polimetrics for Micro Data

desc: Applied methods for policy, politics and public affairs. Primarily quantitative, but may have qualitative elements.
name: PSCI 4702
prereq_text: PSCI 2700 or (PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702), or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Intermediate Research Methods for Applied Political Science

desc: Close reading and analysis of theoretical research in the academic discipline of International Relations; may include analysis of methodology, normative and critical theory, and key theoretical concepts such as anarchy, sovereignty, power, inequality, coloniality, security, gender.
name: PSCI 4800
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3601, GPOL 3000.
subject: PSCI
title: Advanced International Relations Theory

desc: The application of international relations theories to specific global problems, both historical and contemporary. Selected issues may focus on one or more of conflict analysis, terrorism, the environment, migration, globalization and global civil society.
name: PSCI 4801
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3107, PSCI 3600, PSCI 3601, PSCI 3603, and PSCI 3703.
subject: PSCI
title: Selected Problems in Global Politics

desc: Focus on a particular theme related to the interactions of African states within the African subsystem and with other sectors in the international system.
name: PSCI 4802
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3100 or PSCI 3101.
subject: PSCI
title: International Politics of Africa

desc: The foreign policies of the East Asian powers, with special attention to China and Japan; an analysis of the domestic sources of policy, capabilities, interests, decision-making processes and foreign relations.
name: PSCI 4803
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2102, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3102, or PSCI 3103.
subject: PSCI
title: Foreign Policies of Major East Asian Powers

desc: An exploration of the organization of the global monetary and financial system. Issues covered include the relationship between global finance and the state, the politics of world money, and the problems associated with regulating internationally-active financial institutions.
name: PSCI 4805
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours or permission of the Department, and one of GPOL 1000, GPOL 1500, PSCI 2602, PSCI 3600, or PSCI 3703.
subject: PSCI
title: Political Economy of Global Money and Finance

desc: NATO as a political and military alliance. NATO and 21st century threats. Security roles for the E.U. Broader translatlantic security issues.
name: PSCI 4806
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of PSCI 2601, PSCI 3603, PSCI 3607, or GPOL 1500.
subject: PSCI
title: Transatlantic Security Issues

desc: How flows of people -- migrants, temporary workers and refugees -- challenge state sovereignty, citizenship and belonging. Emphasis on role of the state, supranational structures and international organizations in migration and mobility.
name: PSCI 4807
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Politics of Citizenship and Migration

desc: Global politics of transboundary environmental issues such as biodiversity protection, climate change and desertification. The perspectives, actors, institutions and economic relationships affecting international policy responses to these issues.
name: PSCI 4808
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department, and one of PSCI 2401, PSCI 2601, PSCI 2602, or PSCI 3801.
subject: PSCI
title: Global Environmental Politics

desc: A seminar on a selected contemporary topic in Political Science. Topic may vary from year to year and will be announced in advance of the registration period by the Department of Political Science.
name: PSCI 4809
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Honours Seminar on a Selected Topic in Political Science

desc: The relationship between international politics and the causes, consequences and responses to forced migration, internal displacement and refugees. Seminars and case studies are used to examine the evolution of the global refugee regime and the challenges it faces today.
name: PSCI 4817
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing or permission of the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: International Politics of Forced Migration

desc: Latin America's changing relations with states, international institutions and non-state actors in the Global North and South. Topics may include security, South-South cooperation, trade, investment and transnational migration and drug trafficking.
name: PSCI 4819
prereq_text: fourth year standing or permission from the Department.
subject: PSCI
title: Latin America and the World

desc: Tutorials or reading courses on selected topics in which seminars are not available.
name: PSCI 4901
prereq_text: permission of the Department and agreement of an instructor.
subject: PSCI
title: Tutorial in a Selected Field

desc: Tutorials or reading courses on selected topics in which seminars are not available.
name: PSCI 4902
prereq_text: permission of the Department and agreement of an instructor.
subject: PSCI
title: Tutorial in a Selected Field

desc: A seminar offered by The Washington Center, governed by Carleton regulations, and co-ordinated by Carleton's Department of Political Science.
name: PSCI 4905
prereq_text: selection to The Washington Center Internship Program and one of PSCI 2200, PSCI 3200, or PSCI 3210.
subject: PSCI
title: Washington Center Seminar I

desc: A seminar offered by The Washington Center, governed by Carleton regulations, and co-ordinated by Carleton's Department of Political Science.
name: PSCI 4906
prereq_text: selection to The Washington Center Internship Program and one of PSCI 2200, PSCI 3200, or PSCI 3210.
subject: PSCI
title: Washington Center Seminar II

desc: Individual research project resulting in a major essay, completed under the supervision of a faculty member and evaluated by both the supervisor and an appointed reader. Students are responsible for locating a faculty member willing to supervise the essay. Departmental regulations apply.
name: PSCI 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Political Science with a Political Science CGPA of 9.00 or better, or permission of the Supervisor of Undergraduate Studies.
subject: PSCI
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: Un travail de recherche dans le domaine de spécialisation d'un membre du département. Consulter le conseiller des études de premier cycle (Undergraduate supervisor) pour les sujets offerts.
name: PSCI 4909
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in the Political Science Mention : Français program.
subject: PSCI
title: Mémoire de recherche

desc: For students with no knowledge of Portuguese. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. Compulsory attendance.
name: PORT 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: PORT
title: First-Year Portuguese I

desc: Continuation of first-year Portuguese. Oral skills; basic reading and writing skills. Compulsory attendance.
name: PORT 1020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in PORT 1010 or permission of the School.
subject: PORT
title: First-Year Portuguese II

desc: For students with no knowledge of Portuguese. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: PORT 1110
prereq_text: None
subject: PORT
title: Intensive First-Year Portuguese

desc: Further study of Portuguese to reach a more advanced level of ability in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: PORT 2110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in PORT 1110 or PORT 1020, or permission of the School.
subject: PORT
title: Intensive Second-Year Portuguese

desc: Continuation of the study of Portuguese to reach a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: PORT 3110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in PORT 2110, or permission of the School.
subject: PORT
title: Intensive Third-Year Portuguese

desc: Advanced spoken and written Portuguese with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: PORT 4110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in PORT 3110, or permission of the School.
subject: PORT
title: Intensive Fourth-Year Portuguese

desc: A survey of topics associated with psychology's role as a natural science, including neuroscience, cognition, and learning.
name: PSYC 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology I

desc: A survey of topics associated with psychology's role as a social science, including social psychology, personality, clinical psychology, and mental health.
name: PSYC 1002
prereq_text: PSYC 1001.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology II

desc: A general introduction to research methodologies employed within contemporary psychology. Topics covered include research designs (experimental, quasi-experimental) and techniques (observations, surveys), basic descriptive statistics, and how to interpret and report research findings.
name: PSYC 2001
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Research Methods in Psychology

desc: A general introduction to statistical techniques employed within contemporary psychology. Topics include basic data analysis using descriptive and inferential statistics (t-tests, ANOVA, correlation, chi-square).
name: PSYC 2002
prereq_text: PSYC 2001.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Statistics in Psychology

desc: Introduction to social psychology, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. This course will explore how social situations may influence people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviours. Topics may include social cognition, self-knowledge, persuasion, interpersonal attraction, aggression, and prosocial behaviour.
name: PSYC 2100
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Social Psychology

desc: Introduction to health psychology, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. Using a multidisciplinary approach, topics may include the reciprocal interactions among physical health and illness, and psychological factors, including emotional well-being, coping and appraisal processes.
name: PSYC 2301
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Health Psychology

desc: Introduction to study of brain-behaviour relationships, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. Topics may include basic anatomy and physiology of the human nervous system, including sensory and motor functions. Neural basis of language, perception, emotion, learning, memory, decision making and social cognition.
name: PSYC 2307
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Human Neuropsychology I

desc: Introduction to forensic psychology, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. Topics covered may include development of offending, eyewitness testimony, victim studies, risk assessment, offender rehabilitation, offender classification, and police studies.
name: PSYC 2400
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Forensic Psychology

desc: Introduction to developmental psychology, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. Topics may include biological underpinnings and genetics, as well as selected aspects of language, cognitive, moral, emotional, and social development.
name: PSYC 2500
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Foundations of Developmental Psychology

desc: Introduction to the study of personality, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. Explores the factors that contribute to people’s personality and influence how they interact with others. Topics may include traits, motives, the self, physiology, the unconscious, relationships, stress and coping.
name: PSYC 2600
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to the Study of Personality

desc: Introduction to cognitive processes, including a survey of theories, issues, methods and findings. Topics covered may include pattern recognition, attention, imagery, learning (animal and human), memory, language, and thinking.
name: PSYC 2700
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology

desc: Introduction to the study of organizational psychology, including a survey of theories, issues, methods, and findings. Examines individual and group behaviour in organizational settings. Topics may include understanding work-related attitudes, behaviour, motivation, and stress, personnel selection, personality in the workplace, organizational justice, and leadership.
name: PSYC 2801
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Organizational Psychology I

desc: Techniques in data analysis, probability, sampling distributions, and procedures of estimation. Topics include classical, Bayesian, and distribution free approaches to hypothesis testing, linear regression and curve fitting, and analysis of variance methods in experimental design. Techniques are applied with appropriate statistical software (e.g., SPSS, Excel).
name: PSYC 3000
prereq_text: third-year standing, PSYC 2001, and PSYC 2002.
subject: PSYC
title: Design and Analysis in Psychological Research

desc: An introduction to theory and issues pertaining to psychological tests. Topics include the creation, assessment, scoring, and interpretation of results across different testing formats (questionnaires, surveys, structured interviews, performance-based measurements). Classical and modern techniques will be incorporated. Students will apply psychological testing theory through assignments.
name: PSYC 3001
prereq_text: PSYC 2001 and PSYC 2002.
subject: PSYC
title: Psychological Testing

desc: An introduction to theory and research in social psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3100
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2100, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Social Psychology (Honours Seminar)

desc: In-depth coverage of the social psychology of relations within and between large societal groups. Topics may include social identity, stereotyping, prejudice, and intergroup emotions, with emphasis on their role in promoting conflict and paths to pro-social intergroup relations.
name: PSYC 3104
prereq_text: PSYC 2100.
subject: PSYC
title: Intergroup Relations: The Psychology of Conflict and Violence

desc: A consideration of relationship science, with a focus on social psychological theory and empirical approaches to the study of close relationships such as dating and marital relationships, and friendships. Topics may include relationship initiation, relationship maintenance, and coping with the dissolution of relationships.
name: PSYC 3106
prereq_text: PSYC 2100.
subject: PSYC
title: Close Relationships

desc: An applied introduction to theory and research in health psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3300
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2301, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Health (Honours Seminar)

desc: How psychological processes influence outcomes across sport and performance environments. Topics may include self-confidence, goal-setting, arousal regulation, imagery, group dynamics, burnout, injury recovery, and how person and situational factors affect the pursuit of excellence.
name: PSYC 3301
prereq_text: one of PSYC 2100, PSYC 2301, PSYC 2500, PSYC 2600.
subject: PSYC
title: Sport and Performance Psychology

desc: A review of theoretical, historical, and empirical scholarship in positive psychology. Drawing widely across traditional sub-disciplines, content focuses on human strengths, well-being, resilience, and virtue to understand internal, external, and developmental contributors to health and happiness.
name: PSYC 3302
prereq_text: one of PSYC 2100, PSYC 2301, PSYC 2500, PSYC 2600.
subject: PSYC
title: Positive Psychology

desc: Cortical metabolism and research methods for assessment of cortical function, neuropsychological testing in the context of neurological, psychiatric and cognitive disorders caused by nervous system damage or genetic anomaly.
name: PSYC 3307
prereq_text: PSYC 2307.
subject: PSYC
title: Human Neuropsychology II

desc: An applied introduction to theory and research in forensic psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3400
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2400, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Forensic Psychology (Honours Seminar)

desc: A review of theoretical and empirical research in the study of criminal behaviour. Examination of offender assessment and classification, prevalence and types of offenders, and effectiveness of offender treatment including understanding specific populations of offenders such as Indigenous offenders, women offenders and violent offenders.
name: PSYC 3402
prereq_text: PSYC 2400.
subject: PSYC
title: Criminal Behaviour

desc: Neurobiological and social bases of drug and behavioural addictions. Contemporary theoretical approaches to addiction; approaches to current prevention and treatment.
name: PSYC 3403
prereq_text: one of PSYC 2301, PSYC 2307, PSYC 2400.
subject: PSYC
title: Addiction

desc: Critical examination of theory and empirical research in the area of police psychology. Topics covered may include police culture, police selection, police suicide, police personality, stress debriefing, fitness evaluations, police training, crisis negotiations, and investigative techniques.
name: PSYC 3404
prereq_text: PSYC 2400.
subject: PSYC
title: Police Psychology

desc: This course will explore motivational and emotional factors involved in human behaviour emphasizing various perspectives, theories, and research pertaining to physiological, cognitive, and social needs. Topics may include what factors motivates people, how motivation changes over time, and how one person can motivate another individual.
name: PSYC 3405
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Psychology of Motivation and Emotion

desc: An introduction to theory and research in developmental psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3500
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2500, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Developmental Psychology (Honours Seminar)

desc: An overview of childhood exceptionalities including intellectual differences, communication disorders, sensory and physical impairments, developmental and behavioural problems.
name: PSYC 3505
prereq_text: PSYC 2500.
subject: PSYC
title: Exceptional Children

desc: Human cognitive development is examined with a focus on memory, thinking and language through the life span. Topics may include perceptual and language development, emergent literacy, development of strategies and development of reading and arithmetic skills.
name: PSYC 3506
prereq_text: PSYC 2500 or PSYC 2700.
subject: PSYC
title: Cognitive Development

desc: Development of the individual with a focus on social cognition and social behaviour. Topics may include the role of temperament in development, parental roles, siblings and peers in social/emotional development, development of prosocial and aggressive behaviour, moral development and development of self and other understanding.
name: PSYC 3507
prereq_text: PSYC 2500.
subject: PSYC
title: Social Development

desc: Milestones associated with the development of grammatical,pragmatic and metalinguistic competence from birth to about age ten, and the relative contributions of the environment, cognitive development and inborn knowledge to this development.
name: PSYC 3508
prereq_text: LALS 1000 or LALS 1001 or LING 1001 or PSYC 2700 and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: PSYC
title: Child Language

desc: The physical, cognitive, social and moral development of adolescents and emerging adults in multiple contexts including family, peers, media and culture. Major theories and contemporary issues and concerns.
name: PSYC 3509
prereq_text: PSYC 2500.
subject: PSYC
title: Adolescence and Emerging Adulthood

desc: An introduction to theory and research in personality psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3600
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2600, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Personality (Honours Seminar)

desc: An examination of theories and research regarding the similarities and differences in women's and men's psychological processes. Psychological issues relevant to women (e.g., women's health concerns, women's sexuality, violence toward women and children) will be examined as well as feminist and traditional research methods.
name: PSYC 3603
prereq_text: one of PSYC 2100, PSYC 2500, PSYC 2600.
subject: PSYC
title: Psychology of Women

desc: History of the concept of mental illness. Theory and selected research dealing with the nature and etiology of mental illness.
name: PSYC 3604
prereq_text: PSYC 2301, PSYC 2500 or PSYC 2600.
subject: PSYC
title: Clinical Psychology and Mental Illness

desc: An introduction to theory and research in cognitive psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3700
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2700, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Cognition (Honours Seminar)

desc: Introduction to theory, research methods and principles associated with the study of perceptual processes. Examples of how perceptual principles can be applied to solve problems in communications, transportation, medicine, industrial design, manufacturing, marketing, food and beverage industries (flavoring, blending, and scenting, etc.).
name: PSYC 3702
prereq_text: PSYC 1001 and PSYC 1002.
subject: PSYC
title: Perception

desc: Introduction to adult language processing and neurolinguistics. Psychological processes underlying speech production and perception, word recognition and sentence processing. Biological foundation and neuro-cognitive mechanisms of language. Experimental techniques and methodologies of current psycholinguistic studies.
name: PSYC 3709
prereq_text: LALS 1000 or LALS 1001 or LING 1001 or PSYC 2700 and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
subject: PSYC
title: Language Processing and the Brain

desc: Theoretical foundation, philosophy and practical application of techniques for analyzing from a psychological perspective how people interact with designed environments. A major goal is to determine how these environments should be designed to suit human capabilities.
name: PSYC 3710
prereq_text: PSYC 2001 and PSYC 2002.
subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Human Factors

desc: Advanced coverage of the current theory and practices in Organizational Psychology. Selected topics may include workplace socialization, job attitudes, deviant work behaviours, leadership, teams and group dynamics, work-related stress and health, and organizational change and development.
name: PSYC 3801
prereq_text: PSYC 2801.
subject: PSYC
title: Organizational Psychology II

desc: Within the context of an active learning environment, examines traditional and current models in career psychology. Topics may include the concepts of change and transitions, self-assessments, vocational psychology, and workplace onboarding. Students will examine their personal and professional transition from university to the work world.
name: PSYC 3802
prereq_text: third or fourth year standing in Psychology.
subject: PSYC
title: Transition to Career

desc: An introduction to theory and research in organizational psychology. Activities include reading and assessing the appropriate literature, designing studies and experiments, conducting data analyses, and producing APA style reports. Research ethics and graduate studies are also addressed. Taught in preparation of fourth year thesis.
name: PSYC 3805
prereq_text: PSYC 2001, PSYC 2002, PSYC 2801, third-year Honours standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 9.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Organizational Psychology (Honours Seminar)

desc: Experiential learning in psychology via field placement. Students pursue personal learning outcomes focused on the application of psychology within the community. Assignments promote ongoing reflection and the sharing of what has been learned with colleagues.
name: PSYC 3901
prereq_text: Third- or fourth-year standing in Psychology with a CGPA of 7.0 or higher in the major and permission of the Department.
subject: PSYC
title: Practicum in Psychology

prereq_text: None

name: PSYC 4001
prereq_text: each section will have its own.
subject: PSYC
title: Special Topics in Psychology

desc: An overview of the evolution of psychology, with an emphasis on psychology as a specialized area of knowledge and practice in the late-nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Topics covered may include the history of a particular period, content area, or cultural context.
name: PSYC 4003
prereq_text: third or fourth-year standing in a Psychology Honours program.
subject: PSYC
title: Origins of Modern Psychology

desc: In-depth exploration of theoretical and empirical issues related to selected topics in Social psychology. The specific content for this course will vary from year to year.
name: PSYC 4100
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and PSYC 2100.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Social Psychology

desc: In-depth exploration of theoretical and empirical issues related to selected topics in health psychology. The specific content for this course will vary from year to year.
name: PSYC 4301
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and PSYC 2301.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Health Psychology

desc: An examination of theory, research, and the practice of approaches to support peers and their well-being. Students will apply the concepts learned during the seminars in field placements.
name: PSYC 4330
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Psychology, Mental Health and Well-Being Stream.
subject: PSYC
title: Community Mental Health and Well-Being

desc: An advanced seminar on clinical psychology and mental health. Students will learn about frequently used treatment modalities and common factors across treatments. Research methodology and recent advances dealing with a variety of common mental disorders will also be reviewed and discussed.
name: PSYC 4333
prereq_text: fourth-year Honours standing in Psychology and PSYC 3604.
subject: PSYC
title: Clinical Psychology: Assessment and Intervention

desc: In-depth exploration of theoretical and empirical issues related to selected topics in Forensic psychology. The specific content for this course will vary from year to year.
name: PSYC 4400
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and PSYC 2400.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Forensic Psychology

desc: Feminist and social learning approaches to the assessment and treatment of female offenders. Theories and research relevant to selected patterns of law breaking and selected female offender types.
name: PSYC 4403
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing and PSYC 3402.
subject: PSYC
title: Female Offenders

name: PSYC 4404
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing, PSYC 2400, and PSYC 3402.
subject: PSYC
title: Sex Offenders

desc: This course will explore psychological factors affecting child witnesses and victims as they interact within the criminal justice system. The course will survey the intersection of psychology and law within the areas of eyewitness memory, police procedures, and the criminal justice system.
name: PSYC 4410
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, and PSYC 2400 or PSYC 2500.
subject: PSYC
title: Children and the Law

desc: In-depth exploration of theoretical and empirical issues related to selected topics in developmental psychology. The specific content for this course will vary from year to year.
name: PSYC 4500
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, and one of PSYC 3500, PSYC 3505, PSYC 3506, PSYC 3507.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Developmental Psychology

name: PSYC 4600
prereq_text: fourth-year standing and PSYC 2600.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Personality Psychology

desc: In-depth exploration of theoretical and empirical issues related to selected topics in cognitive psychology. The specific content for this course will vary from year to year.
name: PSYC 4700
prereq_text: fourth-year standing, and PSYC 2700.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Cognitive Psychology

desc: The application of psychological knowledge to enhance employee physical and mental health, safety and well-being, and more broadly, to enrich organizational life. Students will be able to learn and analyze critically the relevant methodological, theoretical, and empirical Occupational Health Psychology literature.
name: PSYC 4801
prereq_text: third or fourth-year standing and one of PSYC 2100, PSYC 2301, PSYC 2801.
subject: PSYC
title: Occupational Health Psychology

prereq_text: fourth-year standing and PSYC 2801.
subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Topics in Organizational Psychology

subject: PSYC
title: Independent Study

subject: PSYC
title: Independent Study

subject: PSYC

subject: PSYC

They must also present a research poster at the Psychology Undergraduate Research Event. Students select an area of psychological research of interest to them.

prereq_text: fourth-year standing in B.A (Honours) in Psychology, and PSYC 3000.

desc: The processes of policy-making, implementation and evaluation. Forces that shape policy deliberations and alternative tools for managing policy action and policy evaluation. Theoretical approaches to understanding the origins of policy, and methods by which programs are designed and assessed.
name: PAPM 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: PAPM
title: Policy: Analysis, Implementation, and Evaluation

desc: Theoretical, philosophical and ethical foundations for the study of public affairs and policy management. Drawing from classic and contemporary texts in political philosophy and theory, students consider issues relating to the nature of democracy, civic society and social organizations, the public, public affairs, public interest.
name: PAPM 2001
prereq_text: None
subject: PAPM
title: Foundations of Public Policy: Political Thought

desc: Theoretical, philosophical and ethical foundations for the study of public affairs and policy management. Drawing from classic and contemporary texts in economic philosophy and theory, students consider issues relating to the nature of democracy, civic society and social organizations, the public, public affairs, public interest.
name: PAPM 2002
prereq_text: None
subject: PAPM
title: Foundations of Public Policy: Economic Thought

desc: An examination of the research strategies and techniques relevant to policy analysis and evaluation. Using the case study method, the role of research and research organizations in the policy process is discussed. The issue of ethical dilemmas in policy research is also considered.
name: PAPM 3000
prereq_text: PSCI 2701 and PSCI 2702, or COMM 2001, or ECON 2201 and ECON 2202 and Good Standing in the Bachelor of Public Affairs and Policy Management program.
subject: PAPM
title: Policy Research

name: PAPM 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: PAPM
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Policy workshop focusing on the application of public affairs analysis to develop problem solving and research skills. Seminar is policy-focused and organized by area of Specialization in the program. Students, working in small groups, examine concrete policy problems, actual or simulated, in specific institutional contexts.
name: PAPM 4000
prereq_text: PAPM 3000 and Good Standing in the Bachelor of Public Affairs and Policy Management program.
subject: PAPM
title: Capstone Seminar in Public Affairs and Policy Management

desc: Students address a specific policy problem or problems, in interaction with local, national or international policy experts or practitioners. Emphasis on policy analysis, research, and communication skills.
name: PAPM 4099
prereq_text: None
subject: PAPM
title: Policy Seminar

desc: Analysis of selected issues in public affairs and policy management not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics will vary from year to year. Students should consult with the College regarding the topic offered.
name: PAPM 4100
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program or permission of the Kroeger College.
subject: PAPM
title: Special Topics in Public Affairs and Policy Management

desc: Individual research project resulting in a major essay, completed under the supervision of a faculty member and evaluated by both the supervisor and an appointed reader. Students are responsible for locating a faculty member willing to supervise the essay. Departmental regulations apply.
name: PAPM 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Public Affairs and Policy Management program with a Major CGPA or 9.0 or better, or permission of the Director of the Public Affairs and Policy Management program.
subject: PAPM
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: An introduction to the theoretical, constitutional and practical basis of public administration in Nunavut. Normally offered in Nunavut.
name: PADM 1501
prereq_text: enrolment in the Certificate for Nunavut Public Service Studies.
subject: PADM
title: Public Administration in Nunavut

desc: Introduction to managing the relationship between the territorial and federal governments, with examples drawn from Nunavut, the Northwest Territories and Yukon practices. Normally offered in Nunavut.
name: PADM 1502
prereq_text: enrolment in the Certificate for Nunavut Public Service Studies and successful completion of PSCI 1002 and PADM 1501.
subject: PADM
title: Management of Federal-Territorial Relations

desc: Consideration of constraints and opportunities of public-sector management, including government at all levels and para-statal organizations. Topics may include the accountability regimes, features of the human resource management context, administration of information and material resources, responsibilities and relationships of managers towards citizens.
name: PADM 3105
prereq_text: third-year standing in the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Management in the Public Sector

desc: Policy and policy-making as they pertain to gender relations within the state and in society. The negative and positive effects of public policy on gender relations in the family and the labour market.
name: PADM 4213
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Gender and Public Policy

desc: Selected aspects of the expenditure and revenue budget and budgetary process at all levels of government. Critical review of actual budgets and budgetary processes.
name: PADM 4214
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Budgetary Policy in the Public Sector

desc: Political, economic, legal, and organizational theories of regulation in the Canadian and comparative context. Processes and consequences of regulatory practice in selected Canadian public policy fields.
name: PADM 4220
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Regulation and Public Policy

desc: Canadian health policies and programs set in a comparative political-economic and institutional context.
name: PADM 4221
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Health Policy in Canada

desc: Canadian policies and programs on aboriginal peoples and aboriginal peoples' own policies as nations set in a comparative political-economic and institutional context.
name: PADM 4224
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Aboriginal Policy

desc: Canadian multilateral and regional trade policies and programs set in a comparative political-economic and institutional context.
name: PADM 4225
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Trade Policy

desc: Canadian tax policies set in a comparative political-economic and institutional context.
name: PADM 4226
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Tax Policy

desc: Canadian policies and programs in education set in a comparative political-economic and institutional context.
name: PADM 4227
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Education Policy

desc: The nature and historical development of social programs in capitalist countries, with particular focus on Canada. The course will concentrate on developing a critical understanding of the social forces shaping these programs.
name: PADM 4228
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Social Policy

desc: The development and application of ethical theories to examine not simply what governments could do, but what they should do on the basis of consequences, principles, or motivations. Applications could include policies affecting climate change, inequality, end of life, privacy, use of force.
name: PADM 4230
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Ethics for Public Policy

desc: Development and application of ethical theories to examine what governments should do, taking into account the outcomes, principles, or motivations of public policies and policy-making. Applications could include policies affecting climate change, income inequality, end of life, privacy, restitution, use of force.
name: PADM 4320
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Ethics for Public Policy

desc: Theory and practice regarding governmental policies for science and technology, and the use of scientific knowledge in the policy and regulatory processes of government. Concerns regarding the ethical issues and the transparency of science in government.
name: PADM 4611
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Science and Technology Policies

desc: An examination of sustainable production theory and key drivers, barriers and opportunities influencing innovation in industrial systems and processes. The relationship of public policies and industry practices are explored in a number of sectors.
name: PADM 4612
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Industrial Policy, Innovation and Sustainable Production

desc: The dilemmas associated with energy policy in Canada. Economic, social and environmental dimensions of energy decision making; Canadian issues within the contexts of a changing international scene and long term energy transitions.
name: PADM 4615
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Politics and Policy of Energy in Canada

desc: Canadian environmental policies and programs in a comparative political-economic and institutional context.
name: PADM 4616
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Environmental Policy

desc: Debates regarding health policy in the developing world, in the context of the global health sector reform movement, trade and intellectual property regimes, and strategies of corporate and NGO actors. Issues of gender, class and the determinants of health.
name: PADM 4817
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Public Policy and Administration Specialization of the B.P.A.P.M. program.
subject: PADM
title: Health Policy in Developing Countries

desc: Elementary study of the language required for studying a religious tradition.
name: RELI 1010
prereq_text: Major/Minor in Religion or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Elementary Language Tutorial

desc: A survey of the history, beliefs and practices of these major religious traditions.
name: RELI 1710
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Judaism, Christianity, Islam

desc: A survey of the history, beliefs, and practices of South and East Asian religious traditions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Daoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.
name: RELI 1712
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religions of South and East Asia

desc: The variety of religious experiences and their interpretations: myth, literature, art and religious doctrine. Topics include time, self, the other, journey and wisdom. Examples ranging from shamanistic experience to the abstractions of Buddhist philosophy.
name: RELI 1731
prereq_text: restricted to students registered in the Bachelor of Humanities & Religion program.
subject: RELI
title: Varieties of Religious Experience

desc: An introduction to major issues in the study of religion in global contexts, drawing on historical and contemporary examples.
name: RELI 1741
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Global Religions: Identity and Community

desc: Intermediate study of the language required for studying a religious tradition. Restricted to students registered in a Religion program.
name: RELI 2010
prereq_text: RELI 1902 or RELI 1010 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Intermediate Language Tutorial

desc: The history of Judaism and the Jewish people from the Second Temple until the present day. The organization, basic beliefs, social and ethical practices of the Jews and Judaism.
name: RELI 2110
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Judaism

desc: Introduces the Hebrew Bible within historical and religious frameworks. All texts are in English.
name: RELI 2121
prereq_text: RELI 1710 or RELI 1000 or RELI 2110 or RELI 2508 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Hebrew Bible

desc: An introduction to the history, beliefs, traditions, practices, and diversity of Christianity from its beginnings to the present day.
name: RELI 2200
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Christianity

desc: Introduction to the critical study of the writings of the New Testament with discussion of their Hellenistic and Jewish background, the historical Jesus, Paul and his letters, and historical and sociological explanations for the rise of the early church and interpretation of its writings.
name: RELI 2220
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Early Christianity

desc: Survey of recent and current Christian movements around the world, both by region and thematically, with emphasis on institutions and networks that connect Christian communities across national boundaries. Special consideration is given to the cultural and political capacities of such Christian communities and networks.
name: RELI 2230
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Global Christianity

desc: The study of Muslim religious tradition and investigation of its organization, basic beliefs, social and ethical principles and practices.
name: RELI 2310
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Islam

name: RELI 2330
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: RELI
title: The Qur'an

name: RELI 2350
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Classical Islamic Thought

desc: A survey of Muslim ethical writings on the pursuit of virtue and the good life, human nature, individual agency, and moral responsibility.
name: RELI 2355
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Islamic Ethics
