name: RELI 2410
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Buddhism

desc: Basic beliefs, practices, and social structures of the Hindu tradition as reflected in Hindu scriptures, myths and symbols, and philosophical schools.
name: RELI 2510
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Hinduism

desc: Myths and symbols of the Indian tradition expressed in Hindu and Buddhist art. Hindu theories of beauty and the interface of the arts with the spiritual traditions of India.
name: RELI 2515
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: RELI
title: Religion and Aesthetics in India

desc: An exploration of women and religion in historical and contemporary contexts.
name: RELI 2535
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religion and Gender

desc: Survey of the origins, development, and diffusion of Chinese religious traditions, including Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism and popular religion(s).
name: RELI 2600
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religions of China

desc: The early history, literature and ideas of Judaism, Christianity and Islam from 200 BCE to 750 CE.
name: RELI 2710
prereq_text: restricted to students in the Bachelor of Humanities & Religion program.
subject: RELI
title: Maccabees to Muhammad

desc: Major devotional movements in Hinduism and Christianity, focusing on the love of the divine and philosophical accounts of these ideas over time.
name: RELI 2711
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Love and Its Myths

desc: An historical survey emphasizing the interactions of various religious traditions in Canada, including indigenous religions, Christian missionary and colonial traditions, immigrant and global diaspora religions.
name: RELI 2712
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religious Diversity of Canada

desc: An historical and functional study of mystical experience in its religious context, relying on examples from selected traditions such as the Christian, Buddhist, Hindu, Jewish and Muslim.
name: RELI 2713
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Mystical and Contemplative Traditions

desc: Religions of Inuit, First Nations and Métis peoples, past and present. Considerations include concepts of tradition, syncretism and “creative ritual.” Primary sources may include textual, visual and oral materials. Course may include fieldwork, as well as in-class presentations by community elders.
name: RELI 2720
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Indigenous Religions of Canada

desc: The meaning of death and afterlife in some religious traditions and secular philosophies with emphasis on the Hindu teaching of the immortal soul; the Hebraic idea of collective survival; the Christian doctrine of resurrection of the body; the Buddhist conception of no-soul and nirvana.
name: RELI 2732
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Death and Afterlife

desc: A study of religion in ancient Greece.
name: RELI 2735
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Greek Religion

desc: Cross-cultural survey of religious institutions, focusing on theories and methodologies in the study of religion. Topics may include myth, totemism, cults, ritual, belief systems, altered states of consciousness, new religious and/or new age movements and the relationship of religion with other social institutions and processes.
name: RELI 2736
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religion and Society

desc: A study of religion in ancient Rome.
name: RELI 2737
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Roman Religion

desc: A study of philosophical issues arising from religion. Topics may include: arguments for and against the existence of God, religious experience, death and the afterlife, miracles, God and evil, the relationship between religion and science, and the relationship between religion and ethics.
name: RELI 2738
prereq_text: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
subject: RELI
title: Philosophy of Religion

desc: In this Inquiry course, students will be introduced to a specific topic in Religious Studies (e.g., ritual, narrative, space) and develop a research project related to it. Focus on fostering intellectual curiosity and developing practical skills of reading, writing and research fundamentals.
name: RELI 2741
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Big Questions in Religious Studies

desc: An examination of the basic beliefs, practices, and social structures of the Sikh tradition as reflected in Sikh scriptures, history and philosophical schools.
name: RELI 2750
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Sikhism

desc: This course illuminates a recent category of “World Religions” by examining cases from all five continents, as well as in diaspora (e.g., Brazilian Candomblé, Roma/Sinti religion). Considerations include the study of minority religions, religion in oral cultures, myth & ritual studies, colonialism, globalization.
name: RELI 2800
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Indigenous Traditions

desc: Examination of interactions between religion and popular culture in the form of music, film, video games, literature, and other media. Topic and focus will vary year to year; please check departmental website for information. May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
name: RELI 2810
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Special Topics in Religion and Popular Culture

desc: Attitudes in the major world religions to nature and the environment and recent responses by religious traditions to ecological degradation and crisis. Includes examination of religious sensibilities expressed in environmentalism.
name: RELI 2811
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religions and the Environment

desc: Content of this course may vary from year to year. Please check departmental website for information on the topic.
name: RELI 2840
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Topics in Religion

desc: This course examines some aspect of the intersection between religion(s) and public life, broadly construed, including social, economic, political, institutional aspects, either in the contemporary world or focused on a particular historical period.
name: RELI 3000
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Religion and Public Life

desc: Advanced study of the language required for studying a religious tradition.
name: RELI 3010
prereq_text: RELI 2902 (no longer offered) or RELI 2010 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Advanced Language Tutorial

desc: Discussion of the embodiment of religious ideas in life, law, and practice, for example in food consumption, gender ideologies, sexuality, adornment, and death rituals. Topic will vary year to year; please check departmental website for information. May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
name: RELI 3101
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Special Topics in Religions and the Body

desc: An examination of the experiences of different Jewish communities before, during, and after the Holocaust. Issues to be discussed include anti-Semitism, relations with non-Jewish neighbours, perpetrator motivation, local collaboration, resistance, postwar trials and memory.
name: RELI 3140
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Holocaust Encounters

desc: A history of the Protestant and Catholic Reformations of the sixteenth century, with emphasis on the theological disputes of the protagonists and the impact of these disputes on the social, political and cultural developments of the era.
name: RELI 3220
prereq_text: 0.5 credit at the 2000-level in HIST or third-year standing.
subject: RELI
title: Reformation Europe

desc: A study of the historical records of the life of Jesus, the methods used to interpret them, and the resulting images of Jesus.
name: RELI 3230
prereq_text: RELI 2207 or RELI 2220 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Jesus of Nazareth

desc: The social, religious, and historical context of Paul, the communities he founded, and the letters he wrote to them.
name: RELI 3231
prereq_text: RELI 2207 or RELI 2220 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Paul of Tarsus

desc: An historical survey of key Christian thought and practices at the individual and collective level. Topics may include self-discipline, body discipline, monastic discipline, church discipline and social discipline.
name: RELI 3232
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Christian Discipline

desc: The development of some protestant Christianities in relation to material factors, such as colonialism, industrial or consumer capitalism, imperialism, and in relation to major ideological trends, such as nationalism, economic or political liberalism and atheism.
name: RELI 3250
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Evangelical Christianity in Social-Historical Perspective

desc: An examination of the integral role music plays in religion and sacred ritual in different world cultures and religions. Through various case studies, the course broadly considers how sacred soundscapes shape people’s worldviews, identities, and experiences within and outside of their communities.
name: RELI 3301
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: RELI
title: Music and Religion

desc: An introduction to the main practical and theoretical dimensions of Islam's mystical tradition as seen through the life and work of its key representatives.
name: RELI 3330
prereq_text: RELI 2710 or RELI 2713 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Sufism

desc: Overview of the life and teaching of the Prophet Muhammad, and the most salient motifs and features of Muslim devotion to him.
name: RELI 3340
prereq_text: RELI 1710 or RELI 2310 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: The Life and Image of Muhammad

desc: A focus on post-Qur'anic Islamic literature and interpretive traditions (e.g. tafsir, hadith); texts and topics will vary from year to year; please check departmental website for information. May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
name: RELI 3360
prereq_text: RELI 2310 or RELI 2330.
subject: RELI
title: Special Topics in Islamic Texts & Narratives

desc: The development of early Buddhist philosophy, psychology and practice with emphasis on the Pali Canon and its commentators.
name: RELI 3420
prereq_text: RELI 2106 or RELI 2410 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Early Buddhism

desc: The rise of the Mahayana and the dissemination and development of Buddhist thought and practice outside of India.
name: RELI 3422
prereq_text: RELI 2106 or RELI 2410 or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Buddhism Beyond India

desc: A historical survey of Hinduism from the Vedic era to the development of devotional Hinduism. Vedic religion and developments in early Hindu Philosophy and sectarian Hinduism.
name: RELI 3520
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Early Hinduism

desc: A survey of major developments in Hinduism since the period of colonial British rule. The development of “reform” Hinduism in the 18th and 19th centuries, and the emergence of Hindu nationalist movements in the 20th century.
name: RELI 3522
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Modern Hinduism

desc: A thematic course that examines putative cases of “religion and violence” from a range of world traditions, but also interrogates aspects of the “religion and violence” rubric itself.
name: RELI 3722
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Religion and Violence

desc: A study of period or theme in the art and archaeology of Ancient Greece. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: RELI 3732
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.
subject: RELI
title: Studies in Greek Art

desc: A study of a period or theme in the art and archaeology of the ancient Romans. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: RELI 3733
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.
subject: RELI
title: Studies in Roman Art

desc: Examination of reflection on the nature and origin of religion from the ancient world up to key figures and founders of the discipline of the systematic, critical, and scientific study of religion in the nineteenth and early twentieth century.
name: RELI 3741
prereq_text: second-year standing.
subject: RELI
title: Classical Approaches to Religion

desc: Content of this course may vary from year to year. Please check departmental website for information on the topic.
name: RELI 3840
prereq_text: None
subject: RELI
title: Topics in Religion

desc: This travel course explores religion in its historical and/or contemporary contexts in a particular geographic locale. Travel destinations, religious traditions studied, course content, and themes vary from year to year.
name: RELI 3850
prereq_text: third year standing and 1.0 credit of study in the area related to the year's topic religion, and permission of the department. Permission of the department is required to repeat this course.
subject: RELI
title: Topics in the Study of Religion Abroad

desc: This course engages with the real world implications of late twentieth and twenty-first century scholarship on religion with a focus on applied learning and developing employable skills that facilitate transition from academia to a career.
name: RELI 4741
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Contemporary Issues in the Study of Religion

desc: A tutorial on a topic in religious studies. Contents of the tutorial to be arranged with the supervising faculty member.
name: RELI 4840
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Tutorial

desc: Content of this course may vary from year to year. Please consult the departmental website for information on the topic.
name: RELI 4850
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Seminar in the Study of Religion

desc: Honours research paper (approx. 40 pages) is due on the last day of winter term classes. Written proposal due to the Proposal Board on the first day of fall term classes. Please consult department document for full requirements and information.
name: RELI 4990
prereq_text: 10.0 CGPA and fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
subject: RELI
title: Honours Research Essay

desc: For students with no knowledge of Russian. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: RUSS
title: First-Year Russian I

desc: Continuation of first-year Russian. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 1020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 1010, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: First-Year Russian II

desc: For students with no knowledge of Russian. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 1110
prereq_text: None
subject: RUSS
title: Intensive First-Year Russian

desc: Further study of Russian to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 2010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 1020 or RUSS 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian I

desc: Continuation of second-year Russian. Further study of Russian to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 2020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 2010, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian II

desc: Further study of Russian to reach a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 3010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 2020, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian I

desc: For students who have attained Russian language proficiency in informal settings or who completed elementary school in a Russian speaking country. The course builds literacy skills, formalizes grammar awareness, and develops writing and reading language skills in a formal academic setting.
name: RUSS 3015
prereq_text: Permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Russian for Heritage Speakers I

desc: Continuation of third-year Russian. Progress toward a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 3020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 3010, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian II

desc: Further study of Russian to enhance students’ literacy skills and formalize grammar awareness in a formal academic setting. Emphasis on the use of formal and academic language in oral and written form; further development of writing and reading skills.
name: RUSS 3025
prereq_text: RUSS 3015 or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Russian for Heritage Speakers II

desc: Advanced spoken and written Russian with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 4010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 3020, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Fourth-Year Russian I

desc: Continuation of fourth-year Russian. Advanced spoken and written Russian with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 4020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in RUSS 4010, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Fourth-Year Russian II

desc: Russian language skills for translation of modern history and social science texts from Russian into English, with an emphasis on syntax. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 4115
prereq_text: permission of the School. Not open to students with native-like Russian proficiency.
subject: RUSS
title: Russian for Social Studies

desc: Russian language skills for conducting research in modern history and social sciences, with an emphasis on practice and theory of translation from Russian into English. Compulsory attendance.
name: RUSS 4120
prereq_text: grade of C in RUSS 4115, or permission of the School. Not open to students with native-like Russian proficiency.
subject: RUSS
title: Russian for Research

desc: Research in a topic in Russian language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: RUSS 4900
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing and enrolment in the Minor in Russian, grade of C or higher in RUSS 3020 or equivalent, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Independent Study

desc: Research in a topic in Russian language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: RUSS 4901
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing and enrolment in the Minor in Russian, grade of C or higher in RUSS 3020, or equivalent, or permission of the School.
subject: RUSS
title: Independent Study

desc: While sexuality is often considered the most private and 'natural' of personal concerns, it is saturated with issues of social power, historical change, and public politics. This course offers a critical introduction to interdisciplinary studies of sexuality, focusing on history, theory, and cultural practice.
name: SXST 2101
prereq_text: second-year standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: SXST
title: Sexuality Studies: A Critical Introduction

desc: Historical and contemporary analysis of surveillance, security, and regulation of sexuality, race, class, and gender. Students will critically examine how ‘subversives’ were created through discourse and administrative logics such as policy and law.
name: SXST 2102
prereq_text: second year standing.
subject: SXST
title: Sexuality, Gender, and Security

desc: Exploration of ways that embodied categories of sex and gender, as well as desire are mediated through mainstream and alternative discourses of disability. Topics may include: crip theory, mental health issues, and LGBTQ sexualities.
name: SXST 3103
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: SXST
title: Sexuality and Disability

desc: Students analyze sex, gender and sexuality as power relations within, and between nation-states comprising the Global North and South, as well as new knowledge created through national border crossings. Topics may include: Orientialism, colonialization, and diasporic identities.
name: SXST 3104
prereq_text: third-year standing and SXST 2101.
subject: SXST
title: Transnational Sexualities

desc: Examination of the archival turn in historical and theoretical perspective with an emphasis on sexuality, race, and gender as subjectivities in queer, trans, and colonial archives.
name: SXST 3106
prereq_text: third-year standing.
subject: SXST
title: Queer(ing) Archives

desc: A study of selected issues in sexuality studies considered from an interdisciplinary perspective. The course may focus on any one, or combination of, sexuality studies in relation to history, theory, and/or cultural practice.
name: SXST 4101
prereq_text: SXST 2101 and fourth-year standing.
subject: SXST
title: Interdisciplinary Studies of Sexuality

desc: A critical approach to gender and sexuality by engaging in key debates and texts in the field of queer theory and studies.
name: SXST 4102
prereq_text: SXST 2101 and fourth-year standing.
subject: SXST
title: Queer Theory

desc: This seminar analyzes critically the existence and regulation of non-normative sexual attitudes, behaviours and practices. Topics may include: non-monogamy, sadomasochism, pornography.
name: SXST 4103
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SXST
title: Politics of Kink

desc: An interdisciplinary and intersectional approach to issues in the area of Sexuality Studies focusing on socio-economic relations (e.g. class location, consumption) and the ways they mediate sex, gender, and sexual subject formation and governance. SXST 4101.
name: SXST 4104
prereq_text: fourth year standing.
subject: SXST
title: Sexuality and Political Economy

desc: Students engage with debates within sexuality studies and transgender studies regarding the interwoven relationships between gender, race, indigeneity, desire, bodies and ecological politics. Topics may include: climate change, gendered and sexualized landscapes, and speciesism.
name: SXST 4105
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or by permission of the department.
subject: SXST
title: Queer Ecologies

desc: Critical examination of affective economies made in and through LGBTQ cultural production. Drawing from feminist, queer, trans and queer of colour critique, students will consider how queer affect, sentiment and emotions uniquely circulate in art and aesthetic objects.
name: SXST 4106
prereq_text: fourth-year standing or permission of the Institute.
subject: SXST
title: Queer Aesthetics: Affect, Cultural Production, Sexuality

desc: Explores definitions of social welfare and the structure of the Canadian welfare state; evolution and devolution of the welfare state in Canada; social welfare and its relationship to social work, social change, and social justice.
name: SOWK 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Welfare

desc: Introduction to the profession of social work; evolution of the social work profession in Canada; social work knowledge,values and skills. Explores professional and regulatory social work bodies and international linkages.
name: SOWK 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Work

desc: Evolution of structural social work, theories and critiques of structural social work and contemporary issues and challenges.
name: SOWK 2001
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002. For Bachelor of Social Work students only.
subject: SOWK
title: Structural Analysis and Social Work

desc: Focuses on knowledge and skills for ethical decision-making in social work; understanding social work values and ethics, accountability and the professional use of self.
name: SOWK 2005
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002. For Bachelor of Social Work students only.
subject: SOWK
title: Values and Ethics for Social Work

desc: Political economic theories as lenses for structural analysis of social problems and policies affecting social work practice in Canada.
name: SOWK 2100
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002 or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: The Political Economy of the Social Welfare State

desc: Understand and develop skills required for working with individuals and families; active listening; use of self; engagement; rapport-building; interviewing and interventions; empathy; interpersonal and professional collaboration; supervision.
name: SOWK 2202
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002. For Bachelor of Social Work students only.
subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families

desc: Introduces students to theory and practice skills for group work and community work; structural social work with groups and communities.
name: SOWK 2203
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002. For Bachelor of Social Work students only.
subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Work Practice with Groups and Communities

desc: Examines extent and nature of alcohol, prescription and illicit drug use, theories of drug dependence, history of drug policy; contemporary drug strategies and treatment in Canada.
name: SOWK 2300
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002.
subject: SOWK
title: Drugs in Society: Theory, Policy , Practice

desc: Preventative and protective social work intervention with children and youth. Issues addressed include child neglect, abuse and violence in the context of family; organizational mandate and social political contexts. Programs and services for children and youth.
name: SOWK 2301
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002.
subject: SOWK
title: Working with Children and Youth

desc: Research methods used in social work; research paradigms; quantitative and qualitative analysis in social work and social welfare; stages in conducting research.
name: SOWK 3001
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Research Methods in Social Work

desc: Fundamentals of statistical analysis; descriptive and inferential statistics and their use in social work research. Statistical tests including Chi-Square, t-tests, correlations and simple linear regressions.
name: SOWK 3002
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Statistical Analysis in Social Work

desc: Understanding the welfare state and social policy in Canada; exploring issues in administration including program design and implementation; understanding and developing skills in policy-making and policy analysis. Canadian focus; recognition of the distinctiveness of social policy in Quebec.
name: SOWK 3100
prereq_text: SOWK 2100 and third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Social Policy and Administration

desc: Introduction to theories, models and methods of community organizing as a strategy for social change in an international context.
name: SOWK 3206
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002; or PAPM 2000, or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Community Development and Social Change in an International Context

desc: Examines the advocacy role and capacity of organizations in civil society to increase popular participation in promoting and protecting human rights; includes transnational and national non-governmental organizations, grassroots movements, community organizations, and virtual or Internet-based organizations.
name: SOWK 3207
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002 or PAPM 1000 or HUMR 1001 or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Human Rights Practice in Civil Society

desc: Theory, policy or direct practice topics not covered in the regular course program. Choice of topics varies from year to year.
name: SOWK 3400
prereq_text: SOWK 1001 and SOWK 1002 or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Special Topics in Social Work

desc: Focus on integrating theory and practice in an approved community setting supervised by a field supervisor. Graded as Sat/Uns.
name: SOWK 3600
prereq_text: SOWK 2001, SOWK 2005, SOWK 2100, SOWK 2202, SOWK 2203, and permission of the School of Social Work. Student must be in good academic standing in the BSW program and have a 6.00 CGPA in the Social Work major.
subject: SOWK
title: Practicum I (Fall and Winter)

desc: Focus on integrating theory and practice in an approved community setting supervised by a field supervisor; 352 field hours and compulsory field seminars. Graded as Sat/Uns.
name: SOWK 3601
prereq_text: SOWK 2001, SOWK 2005, SOWK 2100, SOWK 2202, SOWK 2203, and permission of the School of Social Work. Student must be in good academic standing in the BSW program and have a 6.00 CGPA in the Social Work major.
subject: SOWK
title: Practicum I (Winter Term)

desc: Focus on integrating theory and practice in an approved community setting supervised by a field supervisor; 352 field hours and compulsory field seminars. Limited enrolment in this course subject to discretion of Field coordinator. Graded as Sat/Uns.
name: SOWK 3602
prereq_text: SOWK 2001, SOWK 2005, SOWK 2100, SOWK 2202, SOWK 2203, and permission of the School of Social Work. Student must be in good academic standing in the BSW program and have a 6.00 CGPA in the Social Work major.
subject: SOWK
title: Practicum I (Fall term)

desc: Legal framework surrounding the family and family relationships in Canadian society. Topics include marriage and cohabitation, matrimonial support, custody and access, and dissolution of marriage. State interventions through law; law and change in family structures; equality issues; dispute resolution processes.
name: SOWK 3804
prereq_text: LAWS 1000, LAWS 2201 and LAWS 2003.
subject: SOWK
title: Law of the Family

desc: Social work in partnership with Indigenous peoples in Canada; impact of the past on current relationships; rebuilding through dialogue and respect; understanding Indigenous social work.
name: SOWK 4000
prereq_text: third-year standing in Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Social Work and Indigenous Peoples

desc: Advanced theory, methods, techniques, and skills for direct social work practice with individuals and families; individual and family assessments, treatment planning, intervention skills, and evaluation.
name: SOWK 4001
prereq_text: SOWK 2202 and fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Advanced Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families

desc: Advanced theory, methods, techniques, and skills for social work with groups; knowledge of group work and various group formats; and social work interventions in group process.
name: SOWK 4002
prereq_text: SOWK 2203 and fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Advanced Social Work Practice with Groups

desc: Advanced theory, methods, techniques and skills for engaging in community-based practice. Politics and challenges of social work community organizing and strategies and skills for community work.
name: SOWK 4003
prereq_text: SOWK 2203 and fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Advanced Social Work Practice with Communities

desc: Social policy development processes in government and non-governmental agencies; refining skills in evaluating and critiquing processes of policy formation; role of lobbying and social activism.
name: SOWK 4004
prereq_text: SOWK 3100 and fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Social Policy Development and Practice

desc: History of colonization, legacy of colonialism, Royal Proclamation, BNA Act, treaties, impact of residential schools; implications of government social policy for Indigenous peoples in Canada; importance of self-determination and Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.
name: SOWK 4102
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Indigenous Peoples and Social Policy

desc: History of immigration policies in Canada; direct practice with immigrants and refugees; diaspora, settlement and integration issues; immigrants and refugee women; intergenerational family relations; resources and community organizing.
name: SOWK 4103
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Practice and Policy in Immigration

desc: Introduction to theories, models and methods of managing non-profit organizations; role, nature and values of the non-profit sector in a market society; practical knowledge of management in different types of non-profit organizations (e.g. cooperatives, voluntary associations, public advocacy and community service organizations).
name: SOWK 4105
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Management of Non-Profit Organizations

desc: Social perspectives on aging with focus on models of practice that contribute to the independence of elderly people. Social programs and policies, such as social insurance, social services, housing, public health and health care. Social, psychological and political issues related to independence in later life.
name: SOWK 4204
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Social Work and Aging

desc: Examines theory and practice of feminist counselling, feminist counselling skills development.
name: SOWK 4206
prereq_text: third- year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Feminist Counselling

desc: Theory and knowledge development of direct practice topics not in the regular course program. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: SOWK 4209
prereq_text: third year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Special Topics in Direct Social Work Practice

prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.

title: Special Topics in Social Work

desc: Theory and knowledge development of a combination of practice and policy topics not in the regular course program. Topics may vary from year to year.
name: SOWK 4214
prereq_text: third-year standing or permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Special Topics in Social Work

desc: Social work theory and practice with persons with disabilities. Structural analysis of theory, models, policies and practices; disability rights; critical analysis of medical model and ableism.
name: SOWK 4300
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Social Work and Persons with Disabilities

desc: Social work and racialization; racism and consequences; critical analysis of cultural formations, difference, and identities; critical examination of whiteness and privilege.
name: SOWK 4301
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Racialization and Social Work

desc: Social work analysis of theories of poverty and economic inequality; labour force participation; poverty and wealth and income distribution in Canada and international comparisons; Canadian social policies and poverty.
name: SOWK 4302
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Poverty and Social Welfare Policy

desc: Social work and social, political, institutional and economic relations shaping everyday experiences of gender and sexuality and implications for contemporary social work.
name: SOWK 4303
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Gender and Sexuality

desc: Development, application, testing and integration of knowledge, theory and skills in practice with individuals, families, groups and communities, in research or in social administration and policy. Graded Sat/Uns.
name: SOWK 4600
prereq_text: third-year standing in the BSW program; SOWK 2001, SOWK 2005, SOWK 2100, SOWK 2202, SOWK 2203, SOWK 3100; SOWK 3600 or 3601 or 3602, and permission of the School of Social Work. Student must be in good academic standing in the BSW program and have a 6.00 CGPA in the Social Work major.
subject: SOWK
title: Practicum II (Fall or Summer Terms)

desc: Development, application, testing,integration of knowledge, theory and skills in practice with individuals, families, groups and communities, in research or social administration and policy. Graded Sat/Uns. Part one of two part practicum taken consecutively with SOWK 4602.
name: SOWK 4601
prereq_text: third-year standing in the BSW program; SOWK 2001, SOWK 2005, SOWK 2100, SOWK 2202, SOWK 2203, SOWK 3100; SOWK 3600 or 3601 or 3602, and permission of the School of Social Work. Student must be in good academic standing in the BSW program and have a 6.00 CGPA in the Social Work major.
subject: SOWK
title: Practicum IIA

desc: Development, application, testing, integration of knowledge, theory and skills in practice with individuals, families, groups and communities, in research or social administration and policy. Graded Sat/Uns. Part two of two part practicum taken consecutively with SOWK 4601.

Student must be in good academic standing in the BSW program and have a 6.00 CGPA in the Social Work major.

desc: Research essay under supervision of accredited faculty member. Project may be in the form of case study, historical study or other form that meets the approval of faculty advisor.
name: SOWK 4908
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Bachelor of Social Work and permission of the School of Social Work.
subject: SOWK
title: Honours Essay

desc: Introduction to the discipline of sociology; theory, methods, history; key thinkers, concepts and disciplinary subfields in sociology; issues and problems in contemporary society. Emphasis on the everyday world of lived experience and social relations. Topics may include class, gender, sexuality, racialization, culture, social interaction.
name: SOCI 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Sociology I

desc: This course will further explore and expand upon the key thinkers, concepts and disciplinary subfields in sociology. The focus of analysis will shift from the everyday world to social institutions and structural processes. Topics may include globalization, education, media, health, social movements, colonialism, urbanization.
name: SOCI 1002
prereq_text: SOCI 1001.
subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Sociology II

desc: Introduction to the discipline of sociology; theory, methods and history; key thinkers, concepts and disciplinary subfields in sociology; issues and problems in contemporary society.
name: SOCI 1003
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Sociological Perspectives

desc: The origins of sociology, why sociology matters, and how it is practiced. Concepts such as class, race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, work, organization, and social movements help students develop their sociological 'eye' for thinking critically about society and their place within it.
name: SOCI 1005
prereq_text: restricted to B.Com. students.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology for Bachelor of Commerce Students

desc: Introduction to sociological inquiry through the study of sociological approaches to knowledge, the relationship of theory to methods, introduction to different methodological traditions including their epistemological foundations, value and limitations. Students will acquire foundational academic skills.
name: SOCI 2000
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Foundations of Sociological Inquiry

desc: Introduction to theory and practice of qualitative research methods involving human participants: research design; ethics; data analysis; data generation methods. Methods may include: qualitative interviewing, ethnography, oral history, focus groups, observation. Additional topics may include: historical development/debates in qualitative research/key historical studies.
name: SOCI 2001
prereq_text: SOCI 2000.
subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Qualitative Research Methods

desc: Traces theoretical traditions in sociological thought, situating traditions within historical, social and intellectual contexts. At least four of the following will be covered: orientalism, imperialism, colonialism; capitalism, social organization, rationalization; subject formation, identity; self and the everyday; work and leisure; and, social change and revolution.
name: SOCI 2005
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Histories of Sociological Thought

desc: Theoretical and empirical examination of economic inequalities in Canada. Topics may include the experience of economic marginalization, how economic inequality is reproduced, how economic inequalities intersect with other forces, such as gender and racialized inequality, and struggles to transform the economic organisation of society.
name: SOCI 2010
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Critical Approaches to Economic Inequality

desc: Introduction to some of the recent theoretical literature and research on the issues of race, racism and ethnicity. Concepts, controversies and definitions dealing with race and ethnicity from the Canadian context and internationally.
name: SOCI 2020
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Race and Ethnicity

desc: An analysis of work practices and settings in societies. Topics of interest include the development of industrial and postindustrial societies; the experience of work, the structuring of work in organizations and in the society; conflict, resistance and labour relations, and the impact of new technologies.
name: SOCI 2030
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Work, Industry and Occupations

desc: Introduction to the principal theories and methods used by Science and Technology Studies (STS) scholars to examine the social and cultural shaping of technology. The substantive focus of the course is on the design, development, production, diffusion, consumption and use of technology.
name: SOCI 2035
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Technology, Culture and Society

desc: The sociological analysis of food and eating. The relationship between food and identity; the development of social movements organized around food; and more generally, on practices relating to the production, preparation, and consumption of food.
name: SOCI 2040
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Food, Culture and Society

desc: How do we conceptualize the family? How has family changed over history? What are the diverse realities of families today? This course examines different family forms, relations and dynamics, emphasizing the relationship between family and larger social forces, such as gender, immigration or class.
name: SOCI 2043
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of the Family

desc: How gender and gender relations play out in everyday lives, and how people resist, reproduce, or reinforce gender norms. Considers how gender shapes experiences of family, school, work, media, relationships, bodies, violence, etc. Canadian and global cases are examined.
name: SOCI 2045
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Gender and Society

desc: Critical approaches to understanding health, illness and healthcare and how social, cultural, political and economic factors affect our health, our experiences with illness, and our encounters with healthcare systems.
name: SOCI 2050
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Health

desc: Drawing on anthropological and sociological approaches, students will explore girls’ lives in diverse cultural, political, economic, and social contexts. Topics may include: movement and migration, education, media, imaging and humanitarianism, consumerism, agency and activism, health, and violence.
name: SOCI 2060
prereq_text: second year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: SOCI
title: Girlhood in Contemporary Contexts: Anthropological and Sociological Perspectives

desc: Examination of relationships between humans and animals in the sociological and broader social studies canon, including: multispecies ethnography, the role of the ‘more than human’ in Indigenous legal orders, posthumanist and STS theory, relationships between humans and animals and other non-human entities in the Anthropocene.
name: SOCI 2080
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Humans/Animals: the More-than-Human in Social Research

desc: Theoretical and empirical consideration of society and the individual. Topics include the public realm, situations, roles and interpersonal relations. Beliefs, attitudes, interests and opinions, leadership and decision making, conformity, coercion and compromise may be also examined.
name: SOCI 2150
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Social Psychology

desc: Sociological theory and research on large-scale conflict. How society and culture shape warfare through processes of socialization, bureaucratization, and ideological representation. Social impacts of war in terms of gender, race and ethnicity, class relations, and cultural values.
name: SOCI 2160
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: War and Society

desc: Introduction to the study of social justice and the theorization of social justice sociology. Critical examination of resistance to oppression, social movements and solidarity both in Canada and transnationally. Exploration of the relationship between the university and community-based action.
name: SOCI 2170
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Foundations in Social Justice

desc: Study of theoretical debates and practical applications relating to community engagement with a focus on Canadian examples. Exploration of the contested and complex meanings of community engagement in and between diverse communities, public institutions, non-profit sector and private enterprise with an emphasis on social justice.
name: SOCI 2180
prereq_text: Second year standing or permission of instructor.
subject: SOCI
title: Foundations in Community Engagement

desc: The construction of deviant behaviour and the consequences of such construction for both deviant and conforming persons. Emphasis upon deviance as a normal and necessary result of the socio-cultural processes resulting from, and affecting the activities of a viable society.
name: SOCI 2445
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Deviance

desc: Social reactions to crime, criminalization processes, and the criminal justice system, and their intersection with power relations and social inequalities.
name: SOCI 2450
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Crime and Society

desc: An investigation of power and culture, with a focus on how ordinary people contribute to social change. Topics may include activism, leisure, consumption, identity, fashion, sexuality, tourism, health, pollution and work.
name: SOCI 2702
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Power and Social Change

desc: An examination of various approaches to analyzing digital media and their role in the production and consumption of contemporary cultural forms and practices. Students will reflect upon their use of digital media and the influence they have on their lives and popular culture, more generally.
name: SOCI 2705
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Popular Culture in the Digital Age

desc: Selected topics in sociology not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department regarding the topic offered.
name: SOCI 2810
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Selected Topics in Sociology

desc: Selected topics in sociology not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department regarding the topic offered.
name: SOCI 2820
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002.
subject: SOCI
title: Selected Topics in Sociology

desc: Consult the Department for information.
name: SOCI 2910
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Course-Related Tutorials in Sociology

desc: Consult the Department for information.
name: SOCI 2920
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Course-Related Tutorials in Sociology

desc: The conceptual foundations of descriptive statistics and applications of these statistics using software (SPSS or Stata) to analyze and interpret social science data. Topics include frequency distributions, graphs, measures of central tendency and dispersion, measures of association, bivariate regression, and introduction to multivariate statistics.
name: SOCI 3000
prereq_text: SOCI 2000 and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Descriptive Statistics in Social Research

desc: Inferential statistics and hypotheses testing used in social science research. Topics may include relationship between samples and population, methods of sample selection, central limit theorem, confidence levels and confidence intervals, overview of selected hypothesis tests, multivariate data analysis and multiple regression analysis.
name: SOCI 3002
prereq_text: SOCI 3000 or CRCJ 3001 and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Inferential Statistics in Social Research

desc: Specialized examination of select strategies or approaches to qualitative research. Topics may include: advanced application of research design involving human participants; historical research methods; textual/document-based research; visual sociologies; critical methodologies (such as feminist or decolonizing methods).
name: SOCI 3004
prereq_text: SOCI 2001 and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Qualitative Research: Approaches and Strategies

desc: Examination of a select sociological tradition or thinker, or theoretically intensive study of a sociological area. Consult the department for topics offered.
name: SOCI 3006
prereq_text: SOCI 2005 and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Thinking the Social: Theories and Approaches

desc: What makes inequalities so persistent? Theoretical and empirical examination of the intersection of social inequalities in Canada and globally, including class, gender, race and ethnicity and age; study of resistance to structures and cultures of inequalities.
name: SOCI 3010
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Power, Oppression and Resistance

desc: This course draws from global and interdisciplinary theoretical perspectives to examine primarily though not exclusively Canadian immigration policy and the socio-historical forces shaping policy, migration patterns, permanent, temporary and circular migration, the experiences of immigrants, refugees and migrants; and diasporic and transnational communities and identities.
name: SOCI 3019
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of International Migration

desc: Race, racism and ethnicity in Canada and internationally. Critical perspectives on race and ethnicity, which intersect with other social relations. Racism, Eurocentrism, Orientalism, nationalism, colonialism, international migration, citizenship, and diasporic cultures.
name: SOCI 3020
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Race and Ethnicity

desc: Examination of the various dimensions and meanings of globalization and its relationship with human rights, with emphasis on the implications of the emerging global economy for economic, social, political and cultural rights.
name: SOCI 3027
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Globalization and Human Rights

desc: The nature and place of expert knowledge in societies. The development of the practices and organization of the professions and their relation to social stratification, the state, patriarchy and gender; the systematic development of knowledge in societies.
name: SOCI 3030
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Work, Industry and Occupations: Authority and Expertise

desc: Principal theories and methods used by Science and Technology Studies scholars to examine the social construction of scientific knowledge. Topics may include the demarcation of science from non-science, the relationship between experts and laypersons, and the study of scientific controversies.
name: SOCI 3035
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Science, Culture and Society: Social Studies of Science

desc: Issues related to people and the urban environment, including the historical process of urbanization, rural-urban transition, the diffusion of urban values and life styles, contemporary urban problems such as urban renewal, pollution and the pressures of the urban environment on social institutions.
name: SOCI 3038
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Urban Sociology

desc: Sociological and feminist perspectives; applied understandings of gender, gender relations; women's and men's lives in contemporary Canadian society and in historical and cross-cultural terms. Multiple intersections between gender, race, ethnicity, class and sexuality.
name: SOCI 3040
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in the Sociology of Gender

desc: Key concepts of sex, sexuality, gender, eroticism and pleasure. The history of sex and sexuality. The regulation of sexual relations and practices. Social movements relating to sexuality, gender identities and sexual equality.
name: SOCI 3044
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Sex and Sexuality

desc: A socio-historical and cross-cultural exploration of constructions, deconstructions, and the experience of childhood in Canada and internationally. Compulsory schooling, child labour, protection and regulation in law, the commodification and equalization of childhood, children's social movements, and the emergence of children's rights discourses.
name: SOCI 3045
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Children and Childhood in a Globalized World

desc: Current theory and research on health, disease and social responses to health issues. Topics include population differences incidence and prevalence of morbidity and mortality, access to care and government health policy. Focus upon cultural definitions of health and their consequences for health promotion practices.
name: SOCI 3050
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in the Sociology of Health

desc: Survey of alcohol and other drug use in cross-cultural and sub-group perspectives. Relationships between culture, social structure and patterns of use of psychoactive substances. Topics may include: substance use and the life cycle; gender and psychoactive substances; problem and non-problem use.
name: SOCI 3055
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Addictions

desc: Women's health issues and how they relate to social, political and economic factors. The intersection of gender, ethnicity, class, sexual orientation and able-bodiedness with women's health.
name: SOCI 3056
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Women and Health

desc: Course engages contemporary disability theory, culture, and activism to consider bodily difference and its relation to the workings of power and social control, accessibility, normalization, ableism, and medicalization. Students will gain an understanding of the contemporary debates, theories, and methodologies of critical disability studies.
name: SOCI 3060
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Critical Disability Studies

desc: This course will make sense of Trumpism and other rightwing populisms by interrogating their sociological backgrounds and histories. Students will learn to recognize the systems and structures that make populist leaders possible, and how trends in North America relate to far-right movements elsewhere.
name: SOCI 3150
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Rightwing Populism

desc: Sociological examination of political violence. Theoretical analysis of violence as social action that is historically situated and shaped by cultural and economic forces; the relationship between political violence and identity, nation/nationalism, modernity and globalisation.
name: SOCI 3160
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Political Violence

desc: Current debates in social justice theory and practice. The course includes substantial engagement with community actors, including activists and advocates as guest speakers. Students will be exposed to social justice principles applied in the community through a variety of approaches.
name: SOCI 3170
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Social Justice in Action

desc: Selected topics in sociology not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department regarding the topic offered.
name: SOCI 3210
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Selected Topics in Sociology

desc: Selected topics in sociology not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department regarding the topic offered.
name: SOCI 3220
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Selected Topics in Sociology

desc: Critical analysis of selected work in educational sociology. Topics may include sociological theories of education, school ethnography, contemporary educational policy and practice. Note: Topic will vary in keeping with the interests of students and instructor.
name: SOCI 3300
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in the Sociology of Education

desc: Developments in criminal justice are examined in the context of broader social issues. Particular emphasis will be placed on contemporary developments in criminal justice institutions, programs and practices.
name: SOCI 3410
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Criminal Justice

desc: An overview of current issues related to women as both perpetrators and victims of crime and the Canadian criminal justice system's response to them. Topics may include woman abuse, sexual assault, and federally sentenced women.
name: SOCI 3420
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Gender and Criminal Justice

desc: What is a social movement? How do sociologists distinguish between social movements and revolutions? What factors influence social movement development? What do they look like? Theoretical and empirical study of the relationship between social movements and social change.
name: SOCI 3430
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Collective Action and Social Movements

desc: A comparative examination of contemporary law enforcement. Topics may include public versus private policing, centralized versus decentralized policing, and transnational policing.
name: SOCI 3450
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Law Enforcement

desc: A study of sociological theories of law as well as the nature of legal institutions. Impacts of legal regulation on various social institutions and on processes of social debate and conflict.
name: SOCI 3480
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0], or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Law and Social Regulation

desc: Aesthetic practices and institutions. Production and reception of diverse art forms (visual, musical, corporeal, etc.) in various sociocultural contexts. Institutions dedicated to supporting such practices (e.g., museums, theatres, festivals, rituals) are examined through a range of theoretical perspectives.
name: SOCI 3570
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0]; or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Art, Culture and Society

desc: Research and theory in the interdisciplinary area of Cultural Studies. Contemporary cultural change in the advanced industrialized societies and its impact on everyday life.
name: SOCI 3710
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0]; or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Cultural Studies

desc: Historical and current debates on population growth. Historical declines in fertility and mortality from an international perspective. Contemporary demographic issues such as low fertility, longevity revolution, population aging, inequalities in health, migration and refugees.
name: SOCI 3805
prereq_text: SOCI 1001 and SOCI 1002, or SOCI 1003 [1.0]; or ANTH 1001, or ANTH 1002, and third-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Studies in Population

desc: Consult the Department for information, as departmental permission is required.
name: SOCI 3910
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Course-Related Tutorials in Sociology

desc: Consult the Department for information, as departmental permission is required.
name: SOCI 3920
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Course-Related Tutorials in Sociology

desc: This course provides students with the opportunity to apply academic skills and knowledge while working within a sociology-related organization. Placements are organized with support from a co-ordinator.
name: SOCI 3950
prereq_text: third-year standing in Sociology with a GPA of 9.00 or higher and permission of the course instructor.
subject: SOCI
title: Practicum Placement in Sociology

name: SOCI 3999
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Co-operative Work Term

desc: Close study of the works of an author, tendency, or school of thought in theoretical sociology. Topic will vary in keeping with interests of the students and instructor.
name: SOCI 4002
prereq_text: SOCI 3006 and fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Sociological Theory

desc: In-depth study into selected issues in qualitative research design, implementation and data analysis. Topics covered may include participant observation, ethnomethodology, ethnography, grounded theory, discourse analysis, narrative analysis, textual analysis, and document analysis. Intersections between epistemologies and methodologies.
name: SOCI 4003
prereq_text: SOCI 3004 and fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Qualitative Research

desc: Study of specific quantitative methodological issues. Focus may be on one or two of the following topics: quantitative research design, sampling techniques, survey research methods and various statistical research methods including OLS and logistic regression.
name: SOCI 4009
prereq_text: SOCI 3002 and fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Quantitative Research

desc: Selected topics in race and ethnicity in an international context. Specific topics will vary according to instructors' research interests.
name: SOCI 4020
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Race and Ethnicity

desc: Socio-economic, political and cultural realities of Middle Eastern women with focus on their lived experiences, voices and stories. Focus on women in Palestine/Israel with consideration of other Middle Eastern women.
name: SOCI 4039
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Women in Contemporary Middle East Societies

desc: Theoretical and empirical examination of gender relations and gendered inequality with emphasis on the complex intersection of gender with race, ethnicity, religion, class, sexuality, (dis)ability and other relations of power in feminist scholarship, social justice movements, law and policy.
name: SOCI 4040
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Feminist Sociology of Intersectionality

desc: Examination of contemporary family forms including single-parent-, blended/step-, LGBTQ- and common-law families. Topics may include theoretical perspectives; reproductive technologies; globalization; migration; interracial families; cohabitation; separation/divorce; motherhood/fatherhood; childcare/domestic labour; children/youth; intergenerational relations; social class/poverty; family policies and family law.
name: SOCI 4043
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Families in the 21st Century

desc: Critical theoretical and empirical analysis of violent political conflict. Examination of transformations and continuities of war, terrorism and state terrorism; modalities of political violence, such as torture or disappearance; responses to violent conflict; and the representation and construction of political violence.
name: SOCI 4160
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: War, Terrorism and State Terrorism

desc: Students will apply their sociological education working with community organizations in small teams to research issues and advocate for positive social change. Each team’s project will include public education, sociological analysis and creating a tangible product for the partner organization.
name: SOCI 4170
prereq_text: third-year or fourth-year standing, or permission from the instructor of SOCI 4170.
subject: SOCI
title: Community-Engaged Sociology

desc: Students in the capstone will reflect on their engagement experiences and advance their critical understanding of community through a series of in-class activities and readings. Students will produce a public-facing artifact (e.g., blog, podcast, video) related to their experiences, potentially in collaboration with community partners.
name: SOCI 4171
prereq_text: SOCI 2180 and fourth year standing or permission of the instructor.
subject: SOCI
title: Community Engagement Capstone

desc: Critical theoretical and multidisciplinary examination of violent conflict, security and citizenship. How wars produce a variety of abject and new subjects, create and reproduce citizenship hierarchies, and expand and contract citizenship entitlements.
name: SOCI 4200
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: War, Security and Citizenship

desc: Crime, criminal justice, social processes relating to the implementation of criminal justice policy, or other aspects of criminality and deviance.
name: SOCI 4410
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Criminology

desc: Contemporary debates about the role of law in society focusing on the potential and limits of law as a vehicle of social transformation.
name: SOCI 4480
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in the Sociology of Law

desc: Students carry out a small-scale research project to hone transferable skills acquired over the course of the degree programme.
name: SOCI 4700
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Honours Capstone Seminar

desc: Examination of a selected topic in criminal justice and social policy. Topics to be announced.
name: SOCI 4702
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Special Topic in Criminal Justice and Social Policy

desc: Comparative ethnographic and historical approaches to colonialism including topics such as the formation of colonial regimes, colonial governmentality, servile labour systems, missionization, anti-colonial resistance, cultural hybridization and post-colonial memory. Exploration of debates over the relation between colonialism and the production of social scientific knowledge.
name: SOCI 4730
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Colonialism and Post-Colonialism

desc: Selected topics on the confluence of processes of globalization, development and citizenship; examination of debates about the meaning and impact of globalization on patterns of inequality and citizenship both internationally and within Canada, and about strategies for progressive development.
name: SOCI 4750
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Globalization and Citizenship

desc: An examination of sociological research and social intervention.
name: SOCI 4810
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Advanced Studies in Social Policy

desc: Selected problems in sociology not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department regarding the topic offered.
name: SOCI 4850
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Contemporary Problems in Sociology

desc: Selected problems in sociology not ordinarily treated in the regular course program. The choice of topics varies from year to year. Students should check with the Department regarding the topic offered.
name: SOCI 4860
prereq_text: fourth-year standing.
subject: SOCI
title: Contemporary Problems in Sociology

desc: An independent research project under the supervision of a faculty member. Seminar supports students through each stage of the research process: development of a research question, designing the project, crafting a proposal, carrying out data generation and analysis, and writing the final thesis.
name: SOCI 4900
prereq_text: fourth-year standing in the Sociology B.A. Honours with a CGPA of 9.00 or higher in the Major or by permission of the instructor. Students are strongly encouraged to locate a faculty member to supervise their Honours Thesis prior to the start of this course.
subject: SOCI
title: Honours Thesis

desc: Consult the Department for information.
name: SOCI 4910
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Tutorial in Sociology

desc: Consult the Department for information.
name: SOCI 4920
prereq_text: None
subject: SOCI
title: Tutorial in Sociology

desc: An introduction to South Asian studies, including history, literature, religion, philosophy and the arts.
name: SAST 1001
prereq_text: None
subject: SAST
title: Introduction to South Asian Studies I

desc: An introduction to contemporary dimensions of South Asia including cultural, social and political thought and practice.
name: SAST 1002
prereq_text: None
subject: SAST
title: Introduction to South Asian Studies II

desc: For students with no knowledge of Spanish. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 1010
prereq_text: None
subject: SPAN
title: First-Year Spanish I

desc: Continuation of first-year Spanish. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 1020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 1010, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: First-Year Spanish II

desc: For students with no knowledge of Spanish. Oral skills, reading and writing. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 1110
prereq_text: None
subject: SPAN
title: Intensive First-Year Spanish

desc: Further study of Spanish to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 2010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 1020, SPAN 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Second-Year Spanish I

desc: Continuation of second-year Spanish. Further study of Spanish to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 2020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 2010, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Second-Year Spanish II

desc: Further study of Spanish to reach a more advanced level of proficiency in a range of situations. Equal emphasis on oral and written language. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 2110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 1020, SPAN 1110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Second-Year Spanish

desc: Continuation of the study of Spanish to reach a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 3010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 2020, SPAN 2110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Third-Year Spanish I

desc: Continuation of third-year Spanish. Progress toward a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 3020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 3010 or SPAN 3015, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Third-Year Spanish II

desc: Continuation of the study of Spanish to reach a more advanced level, including the ability to handle authentic materials and primary texts required for academic studies. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 3110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 2020, SPAN 2110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Third-Year Spanish

desc: Introduction to principles of linguistic analysis, illustrated through Spanish. Sound systems, word structures and sentence structures of Spanish. Basic principles of language variation and change, as evidenced in the development of Spanish. Linguistic aspects of bilingualism as manifested in Spanish/English bilinguals.
name: SPAN 3220
prereq_text: SPAN 3020 or SPAN 3110 or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics

desc: Advanced spoken and written Spanish with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 4010
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 3020, SPAN 3110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Fourth-Year Spanish I

desc: For students who have attained Spanish language proficiency in informal settings. This course formalizes grammar awareness, enhances literacy skills, and develops existing language abilities in a formal academic setting.
name: SPAN 4015
prereq_text: permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Spanish for Heritage Speakers I

desc: Continuation of fourth-year Spanish. Advanced spoken and written Spanish with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 4020
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 4010, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Fourth-Year Spanish II

desc: For students who have started to develop existing Spanish language abilities in a formal academic setting. This course enhances students’ written expression while building on advanced knowledge of Spanish grammar and vocabulary.
name: SPAN 4025
prereq_text: SPAN 4015 or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Spanish for Heritage Speakers II

desc: Advanced spoken and written Spanish with intensive practice in aural comprehension and speaking in a range of situations and contexts, in reading and in composition in a range of modes and genres. Metalinguistic study. Compulsory attendance.
name: SPAN 4110
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 3020, SPAN 3110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Fourth-Year Spanish

desc: Development of language use for specific purposes in contexts such as the academic, business and technical domains.
name: SPAN 4215
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 4020 or SPAN 4110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Spanish for Specific Purposes

desc: Selected topic in Spanish linguistics.
name: SPAN 4320
prereq_text: LING 1001 or SPAN 3220, and grade of C or higher in SPAN 4020 or 4110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Topics in Spanish Linguistics

desc: Selected topics in Spanish-speaking cultures and societies. Development of advanced language skills.
name: SPAN 4380
prereq_text: grade of C or higher in SPAN 4020 or SPAN 4110, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
title: Topics in Spanish-speaking Cultures

desc: Research in a topic in Spanish language, literature or linguistics under the supervision of a member of the School.
name: SPAN 4900
prereq_text: third- or fourth-year standing in the Minor in Spanish, grade of C or higher in SPAN 4020 or SPAN 4110 or equivalent, or permission of the School.
subject: SPAN
